review: One of the best adventure games everDevelopers had an advantage of taking a very well developed world and one of the most famous story in it. And they not only took it but they delivered on it. Game has wide variety of enemies each of them has it's own backstory (obviously taken from chinese folklore but still) which slightly enlarge our understanding of the world. And just this world and story is enough to give this game a try even if you are not a fan of any other aspects of the game.Game consists of 6 chapters each of which has it's unique enemy cast (with exception of ch5) and corresponding bosses. I remember entering ch5 and my thought "lol those enemies are just reskins of earlier ones lazy devs". But in any other game I would just perceive this as a norm and the fact that I perceived this as a minus speaks very highly about enemy variety in the game.Bosses divides in two parts - chiefs and kings. Difficulty-wise they are mixed up, kings just have more shiny moves I guess...Bosses in a vacuum are all awesome - they has their place in the world, they has a backstory, they have cool moves and good loot. Also they are balanced pretty good for an adventure game even tho I wish they was harder cos amount of bosses I just first try facetanked is unhealthy in my opinion. On the other hand I heard that some people struggles a lot on different bosses so my opinion is not objective here. And yes, I also struggled on those two bosses :)Maps are also awesome - with unique biomes and gorgeous views. They are normal adventure type maps with branching path to the end boss. But game doesn't have any map in menu so navigating and finding all secrets can be quite time consuming (especially in ch3).Chapter 6 map is failed (in my opinion) experiment on openworld type of map. There is literally nothing in it except for a few bad bosses and 1 (one!) chest.Why ch6 bosses are bad? I hate 2 types of bosses: "puzzle" boss and "catch me ♥♥♥♥♥" boss. They are like 90% of ch6 bosses :(But game is not without technical problems of courseFirst of all - camera. Camera can get behind a tree or a wall which is annoying. Also camera tracking is quite loose so if you move around around the boss too much or if boss is has very mobile moveset - he will be out of your field view for a good 30+% of a fight. Also you can just lose target lock during some of boss moves if you don't manually readjust camera during fight (which is annoying if you use gamepad).Minor problem with inputs - for example run button won't register if you pressed it before your run-prohibiting move ends.And annoying problem with lack of target tracking. Like you know how lazy boss designers adds insane target tracking to all moves of bosses - here designers went deeper - heavy attack after roll in 75% of cases will just miss the mark completely - it's not hitting where enemy was, nor where he is going, just some random particle in the air, which is extremely frustrating after you spent like a minute to charge this attack.But despite these problems game is still awesome, bosses are still very manageable due to variety of builds (and ability to redo your build at any time).Solid 9/10

review: 2022 The writing on the tin says "Dark Souls, but open world". And you get exactly what it says on that tin, give or take a few quirks. And it's a rare case of an open-world conversion done right.The combat is the same old soulsborne system that you've already made your mind up about whether you like or not, with some extra tweaks for variety. But what Elden Ring really excels in is the open world of exploration it wraps it in. Strong art direction coupled with intruiging writing make for sights worth seeing, and the reward loop for exploring is borderline addictive. Every single little cave, camp, crevasse and keep has its own boss and unique item as a reward for beating it, making for a ludicrously large assortment of builds to go for. This, of course, comes with the standard high difficulty attached. But in practice the spikes of hardship make for satisfying goals to work towards via leveling.There are other sharp edges, however, that you'll need to acclimate to. In a bit of "have your cake and eat it" design, you'll be showered with lots of weapons, but you'll still need to stick to one and upgrade it. Which can get really boring over the course of a hundred hours if your moveset is narrow. Some items and spells are balanced around PVP instead of solo play. Which can, unintuitively, lead to upgrades being downgrades in practice. And you won't be able to tell until you've invested a lot of resources into unlocking or upgrading them. There's also plenty of things to watch out for that will make the game harder if you're not aware of them:1. The game is designed for co-op. The bossfights are tuned to be challenging even when two players are bouncing aggro between them. Which means that if you're playing solo, your summon is a part of your build as much as anything else. And forgoing it makes things exponentially harder.2. The game expects you to explore and level a lot. If you try to just stick to the critical path to beat it as quickly as possible, you're in for a rude surprise in its later half of the game due to the sheer amount of damage enemies deal there.3. Not all builds are made equal. Your experience will vary a lot based on whether you have a ranged attack, or are going melee only. Especially since some of the bosses are so big that being in melee range means you can't see their swings.But all of those aren't necessarily shortcomings. Think of them as an indirect difficulty setting. You can go for the easiest approach in each scenario, or you can self-impose challenges for extra thrill. It's just a mindset thing that you have to be aware of going in. Other than that, the game is sublime. You'll encounter the odd glitch and weird physics interaction here and there, but other than that it's way more polished that you'd expect for the open-world genre.

review: Buckle up, fellow adventurer, because I’m about to take you on a mythical journey through the extraordinary realms of Black Myth: Wukong. 🌟🐒🔥The Legend Unfolds: From the moment I stepped into this ancient world, I felt the pulse of its magic. The mist-clad forests whispered secrets, and the pagodas stood like silent sentinels, guarding forgotten knowledge. Wukong, our rebellious hero, radiated charisma. His staff crackled with energy, and his eyes held the weight of centuries.Combat as Poetry: Picture this: Wukong, surrounded by foes, his staff an extension of his will. Each swing, a brushstroke on the canvas of chaos. The combat system dances between elegance and brutality. I pirouetted through enemy formations, deflecting arrows, and delivering spinning kicks that sent demons sprawling. Boss battles? They’re symphonies of strategy and spectacle. I faced a serpent with scales like jade, a thunder deity crackling with lightning, and a shape-shifting fox spirit. Each encounter left me breathless, heart pounding.A Canvas of Dreams: The visuals—oh, the visuals! The artists dipped their brushes in starlight and painted landscapes that defy reality. Cherry blossoms swirled in the wind, and ancient temples clung to cliffs like stubborn memories. When Wukong ascended a mountain peak, the world unfolded below—a tapestry of wonder. And those animated vignettes at the end of each chapter? Pure magic. They revealed the antagonist’s tragic past, leaving me haunted and hungry for more.Threads of Fate: The story weaves threads from the classic Journey to the West. It’s like sipping tea with Sun Wukong himself, listening to tales of gods and demons. Sure, some references might elude newcomers, but they’re breadcrumbs leading to deeper mysteries. I reveled in the lore, piecing together prophecies and ancient scrolls.The Glitches and Grins: Okay, let’s address the quirks. Occasionally, the game hiccupped like a startled dragon. Crashes? Yep. Characters switching languages mid-sentence? Confusing, but oddly endearing. And the gear system? Well, it’s like Wukong got caught in a cosmic thrift store. Upgrading his staff felt like polishing a relic—I yearned for more impactful choices.Verdict: Black Myth: Wukong isn’t just a game; it’s an odyssey. Flaws? Sure, but they’re like cracks in a porcelain vase—part of its charm. So, grab your staff, channel your inner monkey king, and step into a world where myths breathe and legends clash. You won’t regret it. 🌿🔮✨

review: I'm not much of a review poster as you can probably see, this is my third review that i'm writing and i played hundreds upon hundreds of games, so that means this is the third game that really made me want to write a review.Almost 100 hours into the game, yes i really took my time on my first run, i literally beat the game hours ago aswell and let me tell you, this game is an absolute masterpiece. I wish that i can express in more detail on how i feel about the game, but i just can't, it's that good. The last time i felt this excited, hyped and super happy about playing a game is when Elden Ring came out, this game managed to bring those feelings forward again.Visuals of the game are so damn pretty, graphics are insane i literally built a PC for this game and it was so worth it, combat is out of this world very fluid and engaging, i absolutely loved every character i met, the cutscene animation after ending the chapters were such a treat to watch, oh and not to mention the intro! i don't think there's a game that will top the intro of Wukong, that sh*t was absolutely epic, UI was fantastic, Amazing boss designs which were based off of chinese mythology/folklore i believe and the list keeps on going, so yeah this game is just a beast. I could keep on going but i dont want to make this review way too long.Bottom line is: Buy this game, its just phenomenal. I am hoping that this game will win GOTY it absolutely deserves the award. - 9.5/10 rating from me too.

review: 2022 ORIGINAL NEGATIVE REVIEW:Game itself is 10/10. But the PC version stutters a lot, and makes it unnecessarily difficult to play. Masterpiece, best game ever made, it's already ruined my life, but clearly it's unfinished from an optimization point of view. When they fix this issue (which I'm confident they will... it's From Software), I'll rewrite this review and soyjak over the game like a redditor visiting Elon's lithium mines.NEW STUFF:The stutters have become less frequent, but I don't really care anymore. This game is such a masterpiece, I get so enthralled by what's happening on screen that I can't tell if it's running at 20 FPS or 60. When I first played Sekiro, I couldn't go back to Dark Souls for a while because it seemed so slow and boring in comparison. This is giving me the same effect, it makes the previous games feel incomplete in comparison. The melee combat is tied with Sekiro for my fave in any game. It even made magic fun, somehow. Still doesn't run the best, but for me that isn't enough to justify not recommending this game to everyone.

review: 2023 Theres a lot more they have added over the years to your campaign map features, building outposts in other factions settlements, war coordination is better and has more options, quests issued by other factions as well as setting quests for other factions, there are many quests centered around artifacts/gear and map elements as well. Interesting events occur during the campaign and overall I'd say that the turn based campaign portion of total war has never been better. Each faction being so different in warhammer has allowed for interesting faction-unique systems to be implemented that keep each playthrough fresh. The mechanics behind each faction will drive you to play very differently than you played the last and it has really sucked me back in to total war for the first time in years. The "RPG" elements are deeper than ever, which I understand was never the draw of total war, but truthfully, in this fantasy setting I have found that it adds a great layer of gameplay I really enjoy. Sending an army stack off to go on an epic quest for it's leading lord is truthfully fun af and it feels like every lord, even the randomly generated ones, can develop a whole story of their own. Meanwhile you are still playing total war.The engine is the best this time around it has ever been. It runs so smooth I can scarcely believe it. I am using the same cpu I played attila on and the difference is night and day. I have had no AI issues, the unit mass seems perfect, the animations are the best they have been and the game just plays extremely well, even on keep walls. It is really exciting to play through imo and if you have stepped away from total war for a time, coming back will be a huge breathe of fresh air. It is so good, my fiance who has never played this kind of game, took to it immediately. It is still the warhammer versions of total war, so expect extremely powerful lords with rpg features, but this game proves the next historical title will be a home-run because of it's engine and AI improvements alone. A big leap forward for the total war franchise.CA sucks for the way they monetize their games though. I wish steam ratings were star based so I could take a star off for that... but.. I have to admit. They have something locked down that is just insanely unique and impressive and they deserve to be the kings of this genre, it's just so frustrating to stumble through their lists of dlc and insane prices. They STILL sell blood in their games. One thing I will give them is they made it so if you own blood for the blood god in any of the warhammer games it unlocks it for warhammer 3, which is great, but it's not an accolade I feel right giving because it should not be there in the first place.Overall, epic fantasy total war game from a greedy publisher.

review: After 282 hours of gameplay:I logged in tonight only to be greeted with a notice that I was permanently banned from my main server without any clear explanation. The only support available is through their Discord bot, which, after I provided the requested details, informed me that I was banned for using cheat software that allegedly gave me an unfair advantage. They even ended the message with a bizarre note, wishing me a good life and hoping I’d leave a positive review.The issue seems to stem from having "Process Hacker," an alternative task manager, installed on my PC. Many other players have experienced the same problem—wrongfully banned due to false positives from their anti-cheat system—yet have found no real help from customer support. The bot is the only method of contact, and it’s frustratingly unhelpful and impersonal.In my experience, the support for this game is effectively non-existent. I strongly advise anyone thinking of playing to stick to the free-to-play experience and NOT spend any money until they address these issues and establish a proper support team. A Discord bot is not adequate support for a game with paying customers.

review: 2019 Tl;dr - fun and a competitive game. Has it's toxic side just like any other multiplayer game. 8/10 would recommend it. This game is the epitome of reflex. I love this game because it's simple yet the most complex of strategies can be implied. It doesn't just test your mechanical skill but also makes you really put in a mental effort. Really fun in a competitive 5 man lobby. Thank heavens this game enables you to access the settings menu whilst queuing for a match.. it was due for years. The new UI seems innovative but I suppose there is still more room for improvement. Having about an average number of hours. here's what the pros and cons of this game are to me- Pros: If you love a fast paced competitive game, this is the game for you. Simple (no breaking walls and ♥♥♥♥) yet it's fun and there's a lot of ♥♥♥♥ you can do to achieve success - victory, fun, both; whatever objective you have set for yourself/definition you have set for the word. Could also make a great game to play casually between other games, you find these kinds of players mostly in the lower ranks. In-game ranking system to motivate you on a short-term to play more and get better. Besides the Competitive (classic 5v5) game mode, there are many others you can choose from. Community made maps and skins to give you a better experience. Being updated regularly- new maps, changes in existing maps, changes in the economy in-game, etc,- leads to creating new metas. 3rd party matchmaking clients (ESEA, SoStronk, Faceit) offer more opportunities with more stable and better servers (128 tick), tournaments over various periods of time, in-built ranking system with lots of prizes to be won- really brings out the most out of this game- thus leading to a newer and better experience, for the ones who take this game seriously and for the ones who play casually both alike. Very active and an entertaining e-sport scene- the content it provides really shows that humans are capable of the impossible. Pretty cool community, I've played a lot of other games and have been a part of many communities but I've got to say the CS:GO community is pretty cool. We have one of the smartest, one of the most humorous communities on Twitch, Reddit and on YouTube, unlike in other games where at least one of these platforms are more cancerous than the better part of them. And ah, some extremely attractive female streamers and pro players.Cons- Matchmaking servers are the worst... I don't know what the devs have planned for this game. The servers are never stable and really ruins the experience for us. This game was at a point where all of us were gonna request Valve to upgrade the MM servers to 128 tick but really need to resort to 3rd party clients and many of us really don't want to do that ALL the time or cannot. So many bugs and stuff being abused in maps and this game takes forever to get them fixed. I know this is a long shot since it took them years to make other sub-menus accessible while in queue for a match.. but would be ♥♥♥♥♥♥ GREAT if we had the option to choose servers. Indians and Pinoys are literally the worst. I'm not generalising but you know it makes no difference to generalise or not because I've never had a good experience with players from these nations. They RUIN our games. Can't have one fun match without an incompetent Indian crying on the mic in Hindi about some really ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. Like just shut the ♥♥♥♥ UP dude. Always looking for something to blame, extremely annoying when they rush first, die and then comment on what you're doing and if you don't do as they say they just have a mental breakdown on mic. Thank goodness this game is capable of a block communication feature. I don't even know how they get to the ranks they do with their intellectually incapable selves. They're extremely bad and just hold your team down. Super toxic. I don't mind losing because it's a fair part of the game but the games are just RUINED by these players. Coming from overpopulated countries where they don't get enough attention or where they can't get any due to the lack of a special talent, they just show their frustration on the mic and ruin the experience for us. Videos on YouTube get super popular in the CS:GO communities and these players just try out tricks/tips/ whatever BUGS they've discovered etc. and because of their incompetency they fail and it isn't fun nor productive. Request to all Indian and Filipinos- please do not try out the stuff you see on videos. They hold an IQ threshold that you people cannot match. It only ruins our games. And I'm sure every region has some ♥♥♥♥ like this so it's only fair CS:GO let's us choose our servers to reduce the risk of getting into a game with an Indian or whoever with an underdeveloped brain. Hackers and smurfs are still into existence despite the efforts of Valve. It bums me the ♥♥♥♥ out because I've exchanged a lot more time and effort to get to the same rank as the hacker or smurf did only to get paired against them for a definite loss in elo points. Ruined the game after it became f2p. After this game turned f2p the servers became WORSE due to the high load and they removed the option to report servers. It's like they knew it was bound to happen. Great, the game struggled with stable mm servers and now make the game f2p and introduce the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ Battle Royale in existence - Danger Zone. Poorly optimised game, anybody that gets <250 fps know the huge drop in fps when in smokes etc. Hope Valve does something about the servers and add more features to this game instead of funding some ♥♥♥♥ p2w garbage like ARTIFACT that nobody gives a ♥♥♥♥ about. -Tips for new players: 1. Get some friends to play with to begin with. More known players more the merrier.2. You can completely customise how the games looks for you. Crosshair, viewmodel etc can be adjusted for your convenience. Make use of it.3. Watch videos. 4. Indians/Pinoys on your team or general mic cancer teammates? Type enable_voice 0 in console.. you're welcome.Conclusion: It's a fun game if you've a taste for competitiveness. Lower skill curve yet hard to master. 8/10 would recommend it.My first review and it's long as ♥♥♥♥ I don't think most of you would read it- but for those who have regardless of whether you relate to my review or not, thank you for spending time on this. Really appreciate it. Sorry for any mistakes I've committed and have not noticed to change them.

review: I can't remember the last time I had strong negative feelings for any game, but I particularly hate WH40K SM2. I have enjoyed possibly less than 30 minutes of this game and the rest of the time, I've been forcing myself to play and try to find something positive about it. Only if you're really into Warhammer 40k AND have enough people to play with, is this game worth the pricetag.- AI squadmates are horrible; they do very little in terms of tanking or dps- 6 operations/missions only after the main campaign (game will get stale quickly)- unresponsive abilities, and high emphasis on melee combat at higher difficulties making some classes useless- quick-time dodge, parry mechanics & unique controls (middle mouse button to aim) has a high learning curve for most players which will be a pain point for most new players- long loading screens even on SSD+ gorgeous graphics+ epic story feel

review: Have not played anything other than the campaign so far and am only 4 hours in. Take that for what you will. If you're a Warhammer fan, this is a must buy. If you're a fan of the idea of a 3rd person DOOM style experience with over the top executions and a fun selection of melee and ranged weapons, then this is a must buy. I've been waiting for this game for 10 years and it has largely delivered, but I do have a few gripes. Gripe 1: Annoying bugs (not the enemies in game). In a 4 hour session, my friends and I managed to bug an encounter that would force us to reload last checkpoint at least 5 times. Luckily the checkpoints are rather frequent so we didn't get set far back, but still annoying. Gripe 2: No camera position or FOV controls. I just wish I could pan the camera back even just a little bit. Titus is a massive space marine and takes up a rather significant portion of the screen. I get the armor is detailed and all, but I want to see the enemies coming at me before they're in my teeth. Being able to back the camera up would be so nice. Also don't remember seeing a setting to change the position of the camera from right shoulder to left or in my preference, middle. Gripe 3: The bolter's sound design is lackluster. They sound like they pack a punch, don't get me wrong. But it does not sound like I'm firing a gun that's launching .998 caliber mass reactive shells. Darktide did the bolter's chunky sound far better justice.

review: 2023 After playing WH2 for hours and obviously enjoying the game, I was really looking forward to WH3. However, as soon as the game was out, my dissapointment was immeasurable and my day(s) ruined. Lots of features and gameplay were buggy (nothing new for CA, unfortunately) and the motivation to play a campaign for more than 50 turns (usually 1-2h) was nowhere to be found due to the state of the game. Minor fixes were out in the coming months, but they didn't change much as to enjoy the game as much as I did WH2.At the same time, CA kept churning out DLC after DLC with less and less content, while major issues still persisted with the base game. Several years have passed and the developers are still unable to make the game enjoyable while stating they need more and more money to keep the "support up". This is absolutely inacceptale and I will refrain from buying ANYTHING from CA ever again that costs more than 5$ because honestly, that's was the content of their DLC's and buggy main games amount to. Luckily, there are other games/ game studios worth looking into.Verdict: Do Not Buy, CA has gone down the greedy dev route and there is no sign they will change anytime soon.

review: As of writing this review I have never been more torn on whether to recommend a game or not.The campaign has moments which will make Warhammer fans giddy like a kid at Christmas, especially on the last two missions (if you've played it you know.) Even non Warhammer fans will have a good time with this. The voice acting, graphics and audio are all strong. However, it's criminally short. Took me about 5.5 hours to complete and I died...a lot. The AI in this game is something out of 2004. Squad mates will watch you getting annihilated and not budge an inch, or decide to stand in front of you as you attempt to lay waste to heretics. It's infuriating, and something you'll need to get used to because the online matchmaking in SM2 is straight up cheeks. I hope you enjoy restarting your game a lot, and loading screens, because you'll become familiar with both. Bugs, crashes, loooong loading times, and infinite loading times are going to likely infest your experience worse than any Tyranid could, and this after the game was already pushed back a considerable amount of time. The core game play of SM2 is really solid. Any third person shooter fans, especially those that enjoyed Gears of War are going to have a great time. It's challenging, brutal and unapologetic in it's approach. It knows it's target audience and swings for the fences, and most of the time it connects.This game will live or die in the next 3-6 months on how much the Dev will support it. Fixing the myriad of tech issues, and bringing more content to coop and multiplayer. More maps are needed, it's a non-negotiable. SM2 is a real mixed bag. A frustrating, disappointing mixed bag all within a room filled with potential. This could be something truly special but it's not there...yet.I'm going to reluctantly recommend it purely because I'm a Warhammer fan, and there are moments in this game that are perfection, but as a non Warhammer fan wait for a sale. By that time you'll have a feel for how many of the issues have been fixed, and what the landscape is looking like with more content to make it worthwhile.

review: Been playing pretty much every day since July 17th, putting in a ton of hours since then. The game was fun for awhile, but getting to endgame and running into a ton of game breaking bugs has killed that fun for me. Doing Prime Wars with large groups of people, which is pretty much the PvE endgame only for the bosses to bug out and become immune, or for the entire server to lag so bad you can't even shoot or switch weapons. These aren't rare occurrences, they happen each and every Prime War. The devs have done nothing to address it, instead they just kept adding higher and higher difficulties. Last update they added a new public event called Ancient One's Trial, I was excited until I climbed all the way to the top of the mountain just to realize the event was bugged and you couldn't start it. They added tameable animals, but of course they are also bugged. They can disappear, their tameness can reset completely or they can just bug through the floor and escape. Of course after everything, instead of fixing major bugs that have been in the game since I started, they added loot boxes which I was stupid enough to buy with currency that was in my account. Woopsies that currency wasn't mine, it was given to me and many other players in error, and if you spent it, well now your account is in the negative and you have to pay to get back to 0 before you can buy anything else.Avoid the game, maybe come back in a year or two if it's not abandoned by then.

review: 2022 For update on this game please scroll to the end of review!I have put in over 1200 hrs into the Total War games series. Over 663 hours spent on Warhammer 2, so am a fan not a hater & am giving my honest opinion of this game.The campaign in Warhammer 3 forces you into a non-expansion type of play using limited armies to play 'wack a mole' with rift openings (which cause out of balance corruption in your territory).The forced claiming of 4 demon souls element was annoying & boring in equal measure.The story line is poor in my opinion. Many gamers have already stated an option to TURN OFF (or at least adjust the tempo of) the Chaos Portals & the 'soul collection' would have improved the game hugely as many players don't like the campaign & others like to play a slower, domination type, or more expansionist game...the list goes on but basically any options for going outside of a very limited & rushed linear play style have been taken away.Sadly I have found the campaign in WH3 to be restrictive, & not fun. I don't think the Campaign is fixable as it would need a complete redesign. Honestly I am sad to say Warhammer 3 is in my opinion not worth buying at the present due to its high price & would recommend Warhammer 2 to anyone new to the series.If & when a free 'Mortal Empires' upgrade becomes available I will update this review, but as for now my advice is save your money for something more fun.Update 20/03/2022After looking for a while online I feel that CREATIVE ASSEMBLY are sadly not replying to their customers attempts at making their views known, to my knowledge no Acknowledgement has been made about the Campaign in WH3 being poorly received by the player base, many other widely made criticisms are also not being publicly addressed.Have CREATIVE ASSEMBLY banned their staff from mentioning anything that would affect sales figures? The Wall of Silence from the developers/makers of this product is deafening & more than slightly annoying for those of us who pre-purchased this game or who have bought early at full price only to get what we feel is a sub-standard experience.Update 22/04/2022 .....I am sad to say Warhammer 3 is now uninstalled , the campaign was boring & frustrating the first time & has no replay value. As a fan I can only hope for a better game in future but will not hold my breath. Really feel let down by this game , especially after all the ads & hype from the developers. A big price tag for a deeply flawed game!!!Update 3/5/2022Warhammer 3 is not in 'Steam Stats' top 100 games when even Warhammer 2 is still clinging on...says it all really.Update 06/09/2022 I am changing this review to positive now 'Immortal Empires' has been released, this is now the game it should have been on release. Although the developers are calling it a beta, I have played around 100 hours & found it to be stable. The game is being well supported at the moment with updates & patches coming thick & fast, a refreshing change to some previous Total War offerings.Immortal Empires is all in all a fantastic game & well worth the money now.

review: 2017 Let me preface this just a bit.I love Counter-Strike. I've met so many cool people over the years I've played, had so many laughs and good times, it's been a blast. However, I'd say about 95% of that was purely through casual. So after 500+ hours in the game, I decided to try and get into the competitive scene. I got a few buddies together and we were gradually progressing through the silver ranks (I know call me bad, ♥♥♥♥, etc.) and we were having good fun. We'd win 3, lose 1, but the point was that it was fun.However, as we got higher and higher up, it stopped being fun. The reason? Absolutely piss poor matchmaking and security from Valve's end. I can understand one bad game or 2, but it got to the point where it was consitently terrible. At this point I had stopped queing with less than a full lobby. Me and a couple friends would get qued up with people with 900 ping who were basically worse than bots, they'd leave, and then its a 3v5 for the entire match. Experiences like this, are not fun, at all. The worst part though, is the amount of painfully obvious hackers in this game. VAC is the poorest ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ excuse for an anti-cheat system I've ever seen. One hacker will basically carry an entire team, and 9/10 times the enemy team won't have the integrity to kick the blatant hacker, because he'll carry them to the next rank. The most you can do is report them, but with how cheap this game is, it's no problem for people to make another account and rinse-repeat. Valve makes more than enough money on this game to justify having a better anti-cheat system. It is honestly one of the saddest examples of a company not giving a ♥♥♥♥ about their community that I can think of in the gaming industry. Say what you want about EA being a money hungry ♥♥♥♥♥♥ company that hates their fans, I guarantee you that you won't run into as many hackers on official Dice Battlefield servers than you will an official CSGO server. That's just sad. Again, I love this game. If you want to play casual or community or what have you, you'll probably have a great time learning the quirks of the game, learning the maps, and engaging with the goofy ass community I've come to love/hate. However, the competitive scene is pure cancer. I do hope that Valve reads these, even though I highly doubt it, because I truly want what's best for this game. Tks for reading.-Sen

review: I am quite impressed with this game both in terms of its gameplay and visuals after finishing the introduction. I'm excited to start playing the rest of the game in co-op with my sister. However, I cannot ever recommend a game that forcibly installs unnecessary Epic Games bloatware on your PC upon initial launch. I bought* a Steam game to play with other players on Steam only. (*Well actually, my lovely sister gifted me the game, but my statement remains otherwise the same. Thank you so much, sis! ^-^) Fortunately, as long as you don't care about crossplay, the game is entirely functional without Epic Games Online and it can be easily removed from the installation. Here's how to do so.1) Launch the game. The game will immediately attempt to install Epic Online Services. Cancel the installation box before it finishes. You will be met with an error message upon reaching the main menu. The EOS was never successfully installed, but remnants of the software are still on your machine.2) Turn off crossplay in the game options menu of the game.3) Close the game. Uninstall Epic Online Services from the list of programs on your computer.4) Delete the Epic Online Services folder from the game's installation folder in your Steam library.5) Reboot your computer and relaunch the game. The game will greet you with the error message when you reach the main menu whenever you start the game, but EOS will never again attempt to install itself on your machine. The game is fully functional without crossplay. Enjoy Space Marine 2!

review: 2017 Death is a great teacher. Failure in Counter-Strike: Global Offensive is, as it always has been for this series, the greatest way to learn where you should have gone, what you shouldn't have done, and how you could have done better. Counter-Strike players spend a lot of time learning -- consequently, they are always getting better. Growth is an important factor in Global Offensive, especially if you're coming into Counter-Strike fresh or after a sabbatical. This is an extremely hardcore, skill-based first-person shooter, and it forces you to think differently than other modern shooters. If you’re a Call of Duty player, you’re going to need to change your play style to succeed here. Counter-Strike also tries developing into something new here as well, despite doing little to push itself beyond what it’s always done best. Global Offensive modifies old maps to keep veterans on their toes, and introduces official new modes that encourage different play styles for the first time in almost 15 years. For the uninitiated, Counter-Strike: Global Offensive is a small-scale, team-based first-person shooter with permanent death. When a counter-terrorist kills a terrorist planting explosives in a classic Defusal match, or a CT escort swallows a sniper round in Hostage Rescue, the victim is dead for good and doesn't respawn until the next round. As such, players on both sides must exercise skill and care. The bomb objective, meanwhile, gives everyone a purpose. Of course matches end when everyone on a team is dead, but a clever and coordinated terrorist team will give the CTs the slip, plant their bomb, and protect the bomb site. Between rounds, everyone spends earned cash on better gear and guns, and the cycle continues. Pieces of the Counter-Strike formula are dated at this point, but the superb heart and soul of Global Offensive is timeless. Teams are small, guns are lethal, and rounds are short. There's an addictive just-one-more-round quality to it, because there's a constant desire to do better than last time, to earn a satisfying kill, or to win in a new way. Call of Duty and Battlefield vets will wonder why they can't sprint to escape enemy fire or look down the iron sights to improve aim; Counter-Strike players will feel like they walked into their redecorated home. Certain map redesigns will catch hardcore fans off guard, but the changes are for the best -- the underpass choke point in de_dust, for instance, has a new escape route. Even in the face of genre evolution, Global Offensive doesn’t care to adapt. CSGO is so dedicated to Counter-Strike's aging ideals despite market and trend changes that it brute-forces its way to success. Part of what makes it such an engaging competitive game is that killing in Global Offensive requires a wholly different skill set than other shooters. Everyone is limited to what they have and can see, with little room for character modification or on-the-fly advantages. Running and gunning is a useless play style, even if you've bought a helmet and kevlar that round, to the point that someone standing still is more likely to score the kill. Walking, crouching, or standing are your best bets to reduce the inaccurate spray of machine-gun fire. Consequently, killing in Global Offensive feels good. There's a sickening sensation to dropping someone dead because you know they're not coming back. It's also satisfying knowing you used limited resources to play smarter than your victim. If players aren't watching corners, providing covering fire, or using smoke grenades and flashbangs, they're more likely to take a headshot from a more delicate and patient triggerman. The desire to experience that distinct feeling is a strong motivator to keep playing, even when you're getting steamrolled by an obviously better team. If you've played Counter-Strike before, Global Offensive probably sounds a whole lot like Counter-Strike. Like Counter-Strike: Source before it, Global Offensive exists simply to modernize the look of the classic competitive shooter, while doing little to disrupt the core form and function. At the same time, it does enough to color outside the lines of tradition to justify your time and effort. Fire is one of the most interesting new combat variables. Molotov cocktails and incendiary grenades either roast groups of guys or force them in another direction. Flames are a useful distraction or scare tactic, too. They're particularly useful during Demolition matches, which focus the fight at a single bomb site rather than giving terrorists two to pick between. The new and modified maps in this mode aren't as big as classic Counter-Strike arenas – entire sections have been cut off to direct teams toward a central location – but their thoughtful design is as intricate as ever. The Lake map is a standout -- there's a wide open yet densely populated yard around the bomb site, which is inside a sizable lakeside home with plenty of vantage points and hiding spots. To separate Demolition from Defusal, players can't buy between rounds. Instead, it takes a cue from the other new mode, Arms Race, in which each kill unlocks another weapon instantly. The better you do, the more you have to switch up the way you play, and because Demolition is so fast you'll need to be quick on your feet. Unlike other game types, Arms Race allows for respawns. It's the most chaotic and care-free mode in Global Offensive, with players throwing caution to the wind for the sake of climbing the kill ladder as quickly as possible. It's a shame there are only two maps in Arms Race -- a problem that will more likely persist on consoles than PC. If you have the option, playing the PC version is unquestionably the best way to experience Counter-Strike: Global Offensive. Mods, mouse and keyboard, and the usual PC-only options are better than the ports. Plus, Valve is much better about long-term PC support -- it abandoned Team Fortress 2 on consoles, and Portal 2's level editor was PC exclusive. If you prefer to play on consoles, Global Offensive is the same great game

review: 2022 I'm not really the target audience for Elden Ring given it's a souls-like, but if that is your cup of tea, this game is phenomenal. Despite really, really not being the game for me, it was mechanically engaging with beautiful visuals and audio. Although capped at 60 fps, it runs buttery smooth and never drops frames on my system. The story is complicated, a little too complicated for a game who's target audience is just going to roll and slash through all the bosses without really paying attention to any cut scenes or flavor text. Some are saying its the greatest open world game they have ever played, to those I say stop playing souls-like games and actually branch out. Elden Ring's world is jam packed with content and enemies, but it always felt small to me and too easily traversed to really be compared to any other large open world game. Lets be realistic, if you think this is GOTY or even comparable to other great classic titles like RDR2 or BoTW, then you already think that FromSoftware's next game is GOTY for 2023 or 2024. My only real complaint is that the multiplayer is HORRIBLE. Despite being the most accessible souls-like game for newcomers, no one thought to allow players to opt out of invasions. Definitely a lost opportunity. The game is hard enough without getting sweat on by people who have never seen the outside world. Playing with friends is clunky, unintuitive, and tied to an in-game item that you have to grind for. FromSoftware clearly walked down the street and pulled the multiplayer design from Nintendo who is known ubiquitously for their HORRIBLE multiplayer implementation. Had the multiplayer been more sound, I likely would not have given up on the game at 14 hours in.

review: 2019 This will be my first review ever on Steam, it's sad it has to come under these circumstances but after 2.5k+ hours on csgo I feel sick to my stomach and I want to let people know what's up. CSGO is dead, the devs are letting cheaters (mostly Russians) plague servers without batting an eyelash. VAC (the "anti-cheat" system) is useless, as is the overwatch. With the game turning f2p hords of hopelessly bad players came flooding servers, turning hacks on the second they get killed by legit players. I've been in games where all 9 other players were openly cheating, activating spinbots, speedhacks, wallhacks, no recoil and many others.I haven't had a single cheater-free game in days. It's shameful for Valve to allow an otherwise great game to get dragged in the mud so pathetically. This is not just a huge waste for the industry, it is also a blatant message that Valve does not care about their community. To me it is disgusting that they would let down a 20-year loyal playerbase in such a disgraceful manner. Sad timesEdit: With Valorant coming out, one really realizes how CSGO actually is hot garbage lol. Servs are trash, the netcode is basically a diceroll meaning your aim doesn't count because the game is developped so poorly. Glad it is getting rekt by Val, Valve deserves Riot as a competitor, both companies are a pile of impotent fools who are clueless af. Cheers

review: Playing "Once Human" is like discovering a new Chinese takeout place. You decide to try it because it’s new and affordable, and then you end up enjoying a succulent meal. It has all the familiar ingredients you’ve seen before, but they’re combined in a way that feels fresh and well-balanced."Once Human" is a free-to-play game featuring in-game currency for cosmetics, with no pay-to-win elements at all. It blends elements from other games like The Division(gunplay) , Palworld(base economy and pets) and Rust(base building) . You can dive into hardcore grinding to get the best loot, or you can focus on building a beautiful base where you can relax and automate the game loop. Alternatively, you can simply enjoy the view on your motorcycle. Enjoy it on a PVP or a PVE Server pick your poison.Overall, it’s a great game, but it does have its flaws but nothing that seems unfixable:Combat: The combat is too simple for my taste. You can take on mobs and bosses that are way over-leveled with ease.Environment: Some areas need reworking. There are places where the floor levels don’t match, creating unsightly gaps where you can get stuck.Despite its flaws, "Once Human" offers an engaging experience with a variety of activities to suit different playstyles. The game successfully combines familiar elements in a fresh and balanced way.

review: The obvious souls-like references aside, something this game does that i find quite interesting; Boss fights in this game play out more like a traditional arcade fighting game, like Tekken.Bosses moves have more mixups and they tend to try and bait/trick you into trying to punish a lot of times. The moves also can be chained from their various moveset making combos you really do not anticipate. There are very few "combo ender" moves where you are guranteed a safe punish so most times you'll need to poke with some risks or go for a combo with major risks.As an example the Black Bear Guai, the final boss of chapter 1, has a few generic attacks that he can do such as combo A of 1-2-3 or or combo B of 1-2. At times he could use less than the combo's full string (such as combo A 1-2 but no 3). That's typical of Soulslike. However, at times, you would see something like combo A 1-2 into combo B 1-2. Another mixup of combo A 1-2-3 - pause into combo ender X (Body slam) to punish people who like to poke (You can still dodge it if your reflexes are fast enough).Sometimes there would even be combo B 1 - pause and then into combo A 1-2 - pause again to throw off the rhythm.Very rarely, the boss would spam a chain of attacks such as combo A 1-2-3 into combo B 1-2 into combo ender Y (double hand slam).It's nice to see a pretty innovative take on the soulslike fighting style as well as emphasis on boss fights as opposed to exploration/common enemies.

review: 2014 Introduction:Counter Strike: Global Offensive is a multiplayer FPS game where you are either part of a Terrorist organisation or part of a team of Counter-Terrorists. The aim of the game is to work together with your team to defeat the opposing force. Even with many new maps, weapons and features, this game still has some classic maps and guns from the older Counter Strike games.Pros:-Over 20 different weapons to choose from.-Many game modes including casual, death match, arms race, competitive and more.-Unique skins and possible drops at the end of each match.-Operations that feature new community-made maps and skins.Cons:-Trolls, hackers and smurfs can ruin a competitive match.-In general, the game does not have a very friendly/kind community.-Some in-game items/features can be quite costly.-Competitive bans may last as long as a week.Overall:CS:GO can be addictive at times and is a lot more fun when playing with friends. The graphics are nice and I personally enjoy the music/sounds. Communicating and working well with your team can be a huge advantage to the game, but there are those who prefer to stray away from the rest of their teammates and play by their own rules. My rating would be an 8.5/10.

review: 2022 CA hasn't regained my trust after the whole Shadows of Change and literally antagonizing their community fiasco (I won't go into detail, you can look it up yourself).Right now the game is in a much better spot but CA has a lot of work to do, they really need to bring back their release system back in Warhammer 2 where they release a DLC and an FLC. When I mean FLC, I mean a proper one not a single hero unit but a WHOLE FACTION with their own unique gameplay mechanics like Imrik for the High Elves.They did something right though with their DLCs currently in which you can now buy the specific DLC for the faction you want and are not force the buy the whole bundle for a massive price.Personally I recommend the game for anyone out there looking for a good Grand Strategy game where manage an empire in turn based system and fight battles RTS style. The game offers SO MANY interesting factions to play as (if you are willing to pay the extra dollar for the previous games and dlcs).Do note that even if you're just buying Warhammer 3 alone, you literally gain access to 10 different factions to play as: 3 Kislev Faction, 2 Cathay Factions, the 4 Chaos Factions and 1 Mixed Chaos Faction. In my opinion that gives players a lot to experience and with the Sandbox Campaign unlocked you can experience the whole of the Total War Warhammer game without having to buy the 2 previous games.I still cannot recommend buying this game at full price though as CA has not re-earned my trust for that. In conclusion, good game but bad company SO BUY ON SALE

review: 2022 Third Update 30/04/2024: Sega fired the right executives, awesome DLC and patch fixing many issues. CA have adopted a pretty anti consumer approach to not fixing core bugs, poor AI performance on the campaign level, and some things that have been broken for far too long. On top of that, increasing DLC prices while reducing content included. Stay away until they're building a product for the customers and not the quarterly report.Update to previous review: Immortal empires is what this game was built for, even at a beta stage it seems so much more care has been taken on the new combined campaign than the standalone. Have not noticed any of the issues that previously had at launch. Would Now recommend the game.Previous Review:Personally had no issues with performance at 60fps without lag spikes, the soundtrack is much better than the last one in the series and generally has a great atmosphere. Some Janky stuff, I'd recommend waiting until immortal empires, as again the campaign objectives aren't really as fun as a sandbox in singleplayer. Really cool that the engine supports 8 player multiplayer campaigns now though, awesome addition!Have to not recommend getting for now, units randomly don't do what they're told to do, skirmish mode randomly comes on in the multiplayer domination, units don't path through settlements properly, campaign is just not really fun unless multiplayer. Worse than Warhammer 2 mortal empires by quite a lot - wait until immortal empires/ they fix the jank.

review: Game is great but needs SERIOUS polishing on the network side of things. I'm one of those unfortunate souls who has been plagued with the inconsistent connection errors since day one. As in, after EVERY mission/op/session of ANY kind I am disconnected from the servers with no way of reconnecting. The only way to "fix" it is to ALT+F4 and restart the game. And you can't make progress offline (at least with ops) as it isn't saved. Would it be such a big deal to fix that if I wanted to solo some ops? I've had multiple runs where I would make it to the end of a mission and disconnect RIGHT before getting out. VERY disappointing. I've tried the PVP side of things as well and I can barely get through a match without getting a network error, and all my progress is lost. So what's the point? So that being said the game is GOOD enough to make me want to slog through this madness, but I'd wait until a patch releases that addresses these issues first before throwing down on it.

review: Awesome game, environment, music, story, and combat are to perfection. Combat in general, doesn't only depend upon abilities, weapons, and builds and it's adjustable according to the player's requirements and needs, it couldn't have been more perfect than this. Even though the music is in the native language, you still vibe with it while playing the game. And graphics and environment were so beautiful that every time I went to a new area, I wanted to capture it.The story takes place after the events of the Journey to the West and the way they have narrated the whole story is marvellous. Every chapter will take you to a new area and tell a story about those who live there. Chapters 4 and 5 were the peak of the way the story unfolds.Now let's talk about the cons, chapter 6 is the weakest chapter in the whole story, and after the banger of an episode before that, I expected more. Boss fights and side bosses of the chapter are not memorable at all. But it's not the worst thing about chapter 6. The worst thing is optimization, your fps will drop considerably and come to around/below 60, and micro stutters start. They will surely patch it out later. Invisible walls are pain in the ars, devs should have could have dealt with it in different manner.I DON'T RECOMMEND if you want to 100 percent the game, as so many different items are locked behind very low rng. I killed one type of enemy around 100+ times to get random armor just for the sake of achievement and that armor wasn't even worth that grind,Overall, awesome game, definitely one of the game of the year contenders. Solid 9 out of 10

review: 2022 Note: This is my first souls-like.Elden Ring is definitly a game for people who don't like to their hands held throughout every little thing.The tutorial area is hard to miss. Pay attention and you will learn the basics of everything you need. Most will die during the tutorial but its designed to be that wayCombat:The combat is incredibly well done, unique and thrilling, incredibly challenging but very satisfying. This isn't your casual RPG like The Witcher, Skyrim or anything else you know where spamming the attack button means you get an easy win. This is not a Hack and Slash either. It's combat is so complex, every movement has to be calculated with a thought in mind of what you're gonna do.It will be hard and you will die alot, but eventually you will get over it and beat whatever gives you a hard time. That feeling of success makes the journey of dying, remembering patterns and studying every enemy so very worth it.Story: (spoiler free)The story itself, is practically nonexistant if you dont know how the Developers approached it. Most of it is told indirectly through exploring, interacting with NPC's, even hidden in Items and Cinematics. While cinematics are incredibly rare, it makes them so much more special and important.Progression:Upon leaving the starter Area you will come across little beams of Light, graces as they are called. Those are basically checkpoints where you can refill your potions, memorize new spells and level up. The golden rays around them, once discovered, lead to the next area you need to go to progress. Though, this is just to lead you to the main story. You are almost required to explore the world and find new gear to help you prepare for whats to come.I haven't finished the game but im very excited to do so. As this is my first souls-like i got a little dragged down as i kept dying alot. But as i kept going i noticed one, very important thing:The enemies dont hinder you on your journey, they are the journey.Don't give up! You will eventually have that rush of dopamine that'll make everything worth it.10/10 will attack the starter npc for calling me maidenless again.

review: Özeti baştan geçeceğim. Çok bir umudum olmadan aldığım Wukong beni gerçekten her çok şaşırttı ve bu yıl şu ana kadar oynadığım en iyi oyun oldu.Oyun oynanış olarak zaten sade ve eğlenceli ama sürekli yeni hareketler, büyüler, bürünülecek şekiller ve geliştirmeler buluyoruz ve yelpazemiz genişliyor. Genişledikçe de oyun derinleşiyor. Üstüne karşımıza çıkan her düşmanın ve özellikle de bossların farklı mekanikleri bizi sürekli yeni taktikler geliştirmeye zorluyor. Oyun çok kolay değil ama sizi cezalandıran bir zorluğu da yok ve düşmanlarınızı yenebilmeniz için her şeyi size veriyor. Oldukça hızlı olmanız gereken bir oyun ve kendine has bir ritmi var düşmanına göre değişen. Oynanış hep akıcı ve üst seviye eğlenceli. Düşmanların kafasına bütün gücünüzle geçirdiğiniz odunu çok güzel hissettiriyor oyun bize. Büyüler, eşyalar ve özelliklerde birden fazla oynamayı hakkedecek kadar geliştirilebiliyor.Haritaları başlarda küçük görünse de ilerledikçe dallanıp budaklanıyor ve genişliyor. Harita tasarımları genel olarak güzel ve bir sürü ufak tefek gizli mekan, nesne ve boss var. Kestirmeler ve gizli haritalarda buna eklenince gayet yeterli bir oyun süresi sunuyor bize dolu dolu.Oyunun zirve yaptığı yer ise sanat yönetmenliği, grafikler, müzikler, karakterlerin diyalogları, her bölümde türü değişen bölüm arası videolar her adımda mest ediyor sizi. Fare dövmeye gelmişken bir anda kendinizi kafası olmayan bir ozanın şarkılarına ritm tutarken buluyorsunuz. Mekanların büyük kısmı Çin deki tapınaklardan direkt aktarılmış veya ilham alınmış ve hepsi büyüleyici görünüyor. Karlı dağlardaki Budha heykelleriyle dolu dehlizlerden tutun, lavların arasındaki bir tapınağın işlemelerine kadar her şey olağan üstü, en ufak detaya bile özen gösterilmiş.Oyunun "journal"i ise ayrı bir övgüyü hakkediyor. Sadece buradaki karakter hikayelerini okuyarak Çin mitolojisinin büyük kısmını öğrenebilirsiniz. Hikayeler hem eğlenceli hem de yürek dağlıyorlar. Sizi sinir eden bir düşmanın gerçek yüzünü öğrenince hafiften dumur oluyorsunuz.Başta da dediğim gibi oyun beni resmen büyüledi ve nefes almadan oynadım. Bir kaç ufak sorunu var belki ama günümüz oyunlarına göre çok komik sorunlar bunlar ve yüzlerce çalışanı olan multinasyonel firmalar bu kadar stabil oyun yapamıyorlar. Bütün içtenliğim ile her oyunsevere tavsiye ediyorum, hele ki God of War tarzı oyunları seviyorsanız. Ne yazık ki ülkemizde artık çok pahalı oyunlar ve hobimizi rahatça tavsiye edemez hale geldik ama bu yıl 1 tane oyun alacaksanız o da bu olsun.

review: 2022 First off, let me state that ive never played a Dark Souls game before, id heard about them though never took the plunge. If those games are anything like Elden Ring, I have seriously been missing out. I bought the game after watching a trailer and the concepts all sounded like a fun time. Turns out, that was an extreme understatement. If you are like me and enjoy challenging games that make you feel like you have actually worked each victory, exploration and beautiful environments I can say with 100% faith that you will love this game. My only negative is the multiplay co-op with friends. Given how difficult some bosses are, its understood that you will die a lot, so having to re-queue each time you die is a bit tedious. review: 2016 CS:GO a game, that forces you to blow.Counter strike global offensive, is a sequel to a game not many mention, that is the more tame and passive counter strike source, or at least by comparison. When you get CS:GO you will immediately know, that you're gonna be bad and quickly get mad. And if you aren't aware of the haulage of rage in less than a minute, your "teammates" will acknowledge and flip it on.Never in my life, have I been in a situation where I wanted people from another nation to be on my team. Because with most of the american players, they do nothing but add layers of irritation and stress, mostly screaming kids or random mooks making bids for weapons while ignoring their dames, when they should be playing the game, that it causes such a mess.The main game is all the same. If you're a terrorist your goal is to blow up things, like a horrible chemist. If you're a counter terrorist, you'll find yourself defending one of two spots like a minimum wage therapist. Both teams do have an alternative option, that they aren't too furtive about. Everyone usually goes for this route, and just kill everyone on the other team without a doubt. This game is not new user friendly, I dare say it is quite deadly to newbies. To sum things up, before I get mad and break a cup. It feels like everyone is a 5 year veteran, but you are some poor letterman that gets headshot instantly and spent more time dead than alive. Your accuracy is off like a dead battery, but every bullet from each enemy is specially graced by gaben to carve a mullet into your skull. It doesn't help, that this games community is rancid, if you dare yelp everyone will shout at you like you're a whelp. Not to mention the huge amount of smurfs, that make you feel like you're in detention. Don't even bother unboxing, because it is outright mocking you what little difference it makes. All you can get is a skin, which is as worthless as the bin you'll put it in. All the guns work, but apparently aren't as fun without bright colors stickers glowsticks or prickers. And don't dilude yourself that if you keep trying you'll get a knife, it'll be a very pitiful strife. And the worst part, that makes the first statement of this review meanginless? This game makes you always feel bad, I rarely see anyone glad to be having fun at all. CS:GO makes you feel like you blow. There is one thing that is a big deal to the smurfs, that they gladly take and seal. But the problem that always hits without fail is, this game is always on bloody sale. So for 40 bucks, the average chucks can have about 8 accounts. So even if they do get a ban, it'll literally be like you threw a rotten tomato at a fan. Just more of a fuss that oozes from this toxic community, like a wound full of puss.You may ask yourself, "why does this random delph still play it then?" The answer is simple, like connect the dots with dimples. This game has challenge, and does need "teamwork" to make you do better than an allonge. Which you'll rarely get alone, it cannot be done. Bring a friend, because in the end it is better to suffer together rather than alone.Otherwise can't recommend.

review: I've played Dark Souls 1 and Dark Souls 3 but never completed them. Elden Ring is my first FromSoft game I have gone far in and even defeated Melania. Sad really. Only bosses I felt was amazing was Godfrey, Radahn and Melania. It might sound like I hate this game but I love it, it's healthy to criticize games you love. I realized why it feels more RNG and why the bosses just feel like they have too many cheese. It's because I refused to use the tools that are available. I beat Melania without a summon and with a pure Dex katana build out of pride that "I have to beat her without a summon/no magic". Elden Ring is not Dark Souls, the bosses will cheese you and it will be RNG sometimes. But use what the game gives you, level past 150, use summons, cracked pots, respec, mage, cheese builds, etc. Be resourceful because sometimes, pure builds just get ♥♥♥♥ on with the bosses in Elden Ring. And thats okay.

review: 2022 Let me preface my recommendation with this: This game in its current state is recommended for enfranchised players of the Warhammer series. At this time I wouldn’t recommend it for newer players or even historical players who have jot played the previous two games. I’ll also preface that at this point I have just completed the tutorial campaign and I am 20 turns into a Demon Prince campaign, so I won’t talk about anything beyond that scope.My specs:Geforce RTX 3070Ryzen 5 5600x 3.4ghz8GB DDR4 RAMI play at 1440p on a curved monitor.The good: The game contains a number of important quality of life improvements from the last game. Aside from the well discussed battle and campaign features that have solved problems we both knew we had and some which we didn’t know we had until they fixed them, CA have clearly learned the importance of having each faction be mechanically unique. Further, the tutorial campaign is exceptionally good, both as a narrative and an onboarding experience.I’ve seen a lot of people criticising graphics. For me, graphically, the game is an improvement from Warhammer particularly in unit detail and effects. I made a point to have a close look at WoC units to compare. I understand that some people criticise the change in visual style on the campaign map, with some finding it to be an overly simplified look. This is not a technical issue therefore, it is an artistic question. I personally prefer this style - perhaps it is playing on a higher resolution screen, but I am finding the campaign world a lot more immersive - in the previous games the campaign map was very homogenous per each region - whereas within one specific region in this game local areas feel a lot more diverse.The bad:For all the positive qol changes, sadly there are some things which have actually led to a quality of life decrease. Of particular note are the unit placement highlights and orders, which on the white snow background seem to be almost invisible. I find this extremely surprising that this has not been addressed before release. Unit order legibility is honestly one of the most important parts of managing battles so I sincerely hope they do something to make them stand out against the snow, which is a very common sight in this game.There are issues currently with running the game at 1440p and if you try to run it windowed you will find the top of the screen cut off - there is no screen safe space adjustment option so your only choice is to run full screen. I hope these issues will be addressed post haste.Conclusion:As stated in my preface, this review is based on a small time playing. Overall the issues I have faced have not been massively impactful and I am enjoying the game immensely. Still I hope these issues are addressed as soon as possible.

I love this game, I want to see it thrive and I want to see more people play it. But the barrier to entry is too steep and I cannot get any friends to join me in this game. review: 伟大，无需多言

Might be the first time where negative reviews actually made me buy a game. No open world Great—Not every game needs to have an open, fully explorable world. I'd much rather have a linear experience in beautifully crafted environments, which this game has. Honestly, there's much exploring to do, and it's always worthwhile. No map! I would never have expected this to be an actual complaint. This game gives me flashbacks to the late '90s and early 2000s, where you actually play a game and don't get directions spoon-fed. You have to use your eyes and recognize where you've been and where you can still go. It's what makes exploration fun and worthwhile. Backtracking through areas to see if you missed anything. It's an endless boss rush, kill a few mobs and the next boss is in sight Again—How is this a negative? The boss fights are the reason we play this genre of games. I'm amazed at how much love and attention has been put into each boss. They all have gorgeous visuals and fun, engaging movesets. No diversity and inclusion! I find diversity, equality, and inclusion important topics. However, not every game needs it. Some games have a good place and fit for it, like Baldur's Gate 3, which does it very well. However, this is a mythological game where you play as a monkey and beat up rats, lizards, and the like.This is one of the few games in the last few years where I'm having a blast playing. It feels like a mix between God of War and Monster Hunter in a Souls-like sauce. The game is hard enough to be challenging but easy enough to craft your own build without googling for strong and effective builds.

review: 2022 To preface, I am not a Dark Souls or Bloodborne purist and haven't even put that many hours into any From Software game before Elden Ring. That being said, I now want to go back and play the Dark Souls trilogy from start to finish just to experience the story and see how it plays into the Elden Ring universe since it has been eluded that it could or may.Elden Ring is the best RPG I've played in years. The game starts with a sharp learning curve that is both unforgiving and not completely clear in the direction you should work through the game in even with the grace items that give you clues, but that is, in part, a portion of the appeal and fascinating evolution of how the game draws you in. Above all else, the underlying story and characters are engaging and make you want to continue pushing on even as your patience and temper are tested throughout. The difficulty of the game can be overcome through trial and error, but can also be supplemented with grinding out more levels and learning the crafting system to strengthen and enhance your weapons.Having not spent long hours in From Software games before Elden Ring I had to learn the timings and overall strategy that you must apply in every fight as this game does not forgive any type of button mashing and will punish you for each mistake you make when fighting enemies that could be 5, 10 or 50 times the size of your character. You learn what "iframes" are and how some animations will prevent you from taking damage, you learn how the longer you hold the button for your "strong" attacks, the more likely you are to get hit, but the greater the damage potential. You learn that parrying and counters are an essential play mechanic and that you cannot brute strength your way through the game and you must apply a level of finesse that is frustratingly cruel at times, but amazingly rewarding when you finally complete the mission or fell the boss at hand.Having played many other 1st & 3rd person RPGs, Elden Ring is the game I wish so many before it actually were. Specifically, I've indulged in the entire Elder Scrolls series except for the very first game, Arena, so I have thousands of hours in the series. As great as the evolution of the series is, story-wise, the gameplay actually declined over the course of the series rather than improved, even with the deployment of newer technologies and engines. In fact, the latest installment was, in many ways, a disappointment in terms of the play difficulty, story telling and the lack of time spent on developing the NPCs and driving factors. When you compare this to what Elden Ring is it's clear that From Software is extremely talented in staying focused on what matters and developing the gameplay and story to craft a universe that you not only want to be a part of, but also want to continue learning and digging through.With all that being said, Elden Ring is not a perfect game and there is definitely room for improvement; the lack of cut scenes and the reusing of them at key points in the game was disappointing. The game could have been greatly enhanced by adding more meaningful cinematics and not leaving so much up to the imagination. There definitely are pros and cons with this approach, but for a game of this caliber I would expect a more complete cinematic element, particularly at key points in the game where you overcome main bosses, make discoveries about characters that can come as a huge surprise and develop the story to your own path that makes the story all your own. The only other part of the game I find is lacking other than the cinematics is the focus on developing the story nearly exclusively through item descriptions. Although this is fairly unique in how you learn the more obscure details, the fact that you basically have to grind out for items with an extremely tiny drop rate to find those complementary tidbits, I wish there were other ways that the story was elaborated upon similar to other RPGs where lore is weaved throughout and doesn't just appear in an item drop.The only other criticism I have found within the game is that there is no truly enjoyable way to play as a physical ranged character and that the lack of ranged weapons tends to leave the game in a balance between magic & melee, which itself leaves a huge amount of content choices for any character development, but with only really a "2 pronged" weapon/class choice balancing act it does narrow down the way you play the game. Regardless this is minor in my eyes and is something that could be shored up in a DLC/expansion or in a sequel that makes the weapon choices slightly more dynamic between melee, magic and ranged.Overall I would say that even if you never played a Dark Souls title, Bloodborne, Demonsouls or any other From Software title, but want a challenging, infinitely fun and dynamic RPG that focuses on true gameplay and a story, then I would profoundly recommend Elden Ring. With the historical elements of the lore developed with the help of George R. R. Martin (Game of Thrones), the intertwining paths of the characters and their fates was amazingly interesting, creepy, diabolical, sad, enraging, thoughtful and yet still left room for even more emotions depending on what you discover on your first play through. The fact that you can then choose to play the main story again, and again, and again, evolving the difficulty to your own desire is a great complement that allows you to relive the ups and downs to your own expectations without needing to start a brand new character.TL;DR, it's the best action RPG of a human generation and there won't be another game that comes close to it until From Software teams up with a company like BioWare to integrate a more dynamic end game experience.

review: I played the entire game on the Steam Deck. It ran 30 FPS consistently in almost all areas in the map. The game graphical settings were all set to low and FSR Frame generation OFF (this setting crashed the game after the intro battle but it was fixed in a recent patch, still I wouldn't recommend playing with this enabled). Every chapter ran good except chapter 3. The more you play the game the more the game lags (it's weird to explain but you'll know once you play it yourself). This "accumulation" of lag was the worst in chapter 3. My deck froze 2 times in chapter 3 alone (but not consequently, I returned to chapter 3 area a lot for other side missions). To fix the "accumulative" lag just restart the game. Overall the game is playable on deck and runs good.

review: 2022 As a writer, Elden Ring is a modern masterpiece, even today with major releases that are stronger than ever. More games seem to take on the pseudo-genre of souls-like but never really capture well... the soul of Dark Souls. Releasing in 2011 the game stands the test of time, remaining a work of genius with unrivaled mechanics and stunning visuals. Even better is the superb storytelling and wonderous writing featuring inspiring interconnectivity that is unbelievably unparalleled. The world was hand crafted by the savants at FromSoft, a publisher I would buy used toilet paper from they are so good, Lordran is some of their best work to date. The map design is master-craft with no crevice overlooked, it's the model of perfection and gamers still have yet to see anything else quite like it. Some don't see it at all because of the difficulty which turns so many gamers away but that makes the combat system the most satisfying known to gamers and gaming. It's so difficult it would turn even the most pathetic incel into a Christian chad! With that difficulty comes some of the most iconic boss fights in gaming (not to mention the rock solid waifus, lookin' at you Queelag). As you are trapped in a life or death struggle against the bosses of Lordran you can feel the passion of the developers have for their game, encapsulating their blood sweat and tears with masterful theming and some of the most unique character designs to come out of gaming. To the player one of the best feelings in the game has to be standing triumphant over a boss you threw yourself at over and over again. It's such a privilege to watch your character progress, it really makes you feel like a dark soul.Even renowned novelist H.P. Lovecraft and the late Ghandi have praised Dark Souls for its vastly superior technical prowess, character design and story telling. It was and still is a groundbreaking and innovative game that gamers everywhere absolutely MUST play. Not to mention haunting the musical score which made me YEET my pants. Simply put Dark Souls is G.O.A.T all year every year as an unparalleled gaming experience that has spawned its own genre and inspired so many story writers such as myself. After all, what do we say about the Mona Lisa in 2019? Still a masterpiece? Every game developer needs to take a page fromElden Ring book, maybe even a chapter, ♥♥♥♥ it, the whole book!

review: 2023 I've been playing Total War for a while now. Every so often the devs drop the ball and get a little greedy, a little lazy, or both, it happens. The community reminds them why the money flows and we move on. This time feels different. Ever since WH3 came out things have not been as expected. More bugs, less content, less transparency, higher prices. WH3 launched in a sorry state, they made it slightly better over a long period but nobody cared much because we were all waiting for Immortal Empires, the mode that would turn the Total War: WARHAMMER trilogy into a magnum opus.The mode came and it was busted. Bugs, balance, design, all far below what is acceptable or fun. Even for these devs it was a bad look. I took a break, willing to wait for them to polish up Immortal Empires so I could come back and play the game as It should be. This is an ambitious game, I thought, give them some time. I come back many months later expecting to play a better game and am shocked to see that not only has very little improved, but the devs got it into their head that it was time to press their luck. The upcoming Shadows of Change DLC will have both less content and cost way more than usual. I gave them close to a year to get their ♥♥♥♥ together and they're trying to cash in on goodwill they spent long ago, so they can fund some ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ hero shooter that is absolutely dead on arrival.We're not your wallet, CA, and we won't pick up the slack supporting your failed endeavors. You put people to work on this game and we can talk. It's not too late to turn this around. Don't let the years of blood, sweat, and tears go to waste when you're so close to greatness.
