review: 2022 Need some serious work right now. Spent a bunch of time with this game and found some many minor things wrong with this game. Went back to WH2 and I was like "wow." WH2 did so many thing right and WH3 just forgot about it. It almost like they took a old WH1 build and just added a bunch of new things to it. As of right now, I can't recommend this game. I love WH2 and this game was a disappointment. I like the life improvement, but what the point of them if the game is not fun. The campaign SUCK! It feel like a copy and paste for each faction. Even the cut scene feel like a copy of each other. They follow the same layout with a few line difference. The old man go to a faction, make a deal where the faction you are playing either want to kill him or don't believe him, he only ask for a drop of blood, and then without even thinking about how they wanted to kill him before, they take his offer on. Now normally I wouldn't care about this, but it is the fact that this happens a lot. This copy and paste of units, story, and game mechanic is so lame. What is CA obsession with harpy like creatures and wolves? There are so many variation of the same units and they suck mid-late game. I also truly hate the new supply system. It fine in minor settlement, but major settlement suck. In the grand campaign, it was fun playing chaos once. After that it became annoying. I can keep going, but then this will only be a rant. Bottom line, it need some serious work. The biggest problem? CA decided to took out the fun like the magic system or how units use to fight so much better in favor of a faster pace game. It was like night and day difference playing WH2 again after playing WH3. For now, don't buy this game, let just hope CA get their act together and make their game FUN. If you like the game great for you, but I think the other review by other people speaks for themselves. We just want CA to fix the game.

review: One the greatest games ever to exist. Ive never had such a hard time coming up with words to explain a fantastic game, a fully fleshed completed game on release. A great story that gave me chills and had me giggling like a child while watching the most badass cutscenes Ive ever seen in a game. The game is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ beautiful, every location and level was designed perfectly. to fit the mood and set the scene. With the addition of operations to see another side of the story with your own customizable character. The armor customization is pristine, being able to adjust every piece of armor to mix and match different chapter armors with every armor piece have its own color scheme. The attention to detail is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ phenomenal while playing through the story there is so much going on in the background that most wont notice, my friends and I spent a lot of time standing around watching battles from afar or listening to the dialogues from NPCs. PVP mode is fantastic and really pushes for teamwork. I cannot wait to see what else the team has in store for us in FREE updates.

review: 2023 THE RUINATION AND TOTAL MISHANDLING OF ONE OF THE BEST GAME SERIES!!!All they had to do was release a mostly bug free release and keep pumping out good DLC, same as they had with TWWH 1&2 and they would still have the goodwill and faith of the community and more importantly raked in Billions in revenue........TLDR New DLC Pricing is a rip off and makes this game a pass until it and all dlc are 50-75% offThe first Total War Warhammer game was a expensive but great game that was good enough to justify even the price of the multitudes of DLC, the second game built on the first and soared to new heights especially after opening up and massively improving the modding potential which allowed for an entire sea of mods, many of which had better mechanics and quality than the official DLC (especially Mixus lords, some of which were legit better than CAs versions of the same lords) despite the amazing modding community the countless still expensive but great DLC were still worth it and sold like hot cakes.by the time they left development of the second game Ca had an mountain of good will and faith from the community despite individuals like me having had to spend in the high hundreds of dollars on the series so far to enjoy the full experience.All of which they somehow burnt up in smoke, TWWHIII on release was a mess, I will gloss over the countless major bugs that we seem to expect these days from AAA, the only map had countless mechanical issues and campaign design was terrible for many factions, they overhauled Multiplayer and improved much of the previously painful experience, yet they still left many of the old issues like in custom battles being very restricted on number of sides and configuration of players between each. also faction DLC on release, really? just ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ manipulating gamers perception to make more money is not a good start to the game.despite all these issues and countless more most people including me still had faith that with time and DLC the game would fix itself and soar to even greater heights than any before. all they had to do was devote devs to the game and it would print money faster than a american national bank.Instead development was painfully slow and seemingly put on the back burner by CA, eventually bugs went away and we got Immortal empires that passed over many of the issues with the old map and things seemed to be looking uphill, then Chaos Dwarves happened, or more its price did, probably the best DLC in the series yet but at a massively marked up price (half price of the full game WTF) which wouldn't have been as painful if it was the only DLC, but in top of the $$$ most people already have invested in this franchise its just way too much but at least it was a great faction and had an excuse.But the insanity that broke the hydras back is the latest DLC the Shadows of Change for the same already high price as one of the best factions yet we get 3 lords 11 units and 9 regiments of renown which is an absolute rip off, a team of a dozen modders could do that in just over a week, and they charge half the price of the full AAA game, WHAT THE ACTUAL HELL!!!and the worst of it is future DLC will probably be the same price or more, if this is what 3 lords costs what will a faction cost in the future? and bear in mind being the final game in the series if they dont drive away the rest of the consumers it could have 20-30 such DLC, were talking potentially in the thousands of $$$, not to mention the already massive investments in the previous games.If you made it this far then you have my condolences. and ♥♥♥♥ CA, there treatment of this game has turned the same as every other AAA developer

review: 2022 Total War Warhammer III Total War Warhammer III is an epic conclusion to the Total War Warhammer trilogy. Though the main campaign "Chaos Realms" may be slightly disappointing the massive update that many of us have waited is finnaly here. Tthe Immortal Empire update combining content from previous Warhammer games into one big sandbox campaign and with promise of support for coming years by CA and amazing support with mods by the community one thing is certain. This is best and definitive Total War Warhammer Fantasy experience. Pros: + Immortal Empire+ Addictive, one more turn syndrome+ Good soundtrack + Steam workshop support ( mods ) + Dozens of unique lords, units, and mechanics for each race+ Game for many, many hours... + Sieges are upgraded finally. Though they are not perfect still.. they are for sure better from what we had in previous Warhammer games Cons: - Chaos Realm campaign it's mixed expierence. Mostly because of annoying mechanics "Chaos Gates"- New missions/battle type: the survival one that let you fight againsta few waves of enemies. Though sounded cool on paper, in game experience it's just not fun.- Missing blood and gore it's still outrageous. Yeah there's dlc for it, but that's just pure heresy.- Diplomacy could use some major upgrade. Not that you want to pact with those demons but yeah...Overall rating: 9/10 Total War: WARHAMMER III A Screenshot of Total War: WARHAMMER III By: ScoRrpioOo Total War: WARHAMMER III A Screenshot of Total War: WARHAMMER III By: ScoRrpioOo

review: Gonna be completely honest, after the first 30 minutes of optimization hell, I am safe to say that the early trials were worth it. A story that sticks to the core of 40k, the beautiful, immersive set pieces. This is THE 40k game I've been waiting for. The combat system has taken some time to get used to, but there's nothing more satisfying than pulling off a chain of executions and heavy hitting slams into the horde that surrounds you (before you turn the entire place into a red mist). And it's not just the melee. The ranged weapons have the most satisfying bolter punches I've seen in a 40k game yet. The multiplayer PVP mode could use some balancing, and the campaign AI really needs a tweak or two, but this is something that nobody is a stranger to at this point. It's an expected headache when you make gameplay surrounding co-op and then give us robots with the brains of a sloth to back us up.I accidentally purchased the early access pre-order, but as far as I'm concerned, it's been worth every penny, and will be for a long time to come. Especially with the solid replay value. I may have distrust in GW, but nonetheless I am very content with Space Marine 2.

review: I am on my fifth playthrough now and I cannot stop playing it lol. Ever since Sekiro, I have been looking for a game that is challenging with satisfying combat experiences. Elden Ring was fun but the combat is just not as interactive and satisfying as Sekiro. And now with Black Myth: Wukong, I have finally found another game that gives such satisfying combat experiences. I would even say this game actually excels Sekiro in some aspects. I love how fast-paced the combats are, and being aggressive is actually beneficial just like Sekiro. In addition, the fact there are so many spells, spirits, transformations, stances, equipment skills available adds variety to the combat experiences. There are so many different playstyle or build to choose from and you can change your build any time. Even at my fifth playthrough, I am still discovering new ways to play the game. My favorite thing to do is to switch stances mid-battle and see-through counter with different varied combos (so satisfying when pulling it off). On top of the move variety, no two bosses are the same and every fight is just incredibly cinematic. For people looking to start souls-like games, I would recommend starting with this one. This game is much more forgiving and easy to get into compared to actual souls games. You don't lose anything on death, you can refund and respec skill points any time you want, you have a much stronger dodge that enables dodging at last second before you get hit, and you can farm levels if you are having trouble with a boss. Besides being lenient, the game is also just very polished in every aspect. It definitely lives up to its "overwhelmingly positive" reputation.

review: 2022 CS2 grapples with a toxic player community, a deficient anti-cheat system, encountering cheaters every three matches, a shortage of casual game modes, the absence of a 128-tick rate, and the implementation of a questionable 64-tick system called "subtick." Additionally, the game is plagued by peeker advantages, ultimately overshadowing the once-dominant CS2 experience.On a somewhat brighter note, the game boasts nice graphics, though it seems that people don't flock to CS2 for its visual appeal.In conclusion, CS2's drawbacks, including its problematic player base, ineffective anti-cheat measures, cheater prevalence, limited game modes, tick rate issues, and peeker disadvantages, cast a shadow over what was once a standout gaming experience. Rest in peace, CS2—this review doesn't paint a rosy picture.

review: 2015 (Update 24th of december)It's just not what it's used to be anymore..Community:COD was most likely known for the game with the most toxic community full of kids, but since cod got worse a lot of kids came to csgo and here is the problem. The CS community became more toxic now and it's quite Annyoing for people to have a squeaker in their team. Their voice isn't even the problem.. It's just that they feel like KennyS and claim the AWP as their personal weapon for the whole game and if you tell them to stop playing AWP, you just get a ''♥♥♥♥ you'' or ''shut up idiot'' in response. Now let's be honest, how many times did your mum get ♥♥♥♥♥♥ by 8 years old squeaker? According to the game probably over 10 times am I right? Don't get me wrong, it sure as hell is funny to make those kids mad, but at some point, they become a pain in the ass. Competetive:I used to play competetive with a full team, but sometimes you just don't get 5 friends to join and you just start looking for a game with 1 or 2 randoms. When you and your 2 friends found a game, you realize it was a mistake to play with 2 randoms, because either they are russians who were boosted and only speak in their language or you get 2 salty kids. Pretty much both russians or kids is bad, because once you lost 3 or 4 rounds, they start teamkilling and as a result they mostly receive a 7 days cooldown. Then you have a bot in your team and the game is probably lost. You are starting to feel upset and you are frustrated, because this match was a failure.Elo system:Don't have to say a lot about this right? A lot of people complain about the elo system in csgo and so do I. You're on a 8 games winstreak and then you lose 1 game and get downranked. Having a good rank is everyones goal in CS:GO, but ranks don't really say anything about skill anymore, because of all the smurfs. Yet you're eager to have a rank like LEM or supreme or even better... Global! Skins:A unnecessary feature which makes the game look nicer, but some skins just cost as much as a car in real life... I know, you don't have to get skins, but so many people buy those expensive skins and try to make other people jealous.. I think, it's kinda sad if someone wasted tons of money just for a digital item. Now skins are not just expensive, the other bad thing about this is the amount of scammers in this game. Now if you look past all of those negative things I named in this review. Go ahead and buy this game. I won't stop you. This game can be a lot of fun with friends. Yet if you try to play it serious, this game becomes a really frustrating experience. CS:GO is broken, because of it's community and the latest updates weren't a big help either. Weapons like the M4A1-S that I used to play a lot are literally unplayable for me now oh and the messed up HUD in casual is still not fixed aswell as the spawning in teammates glitch. Hey but whatever instead of fixing those things Valve decided to add a new gun to this game. 10th december the R8 Revolver was added to this game and you were able to kill 5 people with one bullet. It caused a lot of hate, because this gun was like a freakin' AWP. They reduced the damage now though, but was it really necessary to add a revolver?Oh also. Save your ''just because you're silver'' comments okay? Thank you.

review: 2022 Let me start by saying the game is good! If you buy this game, you most likely will enjoy your first campaign if you enjoyed your first vortex campaign from game 2. They have added a bunch of QoL improvements and changes that I find pleasing.The negative reviews are due to a few things (which are legitimate) like the bugs, the lack of replayability, and comparisons of this brand new game to the masterpiece that was the second game of the trilogy. I felt the need to leave this review to give greater context to the negative reviews. People are comparing this brand new game to game 2 which has had years of tweaks and DLC to flesh it out to it's greatest potential. Game 3 is brand new, no DLC other than the day 1 pre-order bonus, no mortal empires, fresh bugs, etc. It is a bit unfair to compared game 3 at launch to game 2 at it's peak. Game 2 at launch did not have mortal empires and only had a fraction of the playable races/lords available as they do now. In time, game 3 will likely surpass the popularity of 2, but it will take time for the Devs to add in Immortal empires (sandbox mode), new lords/factions and patch bugs. I do think this game was the best of the 3 on release day, but WH2 with all the DLC and updates is currently the superior product (unless you've played it to death and are bored of playing).The Warhammer games rarely ever go on sale, so I would suggest picking it up and enjoying a campaign or two now and when you get bored, put it down until they come out with new updates, especially the immortal empires update which is coming later this year. That should add a bunch of replayability that currently isn't here for a lot of people who dislike the souls race and don't feel like installing any mods to remove that objective from the game. The current factions already offer up a bunch of differing campaign mechanics to keep things fresh for me personally but your mileage may vary. This game gets two thumbs up from me because I know it will get better over time like the first and second games did and I had fun with what they released on Day 1.

review: The game features a vast, open world called the Lands Between, filled with diverse landscapes, hidden secrets, and challenging enemies. The world design encourages exploration and discovery. Elden Ring retains the challenging and rewarding combat mechanics of FromSoftware's previous titles, such as Dark Souls, Bloodborne, and Sekiro. Players can choose from various weapons, spells, and abilities to suit their playstyle.The game offers extensive character customization options, including classes, stats, equipment, and abilities. Players can tailor their characters to their preferred combat style. True to FromSoftware's style, Elden Ring features numerous challenging and memorable boss fights that require strategy, skill, and patience. The game’s story is co-written by Hidetaka Miyazaki and fantasy author George R.R. Martin. It features a rich, intricate lore with deep world-building elements. Like previous FromSoftware games, the story is presented in a fragmented manner, encouraging players to piece together the narrative through exploration, dialogue, and item descriptions.

review: 2022 I put lots of time into Warhammer 2 and was excited for Warhammer 3, its been a while since launch now and it is definitely an improvement on Warhammer 2, but not quite the improvement many people wanted. Warhammer 2 was an amazing game and any improvement on that is welcome, but when you are charging a hefty price plus DLC, it's hard to call the improvement we got as good enough. There have even been some steps back that the community has been very vocal about, it's the sieges, they were already a very weak part of the game and they have just been made more complex in an attempt to make them more fun. The larger immortal empires map size and new factions have been great, but Warhammer 3 is a whole new game, a whole new game that feels like warhammer 2 with a few major content updates/DLC and some quality-of-life mods.

review: Once Human promised an immersive open-world experience in a post-apocalyptic setting, but unfortunately, it fails to deliver on many fronts. The game’s visuals are lackluster and lack the polish one would expect from a title in 2024. The environments feel generic, making exploration feel more like a chore than an adventure.Gameplay mechanics are clunky and unrefined. Combat often feels unresponsive, with hit detection issues that can lead to frustrating encounters. The crafting system, which could have added depth, feels overly complicated and is plagued by repetitive resource gathering that quickly becomes tedious.One of the most frustrating aspects is the six-week reset mechanic. This arbitrary timer not only disrupts progression but also feels like a forced attempt to keep players engaged. Instead of fostering a sense of achievement, it creates anxiety and resentment as players feel pressured to grind through content before the reset hits. This design choice detracts significantly from the overall experience, making it hard to invest time and effort into the game.The story is another major letdown. What could have been an intriguing narrative is bogged down by uninspired writing and poorly developed characters. The dialogue feels forced, making it hard to connect with the plot or care about the outcomes of any of the characters.Multiplayer elements seem tacked on rather than integrated smoothly into the game, leading to disjointed experiences that lack cohesion. The matchmaking can be frustratingly slow, and once in-game, coordination with teammates can be a hassle due to poor communication tools.Overall, Once Human is a missed opportunity that falls short of expectations. It’s a game that feels more like a slog than an engaging experience, leaving players longing for a more polished and innovative approach to the genre.

review: 2022 Quite frankly the best open world I have ever played and will play for a long while. It really is the only game that has perfected open world and that sense of "open". It doesn't force you or tell you to do anything, it throws you into the world with little direction and the wonderment and curiosity of the player take the reigns from there. Very similar to BotW but with an outstanding world, packed to the brim with fun, unique encounters around quite literally every corner. There is always something new just at the end of your line of sight that has this amazing power to draw the player in. The amount of content, and varied at that, that From Soft was able to fit in here will be talked about for years to come.The game wasn't without it's downsides though, albeit few and minor. The performance on PC was terrible and remained for the 2.5 weeks it took me to play. No excuses at this point for framerates locked to 60. The game also for better or worse does not tell you much and while that is a welcome change and makes the discovery feel better, there needed to be some kind of codex for the player to remember the plethora of plotlines. The world is so huge that the next time you return to a plotline you end up forgetting 70% of it. And lastly the balance of the game, something From Soft were absolute masters at with their previous entries, is beyond broken to the point where it is a bit frustrating. I fought Margit completely underpowered because I favored the main story at that point but from then on I explored 95% of the world before tackling the main story portion in the area and found bosses dropping like flies. They need to work in some kind of scaling system if they continue with the open world. For this reason this was hands down, and not even close, the easiest Souls game to date (post Margit).A fantastic entry in the series that also deserves a nod for the world that was created by GRRM. Very unique and very cool with a whole slew of interesting and well designed characters. Will definitely be a game you see high up on many "top games of all-time" lists, and an easy recommendation for anyone, especially due to the low level of difficulty.

review: Another game that's fun for a while, but that I believe will die out within release year.This is quite an amalgamation of themes and genres. The setting feels similar to games like Control / SCP, while gameplay seems to borrow more from games like Rust & PUBG.Gameplay loop is simple: Loot tier 1 areas, create tier 1 buildings & gear, fight boss, unlock tier 2. Loot tier 2 areas, create tier 2 buildings & gear, fight boss, unlock tier 3.Loot tier 3 areas, create tier 3 buildings & gear, fight boss, unlock tier 4.This is fine, 6.5/10 fun, but:The gameplay loop has 2 big issues for me currently: 1. Enemy AI is not great & being reckless is seldom punished. You can melee every single non-boss enemy with 0 issue. They get stunlocked, no matter the size, no matter the level. They can't fight back. This makes looting cities just feel like a checklist. It's not particularly exciting.2. Building structures doesn't feel great right now. The snapping is terrible and results in a lot of lost time.The game optimization seems overall decent, but at the same time when you're driving a vehicle, a player building will pop up from nowhere 10 meters away. Also I saw some PvP servers, but the netcode isn't that great even for a PvE setting. Me and my friend always claim to be doing things that don't match what the other person saw & we often see eachother teleporting, not having animations or phasing through building floors in bizarre ways.

review: 2022 edit: this was originally a negative review due to performance issues and glitches, these have since been patchedElden ring is a fantastic culmination of fromsofts design lessons from dark souls. While i have some personal hiccups here and there, its undeniably a fantastic game.For the first attempt at making dark souls an open world game, its crazy how well it was executed. The term "open world" might make you wince a bit seeing how for most games "open world" means "we made a big empty map of nothing and filled it with objective markers to pretend there is content. There might also be concerns on how the dark souls formula of tightly designed challenges and areas would function if the world is now meant to be freely explored on your own pace. But i can honestly say they found a good way of mixing both together. The world may be open now but youll come across castles or caverns that are tightly designed like the areas of old titles with shortcuts, bonfires and bosses at the end all without loading screen or obvious level transitions. The game will simply force you off your horse and uses clever level design to prevent major skips from happening so you get that tight level design youre so familiar with. The combat is better than ever and uses many lessons learned from previous titles while also mixing in brand new ones to give a fresh but still familiar dark souls feel. The story has the usual vague feel to it, but puts in a bit more effort to try and convey whats happening than previous games (although its very likely youll still need to look up videos by the end of your journey to really understand what you just went through).I could go on and on on what the game does to well but the review would turn out to be very wordy, its easier to say what i didnt enjoy to allow you to come to your own conclusion on if the negatives are enough to push you away from trying this title. But keep in mind that any negatives mentioned dont outweigh the sheer amount of positives this game has to offer.1. The main story path is actively scaled to curve insanely hard at the first boss, so when you get to them you'll find yourself struggling super hard and start questioning if you're doing things right. The game is designed that way to encourage you to leave the boss alone and explore instead (to get new weapons/armor/abilities etc) but its not at all clear when playing that that is what you're meant to do. 2. While the game boasts an impressive 238 bosses, its worth noting that a massive amount of them end up being just regular enemies with beefed up hp and damage. Not to mention having a ton of repeats of the same boss with slightly different attacks.3. The nature of the open world means that its entirely possible (and arguably unavoidable) that youll end up completely overpowered for some areas/bosses which robs you of a fun fight in a lot of cases. (Luckily the main bosses needed for the main campaign dont really have this issue and are scaled quite well with your progress)4. The multiplayer is once again a pain in the butt to use. If youre playing with friends, prepare to grind tons of flower pedals as youre required to use one every single time you die and want to re-connect with friends which also opens your world up for invasions which are arguably more annoying in this game than any other. Because areas are so incredibly large, its not uncommon to get invaded but spend 30 minutes trying to find out where they are hiding because the pvp invasions are not limited to the small castle/designated areas, its entirely possible to be invaded while out in the open world. It literally turns into an hour long hide and seek session and is more annoying than any fun that could be had from the combat, so its better to disconnect and re-connect with friends than it is to deal with the whole thing. People have taken to modding in a better multiplayer that fixes most of these issues.Thats it! If none of those bother you much then you should have bought this game already.

review: 2014 I bought this game for the chickens, and was not disappointed. After exploring the countless lands the chickens have traveled far and wide, I realized their population was growing too large. The chickens had started to inhabit such horrid locations across the world, such as nuclear plants, and offices without cafeterias. I knew what had to be done. I bought a flip knife off of the steam market, and called PETA. I listened to In the Arms of an Angel in my Microsoft Professional Deluxe Gaming Chair 360 for about twelve hours with no response, so, I decided to take matters into my own hands. I loaded up de_nuke and started to put the chickens out of their misery. I cried harder that night than I have ever before. The next morning, with tears in my eyes, I loaded up Counter-Strike: Global Chicken, and I saw a new item waiting in my inventory. My Flip Knife had turned into a Flip Knife Slaughter. At that moment, I realized what a horrible thing I had done. With my hand shaking, I navigated my mouse, and uninstalled Counter-Strike: Global Chicken. I regret everything I have done. I am writing this review to warn you about the chickens, and to let you know I have made a full recovery, and that I have started my new journey in Goat Simulator. Thank you, and farewell.

review: It's been a long 13 years waiting to find out whatever happened to Titus after the end of Space Marine, but the day is finally here. Some people think the single player campaign is a little short, but for me it fell right into the Goldilocks zone (just right) and the story was worth the wait.Gameplay-wise, the pacing is very good. The Tyranid swarms can be insanely frenzied and near panic-inducing, while dealing with the Thousand Sons and their Tzaangor and Cultist allies tends to be more methodical but just as deadly.Dealing with the lowest-tier riff-raff goes along like you'd expect it to... they're a breeze individually but dangerous in numbers; still, most weapons will take them out with a single shot/strike. But as the opposition scales up, even the best weapons start to feel like you're just tickling the biggest/baddest opponents. Naturally they should be significantly tougher, but when your biggest and best guns or melee weapons are only knocking off a sliver of their health at a time with headshots or your heaviest blows, it's a little disheartening. In the campaign this is just something you'll have to deal with, but in Multiplayer you level up your gear and unlock various class perks as you win victories and this becomes less of a burden. There are two modes, Operations and Eternal War, PVE and PVP respectively. Eternal War is definitely fun and challenging, but if I'm being honest, I enjoy playing with two others in the Co-Op Operations, where you have a little more feeling of purpose as you go along and achieve your mission requirements.Graphically, it's just a beautiful game. My GeForce 4080 is running it maxed out with no problems but I was worried for my grandson who's PC is just slightly above minimum specs. Happily, he's also running it surprisingly well with a few lower settings than I have but it still looks absolutely tremendous.Honestly the only gripes I've had are the aforementioned problems with weapons not feeling up to the task on the bossier enemies, and Clive Standen taking over from Mark Strong as the voice of Titus. Strong's voice was just so iconic for me, but after not too long, Standen made it his own and all was well again in short order.

review: What I like about this game: The story is very good. It can work quite well as a possible sequel to the original Journey to the West Overall graphics, design of characters and all aesthetics related material are actually quite good, I like it, even the low graphics setting is pretty solid The gear, and the ability to get the mats are not too bad. If you take the time to explore. You will be able to mostly craft a decent amount of armor sets near end game. I think I was able to create at the very least 2 - 3 sets before NG. Combat is not too shabby either, with a but....will be in the "What I don't like/prefer to see change"What I don't like/prefer to see change: One of the biggest things that I recognized almost immediately is the lack of a map, having a map would've been so helpful in exploring these huge maps and areas. Especially since each chapter is quite long. I personally would've preferred that leveling increased your attack and defense, maybe not every level but maybe every other level or two at the least. Some bosses just do so much damage. And if your someone like me that has a bit of a slow brain and takes time to adjust to these attack timings, it would've really helped alot. Now for the combat, I think that for the most part like mentioned above its not bad. You have light attacks, dodging, heavy attacks and the usual. But what I experienced at least is, sometimes the game will not respond to some of my commands and I will have pressed that hotkey...exaggerating....like a bazillion times. Like space bar for dodge. And there were some bosses were my lock on would randomly disappear on its own. Not for when bosses fly high in the sky or something. Like it would be when its just regular combat near/on the ground. Whether this is a bug or my PC I don't know. But this is what I am experiencing. No mana regen mechanic other then a poor restore rate using gourd. This lowkey ruins the game for me.Comp Specs: CPU: Intel i7-9700K GPU: NVidia Geforce RTX 3080 10GB Founders Edition RAM: Corsair Vengeance 32GB

review: Space Marine 2 is a good example of what we've lost due to games as a service and predatory monetization schemes, with videogames whose sole purpose of development is to serve as a cosmetics and skins virtual store.Saber has transported me back to the first decade of the 2000s when video games were just art and pure entertainment. For sure this is not a perfect game, but it is certainly a great one. A solid campaign, cooperative mode and a multiplayer mode, which is simple, but very fun and entertaining, with a progression system and lots of rewards to unlock for free. Just like in the good ol' days.How good it feels to be able to play a video game with no developer-generated fomo to encourage battle passes sales, with a clear roadmap before release, no microtransactions and no in-game store.Space Marine 2 is visually amazing with stunning graphics, the combat system is smooth and action packed with a blood and gore feast. I'm playing it on a 3080 with no problems or bugs so far, but I think they can optimize the game even more for my fellow brothers who don't own a beefy GPU.The Emperor has delivered. The Emperor will provide. For the Emperor!

Smooth combat (responsive soulslike, you get rewarded for being aggressive, you punish enemy openings at the right timings)2. Large Variety of Enemies (all enemies are different. only 3-4 repeats which are rarely overlapped)3. Good graphics/immersive environment/art4. Actual good stuff rewarding exploration (sometimes its an entire area and numerous bosses)Cons.1. No Map despite having too many big areas to explore2. Invisible walls (mildly annoying to constantly test jumping to check for hidden areas -> use google to make your life easier)3. Attacks from bosses can be too instant, you are dodging in anticipation and not in response (makes the boss fights feel ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥/unsatisfying at times)4. Interrupted spells going on CD when hit while casting, can be annoying esp when its a long animation and has long cd8/10

review: 2022 tried again and still stand by my review, absolute ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. performance is garbage and there's no salvaging this travesty an absolute F of a game. L company too. - 01.04.2024 CA Fix the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ performance on this piece of ♥♥♥♥ game man. 21/01/2023edit: Still no fix for campaign map stutters. 03/05/2023 I've amended the initial review to say is that it is OK and at best, it's OK. it's not a masterpiece and people who say that are clearly blinded by fanboy devotion. Personally, I will play it casually and maybe delve into a campaign for a few hours to kill time in some morbid reminiscence of WH2 and what WH3 could've been, for contrast I have 1990 hours in WH2 and 80 in WH3 after 6 months release. The negatives are quite obvious. - Bad performance and stuttering with no fix in sight really. ( there won't be any fix until the shills start accepting that 30 fps isn't good enough performance.) - Worse settlement battles than it's predecessor which is still in my opinion a superior Total War game. - Worse sieges than it's predecessor instead of improving it's more of a capture point game which turns the inevitable slog that is the sieges in Total War : Warhammer series into an even more annoying endeavour. - Worse performance at high resolution for no apparent reason, i get 30 FPS on the campaign map while WH2 is smooth and around 60 - 75 FPS.- CA keep making abritrary dumb changes to campaigns that aren't really what we needed just in some mad scramble to rectify the absolute sorry state of the game in which it was released.- Less land battles...... ( why ...?) - There's still adundant visual glitches on the maps and lighting, obviously IE released and not all the maps will look perfect but they should've at least gave them a try first ( Blackfire Pass being toned over with a weird blue filter for example.) + Better DLC ( 4 lords in one pack is a good idea and i advocated for this a long time ago) + Better unit texture.... I guess. ( Kislev look terrible.) + Better vassals and diplomacy. All in all i'd say stick to WH2 if you really want to just enjoy a good Warhammer total war experience this game just isn't it, it feels flat and soulless to me and consistently has been like that since release.....and even now with the IE '' beta''. Final note: CA fix the performance cause it does kill the experience, settlement battles aren't improved in fact they're flat out garbage and everyone knows they are, it's not even a Total War: Warhammer game with they way they work as it stands and buffs for units capturing points, with multiple capture points pasted over every settlement battle and siege is stupidity and i shouldn't really need a bunch of modders changes to rectify it.

review: 2022 Worse than TWW2 (current build) but better release than TWW2 release. I'm sure this will be awesome with a mortal empires/grand campaign added, in the future.Positives:-Many improvements to mechanics, diplomacy especially, saves soooo much time.-Allies are useful now, recruit allied units, coordinate and have fun -You can trade settlements!-Badass demon campaign mechanics, you are actually pretty powerful, and you feel it.-Great soundtracks, animations, landscapes and battle locations (except walled cities)Issues: -Some maps, like Altdorf are still missing textures.-Very poor end game reward, without spoilers.....very underwhelming for what it can do and what it comes with. Same reward for everyone, the narrative reward isn't granted, its just cutscenes and you don't get any new traits, abilities or anything.-Once you beat the campaign, have fun with never ending chaos invasions every 10 turns, forever. this requires you to have a hero stationed at each and every entry point, ready to close the portal for 1.5k gold, every 10 turns. if you want to take over the map, get ready to shell out tens of thousands of gold every 10 turns and bump up your hero cap.-The realms of chaos give little to no rewards. you really only go to slaanesh's penthouse to get fancy trinkets, the rest are trash, leaving you with bad traits.-No mortal empires yet-Walled cities hurt you, dont get them. Currently, when you try to dock archers on walls or whatever, their line of sight is often blocked and they just sit there, so you have to set archers behind walls or somewhere they can shoot from.-Adding walls to a settlement will place two capture points for your town/city, so instead of setting all your forces on top of an objective and defending, you have to split your force. Is it worth it to have 3 more units garrisoning your town but have to defend two capture points, which losing one loses the battle? NO, fight in the strees, no walls.

review: I absolutely loved this game. Played it in CBT3, did fan art, was a regular on the Discord, planned to build one of the monsters for Halloween but I am quitting now, absolutely not recommending it, and these are my reasons. I have mostly played it on their launcher so my hours here do not reflect time played. I got to 48 in beta and 39 on my main character since release and hundreds hours of play between the two. The good is as follows... The monster and world design is great, combat is fun, the map is fantastic for exploring (which I have spent whole nights doing) and even just getting on your bike to get where you are going for the sheer joy of driving through it. The game loop is quite addictive till you start hitting the friction points and thinking about the looming demise of all your hard work. This company wields FOMO like finely honed sword. That coupled with the short seasons which have 'exclusive items' just generates a feeling of being rushed even though I know there are several more weeks, I just don't feel like I can get everything done in time and I would end up having to start over in many ways (I am very familiar with what you keep between seasons). This might not be such a huge problem with many gamers but I want to clear all the areas, collect all formulas for the items to put in your base, and feel like I have actually accomplished something.On top of the time limit actually getting these formulas is very grindy and I just don't see how anyone could get them all without being very lucky and in game every waking moment. The other issue is the building system is buggy and limited. The aesthetics are hit or miss, mostly miss and you can't really customize cosmetic or house items, (there are a few you can choose between ugly and ugli). All the build pieces are very modern and that's not an aesthetic I enjoy so my attempt at a Queen Anne house ends up looking like a McMansion. It's hard to justify spending a lot in the cash shop when I have a roof corner that will not place for love nor money even though it was there previously before dissapearing randomly so I have a piano on my roof. Absurd problems require absurd solutions. Another glaring issue is character progression. A lot of the abilities for crafting, upgrading, and maintaining your base and equipment are behind RNG with appalingly limited opportunities to reset anything.. This is incredibly frustrating if you have bad luck in getting the critical abilities like being able to make acid from sulfur and if you do get the good ones they will be reset for the next season. Maybe this is encouraging people to work in groups but not everyone can do that so this mechanic makes the game very unfriendly for those that solo. The economy is also frustrating. There is no central, global way to trade. The vending machines you can sell from are local to your territory or truck later in game and you have to place it somewhere and hope people interact with it. We are relegated to the old days of spamming chat to try and sell what you have, hoping someone will come to your vending machine and we are forced to do this because there is a ridiculously low buying cap on the few vendors in the game so it is impossible to actually level the abilities that aren't RNG which cost money as well as points. You also need money to teleport, buy the expensive formluas the vendors have, and some other things cost here and there too. There are too many currencies, too many menus buried within more menus and it's easy to forget where to do something or lose track of all the buttons you have to click on to get the measly rewards you can get from completing season goals, or daily whatever. It's a chore to navigate this nested mess.The game has a lot of glaring instances where it is obviously unfinished. Missing translations, odd animations and mismatched dialog. I question how they are going to provide new content every 6 weeks in perpetuity, as seems to be what's promised, when the starting scenerio is unfinished.I hate having to break up with Once Human. I have a pretty big emotional and time investment if only a limited financial one. This really could have been THE GAME but there are too many problems, too many choices that cause player frustration, and I just can't spend most of my free time anymore knowing I will just have to do it again in a month or so. I am done.

review: 2023 Good Fried Chicken Recipe:In a large mixing bowl, whisk together buttermilk, hot sauce (optional, for added flavor), salt, and pepper in a mixing bowl. Add in chicken pieces. Cover the bowl with plastic wrap and refrigerate 4 hours.When ready to cook, pour the vegetable oil in a skillet until it is about 3/4 inch deep. Heat to 350 degrees.Prepare the breading by combining the flour, cornstarch, onion powder, garlic powder, oregano, basil, white pepper, cayenne pepper, paprika, and salt in a gallon sized resealable plastic bag or shallow dish. Mix it thoroughly.Working one at a time, remove chicken pieces from buttermilk mixture. Shake it gently to remove the excess. Place it in the breading mix and coat thoroughly. Tap off the excess.Place the breaded chicken into the 350 degree oil. Fry 3 or 4 pieces at a time. The chicken will drop the temperature of the oil so keep it as close to 350 degrees as possible. Fry each piece for 14 minutes, turning each piece about half way through, until the chicken reaches an internal temperature of 165 degrees F.Remove from the oil and place on paper towels. Let them rest for at least 10 minutes before serving.

review: 2022 Edit: The most recent update is certainly a step in the right direction. Anti-player bias was reduced and a lot of big issues such as replenishment was improved for some factions. Whoever is now managing the project seem to be more receptive/involved with the community. I'll keep this as negative still for now but its FINALLY improving the way people asked.Edit#2: Game has fixed most of its launch issues now. A few lay around waiting to ambush you at annoying moments but overall, it's a far better game now. I'm leaving the review up as I personally am very exhausted of total war games coming out with horrific balance and would like this to serve as a reminder. If this game came out in the state it is now in, it would be a big thumbs up.Ooof where to start? The fact that it wasn't ready? The fact that they doubled down on things people hated in the other games? The freakishly slow updates to get some of the most basic issues fixed? The fact a warhammer game needs almost an entire year to get blood added?... a warhammer game, where you can play as the blood god. The fact the main campaign is an absolute miserable experience? There's just.. so much more. I'll start with the positives.The main positive I could give is that factions have much more engaging mechanics to them than earlier games. Even if their rosters are miserably small... no we're trying to say something nice here. Ogres feel actually finished as a roster, with interesting mechanics and a wide variety of units.The bad.. well it's difficult to explain how extremely bad some of these things are with a character limit so short. I could write multiple pages about the design flaws in the main campaign. Flaws ranging from complex issues that are difficult to deal with to amateur design choices that you'd imagine get thrown out the first time they slip from anyone's lips let alone added to a 60$ AAA title.The campaign is effectively a race, which gets triggered every 20-30 turns. Unfortunately, this absolutely kills the pacing of the base Total War gameplay. Everything comes to a halt, as you enter Chaos realms to get a soul first. Only to realiize that you are the only one playing this game. The AI is not playing the same game as you at all. They do not have the same challenges, they do not get the same debuffs, they do not have to complete the same puzzles, they do not need buildings to recruit units, they do not need to actually do anything you do. They just automatically breeze through while you suffer the most miserable experiences of endless debuffs and being attacked by other enemies while your main army is in some pocket dimension. The game actively punishes you for playing the game as intended. Expanding your settlements and empire means the AI will disproportionately focus you. Allowing their own home to be burned down with no reaction, while sending 3 armies to your doorstep. Maybe get allies? They could be useful if there wasn't an in game design that makes any AI who you alliance with, suddenly become the most passive and weak faction. Yes, if you alliance with an AI, they actually get their AI debuffed to not do anything by themselves. The AI is just so obviously AI due to its comical level of player targeting bias. Shamelessly doing anything it can to stop you while doing nothing else the entire game. An issue so bad, even the developers have had to admit it needs fixing. Just keep in mind, this was not added as a bug, this was the INTENDED DESIGN.The game is such a mess, everything has been put on hold. Months dedicated to fix the horrific design choices that were baked deep into the game. Also, 7 months needed to fix replenishment for 2 factions? What is going on over there? How does it take 7 months to fix things that modders fixed within hours of mods coming out?Give it a year or a little more, then it might be in a launchable state. Sadly it could have been good, but CA decided to ignore feedback and stick with whatever they wanted to do. Lets hope that changes fast.

review: 2022 Its hard to put into words the joy Elden Ring has brought me. Rarely do I see a game where you can explore and fight your way through a huge fantasy world, with so many functional builds to play as, and just so much to explore and so much to see, stuff to find that actually matters for the improvement of your character, and unique underground and hidden areas to find.It expertly blends the grand sense of adventure and discovery in the open world, with the tighter more focused exploration of its large 'dungeon' type areas.. while while blended seamlessly with the surrounding world, also feel like a self-contained experience that is more traditionally Dark Souls like in a lot of ways. You'll see what I mean when you get into Stormveil Castle for the first time and see how the feel of the gameplay shifts to something veterans of the Souls series will feel more at home with.I also think it does a good job of making the game a little more accessible to players who found From's similar games to be too difficult, while still offering a challenge. I particularly like how the world allows you alternatives to just trying to push forward when you're having difficulty.. It's a simple matter to just abandon the area or boss that is giving you trouble, and trying your luck elsewhere for a while.. and maybe out there you'll go up in stats, find some more charges for your Flask, improve your weapons or find better gear, obtain some new magic or learn how to craft a helpful item, and also hone your own abilities as a player with practice without frustration.. then when you come back, that impossible boss won't seem so hard anymore.I love this game. It's just one of those things that checks all the boxes for me, and I'd encourage anyone curious to try it... especially since they're now already patching the game to try to relieve some of the troubles that PC players were having on launch (I count myself lucky to not have those problems myself.. I've seen on stream what the issue looks like and I understand the frustration for those that are experiencing that weird 'chug' or 'stutter')

review: 2022 First: I am not very good at souls games and it is sometimes hard for me to stay focussed and don't get too frustrated. I play on an rtx3080 and the performance sucks the most in the open world. There is no difference for me to play on low or ultra, the frame drops will appeare anyway.But in legacy dungeon or other not so open areals the Performance is just fine. A fix, plus widescreen support would be highly appreciated.To the game: It is a masterpiece.I roamed the open world and found places, friendly characters and scary enemies. The longer I played, the better it got to just explore and taking risks.The "bon fires" placement and additional options have made a huge step in the quality of live direction.You can take runs on bosses/npcs/situations without to beat half of the game and slay 3 demi gods on the way. But I already experienced the dark souls feeling in some places but you are far away from being forced to be stuck. The fights feel as good as in other souls game and therefore I can ignore that I am fighting the 1000 knight or skeleton (or crab). 10/10

review: 2022 Let's be real for a second: This game without any DLC or predecessors is not even half a Total War game and the price you are asked to pay for the "full experience" is only stomachable, if you bought the other stuff you want in it over the last years.The balancing is all over the place, since CA ramped up the magic from I to II to III considerably and throws in elite units like it's going out of style, Once you've met a half dead Chaos army that still kicks ass because every single unit is a super elite unit, you'll know what I mean. The difficulty setting essentially just beefs up the AI units to ridiculous levels and reduces their upkeep so a faction a tenth your size may field as many armies as you have, Legendary Lords may have the most special of special effects - or a minor economy buff, so if you meet one in battle, be prepared for nasty surprises. Even just on "hard" difficulty, I've seen the AI attacking me, getting killed to the last zombie (Sylvania) and both attacking armies were back to full strength with the lords I just put in the ground... there may be some ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ around.Endgame scenarios follow the old CA-route: Just throw a ton of elite fullstacks at the player, because that's fun. Idk if it were an actual horde attack, but the spawning of - for example 15 stacks of elite wood elves who just go on the rampage until you burn their stupid forest - is plainly creativly bankrupt.The design of minor villages is moronic in the extreme and mostly doesn't benefit the defender nearly as much as it should in the case of dwarfs, humans and elfs, who may have things like "firing lanes" and "defensive positions" in mind. There are -for example- often courts which might concentrate the enemy by blocking off the exits, but you can't put any ranged units in good firing positions around it. Sieges are still as stupid as they were in TWWHI. everybody has a ladder up his arse and walls are little more than death traps for your troops. Knocking down reenforced gates with clubs and fists takes about as much time as it takes a unit to leave the wall.I'm not saying I'm not having some fun in this game, but it could be much better, especially since it's the third and final entry in the series. So if you liked the other two TWWHs and have all the DLC races you might want to play, go ahead and buy it, but if you are new to the whole TWWH... go get something else, this game will annoy the hell outta you.

review: Problems With the Progression System The current progression system in an otherwise great game is a turn-off and is going to drive would be players away from sticking with the game as it evolves over the course of its road map Separate Cosmetic and Class Progression Having a single currency, Requisitions, be required to progress these categories puts players in a position where they are going to make mistakes as they try to kit out their preferred Astartes Chapter. Players will be in search of the correct right shoulder insignia or company pauldron trim paint and this means sacrificing progression of class skills. There is no explanation of this risk to a new player and the system itself is so frustrating its easy to have level 15 in a class and not be able to afford even the first row of its perks. Class skills should just unlock at the appropriate level. There should be no need to also buy them with Requisitions. The amount of Requisitions for victory should be increased at each difficulty level. You should still receive a reduced amount of Requisitions for mission failure. Continue to require victory to progress in unlocking distinct armor parts. Weapon Progression is Simply A Bad Approach The weapon system is convoluted and tying better weapons behind higher difficulty is a guaranteed way to drive players away out of frustration. The Minimal difficulty in this game is hard and recommending "Level 5" to players to take on the next difficulty tier is meaningless if they have spent their Requisitions on cosmetics instead of their class skills. Mastery tokens should simply be removed from the game. As you progress experience on a weapon class the perks should also just unlock without having to acquire a mastery token. Locking the Armory Data required to advance a weapon class to its higher tier is a bad formula. Some players will never be able to achieve those weapon data tiers and as such will remain stuck at a lower difficulty without a means to improve their offensive abilities beyond a point. Armory Data needs an exchange system such as 5 Green can exchange for 1 Purple as so on. This system also needs FAR better in game tools and tutorials without everyone having to refer to out of date early access review information or Reddit posts trying to figure out how this all works Potential But Also Potential To Die Fast This game is going to draw a lot of attention when it fully launches. People will be excited about playing as a Space Marine. Even with the above suggested changes the game is going to be a GRIND to progress. When players find out their progress is also heavily skill gated in what is a seriously difficult game they will move on to the next thing. Its important to preserve the high difficulty for players who have the skill and want that challenge. its equally important that the perks and equipment necessary to play on higher difficulties become available to players of lower skill and that the systems involved here be retooled quickly or this game will end up with a very small player base of nothing but hardcore difficulty seekers. The entire backbone of what is otherwise a great game, its progression systems, are a total miss and I hope you take the above as constructive criticism to improve the game and sustain your audience while you still have the opportunity to do so.I cannot recommend this game until the progression system and economy for multiplayer are addressed, not at the full price asking point.

review: First off, let me say that everyone has a right to their opinion. I am not here to say whether or not this game is right for anyone else as we are all in different life situations. It is, after all, a thing to do in our free time. Something to get our mind off of life for a while. So below is just "my" opinion on how I see this game. Hopefully it helps those who read it (along with any other reviews listed here) to come to their own conclusion. With all that being said, here are my thoughts..I have been a fan of Games workshop(GW) since the 80's. If you are familiar with the company, then you know they're not cheap. But their commitment to quality models has been stead fast, and my "pile of shame" grows ever larger. This statement shows that I am vested in this hobby and the lore. I don't believe every video game they have released has been great, far from it in fact. BUT Total War: Warhammer I, II, III is truly an amazing game! I have also been a big fan of the total war series since the original Shogun. I bought just about every game in the series and have spent hundreds hours playing them. So when I heard these two companies were coming together, it was a sure thing for me! Below are the hours I have spent on each game and to be honest I'm surprised they are as low as they are.TWW I - 751 hours*TWW II - 3016 hours*TWW III - 1044 hours**at time of this postingThis is a MASSIVE game that includes a least 24 races(not counting rogue armies or mods) with hopefully more to come. Within those races there are multiple factions, each with their own unique play style and goals. I'm pretty sure Creative Assembly(CA) & GW plan on reaching 100 faction leaders! This itself creates an incredible amount of replay ability. Now not all of them you may like, but with such variety, there's something in here for everyone's taste and play style. CA has done an epic job bringing all this together in one massive "immortal empires map". They game can be played as a giant sandbox but GW has so much rich lore that there is a story to follow as well. DLCs were also released with certain factions leaders squaring off with each other which helps with the immersion. The environments in this world are rich and ever expanding with the possibility of Ind, Kuresh, & Nippon opening up in the future. And if that wasn't enough, the AMAZING modding community has such mods as "Dynamic World" to enrich it more.As far as game play, as mentioned above, I was very familiar with Total War game mechanics. So it was very easy to jump right in. For those of you that haven't played any of the series before(whats wrong with you?? jk jk), it may take a little getting use to, but in "my opinion" it is very intuitive on how it works. There are so many reviews on this page that I wont get into everything here but if you are interested I'm sure you can find another review that goes into it in more detail.Now, to address the elephant in the room: the cost.. By now I have said enough about myself that you can tell price isn't a wall for me if I love the product. I can spend WAY more going out these days for this many hours of entertainment (listed above) then what this game has costed me. $237.00* / 4811 series hours played = $0.05 per hr*Price of all available TWW I, II & III content, 10% off (not including Thrones of Decay)I'm sure my math may be off a little but even if it was 10x that amount its worth every cent. And the more I play, the more value I get from it. My suggestion is to wait for a sale and start small. A large part of the player base plays Empire but do your research to see which race sounds most interesting to you. You will need to buy one of the base games to start with and with "Thrones of Decay"(ToD) release right around the corner, all of the base and DLCs will be on sale (good time to jump in!) I've seen the base game I & II up to 50% off in the past. But don't feel pressured to buy all the content at once. For those of you still on the fence, remember steam has that return window policy if you don't like it within the first few days.If I have any complaint about the game, its the series has been so good that I have had trouble playing any of the old Total War historic games since due to the lack of variety in the factions/game play. I remember this being a worry from the Total War historic community before its release and now I see why. Yes, there are some bugs in the game but none of them are game breaking. Most of the time I didnt even notice them until I read the hot fixes. We need to remember few games have ever been this massive before and with all the new content these things can take time. You tube content creators, such as Great Book of Grudges, and the player base are always sure the devs are made aware of these so they are fixed. Maybe not as fast as they would like but again I barely notice them. I will make this part quick.. You may have heard the recent drama over the "Shadows of Change"(SoC) DLC and all the negativity along with it. I will say the player base stood up for what they felt was right, and I "believe" CA finally got the message. The extra content added to SoC DLC and the previews for ToD are looking like a move in the right direction to make the game community supportive again. But only time will tell.So in conclusion I want to again say this is only "my opinion". I am not saying anyone complaining this game is to expensive for them is wrong. What I am saying is that I am willing to pay developers that will bring high level of entertainment and will continue to support them so it keeps coming out. Yes, we should make sure we are keeping the developers honest and the quality of product they are releasing is held at a high standard. But in a respectful and productive way. Thanks for reading and I hope to see you in game! =)Psy

review: 2016 My Grandfather smoked his whole life. I was about 10 years old when my mother said to him, 'If you ever want to see your grandchildren graduate, you have to stop immediately.'. Tears welled up in his eyes when he realized what exactly was at stake. He gave it up immediately. Three years later he died of lung cancer. It was really sad and destroyed me. My mother said to me- 'Don't ever smoke. Please don't put your family through what your Grandfather put us through." I agreed. At 28, I have never touched a cigarette. I must say, I feel a very slight sense of regret for never having done it, because this game gave me cancer anyway.

review: 2022 Ideal. A great blend of exploration, skillful combat, freedom, level design, RPG stat/build nerding, immersion, itemization, and storytelling. The open world is comprised of mindful, intentional design, creating a sense of pacing within the fully player-driven exploration experience. It never seems to end, just when you think the game has played all of its cards and will start slowing down, it delivers over and over again. The main dungeons are an experience to behold, often giant towering structures you work your way towards, each of them a feat in level and art design. The character building possibilities are awesome, the game rewards experimentation and critical analysis of your build in ways Souls games never quite nailed down. The gameplay loop is varied and addicting, equal parts exploration, analysis, experimentation, and engaging, responsive combat. It's a huge well-designed & high budget immersive world in an RPG that puts game design & gameplay mechanics first, with an intriguing story that never gets in the way... and it doesn't compromise on difficulty. The controls and movement are responsive (thanks Sekiro), the animations are good, the art and vfx are real nice.If you have any interest in the excitement of discovering a game's world and mechanics, you owe it to yourself to play this game blindly, with minimal outside influence and wiki'ing—the game supports blind play very well, though it will be worthwhile to take basic notes in a journal or notepad file. I think a player written in-game journal or world map editor are my primary desires, but I'm just gonna blame consoles for the lack of these types of features. as they're hard to implement there.Ultimately though, this game gives back what you put in. If you want to progress slowly, exploring every inch of the world to find lots of meaningful secrets and items, it delivers as an incredible open world game. If you want to rush the legacy dungeons, creating a challenging experience by killing all the main bosses with a more limited option set, it delivers as a good action game. If you want to optimize your build, nerding out testing tons of setups and different viable strategies, engaging with the stats, spells, and itemization, it has tons of interesting stuff to play around with and delivers as a solid RPG. If you want to simply play at a medium pace, learning about the world, challenging some bosses, running random dungeons you come across, making your character stronger with the stuff you happen to find, and primarily letting your whims guide you—All of that will be engaging and rewarded. If you're a pure PVP nerd, maybe try showering someday, but yeah that's here too and it seems OK so far.I don't know how FromSoft did it, but they took the "git gud" approach to developing games and simply killed it. They deliver on not just a single intended experience, but an array of experiences, intentionally playing into the best aspects of emergent game design, while maintaining strong encounter and level design... All wrapped in some nerdy open world fantasy RPG that learns important lessons from all their previously developed games. My sincere thanks to Miyazaki & the whole FromSoftware team for their hard work, expertise, and dedication to making big budget gameplay driven games.(♥♥♥ george tho)

review: One of those games that needs a "meh" middle option. - Campaign is mediocre, individual missions and encounters feel kinda lazy, outdated in design and extremely repetetive. - Enemy AI is extremly basic, most enemies have just 1-2 attacks, bosses maybe 3-4. - Dialogue is kinda lazy and basic, even by cliche 40k standards. - Environments are kinda 40kish, but not enough. Like they're just a tiny step above generic sci fi coridor shooter. - Enemies are bullet spongy as hell. Combat seems to take "inspiration" from dark souls (like literally everything these days..) but just doesnt work with tyranids as the enemy. On veteran (which the game says is the intended difficulty) one hit will take out 50-80% of your hp, while it takes like 10-20 hits to kill the same basic non-boss enemy that hit you. While trash mobs are swarming and stunning you. Its just grindy, tiring and feels like ♥♥♥♥ even after you beat every encounter. Kinda like dark souls 2. - Ranged enemies swarm you and seem to target only the player. - Companion AI i atrociously dumb, but game seems to be designed purelly around coop. enemy hp etc. - Controls feel unresponsive, there's a wierd delay on most things. Especially bad with melee which as a result feel really bad. - AI straight up bugs out in places and does effectivelly or literally nothing - Lots a of different guns with very slightly different names that all feel almost identical - Sounds of SMs walking are ♥♥♥♥, instead of tanks, they're barbies in slipers. - Gun sounds are meh too --- A narative driven sp game designed entirelly around coop mp, even the campaign. In 2024. Seriously? ----- Whoever keeps putting in "hold button to do action" ♥♥♥♥ in video games needs to be publicly excecuted as warning to the next 15 generations. That ♥♥♥♥ doesnt even belong in console games, and is the most ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ thing since motion blur in pc games. + Visuals are good + Shooting is mostly satisfying despite meh gun sounds + Its 40k, and you're a space marine fighting xenos + Voice acting is reasonably good. Minor issues - Some stuttering, but fairly rare. - No ultrawide support yet All in all, designed purely for multiplayer that nobody will play because the single player is mediocre.

review: 2023 Im deeply upset to see the way that C.A. has decided to manage the property this late into a trilogy. The times of WH1 and WH2 were filled with fantastic content and much needed maintenance that made the games continually fun to return to over months and years. However, with WH3, C.A. has seemed to change course. The game has been littered with crippling bugs in the AI, the combat, and the lords that have made many aspects significantly less fun that previous titles. This alone wouldn't kill the my interest, as the variety of potential content has always renewed my interest in the game, but that too has fallen into disarray with the pricing changes. With the announcement of their new pricing structure, content that would have previously been in the range of $10-$15 is now $25, with the expectation that will be the standard going forward.Again, alone that wouldnt kill my interest in the game; Had the price change been matched with higher quality and consistent bug fixes like during the duration of WH2 I would have been more than accepting of it. But together though, these two problems create a game that is neither as fun as it once was, nor a good value for the content.With that in mind I have to sadly say that any individual seeking to get into the WH games should just get WH2 on steep discount, and avoid WH3 completely.

review: 2023 With a total of 340 hours poured into WH2 and 166 hours into WH3, not to mention over a thousand hours across all the total war games, it's disheartening to witness what feels like CA's decline. The game itself is fun, yet the direction CA is taking has left me deeply disappointed. The pricing strategy for their DLCs is beyond my comprehension. Despite my consistent support by purchasing DLCs upon release, the recent two DLCs have been priced at an astonishing $25 each. In all honesty, when evaluating the content they offer, this pricing appears not worthy at all.The thought of spending $50 for just two DLCs is perplexing. Why wouldn't I consider buying Baldur's Gate 3 instead? The repeated assurances that each new DLC will introduce an entirely fresh journey led me to maintain faith in the development team. However, it's becoming evident that CA does not care about player at all. Their insatiable greed is devouring their once vibrant creativity. "Shadows of Change" will be my last DLC, unless substantial improvements are made.It's truly disheartening. I believed that CA aimed to craft a gaming experience that would be treasured, a journey etched into players' memories. Yet, it seems that the pursuit of profit has overshadowed that vision.YOU WANT TO MAKE MORE MONEY? THATS FINE, I GET IT. BUT WHAT YOU DO IS NOT MAKING MORE MONEY. INSTEAD, INSTEAD, YOU GUYS JUST GRADUALLY MORPHING INTO ANOTHER BLIZZARD. SHAME ON YOU.

review: Game of the Year It's been awhile since I played a game that had me hooked to the point I couldn't stop playing. The combat is fluid, the environment is beautiful, the levelling up system is fun to explore, and unlocking new gear not only makes you look badass but also helps you along your journey. Why is combat so fun? Well, you get to capture the souls of monsters that you have defeated and use their skills; you can also transform into bosses you have defeated, and you get to pick which fighting stance to suit your playstyle. All stances can be changed on the fly during combat too. And you get a magic spell on top. Anyone telling you the combat is boring doesn't know what they are talking about.Is this a Soul's-like game? No, but it does have soul-like elements, such as Flask/Gourd, Bonfire/Shrines, and enemies respawn with huge boss battles. If you ever feel put off if this game is too difficult, worry not; I'd say this game is challenging at best and do-able once you practice perfect dodge. Why is this my game of the year? For a start, the music in this game is amazing, from the combat to the story telling and how it hits on the right keynotes for that crescendo moment. Watching the end of the Chapter 5 cutscene and listening to the song, it really fits perfectly when the cord and vocals play out in each scene. Not only was the music amazing, but the art direction, too. Having different styles of art for every cutscene was a fantastic choice. It draws so much attention. I do like how the end of chapter 2 cutscene foreshadows a side mission in the game... Well done, Game Science. That was my favourite side mission. You would think fighting bosses after bosses would get tiresome, but Black Myth manages to make a game where each boss fight feels fascinating and fun. So many times when I play a game, it's just a reskin boss battle with the same attack from a previous level, but not the Black Myth. Each boss fight has their own unique attacks, and it just feels so fresh to see in a video game. Not only is the boss battle exciting, but all the monster designs look interesting too. I had fun reading up about them in your monster encyclopaedia book. This better win an award for music and art direction. The ControversyFollowing Black Myth Wukong from the beginning, it has been so frustrating to see how unfairly treated this game has gotten from journalists, gaming journalists, and even a few content creators, for that matter. For those who are smart enough to know the whole controversy and how obvious it has become once you piece the dots together. DEI asks for money; said company makes DEI friends slander Game Science *Cough IGN*, every news outlet spread it like wildfire, gaming media reviewers purposely give games a low score, and on top of that, it clearly shows they never played beyond chapter 2. To have DEI in Black Myth Wukong would truly break the art in this game. Not only art but the Asian culture and the essence that is rich in its history. It’s "wrong" to include DEI principles in a game based on Journey to the West (a classic Chinese novel); there is cultural authenticity that has historical context that is deeply rooted in Chinese culture and mythology.You also have to respect the artistic vision. Game Science wanted their game to be told. It's their story, their culture, and no outside influence has the right to tell them what to do. It's a game that started from passion. It's also been frustrating to see some content creators turning a blind eye to Black Myth, to either no mention, no coverage, downplaying the game, or no mention how it has broken records and sold X amount of copies and made X amount of millions. Shamefully, even Easy Allies didn't even cover this game, and they were more hyped for Concord, lol. This game is more than just Game of the Year. It has been through a lot, and yet, despite it all, I'm sad to say, it will get snubbed at the Gaming Awards, and if it does, then you and I know, it was rigged. I can't wait for the DLC; it will smash more records to come. Hail To The Monkeyking
