review: 2022 TLDR: Don't buy. Lots of bugs that CA seem reluctant to fix. Plus pricing is a problem. Original review posted July 2022, see bottom of review:So its been almost a year since I wrote my short review. To answer any questions about performance, it has improved greatly, it's still not the best but it is miles better than it was for me at least.As for pricing I stand with the larger community. CA have tried to push a price hike to make up for their predicted losses whilst their other projects are in the works. That's not the communities issue and should not be expected to cover that predicted loss.IS THE GAME WORTH BUYING?? In short I feel it is not. TWW2 is a better game with far more polish at this time. Buy that and any DLC at a key site/on sale and you'll have a blast.Furthermore there has been very little in terms of bug fixing, including a long list of issues that really break any positives I could raise in this review. The following is a comment from the TW subreddit listing a few of the major issues that Dev leads seem to not be willing to fix a year after they were reported:"For me it feels pointless to even consider purchasing DLC when the base game is in a state like this.Most of these have been reported countless times and are often marked as a "Known Issue" for many months.To spread awareness in the playerbase/customerbase of the critical/core long-standing bugs & issues in Tww3, here are the ones I know of:-Campaign map AI utterly sucks, unable to put up a proper fight, build/upgrade up its armies or effectively develop its empires.-Diplomacy mechanics and diplomacy AI in all ways & forms is beyond awful, especially around vassals and alliances-AI is bugged/limited in its perception of nearby faction (AI is literally not aware what factions are nearby [no diplomatic contact]).-Unit pathing in manual battles, especially cities with construct-able barricades, is awful-Units refusing to path through broken city gates & destroyed city walls, instead insisting on using ladders to slowly climb up & exhaust themselves.-Cavalry/monsters getting models stuck, which pulls back the whole unit into death.-Units dropping/forgetting orders, even in the middle of pitched melee combat-Units not shooting because they are "moving fast" while being stationary-Units unable to shoot despite having clear Line Of Sight-Battle maps being broken for pathing and LOSight, especially on top of wall crenelations-Auto-resolve insists on damaging & killing Single-entity-monsters and especially artillery pieces, even when the player army outnumbers the enemy 5 to 1.-Auto-resolve still gives cities a ridiculous advantage, even when the player army outnumbers the enemy minor settlement garrison 5 to 1.-Certain units & lords/heroes fail to properly do their charging attack-Units (especially large ones) will randomly die when attacking certain walls/gates or being remotely in proximity of a collapsing wall (but nowhere near close enough for it to be a valid danger).-Units (even lords on foot) will randomly die when climbing ladders.-Some lords (Cathay dragons especially) just flat out fail to perform melee attacks for well over 10 seconds at a time.-AI does not understand nor properly react during the defence of siege battles, it will spread out its army across the map and be unable to fight a concentrated force.-AI charging his fastest units at the start of battle into certain death, especially lords/heroes like Belakor-AI clueless about properly using AOE magic & magic in general, which also makes anything "anti magic" rather useless-Hundreds of bugs related to skills, techs, items, unit abilities/stats, building mechanics etc etc.-Sometimes two characters (lords/heroes) will be placed on the exact same coordinates on the campaign map, permanently preventing them from movement and interaction.-Item qualities being nonsense, with common ones often being better than rare/special ones.-Lord/Hero traits either not working or straight up inferior compared to other available ones.-WOChaos revive Norsca faction mechanic intentionally broken by CA because they could not be bothered to properly fix it.-Manual battle AI will sometimes simply not activate, instead its units refuse to attack/defend/move. Seen most often in ambush battles and wood elf forest defensive battles.-Countless quests for lord items or unlocking special lords/heroes do not work properly-AI occasionally able to see your ambush/hidden armies from across immense distances & react to their positioning.-Skirmish mode on ranged units often failing to trigger/react, causing the ranged unit to just stand still-AI will often prioritize targeting, sabotaging or annoying the player even if it means certain doom for its faction.-Player units are utterly unable to finish off a broken leadership/fleeing unit, especially if it is a single entity like a foot lord.-Squads of large-sized ranged units (like salamander/razordon hunting packs) after finishing a move order will take forever to "wiggle around" before actually firing-Confederated lords for factions that have loyalty mechanics (skaven etc) will often start at zero loyalty.-Confederated lords will sometimes not be able to change their mounts.-Confederated Legendary lords will sometimes lack their immortality trait, meaning their next death is permanent.-Completely non-functional mechanic for automatic development of cities (everyone forgot this even exists in game because it never worked)-AI lacking any proper skill builds for most lords and heroes, which both makes them weaker and makes those lords useless for confederation.-Bugs related to construct-able objects on defensive maps, where units get stuck in barricades or cannot attack them-Fresh bugs like Bretonia damsels, wood elf ariel, Nakai unit recruitment etc etc.-Black Ark unique map army spawn positions AGAIN bugged, after it was fixed in late TWWH 2-Black Ark capability to offer recruitment to nearby Dark Elf armies bugs out when the Black Ark is garrisoned in a city.-AI will readily kill its own armies by trying to occupy ruins that have just been destroyed by extremely unfriendly (but not yet at war) factions which are still surrounding that location (from the previous turns razing).-AI will readily abandon its capital city and flee to some meaningless tier 1 settlement when facing an equal force (instead of fighting where its chance is best, inside the capitol).-Some sea objects (like islands/treasure/skull/carcass) will cause a guaranteed crash to desktop-AI will insist on besieging a weak settlement for 10 turns despite outnumbering & overpowering the garrison 5 to 1, and auto-resolve showing certain defeat for the players city.-Various lord/hero equip-able ancillaries that fail to work properly-Vampire Count/Coast UI for showing raise dead pool possibilities (near city bar UI) does not show units recruit-able from battle casualties.-Certain unique Cathay Caravan rewards are again inaccessible, despite being "fixed" in some previous patch (such as the vampire weapon).-There is a limited number of names for generic lords/heroes, and once they have all been used up the game notifications will start showing nonsense (mixing up factions, names & icons etc)."20 mins played with very poor performance. It's difficult to understand why they made changes to the engine when WH2 looked great. 3080ti and 7900k for reference. It's a shame because the game is unplayable on the campaign map with less than 10fps unless I am zoomed right in. FYI I did not pay full price for the game. Edit will likely follow if I get this working well enough. Cannot recommend at this time.

I've had a few framedrops from time to time, but the pure frustration of failure after failure against a boss sort of glazes over those few between technical frustrations. I'm loving it. To anyone who has never played a Souls game before... Make Elden Ring your first and you won't regret it!

review: If you are trying to measure this as strictly a standalone video game, and aren't buying this for the IP, it delivers on an 7-8 out of 10 experience fairly well. Nothing too crazy, no standout feature, no unique mechanics. It's a really polished and good looking 3rd person shooter which reminds you of what the bar once was for that genre. Think a 2010s game with 2024 graphics. Move from one area to the next shooting all enemies, rinse repeat. There is no progression of any kind barring the story. There is also no mid-game ability unlocks unlike games. What you see is what you get from mission 1 to the end minus some set piece levels with a flamethrower and a jetpack.For 40k fans though, which I am, this delivers on every promise as a space marine simulator. You now get to BE the little model you spent hours painting (with even the option to customize using actual games workshop paints in multiplayer), and allow yourself to be immersed in the frontline of those epic battles you imagine when you play tabletop. The voice acting is everything you expected. From over the top macho yelling, to fervent screams, and all in the name of the holy emperor.Folks may complain about the simplicity of the game, which is why I started with that point. Still, if you know your 40k lore, and know what to expect of space marines as a whole without dumb expectations (such as characterization from beings who only exist for war), this is all you you would ever need in a space marine game. It doesn't exceed expectations, but it does deliver on its promises.

review: 2022 Despite no official Ultrawide support and some performance issues that need smoothing out, this game is spectacular. But it may take a while to really see why. It does not hold your hand at all. It is brutal. I have struggled with Souls-like games because of this. However, Elden Ring may be the first one that I will finish. Simply because the open world design really improves the formula. If you're frustrated or stuck on a boss, go somewhere else. There is a ton to explore. Co op is great fun once you get used to how it works. Unfortunately, the servers aren't very stable and it can sometimes be laggy or disconnect.Even with these rough edges, the game is going to go down in history as one of the greatest RPGs. I just hope they'll give it the polish it deserves. The combat and variety of weapons and items is astounding. The world is massive and beautiful. Grab a friend or two and go have some fun.

review: Dear CS2 devs,You know what? I’ve finally figured it out. Those ‘cheaters’ we keep complaining about? They’re not cheaters; they’re just misunderstood game testers.Think about it:1. Wallhackers: They’re not seeing through walls; they’re just helping the map designers by pointing out weak spots in the architecture.2. Aimbot Users: They’re not auto-aiming; they’re simply showcasing the game’s advanced AI.3. Speed Hackers: They’re not breaking the sound barrier; they’re just auditioning for the next ‘Fast & Furious’ movie.4. ESP Users: They’re not psychic; they’re just predicting the future.5. Spinbotters: They’re not spinning like Beyblades; they’re just practicing their ballet moves.So, next time you encounter a ‘cheater,’ give them a virtual high-five. They’re the unsung heroes of CS2, pushing the boundaries of human capability.Yours sincerely,A fan who’s secretly jealous of their skills

review: Solid 8/10 with a side of issuesI played through all of campaign on hard and a bit of multiplayer, long story short: campaign is great, multi could be better. I'm gonna go over what problems I noticed so it may sound a bit negative, but overall I'm having a blast with the game, so if you want some Warhammer power fantasy, this is the gameCampaignI'll try to make this as technical as possible and [REDACT] any spoilersI liked the story, I loved the visuals and cherished the weapons. Not gonna talk much about story overall, characters are servicable, they are Astartes, so you don't expect highly emotional and expressive performance, they do a good job conveying their arcs, and the plot kept me engaged.Visuals are amazing. The arenas and setpieces as well as cutscenes are absoultely gorgeous, however there is a huge whiplash when pre-rendered cutscene cuts to in-game one, and there is one bizzare scene, where the squad lands on planet after orbital drop, during which they obviously they all have their helmets on. When they land there is a small dust cloud, and when it sets after half a second, they have all lost their hekmets, regardless of settings Again, don't wanna get too much into individual examples, cause story, I'll only say they peak in Act III for me, but that may be because I love Thousand Sons.About music... to be honest I didn't hear it most of the time (mixing is a bit weird), so not much to say here.In terms of guns all of them are distinct, the sound and feedback is great (tho there are minor issues, like altfire for underbarrel grenade launcher clipping sideways from hand), and the melee weapons and executions let you unleash absolute, glorious and cinematic carnage only made better with executions.That said, there are also issues. For campaign melee is the way to go, and for a good reason. But there are some tanky ranged enemies, which can be a pain to deal with. You see, most weapons seem to be designed for close- to mid-range combat (in multiplayer I saw a tooltip about most weapons damage decreasing with distance, don't know if it works in campaign too), so you have to either get closer to aforementioned enemies (if you can, they sometimes are on inaccessible ledges/platforms, or they just shoot you on approach), or shoot half your ammo into them, which might be problematic, because most of the time you are engaged in melee. You can use some long range guns, but then they are not very good at dealing with any other enemies. In my opinion adding a bit of stagger to shots and making you able to aim while running with side weapon would solve this a bit, and also make the small gun serve a purpose beside finishers.The second problem: these flying f***s. You'll know which ones. This is mostly extention of previous thing, except you can't get to melee range with them at all. They have powerful range attacks and they buff the hordes. So on one hand game tells you to focus them as sort of sergeants, but you can only do this with ranged weapons (and trust me, those guys soak up your ammo) while dodging their attacks AND managing chaff. Tbh they are manageable on their own, but when there's 2 or more, you don't even have that much time to shoot at them, because you have to dodge them (some cooldown shared between all of them would be nice, but then It'd look like they are getting in queue to attack, I don't know). I'm focusing on them so much, because fighting them is one of the very few moments, that feel tedious during the game.Also, play campaign on the controller if you can, it really isn't made for mouse and keyboard.MultiplayerI'll be a bit more critical here, but that may be, because from the beginning I wanted to play the Assault class, which I think suffers from some key problems in the mode.Remember earlier when I said melee is the way to go in campaign? Well here it's the complete opposite, I have to remind myself constantly to not use melee. During melee you are almost completely still, and time before swings is long enough enemies will just run away and shoot you, and it doesn't do that much damage, (which is weird IMO, in gameplay perspective powerful melee is the incentive to get close and take risks, here it just isn't worth it, on assault after slamming next to an enemy it is better to shoot them with a bolt pistol than use melee. And that is if they don't shoot you down on approach) This may be better with Bulwark, but I haven't played it, and they have a shield, so they at least won't be shot on approach."So ok, slamming down on enemies doesn't work, so I'll just try shooting them while hovering." Yeah, about that. Remember when I told you about tooltip saying damage falls with distance? Assault has a sidearm only, so you have to be close to hit your shots and deal meaningful damage. But you don't wanna be close, 'cause then other class with proper range option will just outdamage you (Emperor forbid you get too close to heavy). Long range rifles don't suffer from that, as their damage doesn't fall off, and they love a hovering immobile target on open space. This is a bit of a rant, but I feel like every other class has a way to deal with the disadvantage, I myself had some success with Assault, but mostly when enemy team either didn't look up or I could ambush some solo players, but if they correct for that, it's over. I just love jump packs and desperately want them to have a place, I'm biased here and I don't care. I think melee damage should be upped and some movement during melee added, in this state I think it is just underwhelming, and dueling a World Eater in PvP would be awesome.Also, left side cover is OP, your crosshair being on right side of your model makes peaking from right side of cover very good, and peaking from left side very bad, as enemies see you before you can see them. EA Battlefront solved it by allowing you to switch the side crosshair is on, but I don't know if it is possible here, so I'll just say it's something you have to keep in mind.However, let me reiterateThe game is awesome. The multi is fun. Contents of this review are critical in due to tendency to focus on the bad, me being salty about state of jump pack b0i and avoiding spoiling the game. I had a real blast playing through it and I'll be playing co-op with a friend soon, looking forward to playing this and any future content, great job devs.

review: 2022 I'm sorry for leaving a negative review, but I feel like this game is going to be the first step in a long, downward-spiralling road for FromSoft. People are playing this up as a masterpiece of FromSoft's when the issues are even more glaring than when people were screeching about DS2's "faults". I don't want this to become the Gold Standard for FromSoft (Pun Intended). My complaints have nothing to do with the open-world, and though I wish there were less carbon-copy bosses, I think it was fine to reuse them a little every now and then to fill out the sheer size of the place. Constant boss duos was miserable though, please stop doing that. godskin duo, magma wyrm and the falling star beast particularly were just awful bosses that i loathe to even remember. Nigh-undodgeable shockwaves that every large enemy constantly spams also really doesn't help. Long combos punctuated by the boss delaying for 13 college semesters, allowing you to write a dissertation and graduate summa ♥♥♥ laude with a doctorate's in patience before he decides to hit you for all your HP 3 times over in the span of a millisecond with FromSoft's patented "funny tracking TM" also leaves a bad taste in my mouth.The health and damage scaling in this game is unlivable. Everyone is doing the same 4 cookie-cutter meta builds just to survive the game, let alone do PvP. There is *no* room for build variety in this game, even with so many gosh-darn weapons and armor options. I had to ditch the mace partway through for the sword of night and flame because ordinary, mundane weapons just don't survive into the late game, except for maybe the same greatswords that have been equally-busted ever since DS1. Even with all the weapon upgrades, ordinary one-handers just fall off in damage and the way bosses execute combos with blinding speed or with stupidly-long delays, making windows to attack TINY, it's just not worth having a faster-swinging one-hander instead of a hard-hitting two-hander. I am sick of being buried as a sword-and-board build in every game.On top of that, dying in one hit to one attack in a boss' combo if you aren't actively dumping a third of your total levels in an NG into vigor is unacceptable. If there is a previous game that had this issue, then correct me, but I have never seen it be so bad in a FromSoft game before, especially with how this game packages bosses in a way that they fight like bosses from Sekiro while giving you Dark Souls III movement and controls. It is a recipe for disaster. I have never before now had the issue in a FromSoft game where when I kill a boss, I think "Thank God that's over" instead of "That was a cool fight with neat atmosphere." of course there a few black sheep bosses in every FromSoft game, but I have felt that consistently with every boss after Godrick (I personally liked his fight). It is a chore to fight bosses, especially when their health gets insurmountably high and one single mistake in a fight with them means instant death.People saying to upgrade summons kinda proves my point because the game is so unreasonable in terms of boss health and damage, unforgiving combos, punishing you for punishing enemies and etc. that you are forced to play a very specific way if you want to reasonably win. I don't like games that have only one way to be played, ESPECIALLY when one of their biggest consistent selling points is offering you a wide range of customization options. Also for God's sake please add a left-handed option, DS2 allowed me to beat the game left-handed and it drives me insane that a game touts customization but then refuses to have an option for people who make up 15% of the freaking population. That's gotta be enough to warrant a left-hand option if devs caved to the pressure of the 2 whole people banshee-wailing about replacing gender with body type.I've got a lot of time in all of the fromsoft games, DS 1-3, Sekiro, I've even cleared all the King's Field games except for the first one with a buddy. I wanted to love this game, it looked like a great co-op adventure, and I was willing to overlook the design decisions inspired by George R R Martin (The kinds of stories he writes just don't fit with FromSoft's history of design, in my opinion, George writes too much about sex and political intrigue, and the lore with Mohgwyn and the lover's spat between Radagon and whats-her-face just didn't feel like it belonged, in my opinion) but this game just really made me sad. I was repping this game all the way up to release.All in all, Bok the seamster was my one refuge in this game. I truly loved his character, he was delightful. That's it for my review.

review: Product received for free I recently had the pleasure of playing Black Myth Wukong, and I must say that it is truly a masterpiece. The game is a return to form for the action-adventure genre, with its fast-paced combat, intricate puzzles, and beautiful open world. I am grateful to the developers, Game Science, for bringing us such a high-quality game.One of the things that sets Black Myth Wukong apart from other games is its commitment to its vision. The game does not bend to the "woke agenda" as many other recent titles have in past years. Instead, it stays true to its roots and delivers an experience that is both entertaining and thought-provoking. The performance of Black Myth Wukong is also top-notch. Even on an older system, the game runs smoothly and looks stunning. I was able to run the game on max settings with no issues, which is a testament to the optimization work done by the developers.I will easily put 1000+ hours into this game. The world of Black Myth Wukong is so rich and detailed that I find myself lost in it for several hours at a time. The combat is also incredibly satisfying, with a wide range of weapons and abilities to choose from.In conclusion, Black Myth Wukong is a must-play for any fan of action-adventure games. It is a return to form for the genre, and a shining example of what games can be when developers are allowed to focus on creating a great experience, rather than pandering to a political agenda. I highly recommend checking it out on Steam.444

review: 2022 First game in a long time where you get exactly what you payed for and exactly what was advertised, no micro transactions, no battle pass, just a massive playground where the only one limiting your enjoyment and progression is you. The only thing as grand and marvelous as the world itself are the horrors attempting to keep you from your goals. Elden ring is as hard as you make it.Flaws are few and far between (a few npc quests were unfinished and guess what, its already been patched-looking at you coz!). I wish other game developers put as much love, care, and dedication to its games, its fans, and its employees as FromSoftware has. My advice, explore the world when you get stuck on a boss, go off the beaten path, strike first, strike hard, No mercy.

review: Basically, Once Human is like a mash up of State of Decay, Fallout 76, and The Division, with some Secret World influence.The game has its issues and a bit janky, but it's just so much fun filled with a lot of content. You've got main quests to follow, side quests that you can find in settlements and the open world, as well as side activities and public events. Main quests are fully voice acted, but side quests are mostly not. Combat is a bit too easy so far, but I haven't progressed that much compared to others. Enemy varieties are at least very robust, you'll always find new enemies as you progress through the map and story. Progression is very natural, and the game doesn't give you new gear at every opportunity, so each upgrade feels substantial. Besides combat, you also progress in the survival aspect to unlock more recipes and building materials. The game is very very generous for f2p lots of stuff that could've been paywalled are totally free in this. Most of the stuff from gears to building materials are free and unlockable via your skilltree. Inventory limit is very generous, and you can build as many storages as you wanted to. You can change appearance for free with a mirror, you can buy your item of choice directly instead of RNG with gacha, there's no premium perk or anything affecting gameplay, etc. Most of the negative reviews came from character creation limitations at launch. Like people couldn't delete theirs and move to another server, leave negative review, and left. The devs fixed it quite swiftly, but the damage is already done. There are also a lot of confusions about the seasons, even though not everything will be wiped. The devs posted a FAQ on it to explained it better, since lots of stuff can be carried over to the new season including gears, mats, cosmetic, and many others. Reviews are moving to positive side nowadays.

review: 2023 Elden Ring is a masterpiece, having mastered the art of showing without telling. From the get-go, Elden Ring doesn't impose any particular playstyle or route on you. You are completely free to do what you want to from the very start of the game. Where in previous titles you followed a general path to success, Elden Ring allows you multiple avenues and tools to navigate. The game hides many secrets, shortcuts, optional quests that develop the story, simultaneously make you rethink of a path you'll take. The game drew not just from the landscape of Soulsborne titles but also from the successful gameplay. The combat is challenging. No surprise there since it's FromSoftware game. The diversity of weapons and unique variety of enemies and bosses is astounding. This allowed it to be incredibly diverse in design. It's hard to choose a specific thing that makes the game so enjoyable, from the combat system and transportation to landscape, lore and storytelling. This game deserves nothing but praise from Soulsborne veterans and new players alike.

review: 2022 After patch 1.02.1This patch claims to address some performance issues. First of all, on my rig, the loading times became noticeably slower. Before, travelling to Sites of Lost Grace was almost instant, now it's very much not. I checked with my friend who played before and after - he also noticed the same.Furthermore, now I see stutter in some indoor ares, whereas before I had it mostly in the open-world areas. Outdoor areas are not working any better for me, too. Basically, I have worse experience than before the patch.Original reviewOK, the core of the game is brilliant. Sadly, I can't recommend it now (as of patch 1.02). I disregarded all the technical reviews where a lot of people complained about performance. Most of them didn't run the game on the highest end hardware, so I thought - hey, my specs are better, certainly my hardware will manage. No. This is definitely not subjective, not specific to only my software/hardware, as you can see all over the Internet - people with 20 series and 30 series are having the same problems as I am.I have STRIX RTX 3090 OC, i5-12600K, 32 gigs of DDR5 and WD Black SN850. I also have the latest video card drivers (the ones that explicitly mention Elden Ring support), the latest Windows 10 updates. The game manages to drop frames as low as 40 on pretty much any settings. I also have VRR monitor and it helps but not much - I can perceive frame drops without any FPS counters as it reflects on the gameplay. It's especially noticeable in the open-world areas and affects not only the visual fluidity but also the flow of the battle for me. Basically, not only the frame-rate drops make it harder to time a dodging roll just because the game suddenly stutters right during a boss attack, it also directly translate to input lag where pressing a button does not immediately result in a corresponding action. This game requires precision and the stutter cripples that. In "dungeons" (literal dungeons or areas behind the fog) it runs pretty well. For instance, I had no problems during the Margit fight and enjoyed it a lot. But fighting Tree Sentinel was so choppy, I just had to quit the game for good. Edit after playing more. Godrick the Grafted - which is not open-world and is not optional - fight was pretty awful performance-wise. Most of the time it was smooth but at random times, when I was very close to the boss and he would do some attack, the game would stutter. Only because of that it took me almost twice as long to defeat him.Now, on the same hardware I can run Dying Light 2 with all the ray-tracing effects on at 4K (with DLSS) with locked 60 FPS (well, it drops very, very rarely and I can see it only from the counter, it doesn't affect the actual gameplay). If I disable RT in that game, it runs so well, my PC is dead-silent (doesn't stress anything enough to engage fans to make them audible enough). This is mind-blowing. I mean, Elden Ring looks great but it doesn't have any of the interesting technical effects (I wouldn't call this game next-gen in any sense). It doesn't have photorealistic textures of Horizon Forbidden West, it doesn't have incredible shadows and illumination of Dying Light 2.Sadly, I can't refund this anymore: more than 2 hours played. Most of that time I spent trying out different video configurations and going to different areas of the game. Finally, I went on and bought the game on Xbox Series X. In performance mode it looks good (never scales up to 2160p in open-world, so it's not as clear on 4K display as the PC version) and runs perceptibly better (it does have FPS fluctuation but it doesn't effect the gameplay as much as it does on PC). Furthermore, XSX runs the game dead silent, while my PC is very audible in open-world areas, as the game makes the GPU card clock speed go to the maximum (frequencies are higher here when in Dying Light 2 with all the RT).Please, don't support this sort of attitude from the developer with your money, I regret that I did. This is the only new game that runs worse on my PC than on the current generation of consoles. It's beyond ridiculous. If you have the chance, go for the console version, if you don't, just wait for some patches.Some additional information for more clarity.GeForce driver 511.79 (has "Game Ready for Elden Ring" in the release notes)Things I've tried in the game settings.- Changing pretty much every setting from lowest to max- 2160p resolution- 1440p resolution - pretty much the same issues. I mean, on RTX 3090 - what the bloody hellNow, it's a D2D12 game, so it has direct access to low-level APIs, which means I had little hope in any of the suggestions found online would help, but it didn't take me too long to try, so I did:- The "High performance" thing in Graphics Settings of Windows- Unlimited "Shader Cache Size" in NVIDIA settings- Disabling "Microsoft Device Association Root Enumerator"None of the above resulted in a smooth experience. Basically, whatever is causing the stutter, would cause the stutter no matter what settings I had. I can run at 1080 with lowest settings and get stutters at exactly the same places as with 2160p and maximum settings. The game is not bottlenecked by any of my hardware, it's something wrong about the way the developers used D3D12, it seems.Out of curiosity, I've underpowered my GPU (from power target 100% to 80%), lowered GPU boost clock from 1860 MHz to 1674 MHz. Listen to this - no effect on the performance whatsoever! I mean, Elden Ring was actually utilizing the GPU to the max and stuttering. Now it works absolutely the same with significantly underpowered GPU.Now, as for comparison to XSX version, as I've played it a bit more now.- Initial loading time (continue from main menu) is twice as slow on Xbox Series X as on my PC! This is a bummer.- Looks like loading time on death are slightly better than the initial loading, but it's still much slower than that of PC.- In open-world the resolution is very noticeably lower than 2160p. Furtermore, the frame-rates are very eager to drop. My current go-to for testing is the very early Tree Sentinel fight. On PC it's jarringly bad. On XSX, in addition to having sub-4K resolution, the frame-rate here goes pretty low but it doesn't feel that bad with VRR. I actually almost killed the boss with the initial-level character on my first attempt on XSX. On PC I struggled to kill him even after gaining levels and downing Margit - only because of the major stutter.In conclusion, please don't give money to this kind of developer. I see already that the game sold very well on PC and it's sad. I mean, who forced the company to release the PC version without properly testing it? I am awfully sure, they were aware of the performance issues when they released it (otherwise they had zero testing, which is even worse). Why not release the console versions first and delay the PC version? Also, I scanned the Steam forums/reviews and there are still plenty of people claiming they have a smooth experience. At this point, I don't believe they do. By now I know some people tend not to pay attention. I've seen plenty of people - before current-gen consoles - claiming they are totally happy with 30 FPS in their games and saying that 60 does not improve the game. Now look - since the PS5 and XSX started having plenty of games supporting higher frame rates, the console crowd is loving it and complainign about new games running at 30 FPS. Now people are saying that anything higher than 60 is unnecessary and not even perceivable (yeah, right). In a couple of generation the consoles will have 120 FPS in plenty of games and people will enjoy that.

review: 2022 I put 1,700 hours into WH2 and I just can't get into 3. There are things that are great, like the improvements to diplomacy. But overall I find actually playing the game outright unpleasant. By far the biggest problem for me personally is the settlement battles, These are a slog, with endlessly respawning towers, narrow streets that the game's pathfinding is clearly not good enough to handle, AI that has no idea how to actually fight the battles, and battles that seem to drag on forever without much excitement. Turning minor settlement battles into siege battles has also had the effect of making field battles fairly rare, and the latter are far more satisfying to fight. This all has the effect of making me dread actually fighting battles in this game, and given my dislike of the campaign and its mechanics, this means there's little I'm actually enjoying while playing.The campaign took everything bad about the vortex campaign in 2 and doubled down on it all. There's very little freedom in how you approach the campaigns and everything is on a timer. The game penalizes you for expanding beyond a few small provinces. The chaos realms are tedious to get through, each with some gimmick that that just serves to slow the whole process down and which the AI can often bypass entirely. The survival battles at the end of each realm are like siege battles but somehow even longer and less fun, though mercifully you can autoresolve to skip them. Finally the army rosters are disappointing, especially for the demon factions who not only share units between them but who also have fewer units in the first place than the other factions. This compounds the problems with the battles by making them all feel very samey after a short while.As it is right now, I can't really recommend it. I've been lucky to avoid most of the bugs and performance issues other people are experiencing. But even when it's all working as it should, what's here just isn't very compelling. It feels very thin, repetitive, unpolished, and at its worst just straight up boring. Wait until immortal empires or a couple DLC packs drop. What's here right now just isn't worth your time or money. Though even then, this game has issues that go beyond not just having enough content, and I have doubts about the foundations of this game and its longterm quality I was not expecting to have.

review: I've never been so impressed by a game before and I've only beaten the first chapter which took me around 3.5 Hours with minimal sight seeing. Production value is otherworldly. Played the entirety of the souls franchise , and Nioh 2 is my favorite game of all time. Here's some of its strong points.- ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ the introduction sequence. If you've never seen gameplay, don't ruin it for yourself. You'll want to experience it firsthand.- The game doesnt focus on an uphill battle to reach bosses and the bosses are where the majority of effort was placed, which is how it should be. If you've played the souls series you might have been beaten into submission and forced to think that going back to the boss should be a miserable experience, but it shouldnt be and this game reflects it.- Bosses have incredibly dynamic and cinematic attack patterns, additionally the game has perfect dodges and rewards you for doing so. Not only with resource generation but also makes the combat that much cooler with the visual effects. Well played boss fights make you feel like a god.- The attacks / gameplay loop feels clunky at first but within the first 30min youll realize that you can gain the ability to continue a light attack chain even if you've dodged. this is important because the last attack of that combo chain is the only free move that can produce stagger. Whole system is extremely fluid, but youll be thinking at first if its just a 1 button game, it's not. It's just trying to ease you into it so don't worry.- Baked in , out of the gates, unlimited respecs with no punishment for build creativity. Sounds crazy how easy of a W this is and how long its taken a studio to deliver.- Game is absolutely stunning. Only other game that i can compare that has that 'wow factor' of visual fidelity is the Demon Souls remake, if you know you know.- I usually skip cinematics because i cba, but for Wukong i've sat through every one grinning. All in all i thought this level of production was dead in games. Very very very happy to see this game finally release and its not a pile of ♥♥♥♥. Worth picking up at full price.

review: 2023 To be honest, CS2's performance is completely below expectations. After such a long polishing process, the outcome is quite disappointing. Ignoring the existing bugs, which I assume will be fixed in future updates, the main issues for me are the strange feel of the weapons and odd feedback on headshots, giving a waxy sensation. The game's visuals, perhaps due to my unfamiliarity, seem tiring, with overly bright brightness. Despite expecting to adapt quickly to lower graphics settings as in CS:GO, it's evident that the experience lacks the satisfying feeling of the GO era. Lastly, it feels like CS2 is leaning towards CF, and while some added features like throwable monitoring aren't necessarily bad, they seem unnecessary, adding an extra layer that might be considered superfluous. Ultimately, having spent my entire university period with this game, I hope CS2 can carry the legacy and I trust Valve to refine it. We've seen the significant improvements brought by Source 2, and I believe CS2 has substantial untapped potential.

review: 2023 Product received for free Total War: Warhammer 3 is an achievement. They've taken three titles and mashed them into one giant game. It's impressive. It's almost unique and it "should" be their magnum opus. Unfortunately they've tripped at the last step and the game is unpolished to a degree that I struggled to recommend it. Should you play this game? Yes, but... be prepared for bugs, and AI issues and seeing the same battle maps again and again and again. You will get frustrated and annoyed with how the game treats you and how it can be a struggle to interact with it sometimes.At it's best Warhammer 3 and Immortal Empires is a visual and strategic feast and one of the best strategy games ever made. Unfortunately tarnished by a stubborn resistance to spending time on fixing bugs and introducing new content to make Warhammer 3 the best game it can be.It really feels like CA have washed their hands of Warhammer 3 and are phoning it in. It feels like they just can't be arsed anymore and that makes me sad.

review: Black Myth: Wukong Beat the game with multiple endings around 50hrs playtime,Excellent A-RPG game which borrowed heavily elements from Soulsborne but few points could be improved:+Amazing combat gameplay, skills unlockable with skill tree equivalent Sekiro game, with Spells, transformation, vessel, and spirits as you progress on early chapter.+Divided by chapter but you could backtrack the previous it even on next chapter+OSTs are amazing, Orchestrated wukong tv series version for this game+Moderate length cutscenes on bossfight is an eyecandy, which is something rare for A-RPG genre nowaday+Lore for each Characters written on details on Journal, prepare for TL;DR unless you're speedreader+Amazing storyline (I wished they had more chapter, felt too short for me 40-50hrs)-Boss rushes, prepare to fight 3-5 bosses within Hour (a bit excessive subjectively statement)-No Map to refer to (depends on your exploration memories), also few item missables throughout gameplay-Exploration and navigate terrain often blocked by invisible wall if you approached most of edge almost superficial exploration, even worse when enemies knocked you into below level and you had to back up (Invisible wall but enemies can pushed you, weird)-Missable item put out of reach unless using weird combo jump skill.-Minor clipping texture on empty part of map, also lighting glitch when transitioning between dark and outside cave when navigateCombat gameplay and Storyline are excellent, superb graphic with unreal engine but require latest rig in order to use Raytracing, but exploration a bit drawback and less fun if not handholding with invisible wall. 8.5/10

review: 2022 I never liked the concept of souls-like game, i mean it's just not for me since i don't like the idea of punishing yourself with high difficulty of gameplay. But then i tried this game knowing that i would probably refund it with my lack of skills. I was wrong.The one that hooked me the most is the exploration and story. The problem with most open world games is some 'empty' areas that could be disappointing to explore. This is not the case with this game, every corner of the map has a 'surprise' for you to get.It rewards you with every curiosity you tried to do, but it also comes with a price. I can say now, this is the first fromsoftware game that i deeply in love with, and would recommend it to everyone.

review: 2022 I guess I didn't review this on completion, but since then I've gone back and completed Dark Souls: Remastered, Dark Souls III (almost lol got burnt out), and started Dark Souls II, and I can satisfyingly say, this is an exceptional addition to the series. Great map, lots of unique and interesting weapons, armours, weapon arts, and so much more.As far as boss fights, main bosses are pretty cool, fun to fight for sure, most of the filler bosses are mediocre, and just feel like normal enemies with a bloated hp pool (which 8 times out of 10, they are just normal enemies with a bloated hp pool lmao)overall 93/100 game, I had a lot of fun, and I could absolutely tell this was the mastering of years of games and content, gg wpEdit: I have now finished DSR, DSII: SOTFS, and DSIII with 100% achievements on Steam, completed Demon's Souls on the PS5, and have amassed well over 1000 hours total with the Souls series. I can easily say this absolute masterpiece is the reason I took the time and gathered the motivation to complete such tasks.This series is absolutely phenomenal and has become one of the most important things to my person and interests. I love you Dark Souls, for changing my perspective on gaming forever.

review: 2022 Elden Ring is a phenomenal game but it's hard to look over the hurdles I had to overcome in order to fully enjoy this game.Gameplay: The initial 20 hours of this game were tolerable at best. The first area is too dense for it's own good, filled with the most amount of copy and paste catacombs/caves, containing useless loot 90% of the time. I felt as if my thorough exploration wasn't appropriately rewarded. While this problem persisted throughout my 80 hour play through, it became far less egregious as the filler content became far and few between with an increase in more intricate world and level design.The game truly opens up after you conquer the first legacy dungeon. Suddenly, most of the gear actually becomes useful, and it was refreshing to finally swap weapons 20 hours into the game. This gameplay loop of exploring, killing bosses and looting never got tiresome, because the game gives plenty of opportunities for experimentation and trying new things. Despite the abundance of reused enemies, it was still fun to tackle them with a different strategy.Story: Like every other souls game, the devs didn't bother to explicitly tell me what was going on so I responded by not bothering to pay any attention to the story. The cutscenes and voice acting were cool though.Difficulty: Enemies are extremely aggressive and fast, making these some of the most brutal battles in the series. However, the late games bosses are the definition of artificial difficulty.Overall 9/10

review: 2022 It's finally in a spot where I can confidently say; Yea, go for it. There's still some annoying performance bugs lurking around such as random temporary freezes and slow downs and the like, but no more crashes. Thankfully they're not really annoying enough, or frequent enough, to be bothersome or hamper my enjoyment of the game anymore.Old review (everything not striked out is still relevant as of IE release. I also added some points from post IE release):Honestly a phenomenal game through and through. If you enjoyed the previous TWWH games then you're sure to enjoy this one as well, same as me. However there's too many issues right now for me to really recommend it.Patch 1.1.0: The alt-tab crashing issue ("detailed" below) seems to be fixed but there's still infrequent crashes usually while loading or just after a load finishes. As well as several strange, random, slow downs.One black screen on alt-tab, which forced me to quit through Task Manager, then two crashes on the following alt-tabs. All under the course of my first three hours. Maybe hold off until this stuff is ironed out.EDIT: I've had four more crashes in the following two hours..and one was when I opened TW:Access from the in-game promt. Good times. mini-edit: Also several more crashes in the chaos realms while just interactive with the objective..EDIT: (Tested in the first two weeks of release and again shortly after IE release) Multiplayer is absolutely shafted right now. Chugs every 2 seconds, then freezes for a solid 5-20 seconds, repeat. It's so awful. There's also this lag of about 2 seconds when clicking on anything. It's pointless to do coop right now. It was perfect in TWWH2 with the same people I tried TWWH3 with. (apparently not everyone has this issue so...keep that in mind). mini-edit: So turns out that verifying game files actually mostly fixed this....but introduced new issues by crashing either our games when we would initiate certain battles. mini-edit-2: the issues are back as of IE release <3EDIT: I've kept having issue like the above, as well as other bugs scaling from passable to incredibly annoying and plenty of performance issues after the first 5 hours of my original review. Thankfully CA knows about these afaik and they'll hopefully be ironed out before too long.

review: 2022 As of now, I must admit that I am fairly disappointed with the game which makes me a lil' sad, since I love Total War Games and especially WH2.The hype was real and WH3 was THAT ONE GAME in years which I pre-ordered / bought full price without a second thought. My complaints arn't based on performance stuff, technical issues, etc.My complaints are based on the gameplay which I find in comparison to WH2 tedious and boring. When you start a campaing in WH2 it's like a rapidly growing snowball. Within the first 50 turns you secure a homebase, you can have one army of semi-elite troops and 1 to 2 basic armies and epic army clashes happen all the time. With WH3 everything is different.- you have much less money to play with (at least with Kislev and Chaos factions, havn't tried others yet). You can barely finance one army with your first one province and second province doesn't really change that.- the movement points of lords and heros don't scale well with the huge map, it takes ages to get around. worst experience is with Slaneesh, it takes sooooo long just to cross the lands 'cause regions are so spread out- it takes ages until your armies are replenished, even basic troops need something like 6 turns to geht from 25% to 100%- AI is often running around avoiding combat. even if I debuff there movement speed it happens very often, that I cannot catch them. but I can't ignore them either, cause then they lay siege on my provinces. - Auto Calc is broken atm. especially with sieges of smaller regions. you need to play every little battle cause otherwise you loose way too many tropps (and remember my complaint with replenishment rates). I don't want to fight small fights, which I win 100%, it gets boring. I only want to fight the epic battles.- Realm of Chaos stuff is way to tedious for my taste. I mean it's a great idea and I wish I liked it more. Worst is Tzeentch Realm where your just walking around some kind of labyrinth trying to find the correct portal. booooring. And at the same time your homeland is insecure and you can't do other ♥♥♥♥ because remember, you can only really fund a single army and that army is away in a Chaos Realm.- even if your're a person who likes the Realms of Chaos I bet after the 2nd, third or fifth time, you're done with it as well. There should be a way to de-activate it or whatever. It's like the Maelstrom in WH2, after a while you don't wanna do these kind of scripted stuff anylonger- some of the Chaos factions mechanics don't really work so well, looking at you Slaneesh and Tzeentch. At first they sound super cool, but then you realize they don't really have the impact you expected (example I never saw a Tzeentch provoked revolt being successfull. usually they spawn to close to the settlements. So AI has an easy time crushing them with a lord and just a few troops, cause settlement troops are within reach and help clear the stack before it grows to 20)These are the major issues I am having with the game right now. There are countless other small things that add up to that. What I like is the love for the details regarding map, factions and faction diversity. And to be fair, when WH1 and 2 launched, they were not polished either. So I am confident that CA will be fast in adressing all the technical and gameplay issues within the next few month, allowing me to enjoy the game more then I do now.Thank you for reading

review: 2023 The game itself is fine enough. If you've ever heard or played a Total War game, then more of the same.Let's talk about this developer. They have a niche audience, with one type of game. You'd think they know this, and you'd be mostly correct. The recent responses to the community about valid criticisms was met with...one of the worst responses we have seen from the leaders of a company. That is saying a lot in 2023, the year that companies really let it be known they HATE selling products to their customers. I have bought Total War games for a long time, twenty three years, now that I looked it up. Since Shogun: Total War to modern times, I have bought and played most of their entries. That stops today. Creative Assembly has decided to weigh in on the growing list of companies that really just don't want your money, your support, and most importantly, your time. They won't get any more of those from me ever again.

review: Warhammer 40K come to life. The environment are beautiful and haunting. The gunplay is fun and melee combat fantastic -- more than that they found a way to marry the two together, which is very hard to do. They've managed to encourage you to feel like a bad ass Space Marine and more so play like one. Lighting/FX/Sound animation, sight lines to amazing things happening in the distance. The single player campaign is a epic ride that keeps offering up epic moment after epic moment. I'm so impressed. The fact that you can play the single player campaign with a couple of friends is amazing. Multiplayer I've only dipped into a little, but can't wait to do more.

review: 2022 Immortal Empires update:Finally Immortal Empires is here and the map is glorious! Every region got in nothing is cut!That means the mortal empires map is no longer squished and it adds the WH 3 map on top of it without cutting anything. Its the total campaign experience.The performance is better then expected but since WH 3 reworked graphics it still needs more recources then WH 2.The Warriors of Chaos rework is awesome. The faction is finally very fun and very diffrent from other factions though you need the new DLC for the full experience but its worth it.On top of that Belakor got added as a FREE faction as well.The patch brought factions up to WH 3 standarts though there are some balance issues looking at you infinite healing cap Zombies ;)The game has bugs but way less then you expect. I havent had anything major so the BETA tag should not discourage you from enjoying the game.The game has 2 major issues though and thats AI passiveness on higher difficultys and confederations beeing way too hard for both the player and the AI. Its confirmed that they will adress confederations and AI will surely be fixed as well.WH 3 is very fun and while it still needs some work it looks like its going in the right direction. If it continues like this it will end up as the ultimate combined experience fans crave.

review: 2023 I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 18 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just, watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. loaded into the game, made my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories

review: This is by far the best representation for Space Marines and to a larger extent, 40k in a game that I have ever played. Gameplay might take a while to get used to, but once you get the hang out it, flows quite well. The sound is very good as well. From bolter rounds flying out to crashing down onto a bunch of enemies, there is a very satisfying crunch to all of it. Story is honestly, an average Ultramarines story. But! If viewed as a standalone sci-fi story, then this is a decent story that will leave you wanting to learn more. Overall I would give this a 9 out of 10 and would highly recommend to fans of Warhammer, Sci-fi, or just action games in general.

review: Space Marine 2... it’s everything and nothing, a swirling mess of blood, steel, and madness! You are Titus, but who’s Titus, really? A hero? A pawn? A construct of war?! Doesn’t matter—the moment you grip that chainsword, the galaxy whispers, then screams.The Tyranids crawl—oh god, they crawl! Everywhere, like ants in your brain, gnawing at sanity. I swear, I heard one in my room last night. The combat’s so real it reaches out, grabs you by the throat—are you playing the game or is the game playing you? Endless slashes, endless roars, and then the bolter, the gunfire in rhythm with your heartbeat. BOOM BOOM BOOM! It's not just the controller vibrating, it's your soul shaking apart.The world is too large, but too small. Why does it feel so big, but I can’t move far? Walls, invisible, but I know they're there, I can feel them breathing down my neck. Titus talks, but did I hear him say something else just now? “For the Emperor,” he says, but sometimes I hear “Run.”There’s beauty in it too, in the destruction, in the chaos... but that beauty is suffocating, it traps you, makes you want more. One more Tyranid. One more battle. Just one more... Until you forget how long you’ve been in the war. Hours? Days? Did I sleep last night?Space Marine 2 is loud, violent, a fever dream of warhammer glory... or maybe it's just a trap, pulling us deeper into the madness, into the abyss. Are we Titus? Are we lost? I don’t know. I don’t want to know. I just want to keep playing... 10/10

review: 2023 I should mention I adore this game, but I can't recommend anyone buy it. The dev has been straight up pretending it's DLC is oil and pricing it accordingly. It's ridiculous to charge 25 dollars for DLC that doesn't even add much. Remember the Ikit Claw DLC from Warhammer 2? That was 9.99. And it rocked. It felt worth it. You got 2 new unique lords and subfactions to play with. Now what? We get 2-3 lords for 25 dollars? How about instead of releasing more predatory-priced DLC, you balance your game? Give a tiny amount of a ♥♥♥♥ about the people who give you money. There is a free mod that balances ♥♥♥♥ better then any update CA makes for this ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ game. It's ridiculous. They've been making essentially the same game since TW:WH1, and they still haven't figured out how to balance certain factions. On top of that, the constant price hikes show they give zero ♥♥♥♥♥ about their players. People who bought BOTH the previous games and this one are pissed off and buying ♥♥♥♥ from key-sellers because of how ♥♥♥♥♥♥ they're being treated. This review would swap over to a thumbs up really fast if they actually stopped constantly increasing the price of their DLC. I bet a lot of others would too. I'm gonna add to this review how hopelessly broken the balance is. I almost wish they would STOP UPDATING it because the fan made mod that overhauls each and every single lord is so good, but goes out of date each time the devs at CA make another broken useless update that fixes nothing.

review: After clearing a stage 4.5 hours in I feel like there is a big "something" missing from the combat.It's quite disappointing as the rest of the game looks and feels excellent, from the story telling choices and the UI's.But combat being the main aspect of the game I can't really bring myself to play any further than the Electric Frog Boss very early in the second Chapter.I feel like there is no impact when striking my opponents, the peons are very weak and die too quickly to get that satisfying final hit during the combo but it feels like a waste to use a fully charged heavy to quickly dispatch them with that satisfying smack.When fighting a boss I feel like I'm a flea using CQC on an Ox. I'm relying on my cool-downs to rinse and repeat every single time and after a few too many encounters I can feel the repetitive nature scratching away at my brain.I really wanted to like this game as it IS beautiful the illustrations, the effort in the descriptions of the Yaoguai is insane.I don't know if this is me being picky... but the very obvious invisible walls seems a tad lazy for the quality we see in many areas. I feel like this is an example of "Being a mile wide but an inch deep" when it comes to their level design. UE5 is beautiful but it isn't a crutch.I know it's not an open world game but I'd like some creativity when it comes to blocking my path.Pros:- Storytelling- Stunning illustrations- Unintrusive UI (for how many mechanics are at play)Cons:- Flat feeling combat- Early repetitive nature

review: I absolutely recommend this game. I am not a big fan of free to play games. I do however like survival games. I have played most of the big ones. This game is probably the most user-friendly one I've ever played. On top of that even being a free-to-play game It is super dense with content and doesn't have ads playing in your face 24/7 and doesn't feel like you have to pay to advance. I have a decent amount of hours in the game and this feels like one of the most for the people games I play since hell divers. On top of that for this game having just came out the level of thought and content in the game is mindful. A lot of the annoying Misess in other games tend to not exist in this one. Things like having to individually loot items off the ground, not being able to easily see leave around, having to rebuild the same base over and over and over again from scratch. The game feels extremely well thought out and seems like it is built by players. They also implement a live service system that somehow doesn't suck. They make it rewarding and fun to come back to the game week after week. They also do it in such a way that you're worried about messing out. You can always come back 2 weeks late and collect all the rewards from the prior week. The level of respect that is shown to the player in this game shows how little other game show. They also respect grind in that they give you bonuses between certain times for those who work a little bit more. They also have enough content that you don't feel like you're ever stuck and having to grind. There is always something to be unlocked explored or to do. I would have been satisfied spending $40 on this game. There's no way I would believe it was free. If you're wondering why this game has a mixed review and gets so much hate this is why. In the TOS it is stated that your ID may have to be linked to the game. If you are in the Western world this is not a problem for you you are exempt. However in countries such as China that is a requirement by law. This TOS is to address that. However a lot of Western readers of the TOS have obviously flagged this as a problem. However they have an acknowledged that they are exempt from the problem. So that is a resulted in this game getting a massive review bomb that it just blatantly does not deserve.

review: 2022 Most disappointing game since Cyberpunk.Being a big fan of Total War games in general and Total War: Warhammer II in particular, I REALLY expected to love this game. However, this broken betrayal of a product is not worth your time or money in its present state.Indiana Jones and the Race for the Soul FragmentsThe rifts to Chaos realms opening up COULD have been a very interesting addition to the game. However, the way the game works is that you win the game by entering these rifts and collecting soul fragments. This could be an interesting sort of dynamic story challenge if not for the fact that EVERY OTHER FACTION can do the same thing meaning that even when you are playing in single-player, the whole game just turns into race for the soul fragments VERY EARLY in the campaign.I'm not the only one who noticed this. Angry Joe noted that this "killed" the campaign in his review (skip to 27:25) YouTube™ Video: Total War: Warhammer III - Angry Review Views: 655,778 💥Patreon ► https://www.patreon.com/AngryJoeShow 🔥YT Join ► https://youtube.com/angryjoeshow/join 👕Our New Merch!► https://www.roguesapparel.com AngryJoe gets in touch with his Inner Demon to rule the... and Mandalore Gaming noted that this basically makes winning any other way almost impossible. YouTube™ Video: Total War Warhammer 3 Review Views: 3,466,500 Total War Warhammer 3 has arrived in a month absolutely stacked for games. This review covers anything and everything that came to mind so prepare for trees and menus. What's worse, the rifts can only be entered by your faction leader which means that winning the game is all about creating min-maxed doomstacks and using them to play what is basically a bad MOBA rather than coordinating armies and managing kingdoms as you would in say, an actual TOTAL WAR game. Broken StoryThis game has one of those awful stories that was clearly put together by people who worked separately and hated each other. For instance, the story clearly states that only a certain person can enter the realms of chaos to do the thing needed to win the game but literally EVERY AI faction actually does that the first chance they get. Characterization is also off. For instance, Kostaltyn is a well-played, sympathetic character in cutscenes but he's an ugly, deranged blowhard on the campaign map. Terrible performance and DenuvoKeep tolerating bugs and so will the devs, This is the most unreliable Total War game I have played so far with all of the issues you might expect including broken AI that can't move properly, constant de-synchs in multiplayer, and of course, crashes that frequently cause you to lose your progress after a tough battle...It's impossible to tell how many of these problems are linked to the use of Denuvo but it certainly isn't helping.ConclusionThis is the first Total War game for which I have posted a negative review and I have been playing the series since the early 2000s. This game made me sad...

review: 2023 What is the current status of TWW III 3.0? Quite simple to describe. Shiny on the outside and rotten to the core. But you have to take a closer look to see it. Which, apparently, not many are capable of.To be honest, I have no problem with the price. For me it's about something completely different.For more than 5 months, the numerous bugs haven't really changed to the better at all. In just under 5 hours with the new patch, I've seen the same problems, even worsened in some cases.... . Especially in sieges. ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥... . Still invisible enemies, the AI with completely stupid deployment in cities! Ungrim Ironfists Journeys End still doesn't work. Waaagh! of orc AI factions in battles still not working. Pathfinding in sieges still incredibly bad. STILL! Also, it seems the performance on the campaign map has worsened again. Movement of the vampirates seems buggy, also the rites of the vampirates. Frigg, I don't want to list everything... .The DLC looks really good and great, but if you put more resources into new stuff like the Intel thing instead of fixing the old and known problems/bugs, then I don't see the point in buying the DLC. In fact, I won't be buying any more DLC until something improves in terms of the endless bugs. In my case, the new stuff is not relevant right now.I encourage everyone here to reconsider their buying habits. For God's sake, stop pre-ordering everything! That's one of the reasons why the quality is getting worse every year.CA, get your act together or this will be an even bigger ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ than it already is. As long as nothing changes, I will not recommend the game.Edit:As of today, 08/17/2023, nothing has fundamentally changed. And ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, today's official statement from CA... . I guess I'll wait for the new patch 4.0 before updating the review.

review: 2022 Great game, definitely worth the money in playtime. Huge world to explore and hundreds of hours of playtime.Is it a great game? yes. Is it a masterpiece? totally no, most people that say so, they're either still on the honeymoon phase or haven't left the starting zone yet.The game has lots of content to explore. The world building, level design and lore is some of the best in souls series. Gorgeous views, super complex domains to get lost into. Lots of secrets and surprises when exploring the open world. At least on the first couple of areas.Sadly the quality dips a bit after around half the game, and the open world areas start to feel more generic fields with stuff thrown around.This applies as well to the boss design. The quality dips down on the second half of the game, and there are notable design problems. First, the lack of originality, since every boss has basically the same moveset: every boss has a big AoE that oneshots, every boss throws puddles of poison/dots around the arena, every boss has a grab attack that oneshots, every boss has an anime multihitting unrollable dash that you need to run away from... Also if you're one of those people who disliked DS2 for the ganks, I got bad news for you, cause again past the midpoint of the game, they just started doing ctr+c ctrl+v to most of the early game bosses, so you'll have to face 2 or 3 at the same time.Then some other boss fights are straight up bugged or clunky. From bosses too big to fit the room where you are fighting, making them glitch through the walls or the floor, to bosses that you fight in the open world that can get bugged with height changes on the terrain, making them glitch up and down from rocks or cliffs.If you are interested in pvp, other than duels, there isn't much going on. Covenants are gone, and invasions only work if the host is playing coop. And as of the day of the review, there are several instant kill cheap builds ruining the scene that hopefully will get patched.Personally I'd give it an 8/10. Is a great game, specially if you want to get into souls games, since the open world design allows to take it easy and progress somewhere else if you get stuck, plus there are several new systems added to make the game more accessible. This also sadly lowered the quality of boss fights, which is the biggest appeal for me.

review: I have been following Black Myth Wukong since its first footage reveal during development... I watched summaries and adaptations of Journey to The West and this game by far is the most artistic, and beautiful tributes to the Mythology. Story: A little confusing unless you have knowledge on Wukong's lore, but the animations inbetween chapter clears were wonderful, the True Ending was really neat but it requires alot of things to be done such as beating all secret bosses and doing certain quests.Gameplay: It's not bad, there's alot of cool moves you can do but the boss quality is variable, sometimes there are annoying bosses, sometimes there are fun and challenging ones. Looking up guides is helpful to understand where to go or what to build. Versatile upgrade systems.Graphics: I need not say anything else, Unreal Engine 5 displayed wonderfully, vibrant and realistic graphics I couldn't be happier with the performance on my 3080.Music: Top notch, very heartfelt in certain moments.Overall 8.5/10I would give it a better score if the boss quality was consistent.

review: 2022 One of the few modern AAA games you can buy at full price and get a huge amount of hours per dollar paid.This is Dark Souls ramped up. The world is bigger, the weapons are crazier, the bosses have more BS moves then before and there is just sooooo much to find in the game. Don't go thinking this will be an easier game straight away. It IS easier but not for any mechanical or gameplay reason. It's easier because you can just bypass most roadblocks and go exploring, find more materials and weapons and get levels much easier then previous Souls games. The actual fights will still be challenging and require you to spend time learning boss attack patterns.The game design overall is still "hard but fair" but be aware that by "fair" they now mean you can utilise just as much broken stuff as the enemies can, and not utilising it will often hamstring yourself.Overall it's still not that super tight DS1 design, but it's so, so much larger in scale that it's it's own beast and an absolutely amazing game to play.

review: 2022 Elden Ring on PC is a technical mess and I can't recommend it. The world, Bosses, and Core Gameplay look great but the issues are simply unacceptable for this age of gaming. A 60FPS cap in 2022 is ridiculous, And unfortunately even a stable 60 seems unachievable. With a Ryzen 5900x and a RTX 2080 I encountered FPS Drops, Stuttering, and a Unresponsive and frustrating to navigate menu. For some reason it Shows PlayStation Controller inputs with both my Xbox Controller and M&K. Don't bother Playing on M&K as it has some insane delay and acceleration that makes it unplayable. Also less important but should be mentioned: co-op in this game is awful. The need to use fingers to group up and then regroup whenever you do bosses or enter a dungeon. Progression in co-op is only for the host, so you have to run it for every party member in your group to not be locked out. I know this system is in Dark Souls but this is a new IP and having advertised co-op i expected a much better system. It's really disappointing it hasn't improved after all these years.

review: 2023 It's really disheartening to see the direction CA has been taking with their DLC as of late. Even with the extra work that was put in campaign features, Shadows of Change feels like a DLC that should have cost $15 instead of $25 given the amount of units it adds. The price could have been justified if they at least added more units and generic lords/heroes, but even though the content that's currently in the DLC is amazing, the price is just incredibly overbearing. I deeply hope that CA will look at the community outcry as something to learn from. If Thrones of Decay will be $25 as well, then I hope they at least go the extra mile in creating more units and generic lord/heroes to make it worth the price.

review: 2023 I've been a huge fan of the Total War series ever since Shogun Total War. When they made the first Warhammer Total War I was over the moon which was followed by an improved Warhammer Total War 2.Sadly Warhammer Total War 3 does not live up to the previous installments. The launch was a failure filled with bugs, and the new campaign took the worst of the mechanics from the previous game and made them worse (Timed rush for souls).The siege rework was not an improvement. The adding of deployable towers and walls in the settlement doesnt add to the game, but rather subtracts. Whilst the enemy is marching on your gates, and you should be setting up your own men, you are busy either trying to locate the towers or walls to build or just ignoring the mechanic in it's entirety. The AI has changed from game 2 and again to the worse. It feels more dumb and passive in some regards, and also some things are just ludicrous - Enemy moving an army all the way across the map through enemy territory, just to assault you.Futhermore the prices of the new DLC are not worth the money they ask for them. There has been a huge price increase which just signals greed.All in all - avoid buying this and stick with the previous installments. If you are very interested in it, wait for it to go on sale

review: Product received for free Honestly fantastic game that was worth the wait.The game is visually fantastic and the level design is breath taking. Massive backgrounds while going through a linear level with huge battles going on. Genuinely amazing.Story was great with quite a twist at the end that feels like it's going to lead into some DLC.The customization is pretty great! Being able to customize your Space Marine while being in a known chapter or/also creating your very own chapter makes it incredibly solid.Multiplayer is genuinely fun. There's no limit to the class you play. Can't wait to see what more they plan to add to it.Now for the only negativity I have for this game. The Operations. They're alright, it's simply another campaign that goes along with the main campaign and adds some context here and there and it's pretty fun. If you're into immersion though and think you're your own space marine, tough luck. You're still seen as an Ultramarine. The actual main downside with Operations in my opinion is locking classes if a player has chosen it first. I see no reason to do this when other games like Darktide allow it. I get that these classes are apparently actual characters in the Ultramarine chapter, but it's such an irritating block. You'll have two brothers who want to be the same class and neither of them wish to change, forcing a third player to just stand and wait until one decides to finally leave the lobby. It's infuriating.It's an amazing game that brings a huge win for the Warhammer 40,000 franchise and I really hope it has a good life with future content. I'm incredibly looking forward to the horde mode.
