review: Space Marine 2 is a long-awaited, much-hoped-for sequel to the first Space Marine game. You play as <REDACTED> (jk it's freaking Titus like that wasn't obvious enough) who starts off using Primaris-styled equipment as a regular first-born marine. Hmm. Can't say that's particularly lore accurate, but whatever, it's Titus so that's cool. Unfortunately he's no Mark Strong this time, can't blame him after everything that happened. Be aware. I tried playing the campaign missions on Angel of Death difficulty. This will color my breakdown below.The 'nids are, as expected, annoying ass space bugs that swarm you faster than skaven do at a Warpstone rave party, and they're fairly dangerous. In fact, each of them individually might not seem like a problem but start throwing in 3 or so hormagaunts and you'll start having more stab wounds than a mugging victim in London. The termagaunts, those little annoying freaking shooty bugs, appear to not wield regular fleshborers, since the damn things flash green like miniature rapid-fire venom cannons. If you don't know what a venom cannon is, I'll explain it further down below in the Warrior section.All of these swarm mechanics overwhelming you through sheer numbers is really pronounced. I started having to take engagements carefully and seriously right from the get-go. You can't regenerate any health from simple executions this time either, you need to have taken damage recently (a la Bloodborne) and this makes Titus not only feel like tissue paper, but unable to recover easily. You need to use the medical stims and those are far and few in between, so they definitely took the 'its too easy' critique about the first game too much to heart. Titus will find these enemies dangerous and annoying in equal measure as a result, so don't go thinking you can charge into the jaws of hell and not get tarpitted harder than Abbadon facing a 50 block of guardsmen backed up by a Commissar Lord. They are just as fearless as said guardsmen and unlike Abbadon, Titus can't ♥♥♥♥ out like 10 attacks in a single round of combat, so you better hope you're good at parrying. Note that while parrying or dodging or attacking, you are more or less animation locked. You can't cancel easily, and this honestly makes you feel a lot more sluggish than Captain Titus, who is now obviously the best version of Titus there was. This means you have to thin their numbers at range, hopefully reducing the 'gaunt variants down to less than 3 by the time the Warrior rushes you down.Let's talk about Warriors. Warriors are the big 'nids that have that annoying ass whip, that annoying ass paired boneswords, that really annoying ass devourer, or that annoying ass venom cannon (that long snout thing).The Whip is not too bad in a 1 on 1, just make sure to either stay clear of it while wiping out the small forms or...dunno, charge in and beat it to death before it can get really annoying. When it does that lash combo attack, it's very hard to parry so you're better off just trying to keep your distance and shooting it down.The twin boneswords is just tanky. That's it.The devourer is basically a rapid-fire fleshborer, and the Warrior who uses it is the most irritating PoS you will ever encounter. It will constantly skate away to the backline to pepper you with clusters of projectiles and it adds up a lot of damage very fast. Snipe this ♥♥♥♥♥♥ as soon as possible. If you try to close in melee, it will sometimes unload every shot into you at point-blank range and you can die from this.The last one, the venom cannon wielder, is the sniper variant. A venom cannon is like a biological railgun except instead of shooting a metal projectile it shoots this venomous acidic crystal that is superheated by the electrical discharge (yes, this is how it works in lore) and is launched at high speed to penetrate vehicles...or something. It didn't really work against real vehicles, but it definitely works against MEQ (shorthand for 'marine equivalent') like Titus. You will get a warning in the form of a sickly green laser tracking you and you can dodge the shot quite easily with good timing. The real problem is when one of them shows up and you are fighting a swarm or two and their Warrior melee cousins all at the same time, which is when things get nasty. Even then, its particular attacks are not hard to avoid, so either trust in your mobility or kill them off first, your choice.There's more bug variants and their stupid tactics but I'm tired of talking about bugs so let's talk about weapons.Gunplay and melee aren't mutually exclusive, it retains the general fluidity of the first game and you can swap between the two styles of combat very fast. Pistols are actually useful, they take their own slot and can help offset some disadvantages of your primary, while also serving as a way to perform kill shots on parried enemies.Bolters. Holy Emperor the bolters. There are so many bolter variants, and some of them being very cross purposes with their actual function to the point it makes you wonder who needs this many variants. They are all lifted from the Primaris arsenal, and you get the whole freaking line of them (except Assault Bolters). Bolt carbines, heavy bolt pistols, auto bolt rifles, you name it they have it. In fact, I would argue that there are simply too many bolters. In the first game most of the same roles were replicated by unique weapons, such as the plasma gun, the lascannon, the vengeance launcher, and so on. Now you get...bolters.Some of them are effective and some are not, but all of them are only average on Angel of Death difficulty so I didn't really find them to be that unique. What stood out were the non-bolter weapons, the Plasma Incinerator and the Melta Rifle.The Plasma Incinerator is like a cross between the regular plasma gun and a very small plasma cannon, and it performs well enough in that role. It's plasma and it hurts.The Melta Rifle is basically just like the melta gun from the first game. Tight AOE cone that does more damage the closer to the center of the aiming circle you get, huge shotgun blast that can melt anything.There's some other stuff like the Las Fusil, which is basically just a lascannon if they scaled it down and in-game it's basically a Charge Rifle from Titanfall. It's still a good weapon, but they clearly learned their lesson from the first game where the lascannon's instant shot could utterly destroy an unfortunate enemy's face at close range.Melee weapons unfortunately all feel a little samey. The chainsword is effective but it only swings in tight arcs and relies on a charge attack combo to stun enemies, which is extremely awkward compared to the first game where your stun/charge attack was another key altogether. This means it is very easy to start a chainsword combo then get hit for your trouble because you have no way of interrupting your enemy.The power sword is a little more forgiving as it has actual stances that emphasize AOE or single target combat. It still has the issue of not being able to stagger big creatures reliably, or having a charge attack combo that matters, but it is reliable enough with its large sweeping attacks to actually outperform the chainsword on a regular basis.The thunder hammer took a big hit from last game. It is just as sluggish and slow despite Titus' better augmentations, but is weaker. You can put a lot of hurt on enemies, but you have too many gaps open that leave you unable to defend yourself properly. Compare that to the first game, where the hammer's instant-kill damage and reliable stun combo can AOE wipe out hordes of daemons or whatever. It's very weak in this game.The power fist staggers most enemies. Good enough.So Is game gud? yes. Get. Play. Keel bug.

review: It's a good game sir. Only real issues I have with it are that Tyranids just can't compete with the Space Marine 1 Orks, and that single player almost feels like an afterthought when you look at all of the multiplayer only stuff like classes, perk systems, better weapon selections, armor customization. There are certain sections while playing the highest difficulty solo in campaign that I felt were definitely designed around having multiple players and the AI just wasn't cutting it so I had to get creative on just surviving. Not a gigantic issue and I'm sure playing the highest difficulty wasn't helping me.Something I do want to mention is that the story is not as interesting as it could have been. Space Marine 1 had an ending that could have a much more interesting followup. Instead a more interesting short story was put in White Dwarf to kind of get Titus to Space Marine 2s starting point, and Boltgun was created to cover the other half of the story stuff they needed to put in place.Otherwise the game is generally an improvement over 1.

review: 2022 My advice at this point is to wait for the immortal empires release to see if this is worth playing.Pros-Relatively fun units, lords and faction mechanics.-The graphics are about what you would expect from a sequelCons-The campaign just fails on so many levels. 1) The actual campaign mechanics don't feel rewarding and are oftentimes more punishing as you progress. Realm of Chaos is just a torturous bore that doesn't really offer any reward and particularly in Tzeentch's realm its a crap shoot of racing the enemy AI and hoping you randomly choose the correct portal path. 2) Random warp portals. This is just monumentally frustrating and with limited armies can often lead to positions of you just hoping you've lucked out in having the appropriate forces in the right position if the AI goes for any kind of jankiness. Expect to waste an army or several dedicated to sitting in your important economic/production territories. This is particularly necessary if the AI decides to build up a few stacks before bumrushing a city.- City battles. The AI does not interact well with cities offense or defense. Units defending points that you aren't attacking or wandering units back and forth at random between points. -The AI in general is just... bad. Easily abuseable at all difficulties on the battle map and there are many times you will have to abuse it because the AI cheat stats at higher difficulties makes trying to play with basic tactics moot. i.e. spears/anti-large infantry don't really do anything to units they supposedly counter. Melee infantry is basically useless in the face of more ranged units. Regular cavalry units are generally not good. So basically the strat tends to wind down to hide the army exposing a single fast moving unit usually a lord and break the AI by luring out a unit at a time to pound into the dust via mass range spam/magic. (khorne has some leeway with the free armies they can spam out for disposable melee but yeah ultimately not a good time)-The campaign AI is just bad with the cheats to compete with the player. Also anti-player bias is hilarious watching the AI ignore 6 full stacks of another AI they are at war with to come barreling down at you the player's out of the way undefended minor settlement while they get utterly ransacked and it doesn't mean anything because the AI isn't playing under any of the constraints that the player has to deal with on the campaign map beyond movement.

review: I know I going to be on the unpopular side here, but I just want anyone thinking of buying the game to get the chance to see a review that tells it like it is.I have never played a 40k game before, so without any passion or connection to the universe, I only can judge this game off of what it provides to me. This game is... not horrible, but it certainly isn't great either.The campaign is short. Very short by today's standards. Like 6 hours, short. I finished in one sitting after work. Now, this isn't horrible, but it since the campaign is arguably the best part of the game, it being that short doesn't really bode well. Fun combat, great visuals, and an entertaining story... that you'll be done with at the end of the day. Multiplayer is, well, not as great. The operations are interesting at best, monotonous at worst. You essentially get to play through a co-op mission of the campaign as the "B-team" that you would always order to go do stuff. It provides an interesting and new perspective, but is certainly nothing great. The "endless" war multiplayer, I.E the PvP, is fun for about, well, 2 days. Afterwards you realize you only have 3 game modes on 3 maps. It gets repetitive instantly. Now I know what you're gonna say, "oh but there will be updates, and look at the roadmap!". My brother, you are paying $60 at least for a 6 hour campaign and lackluster multiplayer that you will get tired of in two days.

review: 2013 Initially I was very hesitant about this game; it seemed very risky to make so many fundamental changes to a formula that was barely changed through Counter-Strike: Source and Condition Zero. However, seeing how much Valve has listened and continues to listen the community, and how quickly they make changes in both the short and long term, it has completely restored my faith in the game. Counter-Strike: Global Offensive is incredibly fun and feature-rich, with plenty to do for both casual and competitive players. On top of this, there is also plenty of ways to promote and support eSports, which is a much-needed and fundamental step in reinvigorating Counter-Strike in the competitive gaming scene. However, the most important thing with this game is that the community is incredibly nice and friendly - and with a game as difficult and intense as Counter-Strike, it's extremely welcoming. Good stuff!

review: 2022 Sieges and battles: Sieges are full of choke points, little open space. Any units can scale the walls, they aren't equippable and the units don’t have to drag the ladders to the walls. Battles more generally are more simple than other Total War titles. Feels like they took some of the challenge out of the game, in order to make it appeal to a wider audience. Graphics: This is the best aspect in my opinion, the game looks gorgeous. Map(s): With the immortal empires patch you get the entire world, which is great.Lore: I feel the game could tell the story a bit more, in Three Kingdoms, there are cut-scenes when you reach certain goals, you get an idea and feel for the events around you. Heroes: Sometimes the heroes can get a bit jarring. I wish there where a “records mode” type of option, not because I don´t like heroes, rather because it would bee more challenging in certain situations to have a generals retinue. The Daemon Prince for example is kinda weak and tends to be useless. Balthasar Gelt can almost alone defeat armies with his magic artillery spells. Another solution would be to rebalanced the heroes.Unit size: I also find the unit sizes of the different units quite small, this is important since this game is supposed to be an fantasy epic, but with tiny battles. Well, what about fixing this with mods? You can, there are mods in the workshop that increase the unit size, however, the AI tends to get stuck at the gate and exhibit odd and often devastating (for them) behavior. While, in three kingdoms I use similar mods and have massive battles with a full stack army almost reaching 10,000 warriors. The AI in Three Kingdoms doesn’t exhibit the same issues.AI: I personally find the AI a bit lackluster compared to other titles, though not as catastrophic as Thrones of Britannia. It’s not bad, just not cutting it for an experienced player like me. I also tend to be against increasing the difficulty to legendary, due to the AI getting modifier boosts, thus I prefer to use a AI mod that makes the AI smarter instead. Found that Hecleas AI Mod works well. Diplomacy: I find that the diplomatic options to interact with other factions are a bit limited. Currently you can sway someone with giving them money, but you can’t for example trade ancillaries like in Three Kingdoms. Sometimes I might be just short of getting that trade agreement, but not enough money to to finish the deal, while sitting on a pile of old/useless ancillaries that I could do away with.Linux: Works great, I personally have used it with Proton and played with my friends.SummaryHmm, it’s a good total war game in my view, but not a great one. The game looks just gorgeous and is pure eye-candy, the fantasy setting is also interesting. If you really love fantasy, stuff like Lord of the Rings etc. then you might find the full price justified, but if Fantasy is cool, but not your absolute favorite thing then, I would personally recommend waiting for a -50% sale and then get it.

review: 2023 I was in a Tomb Kings Mortal Empires campaign on WHII when I bought Warhammer III, I started the same campaign to compare. The difference was instantly noticeable, especially in terms of the diplomacy system. The improvements are so significant that going back to WHII felt like a step backward. The diplomacy in WHIII actually makes sense now!Outposts makes complete sense in the context of the game, whether you're building them yourself or getting them from allies. It adds an extra layer to the strategy and alliances.The Quality of Life improvements are also great. Things like auto-building and an easier level-up system have made the gameplay smoother. However, there's still no auto level-up feature, which is a shame. But hey, Middenheim wasn't built in a day, right?The game world is also significantly larger this time around, which is a massive plus. There's so much more to explore and conquer, adding to the depth and longevity of the game.That being said, the campaign map leaves much to be desired in terms of performance. It's not as big of a deal as some people make it out to be, but it's certainly not a highlight of the game. While the map struggles to maintain 40-50 FPS, the battles are a different story altogether. The battles run at a crisp 60+ FPS, making each clash a visually stunning spectacle.So far I had one crash during my battle, one that stopped happening once I disabled 'Control by AI' for my alliance army.In the grand scheme of things, Warhammer III is a huge step forward for the franchise. Despite its flaws, it's a game that I wholeheartedly recommend and I would now finally recommend as the only game to get for a newbie out of the 3 in the series. I'd wait for a discount, since the price is steep, but it does offer a ton of content. Looking forward to the future updates and improvements!EDIT: turns out there is auto-level up feature in the top left corner of each character!

review: 2022 The game has teething issues for sure, but any game of this size is going to. The first patch smoothed a lot of the corners and the roadmap demonstrated that they're in this for the long haul of improvements and content drops as things go on. In terms of its improvements over TWW1 and 2, the game has mostly shown improvement, a few things have stayed more or less the same, and there's been a couple of declines, so overall good. The map design is improved, the campaign map is one of the largest and most interesting in the series, the unit variance is nice, there are very distinct factions and races, diplomacy is better, battles are better, magic is better, and there's generally more content in here at launch than either of the two predecessor games. The main campaign is iffy in terms of its goals and how you get there, but ultimately plays out fine. It has a lot of potential to be better but hard to say how far out they'll develop the ideas. The RoC has a lot better potential than (and to me is more enjoyable than) the Vortex campaign of game 2. If the RoC Campaign doesn't get hugely expanded it's still mostly fine, just isn't sure how to get its ideas together. The combined map will ultimately be good, so like game 2 I'll be able to go between them to keep it fresh. One of the best improvements this game has is in the Co-op campaign aspects. FINALLY we can do 3+ player campaigns and it is glorious fun. Co-op campaigns have been vastly improved, the way turns work and alliances etc. is far more nuanced and interesting than it was. Playing co-op often improves an average campaign, but the Realms of Chaos main campaign almost feels like it was designed with co-op in mind, as it makes the race for souls more interesting and factions can work to cover each other as others do the race. The race itself is usually over within 150 turns, and from there you have a giant map to conquer so it's not a big deal really and we've been having a lot of fun with it. I've seen people disappointed over how long it's going to take for the combined map between the games to come out but anyone with a basic grasp of reality can see that this is a monumental sized project so of course it's going to take time for things to happen. That's kinda just physics at play really, but as with the other two games things will come out as they do and the game will only get better. WH2 at the end of its cycle was an amazing game and WH3 will likely be no different. Overall, I recommend the game and I'm looking forward to what's coming later this year.

review: 2022 FIrst of all: i still play this game casually from time to time, it's good but still, the release was a total mess and now that IE (Beta) dropped out a few days ago, there's a bit more content and there is still so much potential.If you play co-op campaign with more than one other friend, very often from round 30-35 there will be a desync error and this can break the entire campaign for you and your friends. No previous save file or restart of the game will help you. It's like there's that one specific timer triggering the desync error and you can't play beyond that point. This happens in RoC and IE. In other words, you have to restart but as long as 3 people play this campaign, this will happen almost every time. If you play with just one more friend it's ok and the error won't occur.Gameplay is sometimes very tedious. Factionwide, all Units suffer some sort of Alzheimers and they will forget orders in a battle. Sometimes they stop midway, sometimes the won't even react in the first place. In this case, you will have to molest your mouse with rapid clicks and start frantically checking the whole map for your units if all of the commands reached their brain or got lost in their track and start sending out commands again. Rince and repeat... until you develope some sort of paranoia. Damn those foul chaos gods of bad programming.They changed the minor settlement fights so every battle will be a siege (with walls to climb, gates to destroy an points to take) and it's just time consuming. Auto-resolve is still a joke even when you have a good and experienced army, so enjoy fight from now on manually. Imagine playing past round 100 and still expanding your faction. Of all Battles, 80% will be at settlements and therefor a siege battle. Optimization of this game could be better. There were some tweaks but with the release of IE, frame drops and long loading screens are more common again.The current price tag is too damn high for a game that is still in Beta and probably will be for the next 1-2 years, so I don't recommend it in it's current state. If you're about to get your first total war: warhammer, don't let it be this one. There are still two others to chose from._______________________________________________________________________Update after the "Shadows of Change" Update:it still ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ sucks. CA ♥♥♥♥♥♥ up and there is nothing they can do to fix it or redeem themselves. They ♥♥♥♥♥♥ up. DLC pricing is them spitting in your face after the horrendous launch because "inflation". DON'T BUY. This game has nothing to do with pleasing it's fans, it's only about the money and nothing else. review: 2022 Okay, I think it's okay to say now. Having gotten through those first two patches, (1.1 & 1.2) the game is now safe to recommend. Initially, I think CA had botched it. The patches that addressed the build to reduce portals (1.1) and the auto-resolve (1.2) have saved this game. It is now in a place where I can more enjoy the mechanics and tempo of the game.Yes, once the big map that joins the three games AND all the races together will be what we've all been waiting for. But for now, getting familiar with the new and very different races and race mechanics, the minor settlement rework, the constant threat of the portal race that means you can still lose even when steamrolling. Yeah, this is a good game and I'm enjoying it.Would I have said that a month or so ago? Well, let's just say there's a reason I've waited before submitting a review.Long live the DLC team that are the real geniuses that breath life and longevity to this epic game

review: 2022 Reason for PurchaseI love the entire Souls Like series. I started with Bloodborne earlier and then moved on to Dark Souls. After that I played Demon Souls which I thought was fantastic. And then I heard that ''From Software'' is releasing a new part which should even have an open world. At first I was a bit skeptical because I didn't know how ''From Software'' would deal with this new idea but I could say... They exceeded all my expectations.GraphicThe graphics are truly stunning. Everything is designed in such detail. Both the world (which I still haven't fully explored) as well as the NPS's, enemies, bosses and much more. What I want to say is that I can't see the graph difference between Low and Maximum. From that point of view, I mainly play on Low so that everything runs smoothly.Game MechanicsI haven't played a Souls Like part on PC before. However, I have to say that it was implemented very well. And besides, I love this game more than any other Souls Like parts and for a reason. There is a separate jump button! In the other parts it was or is quite annoying and sometimes hectic when you have to press several buttons at the same time.Positive and negativeFrom my point of view, there is nothing negative anymore. Previously, for me, the negative was that it came to such frequent game crashes. Now there is nothing negative for me anymore. The price of Elden Ring does justice to the game in everything. So ''From Software'' has really surpassed itself.FutureI'm going to play Elden Ring for a very long time, as I haven't fully explored the Big World yet. My goal will be to reach the maximum ''99'' for all stats. I also hope that there will be DLC expansions at some point. In addition, I would like to see a few more achievements because I now have them all.Game RatingGraphic: 10☆ <3Game Mechanics: 9☆Spielspaß: 10☆Recommendation of the gameElden Ring is in my opinion a good game to get in because you can get a lot of support from the incantations of ghosts. If you add another player, the boss gets even more life than usual, which is why I would prefer the ghosts. So anyone looking for a ''Heavy Game'' with stunning graphics is absolutely in the right place with this game.

review: 1440p, RTX 3080 user here.The game is awesome, and it runs very well if tweaked correctly - below are my suggestions.First of all, download DLSS Swapper, as the game is using an older DLSS version you can improve on it by swapping to the latest version (3.7.2).About the graphic settings, these are the 2 most demanding ones:Shadows > going from VERY HIGH to HIGH I was able to gain 8-10 fps on averageGlobal Illumination > same as shadows, going from VERY HIGH to HIGH I was able to gain 10 fps on averageSo with only these two settings I went from 55 to 75 fps.All the other settings give minor fps returns.My suggested settings for people with an rtx 3080 / 3070ti are:- DLSS at 80%- Textures on Cinematic- Shadow on High- Global Illumination on High- Everything else on very high (you can crank up Hair Quality and Vegetation Quality to Cinematic with just a 2-3 fps loss)The only downside for me at the moment is the lack of a FOV slider.I'm very sensitive to narrow FOV but so far I was able to play without getting sick, will update this review if things change.

review: What we have here is a weird mixture of various other games with some unique ideas thrown in. The problem is that it all feels really just slapped together. Your character isn't overly responsive and feels like he weighs 8 tons while you're moving around. The general combat is okay though, its nothing amazing but its a very solid foundation that they can build on.The building is terrible, its just bad. The basics are all there but the building itself is uncomfortable and very very finicky. They at least have a free move building camera and that does help but the snapping is troublesome and not intuitive. Having to get the exact right angle on something like a roof panel is cumbersome and it took me about three times as long to just get a roof over my head than it should have.There is a decent variety of things to build and you've got pretty free range to build as you see fit. However the build radius itself, at least where I was at in the progression was very small so I felt very limited. Placing things works well enough, easy enough to rotate things around and there is a decent tech tree to work through.Resource gathering is more or less painless and its what you would expect. Hack at trees to get wood, go find copper or whatever else to mine. Nothing felt like it took too long to amass if you just spend a few minutes doing it. I do like the crafting queue feature at each of the crafting stations, frees you up to go do whatever while you wait for it to do its thing and nothing took all that long to complete.The skills system itself... is a bit confusing. There is this whole what I am guessing is like a pokemon type of system. You can obtain new little critters or deviants I guess they call them to put in your backpack and each has its own skills to use. I only found 2 during my time, the butterfly and a little jelly guy. The butterfly was just some extra dps that would do it when you toss it at something, the jelly guy could turn into cover or act as defense. I honestly forgot I had them most of the time. I got to around level 12 and only fought one thing that put up any sort of resistance. The first rift boss, big thing with some basic mechanics that I was able to match make into..It wasn't hard or anything, had some bare minimum mechanics and it fell overEvery other enemy I came across wasn't a threat.. like at all. The general zombie like guys you see everywhere all are dead before they even know you're there. Couple of weird big cat things with a tarp over their head? They also die easily all you need to do is back pedal while you fight them and they can't hit you. the AI is on a level of PS2 games. Although i genuinely think some PS2 games had better enemy AI than this gameCouple of other larger creatures, couldn't even tell you what they do because they all just fell over dead with nothing but the basic pistol you get shortly after the tutorial. Most enemies seem to have 2 or 3 different attacks that they just spam at random and very slow.What bothered me the most was that you could just see everyone's structures.. everywhere.. you can't go anywhere without seeing someone's little base or forward respawn point. Its just urban sprawl on an active server.. stuff built everywhere and it just was goofy to see. I mean I get it, its going to happen in a game where you can build if its a public server but this was just obscene. Anyone who had played something like old school starwars galaxies know what Im talking about.. houses.. houses as far as the eye can see concentrated around the major areas. It just.. feel bad and sorta takes me out of the whole thing. There is no point in finding a cool place to build or even a unique base design because there is just stuff everywhere and everyone's place looks more or less the same. Im sure that gets better in the later areas but its just a pretty big turn off for me.Graphically, its pretty good. No real complaints. Game looks and ran great. Its not the best visually but in the genre its in, its a good contender for good visuals. No real visual glitches or anything weird happening. Very solid on that front.I might give it another go later, but I think I saw everything I needed to see. It just didn't grab me, For a free game? Seems okay, but there is just too much competition out there that do what they're trying to do but better. Since its free, id say pick it up if your curious, but don't expect something that is just gonna draw you in and make you want to keep going. I lost stream really quickly on it and its a real shame, had alot of potential but alas. Not for me.

review: This game has overshadowed all my expectations of a strategy game.It is expensive yes! If you want all the dlcs. But would also say it's worth it more or less. I never got to play warhammer 1-2 because of bad pc, but now I'm even more excited to skip the other 2 parts and see everything in immortal empires.What i like ++ Graphics (i play on ultra), it's amazing how detailed a strategy game can be these days+ Choice of units is so big that i already forget which unit it was xD+ The diplomatic system has everything you need, it's not as complex as a crusader king, but it shouldn't and doesn't need to be because the game is focused on the battles.+ I find the build upgrade system complex, just like the skill system of the heroes.+ It runs so smoothly and i haven't had 1 bug so far.+ Game gets supported by devs, and watch community feedback rarely nowdays.What i not like so much -(but that is complaining on a high level)- Dlc price is a bit to high 25 euro why not make it 20 :)- Story i mean it give a story mode and much lore, but its not so cool like the amazing trailers total war makes. I would love it if they make in future a campain with such effort of cutscenes.My wishes for future alot more dlcs! or Warhammer IV for Immortal Empires II

review: 2023 Orginal review:The game has enormous potential and lets you play a lot of completely different factions with unique playstyles, but unfortunately there are simply too many issues for me to be able to recommend it. It launched in a pretty sorry state and hasn't really gotten better since then. There are a lot of bugs, some of them still present since launch. The AI poses no challenge whatsoever, since it wastes a lot of time running around just outside of your attack range and it loves to sack or raze your weakest settlements, rather than going after cities that actually matter. Units in battle tend to circle each other forever instead of attacking, the list goes on. And while the game is in dire need of improvements and bugfixes, all it's getting right now is absurdly overpriced DLC, alongside a lackluster free patch that seems to break at least as many things as it fixes.Update:While the AI issues persist (though the game did get harder thanks to the AI getting huge bonuses in lieu of being actually taught how to play), the game has begun getting regular free fixes and new features, to the point where I'm comfortable saying that it's a great experience, and chances are it's going to get even better.

review: Listen, I might get flak for this, but this isn't a $60 title. The campaign is 6 missions, the post campaign PvE is 6 missions. You could knock this out in a couple days, maybe an afternoon if you're really good or have friends, and if you don't much care for PvP (which has 3 maps and 3 modes in total) that is all of the content you have aside from what they're going to dripfeed over several seasons, and I just don't really consider that acceptable for the price point, unless you REALLY like the combat system, which I personally am not particularly in love with. This could've been like $40 and I'd have less issue with the barebones amount of content here. I'm not saying it couldn't improve over the seasons, but if you want to buy it at the time of writing, I think you'd be at risk for being disappointed like myself.

review: 2018 I was very young when I first got to know Counter-Strike back in the early days of Counter-Strike 1.5.It was in an Internet-Café during Holidays where I even got to play the game for the first time. Some years later some friends from the area were playing CS 1.6 and thats where I joined the Steam and Counterstrike-Community on January 8th, 2006. We formed a team, trained about two years and climbed up the ladder of our local CS-League here in Switzerland.However, due to insufficient capacity (private life) of some members and a lack of Morale we split up.I've seen Counter-Strike in all of its states from 1.5 on, 1.6, Condition Zero, Source, I even had my hands on the old mod called "CS Promod" where people tried to get the gameplay from 1.6 with the graphics of Source. Which was something I really liked.After a long break I decided to reroll in CS:GO and check out how the game had evolved. It took a while but the more I played and did matchmakings (good mm's ^^) the more I wanted to set foot in E-Sports again. CS:GO is the perfect balance between the gameplay of 1.6 and the graphics of source (while its not source, definitely and luckily not.), to most efficient CS players ive talked to graphics dont matter and it explains why many Pro's do play with low resolutions and stuff like that because it reminds them of the good ol' days (from what i've read).Though it still has its harsh and sometimes frustrating learning-curve, it is worth the effort because if you truly stick to it and learn about it each time you play and try to learn from your mistakes the better you get. Since all those years i've tried out almost all other game titles in the FPS genre, nothing could ever stand up against the simplicity and competitiveness of Counter-Strike for me. If you're looking for a great team-experience (which you first need to create or join) in where every man counts, every round counts and has a big community involved with tournaments and stuff, this game is for you.However if you're looking for a realistic shooter that compares guns 1:1 like in real life, with bulletdrop and things like that, this game is definitely not for you.I hope my shared thoughts on the game where helpful and gave you a bit of insight whether you want to join our community. Best RegardsKnight

review: 2022 I have not played since launch day, (other than 5 mins to check if it ran better with a new GPU, it did. Still significantly worse performance than WH2) and will not play again at least until Immortal Empires, and maybe not then. The fact that the lukewarm reception to the Vortex campaign should have been an indication to seek to emulate the mortal empires experience, not double down on the vortex type mechanics.Any game that requires mods to have a good gameplay experience does not deserve a positive review. I appreciate that the modding community has been so quick to make so many good changes, but does not change the fact the modding community should be for creativity, rather than fixing blatant issues in the game itself.Somewhat ironically, the tutorial campaign was one of the best tutorials I've ever seen in a game. I didn't need it to teach me, but I play ever TW tutorial anyway, and this was definitely the best one. But, the tutorial campaign is a one-off thing, and does not compensate for the lacking of the main campaign.For newcomers to Total warhammer, WH3 is likely completely fine. But for those who played many, many hours of WH2, it falls flat, well short of what it should've been. Based an what we've seen so far, the game should've been kept in development for at least another year. A poor showing.

review: Has it's flaws and fair share of bugs. CA have been on a downer but looking good with their new DLC Thrones of Decay. Overall it's so fun and very mod friendly so you can have so much replay ability. Few things need to be fixed such as AI and siege battles. DLC's can be overwhelming and expensive for first time players, but there is also plenty of freeLC to try. Id recommend trying a few races, see what you like then consider buying the DLC for that race. My favorite and most valuable DLC in my opinion is anything to do with the Lizardmen, Forge of the Chaos Dwarfs, Beastmen and Prophet and the Warlock. There is other good DLC but i find these offer the most... Overall the game could be better and has more potential, and i love it even for it's flaws. Really take advantage of mods once you learn the game as it's basically free DLC and quality of life that CA hasn't added.

review: 9 / 10 For me, this is one of the best games in history! This game is proof that a project doesn't need battle passes, paid cosmetics, or in-game shops to be successful. This is probably one of the most passionate games released in the past decade; the creativity and attention to detail are absolutely insane.Starting with one of the top selling points: the graphics. The graphics are absolutely absurd; Unreal Engine 5 is the best-looking engine on the market as of 2024, and this game makes very good use of it. Yes, using UE5 means that the game sometimes has some high optimization problems, although they're minor compared to other UE5 titles released recently.The combat and enemy variety in this game are simply absurd. Elden Ring is an amazing game, and even a game of that caliber still struggles to keep up with this game variety-wise. Every single enemy in this game is unique and original, with highly detailed models and movesets; there's only a very small amount of reused assets among the enemies and bosses. Some of the boss fights are creative enough to make your jaw drop. The game has a lot of different skills and movesets, transformations, and items to make the combat feel unique in each encounter. Although I gotta admit that I wish it had more spells.The biggest problem with this game compared to other action games is definitely the limitations on exploration of the map. This game has an absurd amount of invisible walls and limitations on the terrain blocking exploration, sometimes even on clear paths that look like they'd be explorable otherwise. And this is the reason i'm not giving this game a 10/10.The soundtrack fits very well with the theme of the game; the OSTs are magical and epic. Each chapter has an animation at the end with different art styles and music, with different stories and meanings. For a person who is not used to the main theme portrayed in this game, it's a magical experience for sure...I would definitely recommend this game to anyone interested in Chinese folklore and mythology. The story is amazing; I was totally unfamiliar with anything related to this theme, and after playing it, I gotta say I really want to know more about the general theme and meaning behind these stories.I genuinely believe this game will be remembered throughout the years as one of the most passionate and successful projects in gaming history.

review: 2022 I'm not going into depth here because other people have articulated their grievances more fluently than I could express at the moment.Campaign is garbage. I wish there was an option to play it without the Chaos Realms, similar to how you could pick to omit Chaos invasions in the first and second game. Somehow the campaign and sieges are worse than earlier entries. I would pick Eye of the storm over this and that is saying something.Every "improvement" they advertised has been a net negative compared to other games, and somehow old bugs are even worse. strategy doesn't really mean much when units hardly respond to your inputs.Units look great, but a lot of the visual presentation has taken a hit. I get wanting to add more color to the game, but a lot of the models just look too cartoony, especially the trees as many people have already pointed out. I think the second game hit a nice balance, while this third entry seems to have gone a bit overboard.My patience has never been more tested playing this game than any other TotalWar game.

review: 2022 Elden Ring, O Elden Ring. You already know why it's so good, but like Dark Souls, the game is a sad tale of two halves. The first half is absolutely brilliant; an open world experience that encourages a lot of exploration. It really took me back to the good old days of playing video games with a sense of wonder and curiosity. The second half of the game however, is really all the bad things about the new Souls games. Unbalanced and unfun, just stacking "le epic" boss after boss and making them difficult for the sake of difficult. Gone are the memorable bosses of True King Allant and Gwyn, but now replaced with bosses who have to be a "spectacle" and "action-orientated" for the sake of the fanbase. Still a great game though and way better than any of the drivel of open world games out there.-- Score: [9/10] --

review: Game looks fantastic and campagne is fun. Difficulty GAP in PvE is too big. From 2nd to 3rd difficulty it'S just stupid. With all premade you can die your way there, but for anything else it's just like play Helldivers 2 in their worst. Game provides you with epic melee stuff, but whole meta of 3rd and 4th difficulty is "DON'T EVER GO IN MELEE" so all these mighty space marines are rolling like potatopes on the ground, while being folowed by vawes and vawes enemies imune to light melee attacks and while sm burning you with flamer/ shooting you with bolters and you can do JACK SH*T.Melee chars except bulwark are useless, you will do better with 2 chars with melta and one that kills specials on range.Whole relience on dodge/perry/gunstrike changes this game from horde shooter into frustrating and very unfair rolly polly simulator.I have no interest in PvP so i can't judge that.Locking fun behind the hard wall is stupid decission and i'm very sad that i can't get my money back.

review: 2022 Alright so first of all this, despite all the backlash, isn't an awful game. I'd much rather play release tww 3 than the original, that being said it's not a good game either. CA has pulled the classic 2020s razzle dazzle of releasing a game unfinished and patching it until the backlash stops. With every update until now the game has improved overall even if the bugs kept multiplying. Without a doubt the biggest improvement (at least for me) so far has been the implementation of the mod support which allowed the community to fill negative space in the design and improve the balancing overall. This may change soon though as the immortals empire patch looms over the horizon. Now would I recommend people to buy this game before IE drops? No. That doesn't mean it's not worth playing cause I do like playing it and the implementation of IE will bring such a breadth of content to the game that I have no doubts that it will shake up the reviews however I am both excited and scared of how this will turn out because while I have no doubts IE will have me playing hundreds more hours regardless of quality I can't as of yet make comment on how well implemented it will be and how much love will be shown to it (and future releases). I strongly believe that once this game has gotten the DLC support of TWW2 it will be a good game, perhaps even a great one however I shall leave this review on negative because let's be honest here. This game needed another year of dev time and should have released with more content (tho not necessarily IE) and way more polish.

review: I am only on chapter 3 but I already feel like I can recommend this game.Forget the vague "souls-like" definition, this is an action game that's almost a boss rush with some cool exploration and some regular enemy encounters between each boss. I honestly love the idea of fighting so many 1vs1 fights, against beautifully designed enemies that are different from each other (so far I only found 1 reskinned boss out of 20ish).The combat system is solid, the game doesn't have many combos (which I don't mind) and it requires you to use dodges and skills with the right timing, while you focus on building your own meter for stronger heavy attacks that will also help you to stagger the enemies. Imo it's simple but effective, and you will find a lot of satisfaction in chain-staggering stronger foes with a series of heavy attacks and skills.One thing I have to complain though is navigating the world: the game has no map and a lot of areas that, while visually stunning, don't look too different from each other when you have to remember where something, like a locked door you left behind, was. The enormous amount of invisible walls also makes it hard to tell where you can and cannot go.And since the game has tons of secrets (some of which are very hard to find without a guide), all of this makes finding them even harder and somewhat frustrating.

review: Update to my review. I have to give this a thumbs down now. Its a great game, it really is. But it is RUINED by the insane loading times (I have gig up and down speeds) and that you are FORCED to play with others. If you disconnect your internet, you can play with bots, but it doesnt save ANY of that progress even though you get STEAM accomplishments while offline. It makes ZERO sense. Then there are the skins. While some of them are cool, most are simply just different colors of the exact same armor. Its like the Devs think Space Marines are clones or something. They are meant to be UNIQUE, not cookie cutter. This plague of gaming where folks are forced to be online to play single player games will be the death of PC gaming. This along with the non stop need to have account after account just to play a game is getting plain ridiculous. If you are a 40k fan pick it up purely for the campaign which is EPIC and amazing. The rest of the game is a complete letdown.

review: 2014 Basic GameplayYou play as either a Counter-Terrorist or a Terrorist, both of which are deployed into a battlefield and each round are giving a small allowance to purchase weapons of their choice.You can make extra money by winning rounds or you could also hold a knife up to the enemy demanding their money, Although that would be risky since the enemy would likely just to shoot you.On the Terrorist team your goal is to plant and explosive near some uhhm.. important boxes?.Anyway, once plant wait You patiently for it to explode.As a Counter-terrorist you must eliminate all the Terrorist forces OR defuse the bomb, thus Protecting those ever important boxes from certain destruction.Being a honourable opponent, Terrorists are sure to set the bomb timer just long enough to give the Ct's the chance to Slaughter the remaining T's, and defuse the bomb.I'll list some positive/negative attributes of this game here.Positive attributes :- Matchmaking - Teaches children the harsh reality of gambling (although some never seem to learn even after $500 later)- Ranks - Cool looking skins- Fast growing population of players - Fat stacks of loot dropped somewhat often- Chickens- High replay value- Deathmatch game type (I could go into more detail on negative parts of it, but that would make this review too long and boring)Negative attributes :Although I Do love the single player campaign, it could use some work. I REALLY wish it were longer.. And that final Boss fight is pretty lame. It only lasts around 27 seconds, and during that time the only way to lose is by taking offense from the old man that constantly insults you, and how his "7 year old could beat you, blindfolded."- The game mode "Infernal" played on the map "de_inferno"Some people like this game mode however I personally dislike it, For those of you that have not yet had the chance to experience it I'll explain for you.It seems like any normal de_ map However, The real goal is to scurry around finding any shred or scrap of rego, Normally it's hidden in obscurer unused sections of the map, and has the ability to shift/move around to different locations, Or even leave the game entirely for up to 10 minutes at a time.- Demolition, Also known as "jokemode" Added purely as a joke that volvo was supposed to only unlock on every April fool's day, However some hacker probably that "4_chan" guy, permanently unlocked it. (Volvo have been working on a fix ever since)Demolition is the game mode which automatically gives everyone amour and then requires you to get kills with weapons that do extremely poor damage against armoured opponents. Also no block is Enabled And Whoa?, So is team killing!The volka StrategyYou could just play this game like a noob and spend hundreds of dollars on skins, OR you could play the game correctly like me. Here is my strategy :- Don't buy skins to start with, Seriously it's a waste of money.- Play for a good 50 hrs or so and sell any drop you get.- Wait for a steam sale and Invest in as many copies of csgo you can.- Work your way up to about 5 copies or so But make sure you don't get too many otherwise you won't have enough time to harvest all your csgo account drops (having more than 7 accounts may have diminishing returns) [Note- it takes about 20 hrs gameplay to activate the drops].- Keep playing on all copies frequently to maximise drops.- Once you have your economy built up with this method you can now buy skins with all that free income you have. Remember to Never gamble with opening cases. I've made about $100 with this method. I think it's about time to quit my day job.In a whole, I do love this game And would recommend to anyone, Good half, Good half.

review: 2023 I want to recommend this game. I do - I enjoyed WH2 a lot and have some fun moments in WH3. But there are just stupid problems in this game considering it is a direct successor to WH2, and design choices that are just not good.There are still bugs in the game well over a year after release. Ranged units have a hard time firing at targets correctly. Armies can get stuck on agents and be frozen indefinitely. Random crashes can happen in battle maps. Several unit descriptions just don't even match what they actually do/are functionally.The AI are brain dead during sieges. And ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, I think the main settlement sieges are the worst in ANY total war game since Empire. The defender is actually WORSE off than the attacker with the new capture point system. Defenses don't work all that well. Walls are still worthless. The AI can't defend their settlements for ♥♥♥♥. It is such an epic fail and makes sieges just a pain on both ends. I hate them.Several of the older races (Empire, Dwarves, Dark Elves especially) just feel bland now in immortal empires. The Empires mechanics are terrible. Cathay isn't a finished race. Bretonnia needs attention. Realms of Chaos is a bad campaign, pure and simple. It just isn't all that good. Id welcome arguments to the contrary, but it wasn't well executed for the original characters on release and was insulting that they released WH3 with the game being UNFINISHED. Immortal Empires wasn't out yet. And Cathay wasn't finished and still doesn't feel finished. The new chaos dwarves feel much more fleshed out than they do.CA is half assing a lot of their content. It is infuriating to see. They are capable of doing a much better job, and I cannot recommend any product from them in good faith while they keep putting out games, DLCs and other updates that just aren't up to snuff. Unfinished, unpolished, untested. And they expect us to accept it for what it is, test it for them and wait for months to have proper changes. By which point we've "moved on" to the next paid title they've released where they can take in more money.

Yes No Funny Award792 people found this review helpful13 people found this review funny 8 6 6 11Riley02852 products in account4 reviewsNot Recommended24.5 hrs on record (20.9 hrs at review time)POSTED: 18 FEBRUARYUntil CA fix the performance issues supposedly caused by Denuvo, I wouldn't recommend this game. It's a gamble whether you'll have fine performance or worse than normal, even on lowest settings. It seems like the copies they gave content creators did NOT have Denuvo, and thus the performance issues, and they added it upon launch so that nobody would be able to take it into account for reviews. That is an absolutely abhorrent thing to do. Something tells me this is a move on SEGA's part, but either way, it should not be tolerated. From this point on, I'd say keep your money, wait until AFTER launch from CA to decide whether or not to buy the game.READ MORE Was this review helpful? Yes No Funny Award611 people found this review helpful11 people found this review funny 6 3 4R41N323 products in account8 reviewsNot Recommended31.8 hrs on record (29.6 hrs at review time)POSTED: 18 FEBRUARYI REALLY want to recommend this game. I feel like I SHOULD recommend this game. But it is functionally broken on release. I can't encourage people to alpha test this game for CA at the cost of their own money. I have 32GB of Ram and 8GB of VRAM (RTX 3060). The game barely runs. This is mind boggling because of the HUGE advancements that CA has made optimizing TWWH2! Honestly I still have plenty of mileage to get out of the second game and I'll be playing that while they fix this one. I am 100% positive in a year this game will be incredible and have some excellent DLCs I will certainly buy and a great mortal empires mode. But until it's optimized, the UI is fixed and most importantly they fix the INSANE unit control issues I cannot recommend this game.Seriously the unit control is COMPLETELY broken. I'm not sure if they playtested this build at all. Your units WILL stop moving and stand still and ignore orders. To get ANY melee unit to engage a ANY ranged unit thats running you have to literally sit there and click on them for the ENTIRE time, which you obviously cannot do when you have a 40 unit army. All the other issues WOULD be tolerable. I can deal with some crashing and framerate drops, I can't handle the game actually being unplayable and broken. When your level 40 doomstack skarbrand dies to a single unit of archers because he was afk for legit only 20 seconds because he got a charge off on the unit then fell asleep basically ruins the entire game. Every single one of your units will do this and its exacerbated by more than half the factions represented in the main campaign being ranged focused or hybrid.TL:DR DO NOT play right now. Wait for the game to actually finish it's development cycle and this will be a masterpiece, similar to how TWWH2 went from a 6/10 to 10/10 in 3 years. This game WILL be amazing, but if you are on the fence then he at least you know you'll get the game for 10-20 bucks later when all of US have finished alpha testing it for you.READ MORE Was this review helpful? Yes No Funny Award504 people found this review helpful4416 people found this review funny 2 7 8Hobo Joe109 products in account1 reviewRecommended35.9 hrs on record (25.9 hrs at review time)POSTED: 18 FEBRUARYAs of now, Total War: Warhammer III does not exactly stand on it's own compared to Total War: Warhammer II due to a lack of content owing to its current infancy and lack of expansive addons and updates seen in Warhammer II. This likely would not be the case if it shipped with Mortal Empires on day one, and did not elect to release without add the very least a skin-and-bones placeholder version of the Chaos Dwarves, instead using Orks as a placeholder.The game itself runs somewhat poorly, it is not well optimized, however this can be mitigated by running at a decreased resolution and lowered textures. This, however, is entirely temporary, and shouldn't factor into your interest, but only your interest *immediately*. Unless you're a huge fan of Kislev, Cathay, Chaos, or the Ogre Kingdoms, I would highly suggest DELAYING your purchase until the future when there is more content to be had, as your time will likely be better spent in Warhammer II where you will still have access to the content from Warhammer I and II.That being said, Chaos is an extremely well designed faction from a gameplay standpoint and has some unique mechanics that stand out from anything else Creative Assembly has ever made. Having tried out the first several turns of most factions by now, I can safely, but unfortunately say that the Legion of Chaos is by far my favorite, which is unfortunate to me because I was mostly looking forward to the Ogre Kingdoms.As for the Campaign, it is about as sandboxy as Vortex was, but with a new mechanic involving the invasion of each realm of Chaos to slay a Daemon Prince, as opposed to completing rituals as in Warhammer II. I personally enjoy it.Lastly, the minor settlements and siege battles. I am not as adverse to the change as other people are. While the supply system is bizarre at best, I'm not convinced that it is entirely detrimental to gameplay, after playing a few rounds, however, I would appreciate a setting to be able to disable this mechanic and return to the old design. I do enjoy the designs of the maps, though, and I really like the new survival mode for custom battles.At it's current state I would suggest waiting for further updates unless you're a die-hard fan of Total War Fantasy or any of the Races in Warhammer III, barring of course Chaos Dwarves.I run an old AM3 CPU, 8gb of DDR3 RAM, and a GTX 1050ti, which is an extremely obsolete setup for this game. However, after twiddling with the settings, Im able to run the game at about 57fps, which is tolerable to me. It is possible for me to gain almost 100fps at very low settings, but the blurriness strains my eyes.I'd give it about a 7/10 right now. You might enjoy it, conditionally, but I wouldn't recommend it to everyone.READ MORE Was this review helpful? review: 2017 Product received for free After playing the game for roughly 500 hours, I have come to a point that I should express my opinion about the game's current state.Counter-Strike: Global Offensive is a highly competitive game that focuses on team wo--. Really? You REALLY think im going to describe this game as the perfect cut gem of an E-Sports title?.... well, you came to the wrong review comrade!In essence, CS:GO in its current state has some things you really wouldn't want in a game of this type:-Cheaters/VAC:Most of them obviously have been cheating for a long time, but what does valve care? The only thing useful they do is milk their games for money until they are bone dry and deserted. I just can't get over that fact that valve hasn't actually "noticed" that their anti-cheat has flaws, but instead they keep releasing more useless items than bug fixing updates for the game itself.-Griefers:They are not really common nowadays, but back in the day every 5/10 - 6/10 competitive matches i went would have atleast 1 griefer that didn't do anything but insult,generally discriminate or just flat-out do absolutely nothing to help the team win a single round. These individuals are most commonly found on the lower ranks, from my experience.-SMURFS:I have seen more smurfs in cs:go matchmaking than in the actual cartoon itself.Basically this ruins the game for new players by giving them the appearance that CS:GO just isn't worth playing if you don't know how.-THE SALTENING BEGINS:Do you want to experience more highly concentrated amounts of salt in one match than in a salt mine, followed by a community of 12 year olds more cancerous than the radiation levels at Chernobyl? Well my friend, CS:GO is the game for you! (Warranty for broken mice, keyboards, screens, headsets, desks, windows, and possibly hands from hitting your desk too hard not included.)-Servers:When I mean servers I don't intend to talk about the ping/lag, but instead about how most of the time I get matched against/with people from the other side of the damn galaxy. (This is good if you want to learn how everyone has had sexual intercourse with your family members/pets in diverse languages, while you simultaneously proceed to lose the match.)TL;DR:CS:GO is a game that gives everybody a different experience (Unless you are playing in russia, then it's always B rushed every round). Cringy jokes aside, I think this game is somewhat addicting and pleasant in the long run, despite the initial steep learning curve. If valve ever decides to ACTUALLY update their anti-cheat system I will be more than happy to play this game more often.Cheers,James.

review: 2022 Elden Ring is, without a doubt, one of the best open-world games ever released, and among the gaming "Hall of Fame" of the past decade - among the likes of Skyrim, Witcher 3, Red Dead Redemption 2, God of War, and Breath of the Wild.The best features, among many, have to be its unique and refined artistic style and direction, detailed world and lore, mysterious yet alluring characters, incredible bosses and visual effects, and the wide array of weapons and magic at your disposal.The biggest area to nitpick is the graphical fidelity, which, for this time, is outdated. However, as mentioned before, it has an unparalleled artistic design, with a look and feel that more than makes up for its shortcomings in texture quality. The way the color palettes blend and contrast with the beautiful lighting, along with the sheer grandiosity of The Lands Between, culminate into a remarkable masterpiece.The difficulty is punishing. Let me be clear - I am not a fan of such types of games. But as an RPG and open-world lover, with a penchant for medieval fantasy settings and huge swords, Elden Ring hits every other spot for me. A tremendous title for the ages.

review: F2P game. Ingame Shop that only provides cosmetics. No P2W at all! All these critics regarding the EULA are completely irrelevant and shouldnt be regarded! These conditions are completely normal!Started Phase 2 today. So far the game is quite fun! The game loop seems like this: Discover a new area, complete 1-2 quests, use a certain amount of some stations in cities scattered around the area. In the end you defeat a boss and go to the next area. In the meantime you farm resources and build your base, craft weapons/ armor and slay!Difficulty: So far its not really difficult at all. Difficulty increases by region. To be as strong as before youll have to craft new armor/ weapon. Nothing new here.Cons: It kinda feels like a mobile port. But its not thaaaaaat bad .... Result: A fun game thats actually kinda addicting. Its a kind of a Valheim\Rust survival game but combined with raids and bosses that you know from MMORPGsedit: After a while some more input:I do still recommend the game BUT it has issues! For example- You get warnings, when you click your mouse too fast. So using the furnaces and getting all your stuff out may be more problematic than you might think. - Water Pumps behave VERY weird. - There isnt that much content if you think about it. Every region has like 10 quests in total and maybe 6-8 "cities" (towns with 10-40 buildings) to discover. So by now i more or less have done everything for Phase 2 of the Season. And that phase started yesterday! Phase 3 starts next week! - Yes you are gated by phases that disable lots of content to keep you playing for the whole season!- There are bugs! (I was running below the world yesterday, i fell troguh the floor and ran across the void for example) (stopping a craft destroys all already completed materials in my opinion a bug, destroying the crafting building also destroys all materials that were still inside as well)- There are lag issues!- Also even tho its a game with mining, farming and so on in it. There isnt that much you can craft actually. Most things are just improved version of others.- The "grind" isnt really grindy ...- Wipes every 6 weeks (wipes are good for these kind of games but 6 weeks may be a bit short for a lot of people)- Most bosses are (so far) simply bullet sponges and easily killed solo. There are exceptions but just because you wont be able to move if you would carry all the ammo you would need to kill that thing!- Its lacking a LOT of QOL features (you can for example drop all items in a chest but cant empty the chest immediately. But have to empty it to destroy it) Thats it so far. I would still recommend it just because its F2P and still fun to play! But beware that you may experience it a bit different!

review: Ok Review Time!!First of all this game is amazing and absolutley a worthy sequel to the first game.I love the direction the game went with its choice of Enemies, The Tyranids have been rarely used outside of the RTS genre and a small splinter fleet of Hive Fleet Leviathan was the Ideal Choice!!Slightly disappointed at first with Chaos (Again) being used as the second antagonist, but quickly changed my mind when it was Revealed that it was the Thousand Sons, which have been criminaly underused in gaming and instead of one of the more "Safe" options such as the Black Leigon in the first game!!I also Loved the part where you are Underground on an Imperial Tomb World, which ironicaly enough was a Necron Tomb World, so here's hoping in the Future we get some Necrons (My fave Faction) to fight!!I hope Saber Interactive continues this trend of using underrepresented and overlooked factions and armies into the future!!All of that being said the game is not without some issues, Mainly being how the Dodge and Parry system doesn't work most of the time, there are many times I've pressed the Parry/Dodge button with the prompt/during the indicator window up onscreen and I still got hit, it got so frustrating that i was doing all the steps to not get hit and I get hit and take damage anyway that i simply gave up trying to use the system about halfway through the game.Secondly Melee Combat was at the forefront of the gameplay which left the Shooting aspect of the game to feel quite weak and underpowered in comparison.Third is the customisation of your multiplayer Character, while it seems like Sabre have nailed it it first which they totally have, they have missed some key aspects upon closer inspection. These are quite major things if you think about them and they are as Follows:Bulwark's Banner, for some reason its always the Ultramarines Standard, NOT the Chapter that you want or expect to be representing, example a Salamanders Space Marine Planting down a Ultramarines Standard Flag.This makes zero sense and I want to see this Fixed ASAP as its increadably annoying, especialy when you are a fan of other Chapters.Voice Shouts using the Voice Wheel again suffer from the same exact problem, I dont like the fact that (Insert Chapter's Marine) is shouting out stuff like "For Guilliman!" when thats not even there Primearch!!Finally some Chapter Based cosmetics would be really great to have such as Imperial Fists or Blood Angels based wargear with corect Heraldry. Finally ♥♥♥♥ Leandros(Sorry for any Spelling Mistakes, Dyslexia is a ♥♥♥♥♥)BIG EDITNow that I have played the game for a while, I feel the need to add this.Solid game, but in my opinion it has a lot of problems that make it hard to recommend in its current state. I completed the game on Angel of Death (AOD) solo for reference. I played all the operations coop at least once. I played a few rounds of PVP, I won't comment on that since I didn't really enjoy it.The good is that it's a direct continuation of the first. I was happy to see show up in the game in a role that made sense. Overall the lore, environments, and audio were fantastic. The hordes of enemies were impressive and some of the set pieces were neat. Just like the first I loved using the jump jets and thunder hammer to crash down on enemies.There were so many things that combined made this game just not that enjoyable compared to the first for me:The game feels like it was designed for coop first and everything suffers for it. The campaign is filled with generic objectives like hold the location, press these buttons, etc. They don't feel tailor made for campaign experience but a cooperative one. Everything is forced to load to the useless battle barge before you load into an actual mission. This could easily have just been a UI menu.The AI teammates are abysmal. They do not focus on completing objects (ex. defend the chains). The enemies almost entire ignore your allies and routinely rush directly to the player. This is doubly terrible on AODThe game introduces a somewhat more fleshed out dodge and parry system and a kill shot system. In my opinion this is completely out of place. I wasn't looking to play Dark Souls, I'm looking to play a third person shooter. This is doubly bad because the timings on them are so inconsistent. Sometimes you can simply hold the defend button and you will auto parry, others you have to be very precise. The indicator doesn't match the parry timing at all. The kill shot system is also terrible. Both of these share the same problem of parry, dodge, and kill shot not having the ability to be used at any moment in time and interrupting whatever action is currently in progress (ex. a melee attack or shooting). It makes the game feel incredibly clunky and unresponsive on AOD, In general the whole Melee Combat System feels like it was originally designed for a much faster paced combat system which was cut and we then ended up with what we have now.Similar to dodge and kill shot not interrupting all actions, neither does your tactical ability. This is nonsense, that is the whole purpose of the single ability you have for 95% of the campaign, to heal and protect yourself.In general the combat feels like it misses the point of what made the first one great. It should be larger swarms of weaker enemies, not bullet sponge enemies that require dodge/parry/kill shot to do any damageAll of the guns feel too weak. This might be an AOD problem but it feels terrible to have to use 50% of your las rifle to take down one terminator. This is doubly worse because you carry less guns in this game compared to the first.The new health and armor system feels like a step backwards. On AOD you are constantly at 1% HP regardless and there is almost no way to heal yourself through combat like the first game. Everything that touches you will immediately remove your armor so it feels pointless. I would have rather had no armor, more health, and a means to regenerate it through combat (past white damage).You can't queue for a new instance of an operation, it always puts you in one in progress if available. If you are playing for the story, like the campaign suggests, this means you may start at the very end of one if the game decides. When you leave the operation, it forces you to watch the useless scenes in the battle barge over again to return to the campaign which is incredibly annoying.The assault class (the most fun one) is also the most weak one. This is likely a combination of all the above issues though. You cant fly over basic ledges and overhangs, it just feels so weak in operations.I assume most of these issues could be patched for sure and some of them may actually be realistically improved. As it stands though at full price, it's a steep ask for what you get in the package. There is most certainly no longevity to the operations, they are largely static with no variation aside from where/when enemies spawn. PVP is PVP, nothing special. This is a sale game for sure. It does so much right, but the wrong stuff just makes the whole experience feel off.

review: 2022 First of all, in short this is probably the best modern "Soulsborne" cinematic universe game we've gotten thus far in PC (Bloodborne when? pls). The addition of certain micro mechanics like jumping, the horse riding (and battles) and now an actual open world that gives you freedom from where to explore to a much higher extent compared to the other games is honestly just great fun. I would not be surprised If the average playtime til completion in Elden ring is at least 2x of the other games and even as an entry into the series it does the job just fine (I do think Dark Souls 3 is a little better as an introduction to the series)BUT, It's been confirmed several times that FromSoftware/Bandai Namco and whoever else is making money from these games. They make A B S O L U T E bank money when they release these games on PC (And If Bloodborne ever got ported to PC that game would also absolutely be bank money). As FromSoftware is literally one of the few Japanese game studios that is so widely recognized and loved in the west I just wish they actually cared about this market as much as *we* love them. Other people that played the game know this, all the reviewers have mentioned this in their YT videos, I have a computer that is quite literally way more powerful than any console running this same game yet I'm getting the stuttering, frame drops. And this entire thing is a reocurring thing with Soulsborne games ported to PC and the kick in the balls is, while this game is absolutely beautiful, it is not the most "graphically" challenging game in recent times at all.Should this previous complain deter you from trying out this game? Actually? Absolutely not, I would still recommend it and while I have other minor complains about certain game design things themselves it's still an absolute blast, I'm not even half way through the game yet as for people that are completionists this will really make you want to explore every nook and cranny but this is just a warning and just to get the message out there because I don't know how else you get Bandai/FromSoftware to care about the Steam market that actually makes them drown in money.TL:DR: fort night

review: It's not a game that can be in the top 10 ofc, BUT it's a very good example that you don't need a triple A game to have a good time, this is my first review on steam i think even tho i have over 20 games here and i've played hundreds of games on them. So far: 1) Combat techniques are smooth and fun.2) Tutorials are very clear and easy to follow.3) Storytelling is really engaging.4) Tasks and quests are not progressive, so you won't progress in the game very fast and it's not very slow either.5) Visuals are wonderful for sure!6) Character customisation is not overwhelming like in other games.7) Inventory and quick actions (HUD) settings are very good and give you an amazing gaming experience.Maybe i'll update the review when i come across more things.Wonderful game! Give it a try, it's free so you have nothing to lose.
