review: Nobody will read my review, so I'll just say ♥♥♥♥ anyone who starts their comment like that (except me). This game deserves way better than cheap, lazy spam. I’ve 100% completed Elden Ring on PS5, got the platinum trophy which was an absolute blast, and now I’m diving into it on PC. FromSoftware, you’ve seriously outdone yourselves. Elden Ring is nothing short of phenomenal, and it's hard to imagine how you'll ever top this.From the moment I stepped into this vast, mysterious world, I was hooked. The blend of deep lore, challenging combat, and stunning landscapes is just incredible. The gameplay is smoth and perfectly balanced, making every fight feel like a rewarding test of skill.Exploring the world of Elden Ring is pure joy. It's packed with secrets, hidden paths, and lore that keeps you wanting more. The environmental storyteling is so rich that every corner of the map feels worth investigating. Each region has its own uniqie look and feel, so exploration never gets boring.Now, let’s talk about the only thing that annoys me: the catacombs or dungeons. This has been a problem since Bloodborne (my favorite game of all time). Even though Elden Ring does it better than Bloodborne, every dungeon still feels a bit like an AI-generated copy-paste job. But hey, they’re still fun.The character builds you can create in Elden Ring are better than in any Souls game before it. Whether you’re into melee combat, magic, or a mix of both, the depth here is just amazing.In short, Elden Ring isn’t just a game; it’s an experience. FromSoftware has set a new standard for the genre and maybe created a new genre, and I can’t wait to see what they do with the DLC. If you haven’t played it yet, do yourself a favor and dive in. You won’t regret it.

review: It's pains me to say this as a huge warhammer fan but I overall found my experience with this game to be less than superb and not worth the money.For a high triple-A price tag it has far too many bugs, connection issues and sloppy optimisation that weigh down a game that, whilst isn't bad, doesn't feel like it does anything too spectacular. Combat feels very stiff and cagey where you transition awkwardly from spamming melee moves and swinging wildly around the place to firing off one or two mags of your current weapon (before it ultimately runs out of ammunition because of the ridiculously low amount of ammo the player is allowed to retain). There isn't anywhere near enough variety in execution animations, and enemy variety is sorely lacking. The single player campaign is just "good enough"; It has some cool standout moments but it's mostly bogged down with lots of sub par segments and bickering between squadmates that gets tiring to listen to very quickly. Titus feels very watered down and flat in this game, and most of the supporting cast of characters don't stand out too much save for a handful. Operations CAN be good...When it's working and you can connect to a game, which is a struggle to achieve at the best of times. The PvP multiplayer is laughably unoptimised and has some of the worst ping issues I've played in a multiplayer game in years (a massive shame as I was a huge fan of the first Space Marine game's multiplayer which had better ping and servers almost a full decade ago) as well as a veritable host of balance issues with classes and a score limit for matches that's far too short for how long it takes to get into the match in the first place. All of these modes, unfortunately, also have the misfortune of being tied within a very obtuse and sluggish overworld/hub interface. If you want to customise your characters for the multiplayer modes it requires you to matchmake in those modes, which 9/10 times usually leads to you getting into a game before you can even customise your classes or loadout and forcing you to sit through several load screens (that is if you actually ever load INTO whatever you matchmaked for with how bad the connection issues are.) before you can so much as determine what colour you want your space marine to be or what weapon you want them to use. The hub exists to be a diegetic and seamless way for players to experience the game but it manages to do the complete opposite since it brings with it a whole host of problems that ultimately ruin the immersion of the hub in the first place.I really want to like this game but in truth I've derived no joy from playing it to completion, and I feel no motivation trying to finish up the last 3 operations when the game is fighting me at every opportunity to stop me from getting to do so and is just wasting my time seemingly out of spite. At a FAR cheaper price tag and with some tuning up, I could definitely recommend this game, but in it's current state and with all it's baggage and pricing, I'd advise steering clear of this one for now. You'll get more fun out of playing some of the other equally, poorly optimised 40k games that at least don't take too much of your cash.

review: 2022 'Posted: 20 Feb @ 4:02amIncredible gameBuggy at the minute but still worth the purchasecba making a full on review, if u like total war grab it if u have the money idk im not ur dad'I made this review when I was off the first high of finishing a Legendary Slaanesh campaign. I love it, it was fun. I can't say that I still feel the same way. Patching and fixes for this games many problems is abysmally slow. I don't agree with simply calling the game trash and moving on because the actual races, maps, etc. Are all pretty cool, but they just do not play well at all.Infantry is hardly responsive and pushes you to doomstack monsters even moreso than Warhammer two already didTowers are frankly broken and most siege battles are unloseable chores due to god awful AI, in my last run I played pretty much every defense in triple speed waiting for the enemy to die on my tier 2 ♥♥♥♥ infantry as towers bricked them.AI rebuild siege defenses with basically no delay. As soon as you destroy a tower they start rebuilding it. Fighting minor siege battles is legitimately unfun, there are fewer land battles on the map which is where this franchise truly shines.There are a lot of really, really bad performance and visual issues which people experience at different levels. Some people have mid-tier rigs and are completely fine, others are super high end and get abysmal performance on the campaign map.The soul-run campaign just isn't fun. An overwhelming majority of the community would probably agree to this. It is a linear experience of expand, consolidate, expand. Turtle, turtle, turtle. Rifts are cancer and your legendary lord spends the majority of his/her time in either the Realms of Chaos or sitting in favoured corruption settlements to get rid of cancerous corurption traits like -5% replenishment which can severely hamstring certain factions. In my Slaanesh run I had a Keeper of Secrets with this trait and he was literally unable to replenish outside of tier 5 settlements. ♥♥♥♥ game design. The narrative isn't that interesting because its very impersonal, whereas Vortex' story felt very personal to your faction despite the overall plot being the exact same. Supply lines lmaoThis game has potential but I've recently uninstalled it. It just isn't fun, it hardly works. Its difficult enough to get through a campaign even ignoring the absolute tide of bugs that this game has.CA is still displaying a trend of poor management post launch and frank disrespect for their games. Again, this is a good game. Its in a broken state, so I can't recommend that anybody buy it atm.I sincerely hope that I'll be changing this review in a few patches. But from the way things are going I can't see myself changing that.

review: 2022 Game is solid.UPDATE: 2/24/2022HOWEVER,if you are on the fence about buying the game, I'd wait. This game has good bones, and will certainly be a masterpiece in a few years. Once Immortal Empires is released and there have been several updates, it'll be a thoroughly enjoyable experience.In my first co-op campaign, my graphics card failed 5 times. Screen went black, then eventually came back but with black boxes and half the colors gone. This has not happened in any other game, including Total Warhammer II. My graphics card is struggling far more than it should be, and that's on a 1080Ti with settings at medium-high. Simply put, something is wrong here. I don't know if it's the rumored Denuvo, or if there is more optimization that needs to be done. I even have the Nvidia drivers that were designed with this games release in mind.Gameplay wise, it's great. The few nitpicks I do have, I'm sure will be ironed out in the patches to come. Warhammer II had many issues on launch as well, and now that game is very refined and enjoyable. I'm very confident that game 3 will also receive the love and attention it deserves, but it will take time.I look forward to the future of this game with updates, DLC, and mods. It's enjoyable now, but the Ideal Total War: Warhammer 3 experience is probably a year out from now.Regardless of whether you have the game now or are choosing to wait, I hope you enjoy the games you are playing, cheers!

review: Product refunded Space Marine 2 feels like playing a classic AA Xbox game, one that you'd rent from the local Redbox for a week and try to finish in a few sittings. A game that feels catered to rental services, but not worth a full $60 purchase. In one way, I found my playtime oddly nostalgic and charming for the aforementioned reasons, but in another way, I found myself totally uninspired, questioning why I had just spent $60 for a game that, despite its great visuals, felt oddly antiquated. Ultimately, there just isn't a lot of depth here - I don't need games to be complicated, but this one felt sorta mind-numbing at times. Hoard-combat sounds like so much fun in theory, but often has a similar sensation to mowing the lawn: an exercise in patience, as you direct your big mowing machine towards the next patch of unkempt grass, once you're there, there isn't much 'strategy' involved - it's just grass. That being said, the graphics are great. I wish it had ultrawide support, and I'm not sure what about this package requires them to take a month post-launch to officially add it. The environments and hoards look particularly amazing - the lighting can also look incredible under the correct circumstances - it's then a shame that the first 2 hours of this game are set almost entirely on a beige planet filled with swamp-fog and mud. Speaking of hours - I know this campaign is only 6 or so hours long. This isn't an issue in principle if the package is really condensed and well-made, but Space Marine 2 is just so damn average that it becomes a much harder pill to swallow. I personally have no interest in online game modes, so for me: someone seeking a strong single-player campaign the likes of Halo 3, Reach, Wolfenstien, Doom 2016, etc, .. I am left comparably underwhelmed. There isn't enough here for me to sink my teeth into. It's a $60 game that feels as though it's resting a bit too much on its graphical laurels to justify an amateur game experience. Shallow combat and an aggressively short campaign emphasizes the mediocrity of the package, and even if it wasn't true for everyone, it was true for me. The draw of the 40k universe isn't endearing enough for me to overlook the inadequacies of this experience.

review: 2022 Just completed my first campaign, and I'm now able to honestly review the game.I honestly really enjoyed/enjoy this game!The Prologue is absolutely amazing!The campaign was for the most part really good, it has a lot of really fleshed out and intriguing characters and mini story lines that we all know and love from the Warhammer Lore.There was a few minor elements of the campaign that weren't enjoyable (very minor) such as the settlement battles and the enemy AI which depending on what faction you play as can feel like a Terminator chasing you wherever you go (regardless of there own safety), but not to the point of making me want to stop!There were a few bugs., wasn't a great issue and most I saw will most likely get scooped up in the next update or two. To be expected with a new release, not sure why people are whinging about this...This game has released at such a great start point that when they do drop in Mortal Empires, it's going to make this games "replay" ability HUGE!CA has a great record with its previous two titles in the Warhammer series, with frequent DLC additions that can expand and sometimes completely change the way the game can be played! Super excited to see what they bring with W3!

review: Take this with a grain of salt. I ultimately refunded it because of various small issues.1. Performance while stable felt bad on my 3080. DLSS turned on by default with no way to turn it off... not a good look and many other games have had drama just for this, games shouldn't need DLSS to function. (Examples: Remnant 2, Cyberpunk2077). I can't play this game with DLSS forced on, with optimized settings (a combo of mid-very high settings) and RT off at mid to high settings. This gets me around 70-75 fps at 1080p around 65-70 at 1440p. I spent $3000+ on a gaming computer last year to play games at max settings, and high frame rates. Watching 2023-24 games come out and turn a $3000 pc into something thats comparible to a console is just sad.2. Difficulty had weird spike you either beat everything down pretty easy or you get pooped on. In the two hours I made it to the area with the first official fire boss with a side boss (big headed blue guy) couldn't beat either in the time I had with the game. The combat is action based but I HATE that I can't dodge out of an attack. I can't tell you how many times I would attack the game ques the attack but even if I see something coming I can't dodge out of the way instead stuck in an attack animation, speaking of heavy attacks feel weird as I try to implement them into my light attacks but without a "focus bead" you can't string a heavy into your combo and instead have to come to a stand still before you can ques up a heavy attack. Combat feels both clunky and fluid at the same time with difficulty spikes in both directions as well.3. This was the deciding factor: Time... unfortunately because games have a 2 hour limit before they can't be refunded I take that time seriously as $60+ investment isn't so small in 2024 with costs rising. From the time I hit "play" Steam's timer keeps track of shaders compiling (about 5-10 minutes), and then me looking at options (mostly graphics) and bench marking for optimized settings took another 20-30 minutes before I even hit "new game". There I am already 45-ish minutes into a game I have yet to truly try. I fortunately watched a couple people start it up and was able to skip the opening cinematic and a couple cut scenes saving me valuable time and still left me in the starting area as my 2 hour limit came along.Unfortunately because of the time constants and the few little issues I had I can't say for certain whether this game is good or not but it's issues were enough to make me refund it. I wasn't going to lose out on money for a game I wasn't crazy about. I think we need to talk about opening up the refund window on games that boast dozens of hours of content and only having 2 hours to demo that content. I truly believe if I had another 2-3 hours I might have found something to love but as is I couldn't bring myself to spend $60 for a game I was meh about with the 1 hour 15-ish minutes I had with it.

review: 2022 Well what to say about this masterpiece, the magnum opus of From Software?It is just GREAT! Provided you like the general 'soulslike' approach and setting, this game is a wonderful step forward and truly takes the whole thing into an open world. There is so much to explore, to uncover, to find... and to get pounded into the floor.If you are absolutely new to From Software's approach on difficulty and gameplay, then Elden Ring is the most userfriendly one. A really slow paced tutorial (compared to: this is how you move... YOU DIED.) so even newcomers have can get accustomed to the core mechanics.But don't get me wrong: the difficulty spikes are still there, and you WILL DIE A LOT! But this is actually part of how these games work, so do not falter when your health runs out yet again.It is really hard to write a lot about it, without spoiling anything. So to be brief: imagine Darksouls, just in a huge open world, with a metric ton of bonfires and small dungeons and challenges everywhere.Welcome to Elden Ring :)Don't turn hollow <3

review: 2022 As you've probably noticed, some people have really enjoyed this game and others have not. I fall into the category of one who doesn't mind the Realm of Chaos campaign that many others despise. Yes, at times it can be annoying, but as someone who has plays the Vortex campaign in Total War Warhammer 2, I'm quite used to this type of campaign and don't need to wait for Immortal Empires to come out.Some pros to the game:- Decent Faction Selection (base game has 9 Legendary Lords from 7 different factions).- Map is very large and allows for diversity in what enemies and friends you come across.- Individual Faction Mechanics for every faction that adds some flavor to each one.- Skarbrand the Exiled punting most characters across the map.- Graphics are pretty good especially on higher settings.- Modding Community is wonderful.Cons:- Immortal Empires isn't out yet. Less sandbox-ish for now as you are kind of forced into playing the Souls Race unless you have a mod that turns it off.- Limited Units as of now for each faction, especially the Daemonic factions.- Cannot play as the Warhammer one and two races. This doesn't faze me, but I know it affects a lot of people that fancy playing the Empire for the 50th time.- Anti-Player Bias still is strong, but much better than what it was at release back in February of 2022.Conclusion:Personally, I think the game is worth it and it is only going to get better as we progress further into the year. If you are waiting for Immortal Empires, then I would hold off until later this year when the beta gets set up for that. If you really want to try out new factions like Cathay (which is new-ish to lore) and the Daemons, then I would recommend getting this game. I hope this helps you all make a good decision!

review: 2023 I've bought every DLC from WH1 to WH3, with the exception of your newest 25$ DLC pack.For that price I'd expect a new, fully fleshed out faction. What do we get? 3 Legendary Lords and a unit roster that does very little to pad out the existing races you chose to feature in that DLC pack. You lot must be really getting ribbed hard by your investors to destroy all the good faith you've built with your community these long, long years. I waited patiently for WH3. I waited patiently for the DLCs to release -- because I thought it would get to a standard that would match WH2. I was wrong.Warhammer 3 was supposed to be your magnum opus. The king of kings. CA, you can still fix this. Your management just need to pull their heads out of your investor's buttholes and actually support your developers on this project. Help them help you. If you lot screw this game up more than you have, there will be no relevancy left for you. You think anyone will buy anything from you goobers again if you let this beautiful idea fail from mismanagement? Respect our time, respect our money. Inflation has hit everyone. Products are shrinking in size everywhere, prices are going up across the board. I refuse to believe inflation has hit a game company as hard as it has the rest of us. Maybe in your bottom line in the fact you actually have to pay your employees, CA. But I doubt they hardly see any of the benefits of your increased prices, hence - I don't give a damn about any PR speech related to your hardships. Your workers don't get any extra pay, only your crappy management do. I bet your management aren't even game developers. I bet they're just scum sucking bean counters who wormed their way up in the game industry through their sales experience. Guess what, people want a good game. Just give them one and they'll pay. These bad reviews aren't just because of your awful, awful DLC. The game itself is not in a good state. Promises that were made have been under-delivered. There has been an extremely long gap between DLC and updates. People have expectations, hopes - and those two things can only be betrayed so many times.Then you give them Shadows of Change? More like Shadows of the Underwhelmed. There's only one way to teach a bean counter how to invest in a good game. Make bad game. Numbers go down. No need for any of us to invest our time and money in disappointment.Make a good game, numbers go up. I know investors are like children in that they're used to instant gratification. But maybe they can learn how to wait like the rest of us are forced to? At least they wont be disappointed by the cold hard cash you dummies will make if you actually pull WH3 off right. It'll take time. Just show the community good faith, transparency and a willingness to veer back onto the right track. Prices to match the content provided, bullcrap about 'inflation' aside. 3 LLs and some units meant to slightly pad out some base game faction niches? 14.99$.Hey you know what I'll even be generous and offer some solutions, it'll make your desk jockeys heads spin.Change your Shadows of Change DLC to 14.99$ and offer those who've bought the DLC a discount on the next content pack you decide to release, equal to the 10$ they have lost. I mean, it's practically ensuring returning customers!!! If you can't do that? Offer them all exclusive beta access to your next content pack for testing/enjoyment. Wow, a band-aid and it's practically free. All you'd have to do after that is fix/tweak what's already there in between your DLC projects. Maybe fix some bugs and features you promised.I know, I'm a genius. You're welcome.

review: رهيبه

Now that we know what is going to be wiped each season, (every 6 weeks) this game is basically ruined for me. I can not sweatlord my way through from the very beginning and grind out memetic progression, world progression, and unlocks every 6 weeks. I get that they want to set a level playing field around the PVP part of the game, but how are people that have other responsibilities like family / work supposed to ever get anywhere when you require a restart from a fresh character every 6 weeks. If the season wipes are changed to not sh*t on our time spent exploring and unlocking new areas of the map, and character progression isn't completely wiped, I would recommend this game with 2 thumbs up, having been in every closed playtest since the first one. This game has so much to offer and can be absolutely incredible to experience, but they are absolutely ruining it for what I suspect will be a sizable portion of the would-be player base with the season wipe stance they are taking. Hopefully they are open to changing things, because this game went from a 9/10 to a 2/10 for me. I was actually going to dump about $50 into the game at launch just to support them bc of the play tests and I expected it would be a great game to support, but I will unfortunately be holding off to see if they come up with a better system for seasons. Some people are fine with these types of seasons/wipes, and that's fine, but I don't have the time to get reset like that over and over.

review: 2022 Elden Ring is a good game but unfortunately it's very poorly optimized.I kinda dismissed the other reviews saying how bad the frame drops are thinking they're exaggerated but I experienced them myself throughout the whole game.I'm not sure whether it's just bad optimization or because of the Easy Anti-Cheat but the frames stutter constantly, some areas more than others but it's just something you have to deal with through the game.This is also something I heard from pretty much everyone I talked to, this is not an issue of hardware (RTX 2070 and Ryzen 2700X)Elden Ring takes a lot from FromSoft's older titles and improves on most of them.The game is way more accessible with a LOT of ways to make the experience easier and also some very welcome quality of life changes, which I hope they will continue with and expand on future titles.Being an open world has it's draws though as if you're a fan of Dark Souls' old world design then you're not really gonna find that here.Another thing to note is that there is some cut content that's still half in the game and while it's not much, you do notice something's off, as well as a few bugs here and there.Online play is terrible, in coop and especially invasions you're gonna have a bad time. If you even manage to connect, and stay connected throughout the whole thing.One time I even got an "Inappropriate activity detected" error and was booted to the menu unable to go online.This probably was caused by some sort of false positive in Easy Anti-Cheat as I understand it happened to many people during that time and was later fixed but still an unpleasant experience.As much as I like FromSoft I expect better from a Triple A product.

review: 2023 Absolutely insulting and disgusting pricing policy by CA for their latest DLC. But, that in and of itself shouldn't be a problem for the base game, right? So why is the review negative?Simple, CA has effectively abandoned this game for the last year. They worked half-heartedly at fixing the most glaring issues but have, time and time again, utterly failed to keep their words on bug fixes, blatantly lied about maintaining a sufficient number of devs working on this project, tried to pacify the community by releasing roadmaps they have no intention (or ability) to follow, and overall left the game in a lacking state. Just to mention one among the countless issues, is absolutely unacceptable that people who PAID to buy the Nakai DLC (not me btw) cannot recruit Kroxigors, you know, the SINGLE UNIT HE'S SUPPOSED TO USE THE MOST. To call that embarrassing would be an understatement.CA has worked hard to destroy any remaining goodwill they had left after the disastrous launch of this game, and absolutely deserves to get what's coming to them, including but not limited to, low sales and abysmal player retention. Hopefully, the community's effort will make them understand that a change of attitude towards this game is in order. Personally though, I hold little hope.The total war community desperately needs a competitor to bust into the scene and light a fire under CA's sorry buttocks.

review: 2023 Total War: Warhammer will go down as one of the all-time great RTS franchises. The scope of this game will never be matched in the RTS genre.1) Insanely beautiful graphics. The best in a fantasy RTS game.2) Tried and true battle system with massive unit variety. Players can build defensive, offensive, balanced or meme armies.3) Ridiculous replayability - campaign. 24 Races (w/DLC). 90+ Factions each with a unique starting lord and location on the world map.4) Extremely high production quality. Sound, UI, Detail - everything exudes quality.5) Extremely deep multiplayer scene that is quite dependent on both game and meta knowledge and micro. 24 unique factions mean 288 unique matchups - everyone is always learning.

review: The game is indeed beautiful, and the controls are pretty easy to pick up. But man is this monkey weak! It takes a dozen hits from his rather heavy looking staff to take out trash mobs, who can kill you pretty easily with just a few hits. I've not made it out of the first mountain, but so far this is not open world; you are confined to a narrow corridor. And for the bosses, the game is basically grind trash in this hallway until you level up to beat one boss, and repeat this cycle forever. "Temples, towns, and shops" have been replaced with a one stop do everything shrine system, and there's zero exploration. I guess this is China's answer to Elden Ring, except not open world. For the kind of people who like that sort of thing, that's the sort of thing that kind of people like. But if you're looking for an actual adventure game, instead of an Elden Ring/Souls trainer, this isn't the one, hype be damned.

review: 2023 𝙂𝙧𝙚𝙖𝙩 𝙜𝙖𝙢𝙚, 𝙧𝙪𝙞𝙣𝙚𝙙 𝙗𝙮 𝙘𝙤𝙢𝙢𝙪𝙣𝙞𝙩𝙮.

2023 I have bought every xpac but SoC. I have earned the idiot crown I wear, and the right to speak on this game and the franchise's history - since I saw it happen. Way back when TW: WH1 was released, I was hesitantly critical of some things. The usual microtransaction stuff I figured was gross but mildly tolerable for a game I enjoyed. Locking units behind pre-orders? Less tolerable. Units basically just swinging swords at one another, nothing ever connecting? Oh.. Not like I liked to zoom in and watch the lads fight or anything.. (/s) No real incentive to play multiplayer except some momentary fun? I still think a currency from MP battles which can eventually be used to buy factions which I suggested all those years ago could have saved us from this timeline. Now I hear the team in charge of fixing the game was so so small, and the cuts to the workforce reaching like 40%. Where did the money even go then? And saying things like "the right to discuss is a privilege" and banning content creators who are justifiably upset? Yikes.This should be a lesson to all dev studios. When you strike gold with something like Total War, treat it like what it is: art. Pour yourself into it, and make it something you're proud of.If you treat it like a business, your product will rot and you'll be left with a brand that leaves a bitter taste in fans' mouths. Of course I'm sure the ones making all the bad decisions will receive their golden parachutes, and go on ruining other projects. But this franchise could have been something incredible if it had been done right.Thanks for everything, Creative Arts. It was.. enlightening. Enjoy the hundreds (thousands?) I gave you over the years.

review: 2023 Update April 2024 I decided to change my recommendation to positive in view of recent news regarding layoffs at CA, the rampant rumors around Total War: Warhammer III being scaled down from what was originally planned, and lastly because the additions to Shadows of Change were pretty good. Despite the fact that multiplayer campaigns barely function, despite the random CTD's, units having seriously bad pathfinding around gates and ladders, Warriors of Chaos and Cathay tech not working properly, or that there are heroes with not enough skills to put their skill points into, I still love this game. A lot of that love lies in thanks to the modding community, but the love and work that CA the Warhammer team have put into it is undeniable.Finally, a message to SEGA. Do not let this game die before it gets a chance to redeem itself The whole reason we're here is due to CA leadership being incompetent, out of touch, greedy dirtbagsPunish them, not the game that makes money despite their best efforts to gun it down while it's laying the golden eggs. Update Feb 2024Since I posted this review, CA made a public statement "apologizing" (quotes because the wording of the apology was very corporate and didn't really make the point of owning up to mistakes) but also promising to be better. In this vein, they cut the price of Total War: Pharaoh, refunded all owners, and promised to add content to Shadows of Change to match the asking price. This all happened in late December. They are currently coming out with a series of blog posts detailing the added units/lords/heroes in every race (at the time of writing this, only Cathay and Tzeentch are out) and the update is due next week. However, I will not be changing my recommendation yet, as this whole ordeal has been going on since the game was released. I'd like to have them be consistently good for a good long while before I can honestly recommend the game. Plus, it's still riddled with bugs. Original Review in November I'm sorry, as many hours of entertainment this game, which I truly love, has given me, I cannot in good conscience recommend it. Unfortunately, Creative Assembly have been treating it as a money maker that will always make money no matter what, essentially abandoning it in the process. Their idea of "support" is to let a haggard, poor dlc team of, I would wager, less than twenty people to maintain, patch, AND produce content, while at the same time increasing prices to absurd amounts for lesser quality content than for every other dlc ever. In the meantime, as the team is stretched super thin, glaring problems (which the community has addressed in mere days via mods) have been left in the game for months at a time. Imagine buying a faction dlc focused on a specific unit, and that faction being completely unable to recruit said unit FOR THREE ENTIRE MONTHS.And to top things off, they came out with a statement as a response to community backlash for the latest price increase, basically saying "we want more money, buy the dlc or we drop support entirely" Tldr: CA have abandoned this game. QA is non-existent, major bugs are in the game for months on end, and CA came out with an ultimatum to buy the dlc at an absurd price or they'll drop support.

review: 2023 I've updated my review to reflect the good work CA have made over the last few patches. You can no longer win a siege by sneaking in some units via the backdoor, you are no longer required to defend 2 completely different areas of the base in order to successfully repel a siege.There is still a massive issue with AI being far too passive, they no longer build massive empires. The AI no longer confederates (even the Empire rarely seems to confederate their elector counts) which prevents any factions becoming powerful. This might be ok for lower difficulties but Legendary players need more of a challenge. I also can't say how much I despise them making all minor factions just free wins for the AI. The glorious re-playability of WH2 was finding out who survived to the mid/end game. Now it's the same factions every single playthrough as they removed the ability for minor factions to sometimes get the upper hand on their larger rivals. Finding Marienburg had wiped out the Empire or Mousillon had conquered Bretonnia was the joy of starting a new campaign. There's none of that now, bring back aggressive AI empires and none whipping boy minor factions and you've restored my faith.

review: 2022 New factions are fine addition to Total War Warhammer, however the campaign itself is absolute ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. Game really discourages you from fighting the other factions and expanding. Also somehow they made sieges even worse now. I don't think it's a good idea that you can build towers etc in middle of the battle. I think they should only be done in battle preparation phase. Guess I just have to resort to autoresolve the siege battles. At least they made Military Alliances somewhat useful now as you can build outposts and recruit units from your allies so that's cool I guess. ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Man, I really dig the new update. Added late game encounters is really darn pog system which i'm looking forward to. However it still baffles me that siege battles remained the same, they're the worst dogshite they came up with. Whether it's "unlimited" tower ranges or being able to build towers mid combat, that's just ♥♥♥♥ game design imo. I played as Volkmar and generally loved the campaign. I just wish it was easier to get special units from elector counts. When I unlocked 4 books out of 8, the late game event usually starts at that time, and elector count units practically become "obsolete" or come in way too late to make any difference in campaign. + It takes way too long to recruit more of them. I wish you could recruit them through military alliances maybe? Or simply just lower the cooldown for the special units.

review: 2023 Hundreds of hours and almost every single DLC purchased at full price since TW:WH 1. I'd love it if I could convince my friends to play. Lately I wouldn't want to, even if I could. Responding to the community with patronizing language and blaming increased costs (without acknowledging those costs certainly aren't going toward THIS game's future), with a track record of abandoning games and broken promises to the playerbase is a great reason for CA leadership to change career paths. Senior executives really don't have that much meaningful good they can do, but they sure can do some damage. Give your dev team more money and time. Stop plucking the golden goose.For a deeper dive: DLC as of writing this tops out at $260. That alone should make anyone new to the franchise wince. A new person would be playing pared down, outright incomplete, or unbalanced versions of a very small percentage of the total game. Mods would help, some. But CA doesn't pay modders.Further Problems I have recommending:1. Updates and core upkeep of the game: anything that is not DLC gets very very little attention. Includes everything from bugfixes to balancing (especially for single player), new free content, QoL passes especially on older factions.2. Reworks of non-DLC factions are few and far between, and each DLC introduction seems to get implemented without accounting for how it impacts existing factions. Includes obvious things like broken faction mechanics going unpatched for weeks or months, but also basic campaign "is it fun" sniff tests (the least fun campaign starts happened from neglect as DLC was added), under the hood core gameplay mechanics (diplomacy, trade) addressed or overhauled for DLC lords or factions but left 2010 "functional" for the rest, AI cheats in lieu of meaningful challenge etc. Even map design.3. Modding community left to carry the load for creative reworks and revisits, QoL changes, fun factor.4. The reason for all the negative reviews currently: three lords for three of the least played factions makes sense on a corporate balance sheet. It even made me hope that it would include reworks and comprehensive retooling of the factions in question as a whole to make them more attractive to play. Win win for CA and the player base. Without that, without -well implemented- unique new mechanics, core faction overhauls...but maybe even WITH that, frankly, the three factions I would be least excited to see a DLC for, one lord each... $25 was always going to be a stretch, especially without FreeLC or meaningful changes to other factions or universal mechanics. But for friends new to the game? For friends who stopped playing looking for an excuse to dust this game off? This is part of a trend that has me wanting nothing to do with the company OR this game in particular.

review: I absolutely cannot understand why there are so many rave reviews for this game. In my opinion, to get straight to the point: Blackmyth Wukong is a solid game but by no means outstanding or a Game of the Year contender.First, the positive aspects:- Graphics & Atmosphere: This cannot be taken away from the game. The graphics are by far the best I have ever seen in a game. The texture details, the light-shadow balance, and the general look of the game are simply breathtaking.The animations are incredibly well done; for example, the animation changes when you swing into an attack from a dodge move compared to a normal attack. This creates a high level of realism and atmosphere.- Soundtrack: The soundtrack is wonderfully composed and greatly enhances the boss fights and overall atmosphere.- Cinematic Presentation and Cutscenes: The animations at the end of a chapter are absolute masterpieces. (Though I didn’t understand how 4 out of 6 of them relate to the story, but fine), and the cutscenes during a fight (like in the intro or the final boss) are top-notch. This was actually the main reason why I found the game so cool.- AAA Title without Extra Costs: Few to no bugs, no cost traps, no additional content locked behind a paywall.The negative aspects:- Story: I have no knowledge of Chinese mythology and therefore perceived the story accordingly. The intro is absolutely fantastic, it really hooked me, and I was highly motivated to learn who these “gods” are, the “court,” and how to fight them. Unfortunately, this becomes completely irrelevant. You go through chapter after chapter searching for relics, and each chapter basically contains its “own” storyline. The storylines are neither interesting nor exciting. Even when you develop a connection or interest in a certain aspect of the story, the chapter ends and a different, new storyline with new characters begins. There are very few characters that span across multiple chapters. As a result, at least for me, I had no motivation to continue playing. The end of the game is, in my eyes, completely nonsensical in terms of the story and only underscores how cryptic, disjointed, and boring the story is. I feel like the game is trying hard to be like Elden Ring but fails to deliver the story like FromSoftware does.- Map and Level Design: The level design is complete garbage. You wander around for hours, there is no map, and you constantly get lost. Most of the time, the places also look so similar to each other that you almost can’t find your way around anymore. Since the game relies on very few HUD indicators (which I generally think is cool), you don’t know where to go and get lost even more. This wouldn’t be a problem if the world at least gave you a reason to explore: It doesn’t. Everything you loot consists of crafting materials. These give no motivation for exploration. Armor and weapons are only unlocked as part of the story and cannot be found in any chests.The fact that invisible walls border the map doesn’t make it any better, as you often think, "Oh, it must continue over there," and then you run into an invisible wall. In my opinion, that doesn’t belong in an AAA title.- Bosses & Gameplay: The bosses are a topic of their own. Firstly, apart from the intro, the final boss, and a few exceptions, I find all bosses to be completely forgettable. They are boring, there are waaaay too maaaany of them, and they look boring too. In 90% of cases, it's a human with some animal head. Don’t get me wrong; their attacks and all the visuals are more than fantastic. But if you think you’re getting bosses like FromSoftware delivers, you’re in the wrong place.The gameplay is one of the biggest criticisms for me. Extremely monotonous and boring, especially for a game with at least 20 hours of playtime. The combos are very limited (feels like there are about three of them), and you do the same thing all the time. This not only looks boring in the long run but almost killed my desire to play. The dodging feels very satisfying but also partially very random. Often, it happened that a boss clearly hit me with an ability, and I dodged a second later, but the game registered it as a perfect dodge. Also, the hitboxes are so random; I don't know if these are bugs or just poor hitbox design. And when you've been hammering away at a boss with the same three moves for 15 minutes and then die from a hit that clearly misses, you lose your mind. Or you fight a boss who spends 90% of the time flying and is unhittable, and you're basically playing a dodge simulator.- Difficulty: As a big Soulslike fan, I love that the game is not easy. But it's a different kind of difficulty compared to the Souls series, for example. Elden Ring feels very fair in its difficulty. You learn the bosses’ patterns, their moves, and abilities, and you make it on your 50th try. In Wukong, I did not get that feeling. The game is certainly not easy, but it’s not really "fun difficult" either. It feels artificially hard when every boss rushes at you with endless combos, or every second boss turns invisible, or creates six copies of itself, or ten tornadoes that sweep across the map, and just touching one catapults you into the air while you still have to dodge the boss itself. Most of the time, the bosses have AoE attacks and love to dash across the entire map at you. This feels artificially and unfairly difficult. It’s like saying, "Minecraft is the hardest game because you spawn with a wooden sword in a 10x10 room against 100 Endermen." That’s not fun hard; that’s boring and lazy. That’s how the bosses in Wukong feel.I am very, very disappointed after having looked forward to this game so much. You can really see—and I never want to deny this—how much love went into making this game. But sometimes passion and love alone are not enough.

review: 2022 I am huge fan of Souls game, so i was so hyped. For me this game is most worthy for that anticipation of 3 years of date. When i first heard on E3 in 2019 of this game i thought it will be good Souls game, but after they announced freemode and stuff i've had great hope that this will be most rated game ever. I can tell you that 48 hours before game was released i was counting every second of it and when i saw from early reviewers ratings for game seconds got just double up longer. DirectX 12 is breaking every game so this one hits it to with bad peformance, but still game is playable and we haved issue with even more games with peformances of DX12.Game on PC with AMD configuration for me is peforming well without any issue of FPS drops or stuttering, but i see alot of ppl having that issue only on Intel and Nvidia.I don't have alot of hours in this game so for now these are My Ratings:Soundtrack: 10+/10 (I gave on previous souls games 10/10, but this one is really special)Gameplay: 10/10Graphics: 10/10Physics: 10/10 (This is probably causing alot of FPS issue, but still ragdolls and physics in game are so satisfying)Map exploration: 10/10 (There is alot of places that needs to be explored and game is much longer for real souls players now)Boss Fights: 10/10Character Customizaton: 10/10Online Mode: 10/10 (Multiplayer comparing to others is much better and there is alot of improvment, cheaters doesn't exist)My final thoughts about this game: Game is good and it will probably be GOTY for this year, so who ever like challenges and tough boss fights he should try this game. After additional nearly 300 hours and 100% achievments i can confirm this game is worth giving a try and to spend alot time on exploring.

review: Counter Strike 2 – A Haven for Hackers?As a long-time Counter Strike player, I am deeply frustrated with the current state of Counter Strike 2. Despite its potential, the game is plagued by hackers.Hackers Everywhere:You can hardly join a lobby without encountering multiple hackers.They blatantly use wallhacks and aimbots, delivering headshots through smokes as if they weren’t there, ruining the experience for everyone else.Inadequate Measures by Steam/VALVE:Despite numerous reports, Steam / VALVE seem to take no effective action. The report button feels useless, serving more as a decorative element in the interface ?!Loss of Game Quality:The fun and challenge that the game once offered are gone. Instead, most of the time is spent being annoyed by obvious cheaters and hoping that VALVE will finally take effective action.Conclusion:Counter Strike 2 has potential, but the hacker problem is destroying it.VALVE needs to implement effective anti-cheat measures urgently. Until then, it's questionable if investing time in this game is worthwhile...

review: Alright, listen up, people! I just played Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine 2, and let me tell you, it’s an absolute spectacle. Imagine a world where chaos reigns, and you’re the unstoppable force. Yeah, that’s what it feels like!First off, the graphics? Stunning. The environments are drenched in that grimdark aesthetic we all crave. You step onto the battlefield, and it’s like stepping into a painting, only this one’s drenched in blood and glory. You can almost taste the power oh, how I love that taste!Now, the gameplay. It’s intense, brutal, and oh-so-satisfying. You’re a Space Marine superhuman, unstoppable. You charge into the fray, and every swing of your weapon feels like a symphony of destruction. The visceral combat? It’s poetry in motion, folks. You’re not just playing; you’re dominating.And let’s talk about the enemies. These guys are nothing but fodder for your glorious rampage. You’re the hero, the legend, the one everyone looks up to. You know what they say: if you’re not fighting for humanity, what are you even doing?In the end, Space Marine 2 isn’t just a game; it’s an experience. It’s a reminder that power is everything, and in this universe, you’re either a god or you’re dust. So, grab your chainsword and unleash chaos! This is what it means to be a Space Marine.Remember, if you want to be a hero, you’d better be ready to step into the fire and trust me, it’s glorious!

review: 2022 FromSoftware not only integrated all the different core mechanics that they have created through the years but also added some basic(crouch, jump) and new mechanics(spirit summoning, guard counter) to enhance the core gameplay deeply. If you are new to the FromSoftware's souls formula this game is the most accessible title you can ever get. There were some optimization issues here and there but it wasn't that game-breaking at least for me. Fromsoft's artwork as fine as ever. Sometimes you just stop your companion Torrent and take a look at The Erdtree's greatness and magnificence and you might say "Holy S*** this game looks beautiful" despite the fact that graphical quality has never been FromSoftware's primary concern. Mounted combat is the best one I have ever seen in any game. Torrent can do double jump and this made the mounted combat far more enjoyable than I expected. Although I have to admit sometimes it gets frustrating because some bosses can knock you off from Torrent with one hit. Spirit summoning is fun and all but some bosses are way too hard(Malenia, Godfrey, Radagon,) without summons especially for melee users. They have lots of AoE(Area of Effect) movesets and insane health and stamina pool. Sometimes bosses never stop attacking. If you do use spirit summons you don't feel rewarded(at least in my case) after destroying Malenia with +10 Tear Mimic. Even though the bosses aren't that great I loved their themes that's for sure. Fromsoftware's one of the signatures is the boss themes. Even the ambience music tries to tell you a story. As soon as you entered the Caelid you know you are in a rotted and corrupted place to its very core because of the ambience music. Overall, Elden Ring exceeded its predeccessor and changed the meaning of "open-world" and "difficulty"From Software's magnum opus.Thank you for this beautiful piece of art.

review: Honestly Game of the Year 2024. This is what Triple A gaming at 60$ should deliver! And I agree, this sends a big message to Budding Chinese Developers and Worldwide that Singleplayer games ARE PROFITABLE. With how prevalent Gacha Games and Online games are, Hopefully this is a wake up call to invest more into this instead of Gacha and the like. As for the challenge, since im no Dark Souls fan, im more of Different Difficult Game fan (mostly rhythm games) however, this is properly paced and balanced. There are times where camera and weird large AOE hitboxes are frustrating to deal with but the defensive options are very lenient. Havent encountered a boss that took me more than 10 tries to take out. Especially I want to share the Peak moment was (SPOILERS) when I fought the Heavenly Kings and the fight blurred between Cinematic and Gameplay and everything flowed so smoothly. It was an experience! A few nitpicks tho like getting from point A to point B is pretty slow. especially when chapter map sizes open up. The need for the Mount which is the Cloud should've been there early at least. Encountered a bug where a higher quality in Global Illumination, turns off sun shadows and lighting unless I pick it at low. I wish the lore bits in the journal are just descriptive of why and how the characters are what they are instead of some story snippets.

review: 2022 For the first time, I am doing a revised review for a game. Originally, I had given this game a negative review because I felt the cons outweighed the pros. But after patch 1.03 and continuing to play the game, I feel Elden Ring deserves a revised review which I will be giving it a positive score. However, I do have plenty of cons to mention regardless.Graphics:Game is breathtaking to look at. So many moments of me wanting to take a screenshot and enjoy the scenery of it all. Even the 'worst' of places in Elden Ring still looks great, and the visuals are top notch. Out of all the From Software games, they really made this game incredible on the eyes. Absolutely jaw dropping to say the least.Gameplay:Soul games have always been linear and well designed, so I was afraid of how From Software would handle an open world. Gotta say, they did a very excellent job. You can pretty much almost go anywhere you'd like with a few exceptions, and Elden Ring took all previous games before it and placed them all into this one, the best traits anyways. So much variety of builds to go with, a lot of ways to fight, Ashes of War are incredible since they truly spice up combat and the fact you can fight while on horseback is so fun overall. Also every part of the world is filled with something- not a single place is empty. So many secrets, discoveries, unique bosses, and hidden lore that it is brimming. I'm very impressed to say the least.Also which ever employee came up with Spirit Summons, give them a raise. They're a super fun concept and the best solution if you somehow can't (or unwilling) to play online. Fantastic concept and well executed for sure.Difficulty:It's a Souls like, it is going to be hard. While I would even say Elden Ring is the hardest Souls yet, the devs have given people so many ways in approaching a fight. The game rewards players for exploring, getting stronger, finding better weapons or loot, and coming back to a boss to overcome it. While some builds are far superior depending on what you optimize, every build is good enough and so long as you're experienced and patient, the game can be beaten even with a lvl 1 character. It's all about how you go about a fight and learn from your mistakes.NPCs and Quests:Perhaps the most depth of any previous Souls game as well, since there's so many NPCs to interact with, telling a story, having quests, and these ones actually move around the world which impacts the story. Some will be more of a fan favorite than others, but each NPC is well written and I definitely loved their dynamics, including the fact some outright help you in fights you would of otherwise struggled with. Doing and completing their quest lines not only rewards you with loot, but can even lead to changes and some secrets that wouldn't be possible otherwise.Cons:So ... despite Elden Ring is a very good game, great even- there are a lot of issues I have with the game even after patch 1.03 which fixed or improved the problems I had beforehand.Vagueness:To explain, the game gives little to no hints on how to progress certain NPC quests, what they'll do next, where to go at times (apart from main mandatory bosses), key items, very essential items, and so forth. I understand Souls games in the past have held back secrets but because they were linear, it was easy to check every corner and not miss too much. Here? The game is open world and the devs went out of their way to hide a lot of stuff, to the point you WILL need a guide or go into NG+. While I get they want you to replay their game and invest, it isn't properly executed. I know fans will say it rewards players for discovering stuff on their own, but the fact there's no quest markers, completion entries, or anything to let you know who's gone where, it takes me out of the game by a lot since I hate missing stuff.Multiplayer:So this is a big one. I can't seem to co-op with friends, much at all. I can help strangers but if I use a password, game often disconnects me or downright crashes. Then you have people who are cheating often in PvP, using the most meta stuff that makes you die instantly (bleed builds ...) and honestly it doesn't feel like the devs balanced it well at all. The game is amazing in PvE, but PvP? Very unstable and not exactly good. Only plus side is helping those struggling with a boss but that's if the game lets me do so. No other game in my library has this issue with me doing multiplayer.Crashes and Stutters:Game will at times crash or stutter hard. It is at random, and nothing fixes it. I am not too upset due to the fact it isn't often, but when it does happen- it is quite terrible to experience. My graphics card is up to date, newer version, and again no other game in my library (besides infamous Skyrim) has this problem. I personally think they need to do more patches to fix this since so many are facing this issue still.Meta:This game is obsessed with certain builds, as they're very strong and can make the fight trivial even. If you do a bleed build or hyper magic build, you will destroy both PvE and PvP. If you do a strength build, you are hindering yourself sadly as so many enemies are fast, hit harder, and can tank against your heavy hits. Also some Ashes of War are outright broken. Also the meta for this game is very off putting- rather than earning your stuff, you can easily run around collecting upgrades and get your weapon to +9 or even 10 before killing a single boss. I know you don't have to do this, but knowing it's possible makes me wonder why handicap myself and struggle when I can just be overpowered off the start. I'd rather struggle and be forced to like previous games, even if there was cheese-like methods this game has too many opportunities to make you feel you need to be meta to just keep up in PvE and PvP.Conclusion:Game is great, very good I would say. A lot of downsides, with mostly it hiding important information and key items from you, forcing you to scout and possibly become overpowered to just win early. Not exactly the best, but for those who like to do whatever- it does benefit those people since they can just get to level 45, 10+ weapon before fighting the first boss (after the tutorial boss). Game's balance is questionable, and a lot of issues with multiplayer with meta and disconnections / crashes. But otherwise, game is very fun, engaging, has so much content, awesome bosses, and so much variety to the builds if you don't want to be meta. I am giving this a positive score but it was close to still being negative like the first review I did.Still hoping DLC comes out for this game i'm waiting with baited breath!

review: 2022 I had enormous expectations having put a thousand hours into Dark Souls 3 alone. Sadly, ER is tainted by design decisions not fully thought through, and a refusal to question the ideals of a framework first established with Demon’s Souls in 2009, and I ended it wishing I hadn't played it at all (more on this later) - or that Steam would finally add a neutral rating.For context, excluding a discarded run and multiplayer, my completionist and almost entirely guide-free solo run lasted around 150 hours, beating every boss barring Malenia without summons.Let’s open positively: Elden Ring inherits DS3’s DNA, particularly combat: The same crunchy brawls, responsive controls and top-tier animations that characterised DS3, aided by expanded enemy, weapon, and ability variety with magic being more diverse than ever.From’s signature storytelling returns, requiring piecing together environmental details, item descriptions and other vague information to decipher the full picture, avoiding interminable cutscenes or overbearing HUD notifications.The Lands Between is geographically impressive. It fuses aesthetically and mechanically diverse biomes into vertiginously stacked layers, threading interesting discoveries through challenging navigation, aided by a time of day and weather system that adds subtle gameplay changes.So why the thumbs down?DS3 is great because it’s meaningful. It’s an incredible fantasy brawler, but shines with its premise of a cursed world having its blighted existence artificially prolonged by an age of fire unnaturally lengthened by Gwyn and his tragic legacy’s followers. The Ringed City DLC literally warped and smashed the series together until only ash remained at the end of the world and time itself in a manifestation of cosmic decay from a realm prohibited from moving on. Its creatively defiant metacommentary rejected a pop culture engorged on commercialised nostalgia and humanity’s obsession with the past impeding a new, better world being built, using From’s own ludography to show stagnation blocking progress. It had to innovate to avoid hypocrisy, so it repurposed old combat mechanics and weaponry into new rhythms, and tonally shifted from quiet hope in the face of graceful sadness to crushing desperation - not to fix its cursed world, but to euthanise it and start anew instead - while retaining the series’ unrelenting melancholy and heart of gold.ER ignores that. It retroactively invalidates DS3’s message of moving on from an unsustainably tired world by repurposing years of content, and when it does deviate, it does so uncharacteristically clumsily for From. This is why I wish I hadn’t played it: DS3 made me laugh, cry, and stuck in my mind for years, and was ultimately about something bigger than itself - and powerfully resonated for it. ER contradicts DS3’s critique of wheel-spinning by indulging repackaged nostalgia in the same way Disney’s maligned Star Wars trilogy has left people feeling worse towards the franchise than if no new films had been made at all.The story is shockingly conservative, with almost identical plot points, settings, characters, and themes to From’s back catalogue. We again have well-intended rulers cursing the world in an attempt to save it, religious fundamentalists, spurned vengeful offspring, agents of chaos, and a tarnished (now literally!) player enforcing a new world order. The biggest change is a bloated chain of divine command, expanding DS' demigods with Empyrians, Fingers, the Elden Beast, aliens, and cosmic gods, but it brings few new ideas. This is the reanimated corpse of a concluded story that meta-commented on such narrative necromancy, and is immensely disappointing for it. Worse, what little new exists is often explicit and definitive, trading the intriguing mystery of DS’s nebulous motivations and history that still produce seismic theories a decade later, for a story nearly entirely resolvable in a single playthrough.There is a tonal shift from quiet tragedy to bellicose grandeur of divine infighting exploding into total warfare - but if anything interferes with deep emotional investment, it’s unlikeable middle managers arguing over who deserves the office promotion. Conflict between irredeemable villains is a far cry from the turbulent power of DS’s Greek tragedy, particularly in a setting largely morally binary and with a less charismatic cast. Standouts like Rya or Blaidd don't impact like Solaire’s devastating misfortune or Siegward’s surprising nobility. Characters were the emotional core of DS, but are neutered here by worn tropes and the meandering pacing inherent to open worlds.Gameplay is also a missed opportunity. DS3’s combat is great, but Sekiro’s is easily the best ever in a game of its type - yet we’re back to DS3’s unbalanced weapon classes and abilities, inconsistent magic, and same old movesets, lacking Sekiro’s thrilling posture and counters mechanics. Dual wielding, ashes of war and guard counters are small improvements rather than an overhaul that had six years to materialise, and the camera is as bad as ever. Content suffers from repetition too: Dungeons keep cropping, with the same music, bosses and presentation, occupying a huge chunk of a completionist’s playthrough, and the non-dungeon biomes feel interminable as you’re incentivised to be extremely thorough in these needlessly enormous areas in search of equipment, lore, and quests.Quests are as obtuse as everyone’s saying, borderline impossible to complete without guides, a From staple magnified by the overwhelmingly gigantic map diluting quality even further. ER’s first areas are exciting, but fifty hours in become tedious, particularly with the second half’s environments primarily being single-level plains with occasional repeated giant assets.The initially impressive scope grows tiresome in its enormity, and leads to a game that’s harder to balance and populate with unique content, particularly evident in the later difficulty spikes and clearly unfinished areas and encounters, including final bosses that pale in comparison to the thematic or mechanical significance of DS3’s Soul of Cinder and Slave Knight Gael. Bosses are just bad across the board: Most movesets chain four or five attacks together leave you waiting for an opening far longer than actually fighting, and many require specific builds to overcome damage sponges, homogenising combat into a wait - wait - wait - wait - single attack - wait loop. ~150 bosses is too many for From to make each interesting, fair, memorable, or downright enjoyable.ER’s multiplayer is also From’s worst since DS1. Hits can sometimes take over ten seconds to register and disconnects prevail. Reduced summon counts neuters fight clubs, invasions are overly unbalanced and spawns are terrible, and with covenants gone, so too are the emergent player dynamics and roleplay.Finally, ER’s presentation is mixed. Its style is outstanding: Characters are strikingly creative and full of personality, environments are dense with detail, and sound effects are as satisfying as ever, though the music rarely reaches DS3’s heights and is often repeated. But From’s ambition far outpaced their technical capacity: ER is graphically antiquated, but the elephant in the room is the worst shader compilation stutter in years, paired with disappointing framerates, considerable crashing, and cheating aplenty. The stutter single-handedly ruined the first third of my playthrough, dissipating after about 70 hours but never fully resolving, and is bad enough to alone make this review a thumbs down.ER wavers between being a retread of old ideas and a failed attempt at new ones. It's such a missed opportunity. If all you want is killing enemies in brutal combat, it’s great - the DS template alone earns ER inherited praise - but if you’re after an emotionally and philosophically challenging story, pick up DS instead.★★★☆☆

review: First off, this game has been an absolute joy to play. The story missions are fantastic, and the cinematics really enhance the experience. The way the operations work in tandem with the missions is also impressive. I highly recommend tackling the story missions in order with the operations; doing all the operations first can spoil the storyline.I’ve maxed out two classes and can comfortably handle the hardest difficulty with ease. While the PvP aspect is a bit slow-paced by design and I haven’t invested many hours into it, it hasn’t been particularly engaging.Unfortunately, I’m nearing the end of my time with the game, aside from maxing out a few more classes and helping friends. I really hope they add another couple of difficulties beyond the upcoming lethal mode, as well as some extra challenging enemies during missions. I wish I could experience the first 15 hours of the game again.Replayability is somewhat lacking due to the limited number of operations and the absence of significant challenges once you reach level 15 on any class. The excitement starts to wane after completing the story and operations.It’s also disappointing that the horde mode isn’t coming until 2025. However, I would definitely recommend this game. Just don’t expect it to be a staple in your gaming routine; once you’ve completed the story and operations, there isn’t much left to keep you engaged.Overall, I’d give it a 9/10. ❤️

review: Product received for free I got this game for free as a promotion with a graphics card I bought, I hadn't watched any trailers for it and never really looked into it. I went in with no expectations or hype whatsoever, and frankly I don't get it.The game has terrible level design, you are bound to hit an invisible wall (even if the place you are trying to reach is part of the level, sometimes there's just an invisible wall to prevent you from going there from a specific angle for some reasons) no matter where you go, the paths are also not intuitive, I was actually going around the level trying to find what I had missed only to find out that there was a small gap to crawl in to progress hidden inside a cave, there was nothing to tell me this was there, I found it by pure chance, the combination of the invisible walls, non-intuitive levels and the lack of a map to find those paths on makes exploring very frustrating.The combat feels wrong, sometimes you do an input mid-roll and the character does the move related to that input right after the roll, and sometimes he does not, heavy attacks have ridiculous delay to them which makes them feel terrible to use. In some fights, you could start a heavy attack before the boss starts his attack and get punished anyway. You barely do any damage to bosses and kill regular enemies way too easily, which makes the bosses the only actual challenge, well except for actually finding them, unfortunately the bosses have terrible arena designs and sometimes attack fast enough to get you with a follow-up attack right after your dodge. The story relies way too much on the base material, if you have not read the book, none of it makes sense.The game does look pretty, but if its not fun then why would I play it.

review: 2023 It’s a sad day when I have to write this review. TWWH is, in my very humble opinion, the best strategy game/trilogy of all time. There are grander strategies, I.E. the paradox titles, and there are more accessible titles, I.E. the Civ series. But no game does it quite like this one. Let me get my thoughts out the way, and then I’ll explain why I can’t recommend the game, although I’m sure you’ve already heard, despite me loving this title so dearly. Let’s start by saying, this is a good game. Phenomenal even. At it’s core, it’s in every sense of the word, fun. It can be brutally challenging, but is far more accessible than many of the paradox titles for example. I’ve dipped in and out of a range of strategy games (not just on steam, but Epic, GoG and growing up playing CD copies of games I still own to this day), and generally speaking, I love the genre. I grew up playing Age of Empires and Warcraft 3 before moving away from RTS games in favour of more 4X style games. Eventually moving onto grand strategy such as Total War. And let me tell you what a blast this has been. I adore this game, I’ve spent many nights up until 5/6am, just playing “one more turn!” And being late for work the following morning because I was so tired I just overslept. I’ve sat watching videos on my lunch breaks from Legend and General, I’ve fallen asleep to Total war streams, having it consume my life for a period of time. And I don’t regret a single second of it. I’ve bought copies of it full price for my friends to play so I can share that experience with others and bring them into this community. And I mention this because despite my low playtime, I genuinely love this game, and even when I’m not playing it, I’m consuming it in whatever ways I can, or being that annoying friend who pushes you to do the same. But why? Why do I think so highly of it? Well there’s just no experience quite like it. It’s easy to learn, hard to master. Despite what perceptions of it are, it’s incredibly easy to pick up and play, even if it’s a little confusing at first. The in game tutorial does a really excellent job of just teaching you the core of what you need to know, and the rest of it you’ll pick up as you play. Unlike a paradox game, it doesn’t feel like you need a YouTube guide open as mandatory training while you play (although I suppose that subjective based on skill and patience). All my research and external work has been because I’m invested and the game is so good, that it incentivises you to learn, not because it’s too complicated for it’s own good, but just because I want to improve and get better on my own terms. And unlike more casual games like Civ, where after a campaign or two, you just go through the motions, you actually have to keep atleast a small part of your brain switched on. Even at lower difficulties, you will get smashed by what can often feel like incredibly unfair AI. The game actually ends up almost feeling rogue like in nature, you play 20 turns, realise you messed up at turn 15, and then start again, using the knowledge you gained to progress further, this time getting to turn 40 and realising you made a mistake or didn’t account for something on turn 35 and repeating. It’s an incredible loop that never gets dull or boring based simply on the fact that every faction plays so uniquely to each other. From Skarbrand’s all out blitzkrieg on anything In sight, to my new personal favourite, Empire campaigns, where you slowly build up and out, playing politics and managing multiple states of affairs. I firmly believe there is a faction for anyone and everyone, and you WILL find something or someone you like in this game. I’m going to brush over gameplay and such, because I won’t lie, it’s great. As the ancient Chinese say, “It Just Works”. The overworld map is basically a relatively simple 4x style game. You have cities, ruins, towns etc, various sizes locations you can colonise to control regions, before setting out and conquering or politicking your way into others. There’s not much to say to it. It’s big, it’s fun, it’s a paint the map in your colour type of ordeal that isn’t particularly unique to this game. And then there’s the battles, where the game just blows you away. Hundreds and later at times thousands of individual units, all modelled and animated smashing into each other in the RTS style battles. You can watch as a giant T-Rex smashes it’s way through tiny little nurglings, small creatures that clump together to make large monstrosities, all while your massive great unclean one charges into ranks of lizardmen before tactically chundering and excreting all over them. It’s phenomenal and if you’re the type of person to watch AI battles on YouTube, you’ll absolutely adore it. Hundreds of battle maps, hundreds of unique units, with thousands of animations (I’m sorry I didn’t count each one but there’s a lot!). It’s immense in scale and spectacle in a way no other franchise can really rival. And most importantly, it’s fun! Winning feels great, but losing doesn’t feel bad when you watched as packs of rat men slowly swarm your empire city, each man holding the line as best they can, faith and steel binding them. It’s exciting and gorgeous. I’ve never enjoyed getting my ass handed to me so much. But onto why I can’t recommend the game. Two reasons, with one being an ongoing issue in the state of DLC, and the other being the recent actions by the developer. DLC for this game is kind of egregious. There’s going to be people who say, just buy the ones you want, but I’m not a huge fan of that mentality. The main draw of these games specifically is the immortal empires map, where all the factions across all three games play on one unified map. It’s huge, and really brings the grand into grand strategy. It’s a spectacle and genuinely an incredible feat, with 200+ factions on the map. However, of the around 80 playable lords, buying Warhammer 3 alone, only gives you access to around 15/20, which is a lot of gameplay don’t get me wrong, but with around half of those being chaos themed, and the rest being a take your pick between Slavic stew or ancient Asian hotpot, there’s not all that much variety in terms of visuals and aesthetic. To get the full experience and have the choice of playing whatever you want, you need to pay out hundreds of pounds just to get every dlc and every game and then every dlc for those games. It’s just all a bit much. It’s something total war fans have put up with, and it’s something I’ve financially supported due to having the disposable income and enjoying the games. However as a new player, imagine looking at the game thinking, I just want the complete experience, access to everything that’s in the game and finding out you’ll have to spend well over £200 just to have the option to play a race. And it’s not like you can try the races either, there’s no demo, and with campaigns lasting anywhere from 10 to 60 hours, you can’t try them and then just refund realistically. It’s something I looked past for a long time, but with recent events, I just can’t support this model anymore. And those recent events. You’ve heard about them, there’s a reason everyone is reviewing this negatively. Creative Assembly is now forcing unwarranted price increases on these already quite minimal DLCs. £20 (a third of the price of the game might I add) for three lords, no one was particularly excited or asking for, with very few additions other than that no real new units with issues coming with the ones they did add, serious bugs that they still refuse to fix or just ignore, and a frankly, quite disgusting response to fan criticism and feedback, vaguely threatening to cut support for the game should fans choose not to pay for the dlc. This is a company who’s revenue has increased by 20% over the last year, who release updates at a speed that it would be generous to call slow, all while claiming that they need to do this to keep up with the market
