review: ALL OPINIONS ARE BASED ON ANGEL OF DEATH DIFFICULTY PLAYED SOLO. THEY MAY NOT BE ISSUES ON LOWER DIFFICULTIES This is a good game, a game with alot of issues but I do recommend it if you are even slightly interested in WH40KCombat is pretty good, the parry system can sometimes have issues if multiple parries come up. If you time one right but then another pops up it seems to cancel it sometimes and you get hit when you were not even trying to parry the 2nd attack. The dodge always seems to work, but the problem is this game has some really wonky hitboxes so you will get hit dodging and wonder what even hit you (espicaly with bosses oh god its bad with bosses) where they have invisible hitboxes that will hit you even if you arn't even close. The Carnifex was the worst for this but its manageable.The healing system is awful on Angel of Death, the melee to restore health becomes pointless because you take so much damage you never get any back with all the enemies jumping at you. And health injectors are so rare, for many sections of the game its laughable. Your fury mode becomes the main option for healing, where you want to avoid combat and stand there and recharge but it feels counter intuitive to what it was actually meant forThe guns feel great but they sound really, really weak. I don't know if its a mixing issue or something but they lack any real oomph to them and bolters sound more like you are firing a semi automatic pistol or something and it kinda sucks, but gameplay wise I found myself using almost all the weapons at one point or another and getting results with them. Which leads to alot of experimentation and exploring the systems which is really good.There are some major bugs, some levels glitch out and you cant pickup guns or items(looking at you cargo elevator) and also sometimes the AI totally bugs out and will just refuse to rez you, they will walk towards you then get distracted and run back and forth while your meter ticks down and its infuriating. Sometimes the AI just totally loses it and will just stand still and do nothing for large periods of time. Also randomly when Acheran was giving his speech in the hanger I walked up to watch it and a space marine came up behind me and trapped me and I had to reload the entire game because I got stuck which was really random.The game falls into the trap difficulty wise what alot of games do, which is just turning things into bullet sponges that do alot of damage as opposed to real difficulty. Ghost of Tsushima mastered this, and honestly on Angel of Death if they just lowered the health pools on some enemies and kept literally everything else the same it would be way more tolerable and actually fun. Having to put 4 clips from a bolter run to get a full reload and then another couple clips into a Zoanthrope to just get it to go down becomes a point of hilarity. Although this is remedied by just having Krak grenades(which the game seems to keep forgetting you have because grenade pickups basically become extinct in the certain parts of the game)The campaign at times becomes kind of a slog when many of the major set pieces s just stand here, and do the thing that prevents meter in the top corner from going down/up. Its distracting having to watch the meter while you want to actually look at whats going on, on the screen and annoying because it feels uninspired after you do it for like the 6th time.Now all my complaints I had though, are entirely remedied with the sections of the game with the jetpacks. I honestly think they should of just built the entire game as Assault Troops because it feels amazing. The quick movement to escape hordes, jumping in and out of melee, picking off enemies in the air. It feels like thats how the game should be played. It almost turns into a doom-esque with how fast paced it becomes and its glorious. The pvp is also fantastic and I think if they keep updating with maps and unlockables it has a real leg to stand on.Games like a solid 7.5 maybe 8/10 because I am a biased fan

review: 2022 A fantastic game FromSoftware, probably the best game they've ever made alongside Bloodborne. While the gameplay formula mainly stays the same, they expanded exponentially on the world you get to play in,Unlike other Souls-like games where your options against a challenge are fairly limited such as farming up or become really good at reading a boss's movements, Elden Ring provides you with a plethora of options. You can explore the world and find new weapons, level up up, buy or find several unique items some of which are made to work against bosses like kryptonite.All in all, it's quite accessible more so than before so there's a lot to love here.That doesn't mean the game has become easy...oh no...It probably holds the largest amount of bosses in any games ever released. They're just staggering, with some of them being unique as well as recurring ones. While they do recycle a few, I have to say it doesn't take much from the experience as it gives you the feeling of growing and becoming more experienced showing that your struggle and effort was well worth your time.The items and weapons as well as magic gives so many options for so many builds and things to mess around with.You can now re-edit your character in case there's something you don't like about it as well as resetting your abilities in case you want to try out different builds. This addition was great and it doesn't mean you have to remake a different character just in case you want to try something different.The map is huge, enormous even and in any direction you will go, you will stumble upon something interesting. Those things can be either a quest, collectable crafting items, various dungeons, enemies, portals, weapons and merchants.I can't put my finger on it but this game truly has something special going for it. There are some downsides I'd like to mention that I wish they were different.First off...while, for the most part, the start of the game as well as the mid-game feels fun, challenging and everything you do is rewarding, the later parts of the game become absurdly difficult in a not-fun way.Vigor is a stat in the game and it's quite important unlike Bloodborne for instance. While Elden Ring provides you with fast moving abilities and spells, it still doesn't match Bloodborne speed....This means that the chances of getting hit are quite high unless you're going out with a shield. The thing is, enemies late game will one - two shot you and it'll make you feel that the effort you've put in the game was for naught.... it's not too bad but it's surely not fun. The exaggerated difficulty spike could've been reduced a little bit by maybe 15-20%. While the bosses are super cool, I found issues with the camera sometimes. Not too big but there are some large bosses that love to fly across your screen. The Lock On system is useless in such situations since it will mess you up. I wished they would innovate this part just a bit and take some risks such as zooming the camera out a bit.The PVP of the game is....not so good....broken builds, 1 shot, cheesing, cheating, the list goes on. You'll either love it and have a huge fun with it or...not care about that at all unless you're invaded while playing co-op. The likeness of this mode depends on the player. I don't mind that it's there, in fact it's good that it's there, it's just not for everyone. And the last negative I have to say isss....the story.It's...huge...complex, dark fantasy...but not too special. Bloodborne rocks that front...Dark Souls 3 too.And that's it... Elden Ring is a masterpiece of a game. It's not perfect, it has its flaws but the game's unique, it brings something new to the table and it'll be remembered.

review: 2014 CSGO is a near-perfect multiplayer shooter. Unlike the previous versions, which were often difficult to get in to, this one offers a variety of modes that will appeal to all skill levels. It has a large community and a well supported workshop, ensuring that this discount-priced game will be around for years to come.In short, you either play as the good or bad guys and must either kill the other team or complete objectives to win the round, which will earn you more money to do the same thing again but faster. It's been around for years and has spawned many imitators.The game isn't much of a looker as it is based on the same engine as the original Half Life 2 was. However, Valve have polished it as much as they can and the community consists of lots of awesome mappers who have been churning out brilliantly imaginative and beautiful maps almost on a daily basis.Is it worth getting if you already own Counter Strike: Source? Yes. CSS was always Counter Strike shoe-horned into the Source engine. CSGO feels far more like a standalone game. Valve have very carefully listened to what people have wanted and have made a very appealing game. The best feature must be the competitive play. You cannot leave these matches or you'll suffer a temporary ban from the feature. After 10 wins in this mode you'll be ranked and will be paired up with people of the same skill, meaning that the game is challenging but fair regardless of your skill level. These matches are exciting, occasionally scary or frustrating, but are the most rewarding part of the game and improving your rank is one of the most satisfying experiences in any video game, ever.

review: What an incredible game. I haven’t felt the want to finish a game that badly in a long time; and do as many of the achievements and things I can along the way. The combat feels great once you understand how to use the different stances together, along with spells and spirits. The story is amazing, and makes me want to watch the 1986 show and listen to the audiobook to really understand everything. That being said, Chapter 6, and one other boss in Chapter 4 are not great. The Scorpionlord, a secret boss in chapter 4, along with the first and the final bosses of the Chapter 6, just feel very unfun. There’s a lot of flying and moving and the game takes what you’ve learned through the entire game and throws it all away and even punishes you for it. Along with that, Chapter 6 feels very unfleshed and is the first instance where you see copy/paste bosses (because they are literally the same), granted they are mini bosses. In any case, I still loved this game and my time with it. I plan on going through and doing at least NG+, as there are a couple missables and I don’t think I’m that tired of the game just yet.I’d rate this a solid 8.5 or 9 out of 10 for me. Incredible, fantastic, fair (except for a few instances), thrilling, and length feels great. I am excited for a future DLC!

review: 2022 Elden Ring is an open world game set in a world ruled by demigods and populated with beautiful environments and structures, allowing for players to traverse the Lands Between, discovering secrets, engaging in battles, and mayhap get some maidens.There are some problems with the low fps being capped at 60 for PC users but there are solutions on the internet that can help rectify this issue, in addition there is also some fps stuttering at times, it can be annoying but other than that the game is still very much playable. But with that said let us get into what I think is great and what I dislike about Elden Ring.-Enemies-Bosses:The bosses are fantastic looking and have some fantastic flashy move sets, however most of the main bosses have attacks that are too fast to be dodged, insanely long combos, always have some sort of AOE attack, and always keep moving making them hard to hit with melee weapons. Malekith the black blade fits in most of these points vie stated, having ranged abilities, difficult to dodge attacks due to his wide range of attack also making it hard to run away to heal, and a DOT (damage over time) after being hit with his blade. And this trend continues for most of the bosses, making them quite unfun.Giant bosses:Giant bosses are also quite hard to battle against, it's hard to see when they are going to attack IF you’re using melee due to you needing to be up-close to the boss.Duo bosses:Duo bosses are not too fun to fight, considering that they can kill you within 2-4 hits and you now must focus your attention on 2 enemies which considerably increases the difficulty in a cheap way.Enemies:The enemies in this game are fantastic with a wide variety of epic designs making the world feel populated, however some of them are made to be quite annoying, the Rotten Stray constantly staggering you, the Lesser Kindred of Rot with their spammable ranged attack, the Bladed Talon Eagle being hard to hit for melee users and so on.Dungeons:The dungeons are fun areas to explore, containing resources that can help the player out by giving them better weapons or useful materials. However, some of the dungeons have bosses that are too large for the area it is placed in, mostly referring to the Tree Spirit enemies. Fighting in these small rooms is extremely difficult due to the combination of your third person camera, a large boss and a small room, making it quite a challenge to know what is going on, not to mention the AOE attacks this boss has that basically reach the entire room.Too long didn’t read:Bosses are too quick with too many AOE attacks to avoid, a handful of enemies are annoying to fight against, duo bosses are hard to fight without summons but possible, hard to keep track of when giant boss will attack, small areas with big bosses are hard to fight against.-Gameplay-World:The world of Elden Ring is fantastic, not needing to always rush head in towards a boss first, you can always explore and grind levels, get better equipment before trying to battle the bosses, in addition to better equipment, you can also use summons which dramatically makes the fight easier.Combat:The combat in this game is decent, having many different attacks, light attack, heavy attack, rolling light, rolling heavy, jump light, jump heavy, sprinting heavy, sprinting light, guard counter, block, parry, and unique weapon skills that can be applied to each weapon. You can also switch between two handing and one handing weapons as well as dual wielding weapons of the same type as well as mounted combat. There is also the introduction of the stance/posture system. If you are familiar with Sekiro, it is like the posture system. After hitting the enemies enough, it will cause them to stance break and leave them susceptible to critical hits, this is also applicable for bosses too. Some attacks will cause more stance damage than others such as jumping heavy attacks, counter hits and charged heavy attacks.Rolling is a little different in this game, rather than rolling on pressing the button, you roll when the button is released.Runes:Runes from bosses and enemies are a little low. The rune scaling also does not improve much for enemies when you progress to more difficult areas, but bosses do drop more runes. And the runes you get from bosses and enemies are increased permanently after NG+ as well.But aside from all these issues this game is exceptional, one of the best Maiden Pick up simulators I've ever played, a solid 9/10, definitely would recommend to anyone who wants to get into the Souls-like franchise or anyone who is a masochist.

review: Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine 2 Despite the fact that the review is positive, for me it's more of a "yellow" type of review (which I hope they will eventually add to Steam, though I’m starting to doubt it). The game looks expensive and polished, it's a good, not overly long action game set in the Warhammer universe, with excellent cutscene direction and beautiful visuals. The combat looks epic, and the gameplay on a gamepad is really well done. The joystick vibrates and even reacts to walking, giving the character in the Space Marine suit a sense of "weight." Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine 2 A Screenshot of Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine 2 By: Wooohooo However, that's where the positives end for me. Here's what really bothered me. First, the combat feels quite repetitive. While smashing enemies is fun in the first few hours, it quickly gets stale and stops being enjoyable. Moreover, I noticed that the difficulty seems a bit broken because on higher difficulty levels, combat turns into an unpleasant mess. You have to constantly spam parries, and even then, enemies will still flank you and "make your life miserable." But if you lower the difficulty just one notch, the game becomes too easy and uninteresting. Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine 2 A Screenshot of Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine 2 By: Wooohooo The variety of enemies is small, and they're pretty dull, requiring no special tactics to defeat. The multiplayer PvP mode, by the way, is terrible - I didn't like it at all, and I don't recommend it. It feels like it's just there for the sake of it.The special operations that run parallel to the story can be considered a positive aspect, as they let you try out different Space Marine classes and include some progression. However, they don't add much depth to the game, though they do make it a bit better. Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine 2 A Screenshot of Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine 2 By: Wooohooo For fans of the Warhammer universe or those who just want to switch off their brain and enjoy some action and shooting for a couple of evenings, I would recommend it. But it's best not to have high expectations, as they got in the way for me.

review: Warhammer 40K: Space Marine 2 at launch is a "good" video game that feels and looks very "bad ass" while playing it but it's also held back pretty hard in my opinion because of feeling very repetitive with gameplay that never really evolves from the first mission to the last. The game has a decent story (singleplayer or co-op) mode, good (co-op) operations and a PVP mode (which is surprisingly good) but the game at launch is missing simple modes like a survival/horde mode which feels like a no brainer for this sort of game so I can't help but feel a little bit disappointed that it's missing (among other things..)It also has some design problems in my opinion when it comes to the shield regenerator "execute enemy" system as it makes you compete with your own team mates in co-op about getting health back (if you played it you know what I'm talking about) which doesn't feel intended (but a lot more like a design flaw in the combat and health system)The 6 operations you replay over and over again at launch are not enough.So to keep it (somewhat) short.. As of right now (with the launch content) I'd give it a solid 7.5/10 but it can and likely will easily go up to a 8 or even a 9 with future content. I will definitely play more of the operations and PVP mode but for how much longer I don't know.

review: Black Myth: Wukong completely exceeded my expectations. Right from the start, the combat feels sharp and responsive, rewarding both timing and strategy. The variety of environments is staggering—each one is beautifully designed, with its own atmosphere and challenges, keeping the game feeling fresh as you move through different stages. And the boss fights? There are over 90 of them, and they aren’t just there to pad out the game. Each boss is unique and demands real attention, forcing you to adapt and perfect your approach.The skill tree is another standout feature. It’s not just there to unlock a few flashy moves—there's real depth to it. You can build your character in so many different ways, whether you want to focus on raw power, agility, or more technical skills. I loved being able to fine-tune my abilities to fit my playstyle, which made every fight feel different, even after hours of gameplay.Overall, the game kept me completely hooked. It balances challenge and reward perfectly, never feeling unfair but always pushing you to get better. If you're into action RPGs and love the feeling of mastering a complex system, Black Myth: Wukong is an experience you won't want to miss.

review: 2022 Updated Review:I came back to this game after 9 months and overall I am mildly impressed with the changes. While the game still runs like a turd on my 11700K and RTX 3070 PC, it no longer crashes and there's a lot less bugs, none of which are game-breaking (so far). Plus your mouse now works in 2k/4k fullscreen mode, though I am not sure if they fixed legacy Xbox avatars crashing servers though.They've even improved the interface in a lot of key ways. Once again red means something is being destroyed and green means something is being built on the city screen. Gone are the days of every UI element being red for the heck of it. And, while Immortal Empires is lacking in its beta form, it is there, playable, and fun.If it only ran well I would be extremely impressed. As it is, mildly impressed and I will say it is now worth buying on sale.Old Review:Come back in half a year. Game runs poorly despite hardware that drastically exceeds the recommended spec. If you're on 1440p+ your mouse probably won't work properly in fullscreen mode and windowed mode won't support your resolution so you'll have to play the game in a window that doesn't fill your screen. Then when you actually get to play you'll notice the bugs. Bugs everywhere, terrible performance, if you're on Xbox and have a legacy 360 avatar (mine was a Daedra from Oblivion), it will crash any multiplayer lobby you join as the game can't load legacy Xbox avatars lol. The UI is ugly in general, everything is red so you can't even tell if you're building or destroying something at a glance, and it has its own bugs too—but PCGamer gave the game a 90 and IGN gave it 9/10 so whatever, I'm glad critics enjoy a barely functional game with a staggeringly ugly interface.

review: 2022 It's amazing. It's everything you've heard. It's open world Dark Souls. Please play this game.However.... I'm quitting before the end. Here's why, as briefly as I can put it:It's too hard. Not like, oh it's challenging git gud. I'm feeling like when I die, I didn't cheat the system or find the right cheese rather than build any skill for the next fight. review: 2023 I'm writing this review because CA has gone back to warhammer 1 level of incompetence on this one. I loved Warhammer 1, loved Warhammer 2 much, much more. I had the highest of hopes for Warhammer 3, but so far CA did not provide. The game is stagnant, Warhammer 2 was a constant path of improvement, which, admittedly, did come out as a fairly bad game. The difference however is in the urgency of CA's actions. In Warhammer 2 they released content that was good and did it fast (while also charging reasonable prices for dlcs), Mortal Empires came out much sooner than Immortal Empires. In Warhammer 3 it's been like 1.5 year since launch and the game is very similar to the game at launch. They provided less, improved less and yet charge more while also removing free content. I will change my if at any point I feel like the game has come back on track, but so far I feel like I'm back in Warhammer 1 which I stopped playing after the ridiculous dlcs that were "The Realm of the Wood Elves" and "the Call of the Beastmen" dlc, which were overpriced (and yet, still cheaper than the new "just lords" dlc). When it comes to pricing, just look at the dlc tab, recognize there ain't no more free stuff, and acknowledge the game is rarely getting updates, so it's in a somewhat lackluster state when you realize what it should be at this point

review: Essentially, I went into this game not knowing what to expect. Be advised, many will cry and complain, disagreeing with my review, but it is 100% honest, and factual. This game offers some of the most fun I have ever had, however I cannot recommend this game to anyone, as it is deceptive. You could spend hundreds of hours grinding, farming, upgrading, collecting Deviants, and it is all for nothing. Apparently at every new season much of what you've worked for, will be removed, Deviants being one of the major ones. Had I known this, I would have never started playing the game. It's as if they're teasing the player or punishing them with that type of system wipe. Most people cannot play games 24/7, and many do not want to farm the same deviants or items over and over again and continue losing them every season. This game has alot of potential, but this is an extreme turn off, and believe me I'm not the only one who feels this way. The combat and harvesting/building bugs are the least of my worries, I accept that all games have bugs, and yes Server lag. I never wanted to leave a review such as this, for a game I loved with a passion starting out. To those involved with this game, production, creation and inception, Starry Studio, NetEase Games, Exptional Global, you're just plain wrong for this. I spent over $100 on the game via microtransactions because I felt you cared about your players, and were offering a solid product. I'm not angry, enjoy the money, you need it far more than I do.

review: 2023 EDIT: The overtures made with the Shadows of Change update patch are a nontrivial step in the right direction. The community letter preceding it certainly *sounded* like it was coming from the right place, but the amount of content offered as a free update feels like a commensurate material change for a studio looking to truly change direction. As it stands now, I'm downgrading my outright concern to wariness, but I'm hopeful for where development is headed at this point.See below for my previous concerns.-----------------------------------------------"The right to discuss is a privilege"I normally don't like getting involved in dev drama, but so it goes. The price increase for the DLC didn't bother me at all, but the dev response to recent criticism indicates a level of delusion that doesn't bode well for any aspect of CA's work (development, community engagement, etc.). I've been a huge fan of the TWW series, but I don't know that I will make any future purchases unless there is a clear change in direction.

review: 2015 I've played CS.GO for a thousand hours plus. I think, I've clocked in a decent number of hours to offer genuine and reliable thoughts/insights/feedback of the game. If there had to be reasons why i would not recommend this game, it would be for two reasons.Firstly, I have to say that the CS.GO community is horrible. People show no signs of mercy to those who are new (Including myself at times). There are plenty of rude people. Of course i've met really nice people who respect one another but that is just a small minority. Too many people kicking out starters from casual matches for being noob ( not forgetting many times people kick out random players to allow friends to enter the match) and many times sore losers who constantly restart the match just because they died/didnt get a kill/for fun.Secondly, the number of hackers and smurfs that are present now. These people are spoiling the game for those who enjoy some casual FPS and also in competitive mode. Especially for smurfs, I know of many who wish to rank up higher in competitive but simply cant due to the number of smurfs who are actively cockblocking them. And as for hackers, there are those who use it for personal glory or to use it to sell people ranking up services. These people are simply a real pain to the CS.GO community. Need I say more?CS.GO, honestly, is good fun. I do love CS.GO. I have spent many good hours with friends, meeting new people and killing chickens. However the harsh reality of the CS.GO is simply cruel and merciless with people constantly yelling at you and telling you that you're no good, along with a good bunch of hackers/smurfs who ruins your gaming experience.If you cant handle the harshness of the CS.GO community, dont start playing it. However if you choose to enter the CS.GO world alone, good luck. I hope you meet a few reliable and friendly comrades.Until Valve finds a way to counter the problem is hackers and smurfs (especially in competitive mode), I will not recommend it. (Suggestion to counter smurfs: If the IP address has been in a CS.GO server before, he/she will not be allowed to play in the same pool of players in competitive mode.)EDIT: Valve's implementation of having 24 hours cooldown after every 2 wins for fresh competitive accounts is a great effort in slowly down smurfs and catching hackers via overwatch, however i think a more full proof method would be required after once they reached 10 wins.ADDITIONAL NOTE: To the few who have disagreed with my review because 'It's the community you're unhappy about, not the game', here's what i have to say. I strongly believe for a game like CS.GO (in fact any game with multiplayer funtionalities), community is a very large contributing factor if the game is good or not. It is the community that makes the game whole and who it is, especially for a game like CS.GO. I highly doubt people buy CS.GO to play offline mode/bot matches.Though I understand your point of view, and that i should be reviewing the game base on its mechanisms/funtionalities like movement/gun bullet mechanics/matchmaking. However for my review, my aim is to offer my readers a deeper insight to the game than just what you see it on the surface/trailers.At first you might feel that the community doesnt affect you at all, however once you get into the game, i believe you'll change your opinion. If you still disagree, I think its either you havent been exposed enough or you're just darn lucky meeting really nice and legitimate players in your matches. @Shadowdance You're welcome. You gave me the push to write this reply.Cheers fellow comrades.

review: Servers are not based on players online but on characters created on a server from unique Steam accounts. The devs refuse to kick characters off a server even if they've been inactive for weeks. Because of this, if your friends had a head start on a server, you most likely wouldn't be able to join them because it's permanently full of offline randoms. Joining another server restarts your hard-earned hours of progress, and the server reset time is six weeks. Don't play this game with multiplayer in mind if you don't want to be sorely disappointed.

review: A fantastic follow up to Titus's Story from the first game, with many fun callbacks. It's a classic Warhammer 40.000 story that is easily digestible even for newcomers with gameplay so finely and tightly crafted that I still catch myself getting giddy at the gory spectacle even after 80 hours. A true labour of love from a Developer that clearly loves and respects the IP and who I hope will continue to be with us for years to come.. what more can a 40K fan ask for?I highly recommend this game to anyone, even if you are just slightly interested in the universe or loved the first game.. and who knows maybe this game can be your gateway into our awesome hobby that is Warhammer 40.000!And a huge heartfelt thank you to Saber for memorializing the late John "TotalBiscuit" Bain in your game's credits, we miss you TB.

review: A very ambitious, refreshing action-RPG that focuses on cinematic action and hyper dynamic combat while doing away with the usual open world fluff that has gotten way out of control since the mid 2010's.Its a little linear, cut in straightforward chapters and contained areas, almost in a retro / nostalgic way, but it really doesn't miss a beat thanks to stunning, epic cutscenes and frenetic, unique boss fights, constantly pushing the player forwards through the chapters, yearning for more. Sometimes pushing a little too far ahead, to the detriment of the story while at other times offering up some incredible characters and lore along with touching moments... And lots of research to do on Journey to the West and Chinese mythology.Combat is speedy and dynamic although quite precise and usually pretty clean / readable. It sometimes turns messy because of weird camera movements and even weirder hitboxes. A somewhat uneven localisation (at least in English) and a frustrating amount of invisible walls. Definitely old-school .It's spent a long time cooking and ultimately feels like a great first step in Chinese AAA gaming.

review: 2022 In a few words: Amazing, but in moderation.Elden Ring - the latest From Soft entry - entered the gaming scene with one of the biggest hype trains ever seen. Now that the dust has settled at the station, we can mostly agree that the game has definitely lived up to that hype; albeit with a few small caveat. But first, the great: The game is wonderfully illustrated, both with the world building and its inhabitants' design: from the detailed local flora to gigantic enemies, they all feel unique and alive. It is almost guaranteed that players would stop in awe of the surroundings every now and then just to take in the world's grandeur.The NPCs that one meets along their journey also feel very colorfully animated and dynamic, most of which has a semi-hidden questline that the player can follow - as is the tradition of From Soft's games. However do be careful that some of these characters' questlines are either very easy to miss or to be messed up.A bigger world also means a much bigger variety in how the player can build their character. Weapons are definitely the strong suit of the game with one hidden in every nook and canny of the world, awaiting adventurous players seeking off the beaten path. And the special effects of weapons, spells, incantations... in the game feels extremely beautiful and in a way, badass. And now, the the not so good: While beautiful, the game on PC does suffer from performance issues like most From Soft ports to the PC. Patches have been released to iron out major problems but some remain. Most serious for me personally were the random crashes.Enemies do feel unique and boss fights are quite epic, but it is rather unavoidable that a game world of this scale will eventually have to resort to reusing enemies and bosses: turning bosses from early game to later game common enemies and vice versa. Though it does not ruin the experience as a whole, it does a get a little repetitive to see the biome changes but not the enemies we face.This game also has serious balancing issues with most of the later game contents being way overtuned, forcing players to invest heavily into HP in order to just survive from being one-shotted. Some bosses, ahem Malenia, feels very frustrating to fight against due to unfair and unfun mechanic. Some spells that the player can utilize also feels very broken turning some parts of the game a cake walk - but I do tend to stay away from such spells.And finally, with such a size, I do occasionally feel burnt out exploring the world's vastness. And the no hand-holding policy along with intentional vagueness in these games can disorient and discourage newer players from adventuring about. Hence, I found the game most enjoyable in short bursts rather than doing long playthroughs at a time. All in all: The game is great, despite some flaws. It takes all the goodness from previous Soulsbornesekiro titles and mash them together in an open world frame: an unforgettable dish that die-hard and new fans will definitely enjoy.

review: 2022 If you like dark souls or any souls like game, play this. If you like breath of the wild or any open world game, play this.Idk, just play this. Give it a chance if you aren't used to this type of gamed.FromSoftware never fails to deliver with the quality of their games. The amount of though that goes into creating the background stories and the environments of this game is unrivalled. This is one of the finest open world games to ever be made. You may be familiar with the classic open world games that studios like ubisoft is making now, go here do this. go there do that. This game is not like that. Exploring is one of the best things about this game and it truly feels rewarding. This game is full of content not just filler. There are so many unique situations that are wonderful. From enemies to friendly npcs and their stories and to weapons there is a huge variety of content. Heck I'm 95 hours in and I havn't finished the game yet but none of it has felt like a chore. I've enjoyed all of it and it 's definitely my favourite game of all time.There are a lot of people getting stuck on this game either saying it's too hard or that it should have a quest log. Some people are seeing the first hard enemy they find and giving up because they can't beat it. You don't have to! It's an important lesson that you can leave that challenge for later and just explore the world. Not having a quest counter makes this game much better. As people have suggested if you really want to you can get a pen and paper to help you remember characters. Don't complain that this is dumb because you aren't in school anymore. I'm sure you can manage. It makes the game so much more natural. You aren't meant to complete quests perfectly and it Isn't really possible to. If you miss a character or a part of a quest it may change other npcs stories in doing so. This makes them so organic and unique to you. You have to puzzle together their dialogue and this world in your own way. If you find something too challenging there is always something else you can try in this game. A different sword, a ranged weapon, magic, a summon, bring a friend along!TLDR: This is one hell of a game with rich and vibrant environments with deep lore. With a lot of it written by George R R Martin adding to even more of what we've come to love from Miyazaki. At it's core this game is an epic fantasy open world with great solid combat and it goes beyond that and is so much more as it's elements have been refined over years of FromSoftware experience.

review: ALMOST 400 HOURS! I have been here since just after inception, almost 400 hours on the game. Uninstalled it yesterday. The wipe and the forced server move and loss of progress, loss of many hours of mats collection and base wipe killed it for me. I don't want to play Tarkov or Rust. This could have been a great game that people could have specialties and go to the market and sell to people. Join strangers in open world and battle with them and be part of helping the working community. The novice servers when it first came out felt like that. So many people giving each other items they needed. Kindness in the chat. People willing to come help you do the Bosses and random people joining you in the open world and hanging out to do things with you for the day.They say this is a MMO game. It's not. They made it seem like essential items from the first season would be able to be transferred to the next season. That is NOT what happens. You are extremely limited to what you can bring over with you and you are basically starting from scratch without the leveled up armor and leveled up weapons you worked hard to get before the wipe. They made it seem like you could bring everything over for the next season and get bigger and better from there. Not so. You start like a noob again, have to level your character up again, don't have access to your blueprints until you have leveled up again and all the additional special items and hoard of mats you farmed the first time don't move over with you. It's insane. Who wants to bother with starting over again and again without being able to bring your progression and skills with you? You are not going into a new season server with your weeks of hard work, you are being thrown into it like a noob. I've put thousands of real hours into many different MMOs, picked my specialty, built my homes, castles, farms etc and carried on in the same fashion without being forced to lose everything. This game is a cash grab for loot crates and cosmetics the way it stands now. The wipes ruin your long term progression. The base you spent hours grinding mats for and making, gone in 6 weeks. The mats you grinded for hours and carefully inventoried in crates, gone in 6 weeks. The farm you made, the meat you dried, the specialty items, gone. The Deviants you upgraded so you could have 20 to help run your base. Gone. The give you a TINY AMOUNT OF ITEMS that can be transferred and even then, you can't use them until you have leveled up from scratch again.This is not an MMO. There is no purpose to try to do anything like you would on an MMO level to have it all removed from you in 6 weeks. The balance on the servers is borked. The FPS is borked. The community became uncomfortable and hostile and rude when the changes were made for hard servers and everyone was struggling with NO MATS OR ITEMS FROM YOUR HOURS OF GAMEPLAY after 6 weeks. The world chat is now full of trolling and abusive players. A massive amount of people left, including my mates, so you now get stuck without anyone you knew from before to play with. Servers became full without many people returning to the server so you couldn't even invite a friend to it. It's just a full server with no one on it now, and no way to invite a friend to it. Customer service is AI, not a human.I don't want to play a MMO that is a RUST or TARKOV server. That is ridiculous. I have no idea why they are saying this is an MMO. It's at best, a slow RPG with massive amounts of anime MMO items (teddy bear costumes, cat tables etc) that are pushed on you all the time. Why would I bother to spend massive amounts of hours trying to get mats to rebuild a home and can't even use my furniture I got because its locked behind my progression again and I don't have the mats to rebuild a home that cannot be rebuilt with your blueprint because you haven't unlocked that ability, that you already had unlocked before the wipe. Absolutely insane.Why would I build an awesome base to have it gone in 6 weeks? Why catch and keep animals only to have it gone in 6 weeks? The whole premise of this game is discombobulated and all over the place. What could have actually been a really pretty MMO with the ability to create your own kind of place in the community has become a loot box mess of a wanna be Rust server with the premise of MMO community that doesn't exist and MMO loot box cosmetics spammed at you all the time.Almost 400 hours. Yes, I played everything, twice. Then I left. I won't go back in the state it is in. The loot boxes, the lack of listening to what the actual game playing community wants and NOT JUST WHAT STREAMERS WANT is bizarre. There is no understanding by the devs that most people do not have 40 hours a week to devote to the game and don't want to come back to something they used their available time for to now suddenly be wiped. It is an epic disappointment in multiple ways. If you like wasting your time on restarting the game from scratch with no carry over progression, over and over again, then enjoy this free game. Otherwise, if they don't make a lot of massive changes to the structure of the game it will be played one time through and dumped.I am not the only one who has expressed these views, there are thousands of us that played and left. I just wanted to say that after almost 400 hours of this game, I'm out. And the people who have also expressed these exact same concerns are also out. This could have been a really nice MMO to explore and grow into. It's not.

review: 2022 For the amount of content promised and actually in the Shadows of Change DLC, which I refuse to buy until sale/price lowering, I'm astounded as to how this company stays in business. I would've been a good consumer and bought it if it were like 8.99 like the Grim and the Grave, because the aforementioned DLC, Shadows of Change, only contains 3 legendary lords for 3 separate and different factions and a handful of units for their factions, along with the subfaction mechanics of each of these three legendary lords.For the layman who doesn't know what I'm talking about:Each legendary lord is one of the playable factions, and usually when legendary lords are made, they arrive in a faction pack or in a style similar to the various smaller Warhammer 2 DLCs, which all pretty much are 10 bucks at most for about 2 new legendary lords, and such. This DLC in particular should be priced as such. The Chaos Dwarf DLC for this game was a one-off price-spike that also has been met with mixed reviews as well.If Creative Assembly wants to survive, they better start going back in the direction of their Vampire Coast and Tomb Kings DLCs where they gave an entire faction (a full unit roster, 3 legendary lords, an entire campaign fully voiced and designed for the faction. (This was especially prevalent in the Vampire Coast DLC) for at most, 18.99, not just 3 dudes and a handful of units for the same price plus about five bucks (24.99).In addition, alot of the content from the WH1 and WH2 DLCs, and even base-games is missing in WH3, such as the various campaign scenarios from WH1, the WH2 cutscenes and other campaign content for the Vampire Coast, which should come with the WH3 version of the DLC, because that's one of the cornerstones for buying the DLC in the first place. Now I know everyone in WH2 loved Mortal Empires, but I believe I have a legit point here, regarding the fact that alot of content is just straight up missing.Settlement buildings for various occupied variants of important capitals aren't present (they're just the generic occupied ones). Various landmark buildings aren't even in warhammer 3, such as Cylostra's Opera House. (Come on CA you literally made the character you can move her landmark building anywhere, nobody is going to whine about that) In essence, this can be seen as a gigantic money laundering scheme more-so than a company-fanbase relationship, and I'm afraid it's only going to get worse.Total War is on life-support and Total War Warhammer's DLC policies have put it there. This throwing 24.99 DLC crap at us isn't going to make anything better, come on CA, you're not Paradox Interactive, you don't need to nickel and dime us for ♥♥♥♥ we already get nickeled and dimed for on Games Workshop's various legitimate retailing locations and websites to buy the actual figures for the tabletop game that this is based on.You need to invest in new mechanics eventually, CA, and we're not talking Legendary Lord mechanics, we're talking legitimately changes to the actual gameplay. People are literally calling Total War: Troy and Total War: Warhammer the same freaking game, because there's very little difference other than unit roster and one being a Games Workshop licensed game. Empire had special buildings all over its provinces, Shogun dipped heavily into Daiymo diplomacy and improved on what Empire started in terms of the varying differences on the map. Everytime Creative Assembly ♥♥♥♥♥ up a game they release a "fixed" differently named version slightly altered formula game later. For example: Rome 2 and then Attila. It's starting to get very grating.Bretonnian Cavalry doesn't even compare to that of earlier Total War Titles cavalry, Total War: Attila was the last game where it felt like cavalry charges mattered.And now Creative Assembly is charging an upwards of 24.99 for a freaking DLC when their games are pretty much now prefabbed on the same cavalry-hating engine, for literal years.This is on the same engine as Total War: Empire. Let that sink in. And now they want to release Total War: Pharaoh on the same engine. Give me a break. I'm actually more invested in literally any other title at this point, and I feel like my money is being wasted on empty promises of "we hear you, we hear you" and then not a single price-change in sight. It's like we're putting up with the same PR and Law team as Unity Technologies.

review: If you've watched any content on the game whatsoever, that is the game you are getting. No smokes and mirrors. (But I'd still hope you're properly informed on the scope of the game as a whole)I've had this game on my radar for almost 3 years, was somewhat concerned when it got delayed a year but man am I incredibly happy they decided to because this game feels insanely polished. I played this game solely in low graphics for the entire main campaign and it still is one of the most atmospheric and gorgeous games I've ever played. If you're familiar with Warhammer 40k in any capacity (or are somewhat of a tourist that knows some lore tidbits like myself) and you love the aesthetic and have wished for so long for a sort of immersive experience that takes place in the franchise's world in a form that ISN'T a turn based game; this is a must buy, instantly. The campaign was amazing, around 8-9 hours of content but it felt perfect for me, not too short, not too bloated. And the finale just drove me over the edge, genuinely such an incredible high note to add on with plenty of fan-service that satisfied me and will surely make a bunch of loreheads incredibly excited and happy to see through.Very small complaints, it would seem the game is generally scaled for 3 individual players given that the bot companions are actually not very useful at all! My recommendation if you're getting into the game with your friends is to go into veteran difficulty and experience the game that way, but I'd advise against higher difficulties solo. It's not impossible, just feels overwhelming when the enemies don't ever focus anyone but you and you're tasked with just using the best gear, leaving no real room for customization or experimentation (when it's your first time playing through the game). Aside from that, not much else that I care about, oh aside from the final boss seemingly not letting you go in with your preferred loadout in the main campaign? Seemingly the only place that happens and I'm not sure if it's intentional. Granted I played this over the course of the first day for ultra and gold edition owners so this will surely get patched out in a week or less.Oh and operations are incredibly cool and will be a lot of the replayability for many players with how you can customize your own class specific space marine in SO MANY LEVELS of fashion. I'm still waiting on my friends to get on since they only got the base game without the headstart, but I'm excited to play through these missions with them.Last notes, I do wish you had some kinds of Chaos customization but I'm not damaged in any way that it isn't there. Also there is going to be a lot more content coming out in at least the next year and a half, the developers have actively released a roadmap explaning the addition of full on enemy classes and operation missions ENTIRELY FREE, with the only paid DLC coming in the form cosmetics, plus talks of adding full on playable classes in the future? We'll see if that talk actually goes anywhere but I can't say the idea of it doesn't have me thrilled.As it stands now, I've yet to 100% the game and excited that I have plenty to experience and unlock. I'm extremely grateful for everyone involved in creating this product (that was clearly made for me since it comes out officially on the day I was born!), and I'm excited to see what comes in the future of this great game!

review: Fascinating game by Game Science! This is the first ever Journey To the West related game I've ever played and so far being surprised on how well this game is doing. Firstly, the gameplay is one of the best part of this game. There are lots of system to play with regarding the transformation, spell and heavy attack options. Each skills have their own purpose and can be use in diffferent situations, offer large flexibility and a whole lot of fun to play. The monsters are considered hard, but with proper use of these systems, you can pass it quite easily. 9.5/10 for gameplay.Next, the story is very good and deep. It is about the after story of the Journey To the West. We can have a different view aside form the main story and it focus about the darkside regarding the story of Journey to the West. The story are well written and presented in a cinematic form, which greatly helps in immersive experience. After each chapter, there is also a short drawing animations that present and summarize the background story of the current chapter or might highly relevant to the other chapter, which even make you more interested in what will happen next. The game also gives you a menu list of enemies that you fought or person that you met along the journey, along with a long background information. The musics are also very well chosen and suits the situation well, especially the musics after the transformation, definitely will lit you up. 9/10 for story and music.However, this game also content of some downside that might ruin your experience, and the most mentioned will definitely be the map. There are NO mini map in this game, making it a very hard time for me to memorize and walk around the map without any idea where am I going. The graphics and views of the game is good with the help of unreal 5 engine, but sometimes I might experience lag spike when playing with monsters that have lots of effect, like fire or lightning, which might destroy your gaming experience. The cameras are also very frustrating, especially when playing against large monsters or in small spaces. These are the spots that might need further improvement or optimization.Overall, this is a fantastic games with interesting gameplay, graphics, stories and music. There are flaws in this game, but the goods overshine the bads and gives me a very good experience. To be mentioned, there are alot of side quest and hidden boss in this game, which you can find out if you miss any boss in the enemy list, make sure you run through the whole map patiently to not miss any good contents. Recommend this to every action games lover. 9/10

review: Per usual, there's nitpick and ganging up over the smallest of things in reviews without people reading into it or actually taking the time to experience it. There's pros and cons, like any other games.This is a Free to Play. I am astounded by the character customization that we get in comparison to games you have to buy. There's a decent amount of content and places to explore and fun little things to collect - a LOT more than many of those "early release" games you buy can claim. This game isn't completed in just 6 hours or less and new content continues to be released at a decent pace before you can finish the current content (or at least for me). It's enough for me to comment to myself "This is a free game?" with each new feature that astounds me. Better yet: it's not pay to win.Now.. The enemies are a bit easy in the starting zone, which can make the pace feel slow or the combat a little dull. The base building could also use some touch up in how the pieces snap together (i.e. the curved crescent shape snapping to the underside of ceilings), but otherwise has been enjoyable once you can move your base away from the first zone (where everyone is heavily crowded). I am also a little iffy with the seasonal resets, as my play is so limited between work and family and I feel I might not reach the end before reset happens.Maybe I've been a little starved for a finished game, tired as hell of all those paid "early release" with slow moving promises. But this is still a breath of fresh air and worth giving a chance.

review: 2022 Ive played every soulsborne game to date, this is by far the best game they have put out. It takes all the great things from previous games and mashes it into an ultimate experience that just feels good all around. The story has been hitting hard and has a lot more dialogue and interactive story for you to have fun with. As well as brings back some relics from past games. All while feeling new and fresh. This game isnt perfect by any means, it has its minor glitches and stutters but nothing I haven't seen worse on any other game, and most of those issues can easily be patched out. Its a game I have already sunk 55 hours into as of writing this review and I have only reached a little over the halfway point in the game with so much more to explore.TLDR: If you enjoy previous FromSoft games you will love how this game feels and plays, if not but are looking for a game that rewards persistence and drive maybe give it a shot. If not it may not be the game for you and thats alright not everything will be. Overall I personally love what Ive seen so far and can't wait to play more

review: 2023 Since the release of Skyrim on 11/11/11 I have been craving an open world experience with rewarding combat, build theories, crazy-beautiful aesthetics, and a real sense of accomplishment (items, dungeons completed, etc).This game delivers the entire experience in a way I've never quite seen. I'm new to the souls-like genre, and FROMSOFTWARE games. Here are the takeaways for me: 1. Combat is extremely rewarding by being unforgiving. At first glance, it's hard, but as you delve just a little deeper you realize that combat in this game is an art form that takes practice, and then more practice. The satisfaction is higher than any game I've played in the last decade. The light attacks, heavy attacks, blocks, parrying, sprint attacks, sneak attacks, all play a little different and allow you to really pick your method or avenue of approach. 2. Items in game (from armor and weapons, to craftables and ashes) are each, individually, potentially game changing or build changing and can really flesh out a 'build'. It's rewarding to find items in game as any one of them could be the weapon of choice for your desired build. 3. Open world is absolutely stunning and feels very scary, yet very exciting. Every new enemy seen needs to be studied, practiced, and learned for optimal combat. New enemies can be scary as you don't immediately know their capabilities. Boss fights are hard (some more than others) and many enemies are the type that require you to come back at a later time when you have stronger tools, or more HP, or you git gud. Roaming new areas is thrilling and you begin to truly have to balance and manage your HP, FP, and Stamina while in combat. The lighting in caves with torches or lanterns is immersive and you feel the danger.4. Character building is straightforward. You level up as you beat enemies and use the runes (XP, currency) as you see fit to either purchase things, or level up....etc and you can decide what attribute to increase. Trying new weapons, new armors, is both fun and interesting. The need to knows: 1. Game won't hold your hand. You are in a labyrinth with many things that all can kill you. You will not know exactly what you're doing, where you're going, or why you are existing. 2. Everything you see can kill you if you become too careless. Slow and steady usually is the best method. Slow is smooth and smooth is fast.3. Ashes of War, summoning and crafting must be experimented with to understand. Again, no hand holding.4. You will ask yourself, "How in the world am I supposed to ever be able to complete this?" Many, many times.5. Puzzles and secrets abound, exploration and a good memory are key. 6. While there is a multiplayer experience (PVP and PVE) it's a bit confusing and from what I've experienced so far, not necessarily mandatory. The single player experience is strong with this one.I've spent 42 hours in this game as of writing this and I've barely left the starting area - Limgrave. My nightmares consist of Runebears, traversing the mist, and boss fights. I've been startled, pillaged, rekt, and absolutely confused many times, but I wouldn't change any of it. I remember the first time I saw a giant I had Attack on Titan flashbacks and began trying to summon my inner Captain Levi. It's just a blast. An absolute blast. The greatest feeling of accomplishment is when you start to beat bosses or new enemies on your first attempt. You can feel your ability, your reaction time, your muscle-memory coming more and more into play as you practice, and it creates a thrilling experience. Struggling with an enemy type for hours only to come back a few days later and realize how much stronger and faster you've gotten is a very rewarding experience.

review: 2022 I got my brother in to playing this game. Which is not much of a feat but he seemed dead set against playing a "Souls" game. To be honest, I'm no fan of Souls games either. But the RPG aspect gave me enough hope to give it a try. So far I have cursed out loud more times than I care to admit. This can get real embarassing when you are living in a hotel for work purposes and you come out of your room and people are just like "What the hell man." My brother summed this up this game perfectly. "Skyrim on insane difficulty." This is the highest praise I think he's given anything. If you haven't picked up this game and you are thinking, I don't like Souls games. Take heart. This has souls like aspects but it is NOT a Souls game. This is a VERY good RPG pretending to be a souls game.If you took an RPG and took out all the hand holding and FETCH QUESTS, then ramped up the difficulty, took away the easy mode indicators (Oh, he's level 40 I should wait) and said do what ever you want. You would get close to this game.Graphicly superior to many games I've played recently. There are still some funny "graphical" situations. Things like "Don't look at the trees too much in the wind. They look like giant dusters all moving randomly." Though I don't buy RPGs for graphics alone, I do expect that modern RPGs have modern graphics. There is no real reason for 8bit characters when the world is capable of so much better. Sorry, small tangent.Sounds, including music are well thought out and placed. I normally turn the music in games right off. This game I leave it on. The music is subtle almost not there but it adds to the atmosphere rather then distract from it. Many times I only realise there was music after I've died (most likely) or I won the fight(I'm getting better but this is still the lesser).The last thing I say is don't be disheartened when you die. It WILL happen. You will lose a LOT of runes. This game makes you "Git Gud". Time and again I've fallen to the same enemy but the joy you feel when you defeat them. Unmatched in ANY game I've ever played. You feel like you've actually accomplished something.If you like RPGs (especially the old style where you didn't have your hand held the whole way) buy this game. You may curse me in your sleep but you will enjoy yourself.

review: 2022 Edit: The release of IE fixed one of the most glaring problems with the game - and the new Warriors of Chaos rework is loads of fun. The release - for me at least - is stable and relatively bug-free. I am therefore changing my recommendation. Se below for the old review.Don't buy this game as of yet - come back and check again in 2023...The current campaign is riddled with odd design decisions and bugs that could have been avoided by looking at Warhammer 2 for 30 seconds. For example: Why are there issues with unit responsiveness and missile targeting when it worked fine in Warhammer 2? Why is the performance on the campaign map WAY worse, to the point where one of my friends couldn't even run the damned thing, when Warhammer 2 ran perfectly fine on medium/high?(while 3K and Troy ran buttery smooth) Why did they look at the slightly railroaded Vortex campaign, see that it was nowhere near as popular as the Mortal empires campaign and think: "The solution must be to make the new campaign even more railroaded!"?Now I would have forgiven the campaign side of things, because I was confident that we would soon get the Immortal empires combined campaign, but as it turns out, it is nowhere near completed. They only comitted to releasing a BETA version of it (I.e. probably barely functioning version), possibly as late as september.. god knows how long it will take for the full release. I have paid full price, three times to get that combined map, and all they can muster is to wait several months to tell me, that I have to wait for several more months to get to BETA test what was promised and what I paid top dollar for? The changes they are working on are promising and needed, but they are being implemented WAY too slowly. It really sucks because there are so many good moves in the game: Better diplomacy, better siegemaps, 8 player campaign multiplayer with simultaneous turns to name a few! But if you don't feel like playing the campaign, these don't matter much. I wish the DLC team the best of luck with Warhammer 3, because they did a sterling job on Warhammer 2 post launch.

review: This is a great ARPG and probably one of the better GoTY candidates. The overall experience is let down by some questionable control input delay/unresponsiveness mechanics and less polished last chapter.If I can only describe this game in a sentence, then Black Myth Wukong is ’a reflection of a labour of love and reverence paid to THE ORIGINAL Chinese mythology that is Journey to the West. Throughout most of the gameplay you can feel the reverence & details the devs put into this game.’ I absolutely recommend this game if you enjoyed Seikiro, Devil May Cry, Nioh series, GoW, Lords of the Fallen, Nier Automata series etc. This game builds on the legacies of others but also proudly stands out as the one of the most memorable ARPGs for me in recent years after 70+ hours.Key Things to Note1) Black Myth Wukong is a very carefully composed, curated and guided linear/semi open world experience. You have options to explore untrodden paths but eventually all paths lead back to one. 2) It enhances your game experience to actually know some background context about the Chinese mythology that is ‘Journey to the West.’ Black Myth Wukong takes place AFTER the original events of Journey to the West with plenty of liberal interpretation & further new world building based on a version of the Monkey King. 3) The game is best when your mid way through but falls flat & rushed at the last chapter. There’s not many reviews that talk about polish of this game near the end but it’s bad. The assets/terrain look like placeholders, you can pass though solid objects like trees/NPCs… The feeling of rush to the finish is very distinct and is extremely jarring compared to chapters 1-5.4) This game rewards adaptive gameplay (freely respec skills & your gear), iteration (learning boss mechanics through failure) & exploration (methodical slow play). The game plot often interweaves through side quests & seemingly random encounters with lots of hidden information that requires reading text via in-game journal tab. The English translation is not good and overall story telling can be obfuscated and full of riddles adversely impacted by translation issues.5) You need to retain most in-game events in your memory bank and connect fair amount of dots throughout your play through. Chapters whilst self contained has overarching connected side quests, world events, where even seemingly random picked up item hold important core narrative lore to add context. There’s also numerous NPC background stories that all contribute to different game outcomes & also help explain the overall story. E.g. a hidden zone in Chapter 2 with associated boss fight and story is directly tied to end event of Chapter 2 bringing a more fulfilling conclusion to Chapter 2 arc whilst also hinting at the constant time shift mechanic employed in this game’s story telling.6) There’s issues with how this game process player control input. There’s some issues with general input lag and how the game fails to register input due to animations locks out input even after animation seemingly completes. Best example is gourd use is mostly able to be triggered even between dodges or attacks. Medicines cannot. Taking medicine requires player to stand perfectly still with no player animation happening or other input.7) I also have this game on my PS5, my kid plays that mainly so as to not have my PC save file accidentally erased. PS5 version is definitely playable including PS Portal via remote play.Detailed ReviewStory/setting/visual: Very good story with Chinese voice over better than English (more nuance in the emotions conveyed - I keep English subtitles so I can keep up). To enjoy this game you need to have some cultural awareness, English/Chinese listening aptitude is essential (if you don’t want to rely on subtitles) yet bulk of the context to what plays out in this game is gathered through text as well. I give overall story 8/10 but YMMV especially if you don’t take time to fully comprehend the side stories including boss lore & tying it so together for yourself.Technical performance: I'm playing across range of PC hardware including at 1440p/4K with maxed out settings including ray tracing at Very High and everything on cinematic with DLSS at 75%. I average 80~120fps+ in-game with uncommon dips below 80fps with peaks around 125+fps. This is on a RTX4090M + 13900HX laptop as my desktop PC is currently out of action. I also play this on Legion Go (1200p) & tried on Asus Rog Ally (1080p)… Both played fine with FSR/XeSS at 40-50%, low-medium settings yielding 30~55fps in game without frame gen. On AMD hardware if you have anti-lag & AFMF toggled on via AMD Adrenaline software, it can cause severe stuttering issues in-game especially in Chapters 3 & 4. Chapter 3 is also less performant than all chapters with overall average fps dropping by 10-20% easily. There’s UE5 traversal stutters but this game at v1.0 launch is in a better technical state than most other UE5 games I’ve played. This game at launch is also playable & actually enjoyable (not something that can be taken for granted in modern AAA releases). Remember Game Science started with 7 devs in 2017, started really recruiting people after 2020, worked through COVID in China, never developed AAA level ARPG games and with barely any experience across the team has managed to deliver a product at v1.0 that is almost on par with the likes of GoW with a captivating world, better overall graphics & an original story setting.Game content, variety & depth: in my first 70+ hours I thoroughly enjoyed chapters 1-5. Chapter 6 is by far the worst and is actually subpar below AAA level due to lack of polish, glitches, enemy hitbox issues, low fidelity assets, boring level design (bland copy and paste to create false sense of scale - due to flying ability).As for lore; if you’re not reading at a minimum the character description scrolls after defeating each one, you’re losing out on critical lore & often interesting background. E.g. the 3 rat princes backstory if you read it (take you maybe 2-3 mins max) offers a great insight into why they act the at they do when you encounter them and made my experience more fulfilling after defeating them as more than just a boss rush.Controversy around this game : We seem to be trending towards more expensive game development but less value offered to customers with missing content, lack of variety/depth of content and even content locked behind day 1 DLCs. This includes games like Jedi Survivor, Starwars Outlaw & Space Marines 2 which shows how widely the industry has shifted in favour of monetisation above core game value. Often it’s more important how diverse a game appears with in-game NPCs rather than the diversity that matters like actual human beings that worked on the project, cultural representation etc. E,g. People should Google the English VAs that was paid and worked on Black Myth Wukong where they even had females play as male & deity type NPCs etc. The diversity of the VA cast and the dev team is overshadowed because of the ridiculous manufactured outrage over either mis-translations of embellished social media posts from years past or outright defamation by biased and inaccurate gaming ‘journalism,’ gobbled up by swaths of the public that are either misinformed or uninformed.Also those people that hate, review bomb or boycotting this game without even owning/trying this game because it’s Chinese developers is about as vile as it seems. There’s no justification for generalisation or bias confirmation. The devs have harmed no one in making and releasing this game. Buy this game if logic, real life diversity, cultural value, great gameplay & value for money appeals to you.

review: The gameplay is enjoyable and as of level 15 in game I still don't feel like a f2p player so that's something but it is still early.The game is in dire need of optimization though as frame drops and input delay can get unbearable very often, it'll run completely smooth for an hour then be unplayably laggy the next all while server ping is stable.My pc isn't top of the line but it is better than what's recommended and I am playing with very low setting.It made a big difference to run the game on DX11 through the -d3d11 steam launch parameters and locking fps to 30 somehow which is odd because it really doesn't seem locked to 30 fps when the option is set.There's a lot they could massively improve but the game has a solid core and feels more complete than D4 did on launch.

review: So, after a year of subjecting myself to this game – and trust me, 'game' is a generous term – I've come to the conclusion that debating whether a group of koalas could do better is a legitimate argument. And forget about comparing it to classics like CS:GO; this game is like comparing a tricycle to a Ferrari.Picture this: You're spraying bullets left, right, and center, missing every hit and suddenly, you've got a team full of Russians offering you extremely positive criticism. It's like being in a tutorial for 'How Not to Play.'And the thrill of victory? Oh boy, it's a wild ride. Win a match, and you're rewarded with a whopping 100 elo points. Lose? Well, say goodbye to those points faster than you can say 'disconnect.'Now, let's talk about the PC requirements. You could have a PC that costs more than a small country's GDP, and this game will still make it perform like it's powered by hamsters on a wheel. Lag? It's not a bug; it's a feature. Let`s focus on the positive:The anti-cheat system – it's a masterpiece of nothingness! There's only a 7% chance you'll face off against someone who's downloaded every cheat code known to mankind. And those players with 600-1500 hours? They're like gaming gods, smiting 15-20.000 hour mere mortals with every click of their mouse.So, if you enjoy subjecting yourself to digital torture, I highly recommend giving this game a try. It's like a bad relationship – toxic, frustrating, but somehow, you just can't quit.

review: 2023 Total Warhammer 3 is an impressive game. It offers hundreds of hours of entertainment. The scope of the game is simply staggering. The Warhammer fantasy world is available to you in a sandbox campaign for you to paint the map with a diverse selection of factions that play uniquely in both campaign as well as in battles. Animations in the game are fantastic and the units have nice attention to detail for the most part. It truly is a fun and great game. However, what isn't fun and great is the cost and lack of updates.CA should invest more in a custodian team to fix bugs that have been present for months.These bugs can ruin campaigns such as how Nakai couldn't recruit his signature units.Hard to say what is truly going on at CA but it is suspected that the higher ups aren't giving the devs enough support. It is hard to recommend anyone get the game because of the predatory pricing (especially recently) and amount of DLC. You'll end up spending like 300 to 400 dollars on this game.If you have deep pockets, don't care about bugs, and can stand tone-deaf responses from CA's suits then get the game.

review: 2022 Short version is it's just Dark Souls 4 with jumping and a horse. Long version is that it's one of the most in depth games I've ever played.The world itself is so detailed that you can easily miss little secrets and dungeons. The environment is beautiful and numerous times I've had to check what time it was while playing. I have just gotten lost in the world exploring. If you are a souls vet, you should already be playing this. If you are on the fence, give it a try as it is easily one of the contenders for game of the year already, and its only March. For the PC issues, yes there are stutters, but they aren't that bad and as long as you have your drivers updated you should be fine.Also for the record, I don't believe anyone saying they are beating the game in 60 to 80 hours unless they are following a guide or skipping all of the content that makes this game special. For reference, I have just completed everything in Limgrave , and have only beaten the first major boss. I have explored a little bit of Caelid (red area to the east) and have just went south to The Weeping Peninsula . I am almost at 60 hours and have barely scratched the surface of this game.

review: 2022 My thoughts about the game on 13th of July 2022. Overall 8/10.I think with the coming of 1.3 my initial review of this game needs work.If initially I was quite annoyed with WH3 coming fresh out of WH2, things have changed.At the moment I can safely say that most of my gripes with the game have been solved. - most of the mechanical issues I faced are sorted. - the RoR units are adding some of the required spice in the game. - The intercept enemy mechanic added in 1.3 is turning the current campaign from a chore to agreeable and fun. - the balance and unit fix aspects helped a ton. Examples: Gorgers went from God mode to decent and Ironguts can actually hit tiny units.There is still one aspect that needs a bit more fixing and that's the Chaos Prince. The direction is ok but he is quite underwhelming from what I have played. I am not going to start quoting Legend but the man speaks the truth.All and all I can see myself recommending this game to my friends as of 1.3.I will also leave my initial review below because removing it would be unfair in my opinion.--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------My thoughts so far (8th of May 2022):1. Campaign:a) Khorne - 7/10b) Tzeentch 6/10 and that is without taking the last battle into account.c) Nurgle 1/10. 1 point for nurgling terminator squads. The rest of the roster is complete garbage.d) Slaanesh 0/10 just horrible. Start to end.e) Asians 8/10. Both are fun to play.f) Kislev 3/10. When you play them they are chaff, when you fight against them you get karate chopped by normal Kossars. g) Ogres 2/10. Pathing / siege related game breaking issues.h) Demons of chaos. 4/10 Its a bit like the Ukraine situation right now. Your enemy harrases you non stop. Your "allies" are committing 9 armies to deal with a rebellion on the other side of the map. This faction has the potential to be the most fun yet weak one. And dont touch Nurgle units / factions or Tzeentch will make you slap your family members then go to war with them.Now for some general thoughts:AI - dumb bully / zerg tactics. They keep recruiting untill they overwhelm you, armies and heroes both. 1/10.Map - 8/10. Preety good but tiny. Rifts make it feel even smaller.Faction Mechanics: 6/10. Some are amazing and some (nurgle) are by default useless (atrition, plagues? plagues as buffs? 1/100 casualties per turn?.The empire factions: - someone screwed up big time here. Last i checked they were not some village idiots clubbing each other to death until the ogres kill them (100% of the time). And 200 turns into the game 4 alied empire factions cannot conquer one vampire castle. 0/10. Empire fans will just delete the game and move on.Overall? 6/10 i guess. I didnt factor all my thoughts up there.Do I recomend it now? No. It is a pale shadow compared to what wh2. Indeed wh2 is fully developed but...If I take my girlfriend to good restaurants most of the time and to McDonald's on her birthday she wont like it. Not one bit.
