review: 2021 From the moment I first partook in this illicit, nefarious substance known as Counter Strike, I was initially distraught, disillusioned with life, with my inner hope in humanity dimming immensely. Ever since my first interaction with another in this accursed contraption, which devolved into envisioning him preaching support for some form of radical ideology, I became wary of its inhabitants, initially deeming them all as rabid, saliva frothing fiends, that were effectively released primates, which insidious Saes scientists had abducted and connected to a computer. Overtime, my original derisive demeanour towards the inhabitants of Counter Strike gradually altered, I began to view them in an utterly inconceivable way, I began to regard them as humans. Perhaps it was a form of Stockholm Syndrome infiltrating and ultimately subverting my senses, but after witnessing such these creatures antics, I began to comprehensively analyse their bewildering personality arcs and acknowledged their intricate quirks and demeanours, that varied depending on the individual. It was through meticulous, deductive investigation that I gleaned a hierarchy of sorts, a selective system of power that presides within Counter Strike. It appeared these peculiar anomalies had an unspoken agreement of those who commandeered respect and were designated to obey within a server. To state it in a simplistic manner, the realm of Counter Strike bears four classes, each one wielding a distinctive set of attributes and a varying degree of influence. These classes can be located in any typical server, with the four social castes being simplistically defined as ‘foreigner’, ‘child’, ‘female’ and ‘adult’. Presiding within the upper hierarchy, lies the adults, a term defining a loose collective of individuals with varying degrees of deep, masculine voices, that emanate through their pristine, gold plated microphones and are projected onto any server they come across. Typically, the adult branch bears two subsects, entities with slight feminine lisps, that are accentuated by their inability to pronounce various vowels, with the other branch being zealous nationalists, who presume that they are Oswald Mosley himself, bellowing their political idealogue to a blackshirt rally. The first subsect, who for conveniences sake we shall refer to as the men of Sodom, are often envisioned preaching compassion and tolerance in games, all the while simultaneously attempting to solicit nude imagery from the children or female social caste, seeking to beguile them forth by demonstrating their aiming prowess. Contrary to the men of Sodom, the nationalists are frequently observed preaching distinctive political ideologues, all the while bellowing racial slurs and preying upon the conspicuous susceptibilities to all who are not swayed to their cause. At times, as featured by droves of Jesus Bots and individuals masquerading as George Floyd, the nationalists endeavour to bolster their forces and as such go on mass recruitment runs, dedicated to converting any with a fragment of intrigue to their zealous cause. Due to the conflicting demeanours and philosophy between the men of Sodom and the nationalists, they are routinely envisioned warring within many a game, attempting to gain a remnant of ground and control in their perpetual, tenacious struggle. Asides from the adult sect, lies the female branch. This branch is generally regarded by the most renowned of philosophers as the second most integral and influential organisation presiding within Counter Strike. Frequently this group of temptresses utilises their feminine voices to beguile any they come across, often being able to captivate a throng of admirers, who will defend their seductress to their last breath. Often this group demonstrates antipathy towards the foreigner subsect, as they cannot comprehend feminine voices and thus are not swayed, alongside the nationalists who attempt to purposedly anger the female caste, as a way of acquiring newfound combatants from their admirers. Based on the females ability in serenading a sirens tune, it would be prudent to be wary of this potent caste. Fortunately, as a result of mass cullings stemming from the nationalists and rampant abductions, derived from lustful children and men of Sodom, the females ranks have significantly decreased, making them a sparse and prized commodity in the Savannah of Counter Strike. Measuring at the second lowest slot of the social caste, lies the children, the youth of Counter Strike. Frequently, as a result of their nasally, high pitched, helium induced voices, equip with petulant demeanours, they are subject to much ridicule, mockeries that often revolve around the children being verbally beaten into submission from both subsects of the adult caste, alongside the females. Lastly, residing within the lowest social caste, features the cheap, unskilled labour of Counter Strike, the foreigners. This caste comes in all ranges, Asian, Russian, Spanish and many others. Frequently, as they incessantly gibber away in their own dialect, they are insulted from all corners, particularly the nationalists, who attempt to provoke the slumbering, indefinite horde. Any provocation or obscenity hurled in this castes direction often bears a minimal effect, as the foreigner is unable to comprehend the English tongue, instead being content in incessantly sprouting their gibberish, oblivious to the hostility they are beset by. Regarding the social castes, it can be stated that they remain a vicious and conspicuous feature of the realm of Counter Strike, with each social sector roving around servers, attempting to emulate 1920’s Birmingham gangs, as they extort and intimidate rivals into complete and utter compliance. Ever since acquiring a travel ticket and touring throughout this backwater fiefdom, I have developed an epiphany, a realisation of sorts. I have gleaned that nothing procures more joy in my life, than hearing the anguished cries of prepubescent youth, equip with the smacks of batons and boisterous snarls of adults as they yell every obscenity that exists within the grand tome of grudges at all forms of denizens that reside within. What else provides an inexplicable happiness is observing Asians of ambiguous ethnicity being slurred at by intoxicated patriots, who envision themselves at the glorified border guards of Counter Strike, critically acclaimed sentinels who will strive at nothing more than to fulfil their oath in purging all undesirables from their rural border town. Asides from the trivial antics of the unhinged, I discovered something utterly sinister, a note provided by a messenger that bears a distinctive, albeit ominous message.

review: The scenery and gameplay—great.However, this game suffers from poor design choices in online play. Matchmaking is terrible. Sometimes you connect to an operation already in progress. Other times, the game decides you're going to be the host and keeps you waiting. Wanna roll again? Quit to title screen and try again. You can spend a long time loading in, only to find out that the class you wanted to play has already been taken by someone else—or worse, both of your preferred classes are taken. Suddenly, you can't do that ruthless run you signed up for because your other classes aren't leveled up. So back to Battle Barge, roll again, load again... and then randomly disconnects without any easy way of connecting to operation. This game waste a lot of your time.I'm not sure how obvious these issues were to the designers, but they really should have considered them. You waste a lot of time just waiting and searching for a match to play.

review: Finally.....some good f_cking food.... (c) - Gordon RamsayAfter years and years AND YEARS of really bad Warhammer games...after THQ left us to suffer with failures like Eisenhorn, various Turn Based cringe games, indie games, Fantasy games, DOW 3 - let Emperor make me forget about that - and god knows what elseWe finally got it - a fine successor to good Warhammer games and also a sequel to a game from 2011Lots of bugs are flying by in search for some food - and also heretics doing funny stuff🟡The plot of this game is pretty much the same as SM1 - but instead of Orks - you fight Nids, brutally. Very. Brutally.After some time - there's gonna be Chaos Marines - Thousand Sons to be exact.Also lots of nods to the previous game and overall - this game is way more serious and lore accurate than SM1 - for better or worse. With occasional lore errors here and there but its okay.🟡But tbh - the plot remains kinda boring until the very end.When you'll get to the 3-rd planet, story finally starts to become fun and entertaining so there's that.Barely optimized horde game🟡I was not expecting much for 50 bucks - and to be fair, the game look - not exactly spectacular. The most weaker parts of the game - are faces and cutscenes on game engineCGIs look great, models and animations too, hi-res textures, decent effects - but nothing moreThe game is like from 2020-2022 🔴And yet if you want to run it properly - you better have a pretty damn good rig from 2024 or else its gonna be a bad time.I'd actually suggest to play this game on PS5 because on PC....In short, Im glad I can run it in 40 FPS with my RIG, but I heard dudes on better hardware cant even render the game properly and have even worse FPSes which is weirdAnd oh boy, I hope you're prepared for Ripper rooms and Big Waves🟢Although I REALLY like Tyranids models in this game🔴Finally, there are some funny bugs here and there. Mostly just broken animationsAlthough there was one critical bug - a random joined me in coop mission when I was pressing a certain button to blow a bridge - I stuck on this button - and noclipped through air to the edge of the map..............A game about shooting, slashing and shooting some more🟡3 player coop game. mostly. You can play campaign with friends only (or solo but its harder on highet difficulties)Campaign is about 6-10 hours, depending on how well you play and if you look for collectibles/care for achivos.There's also 6 coop missions with randomsPVP mode with 3 maps, 3 modes where 6 players fight other 6 players - pretty dull.🟢The gameplay itself - a pretty basic 3-rd person shooter with basic combo mechanics. You can also parry, block and dodge. Those are sound simple, but at the start - its kinda awkward and you gonna mess up timings a LOT. Finally, there's lots and LOTS of gore and blood.It CAN be repetative and tiresome - but it is what it is. We wanted a horde game about Nids - and we got it, what else would you want?Grimdark is really grim🟢The overall design of this game is a masterpiece. Its been a long time since I could actually immerse myself into Warhammer game. Swarms of bugs are everywhere. Literal PILES of dead bodies, disaster, actual war - I absolutely love it.🟡But the actual level design? - Mostly corridors with hidden collectibles here and there and thats it.About the music and sound design🟡Nothing to say here really, its your standart epic cinematic Warhammer OSt YouTube™ Video: Warhammer 40000: Space Marine 2 OST - Onslaught (Nima Fakhrara & Steve Molitz) Views: 419 Warhammer 40000: Space Marine 2 OST - Onslaught. Music By Nima Fakhrara and Steve Molitz 🟢Although I Really think that sounds in this game are amazing. The sounds of bolters, chainswords, tyranid screams - its just perfect.About the characters🟢Now this is also goodIm actually surprised how well TItus and his new comrades are developed through the story.Lots of different nids to shootThousand Sons are well presented (although not really fun to fight)The main villain is cool🔴The only thing I dont like (beside Chaplain) is Cadian Major....oooof now that is a bad decision if you ask me.In the grim dark future...there is only Grind🟡Finally, lets talk about Replay Value.Oh boy, after you've done with the campaign and collect every collectible and done every achivo that could be done in single player (curse you Terminator Combo and curse you Save From Ravener)Its time for PVP and PVE🔴PVP is easy to do (for now since people are active) but 5 kills-in-a-row is rough🔴But PVE......well. I hope you have a LOT of spare time because you gonna need it. The game challenges you with levelling up one of the 6 playable classes. And also levelling up at least one ranged and melee weapons. Finally - beat at least one coop mission on hardest difficulty (which is not that hard tbh) The difficulty in coop missions relies a lot on your actual level.🔴After you do that - its time for 41k kills - have fun.Conclusion🟡Its a good game. It really is.But its FAAAR from being perfect. I love it, I wanna love it even more. But will I get back to it after some time? Probably not since - its not memey enough as SM1 and not exactly original either.Hell, after I've put 40+ hours into this game I started to feel like Im playing Fireteam Elite again instead of Space Marine. And that is not very good

review: 2022 Ok I think it might be a good time for a re-reviewEver since immortal empires had arrived, this game feels SOO much betterIt feels like we were given an underwhelming appetizer, only to receive an absolutely delicious main course Many patches and updates had arrived after I made a previous review, fixing areas that were previous mentioned such as Rifts, balancing issues and Anti-Player bias AITo be honest, the Realm of chaos campaign is still meh, atleast its not as bad as before and can be fun at timesThe Prologue is still really good for anything else they have done and is actually a pretty good tutorial on teaching new-comers how the game works and its mechanics Oh boy Immortal empires my beloved, this is the true reason why any would get this game. A giant map with all different sorts of factions scattered around and unique experiences for basically every legendary lord in the rosterMany campaigns with different lords can have interesting experiences whether it be the challenge, the opponents you face, the allies you make, the battles you fight, and so on.All of the factions can be a blast, and those who are considered a less enjoyable experience still have their moments of joy. Immortal empires map is actually ridiculously huge and many parts of the map are aesthetically pleasing to look at with many small details that add more to the world of warhammer. Personally Cathay and the realms of chaos are very nice locationsThe graphics of this game are very good, the models are great, and the fact the CA had taken old games workshop models and updated them for the game is incredible.One thing I must say about the game is that the performance can be rough, the immortal empires map can be rough for performance (atleast for my computer)On top of all of this, this game is 8 PLAYER COOP! with simultaneous turns so no waiting for others to end their turns. This is the game I was waiting for when I first played total war: warhammer 2, this game has truly restored itself and has DLC coming along in the future. This will be my favourite RTS forever and will stay in my steam library foreverThis is now a good gameif you like good gamesbuy this game

review: 2022 Before i start, i want to say that every experience is subjective. So for you to have a little bit of context about my experience of the game :- I've already played and finished dark souls (I,II,III) and sekiro and i really liked those games.- I play video games regulary but i'm not that good, i can struggle and i'm not a "sweat" type player- I did not experienced any performance issues while playing elden ring for some reason, even with my laptop (gtx1070, 16 gb of ram)- Even if give the game 10/10, i don't think EVERYONE, should play it, every games are differents and offers differents type of experience and therefore, every game is not meant for everybody.BUTElden ring is for me a : masterpiece. As an artist who works in the videogame industry, i find the art direction unmatched, the graphical quality of the game is not meant to reproduce the reality with gorgeous texture but i look FANTASTIC nevertheless. As you progress to the world you are in constant ah of what the game as to offer in his character design, places, music everything come together to immerse the player in the dangerous world of the land between.The game in itself is extremely dense there are cave, ruin, fort, castle in every corner, and it feels really rewarding to be curious, because of the variety of enemies and unique loot to find in those caves. Even with an open world dense like that, the main level that you have to go through for the story have the same quality of the game before them, but with a lot more verticality you Can go 3 time in the same castle and find 3 differents way to explore it.In term of gameplay, for a "souls veterant" like me, i feel like this game offers the most ways to build your character in any ways you want, you can customize weapons by swapping theyre special attacks, and use whatever tool you want to tackle the game difficulty : you want to be a tanky mage ? A fast bowman ? A heavy knight with dragons power ? You can do it and mix everything while still maintining it viable and enjoyable.Now let's talk about the elephant in the room : The difficulty. If you're new to the serie i think this is the best place to start, elden ring is still challenging in the classical souls way, but there is a loot of tools to give the player a little rest in combat (like summoning npc to fight with you on command) and a lot of ranged weapons and ways to fight.Additionaly, elden ring being an open world you can explore the world to seamlessly lvl up before trying to tackle a boss. This give the player room to breath in between bosses.I will add that from software games are suffering from their reputation of being difficult. It's not an easy game, and it requires a little bit of getting used to. But after some time if you're willing to learn how the games works, you can finish the game without that much of problems. And i really encourage people to do it because it's really rewarding.For me who was tired of most recent video games, Elden ring give the fresh experiencz i needed to "fall in love in a game" once again. The last time i felt like this playing was in zelda breath of the wild, it feels like i'm entering a new world, with everything to learn and it's a lot lot lot of fun.And uf you're worry about the lenght of the game, be not. It's really really big and it has a lot of quests outside of the main one, it take probalbly 80 to 100 hours to finish the first playthrough, without taking all the npc quests.So yeah 10/10 because Elden ring is exactly what itns aspiring to be, it's different from everything i've played, it's beautyfull it sounds good, the voice acting is perfect, i'm never bored while exploring the open world, it's not frustrating to fight boss, and it has a lot of replayability with all the builds and differents branch of quests(And yes it's different from dark souls, it's not just BIG DARK SOULS 4) Don't hesitate give it a go.

review: 2023 Отличная игра, но брать только по скидке

2023 I preordered the game and wanted to save my review for later on and I feel that now is the time. I'm a fan since the beginning. Truly, the game is the most crazy undertaking in the whole history of pc strategy games. I had a blast, like I had a blast with CW games in the past.I stopped playing when the Chaos Dwarves DLC came out. It felt too much like a rip off. It opened my eyes. Let me show you:I bought some games and DLCs on sale, some not. At 10$ per DLC (averaging down), + 17$ for Warhammer 1 (that I never played, bought it on sale for the factions), + 50$ on WH2, + 80$ for WH3,+ 30$ for Champions of Chaos, I'm at 350$ lol and rounding down. I'm not even couting sale taxes, which we have in Canada. Am I that stupid? How did I let that happen without even realizing it?Part of this is is on me, sure, but how the hell did we come to this?Well, I choose not to be a part of this anymore. Life is not getting cheaper. No company nor person should take anyone for granted like that. They say that you vote with your wallet, well... be my guest and buy Baldur's gate 3 instead or any other game that respects its community.

review: So i was really excited for space marine 2, I've played the first and its a classic among warhammer fans however space marine 2 has been nothing but buggy upon release. In a campaign that is designed to be played with friends, there are so many bugs that make it impossible. firstly when we assembled the squad it all seemed fin until we got the infinite loading servers bug. OK we thought that it would be an easy fix, just turn off steam overlay and some other stuff and it will work. and it did... the first time. After that we got to actually play, it was about 20 mins of fun until we got soft locked at the flower wall on the first mission. A quick reload to last checkpoint and we were good.... for all about 10 mins when we got soft locked again at the airlock entrance of the bunker. this time loading the checkpoint didnt work so we decided to start the mission over again. that was until we got the infinite loading bug again... At its current state space marines 2 is an unplayable buggy mess for us, id imagine playing single player might work but the campaign is clearly designed for multiplayer and that just isn't working for us.

review: 2019 I probably won't have a popular opinion here but it is how I feel none the less.I played CS a lot when it was first released as a mod for Half-life. I put hundreds of hours into both pub matches and matches with my friends in private servers. I stopped playing it at about the time that it was about to make the move to a retail product Counter-strike as a franchise is something of a time capsule. It is a example of a late 90's shooter frozen in time that never really changes and that is probably what makes it both novel for the average gamer and important for the competitive scene that has formed around it (and taken control of it in a lot of ways).Because a e-sports style competitive scene has formed around Counter-strike, it puts Valve in a difficult position because they can't really change anything without facing harsh resistance from the veteran players. Even minor visual changes are met with extreme criticism because they may upset the carefully cultivated meta.It was not always like this. When I was playing, the idea of e-sports level competitive play was only just starting to manifest and thus it was more rare to find the ultra-competitive players who get wrapped up in memorizing spread patterns, researching dominant strategies and reading up on the established meta. A lot of players back then were just there because it was fun to play and had a huge playerbase (thus meaning that servers were always reasonably available).Playing Counter-strike back then was not the commitment that it can be now. The overall behavior of the playerbase was different. You may have gotten the usual smack talk during a match but you did not have people telling you to do things exactly this certain way in order for the whole thing to play out like a E-sports match either (at least not in any great number).Playing Counter-strike now is essentially a test to see how much you like getting pub-stomped by uber-experienced and ultra-competitive players. It is not a overly welcoming place for new players (though not everyone is negative to new players and some will help you out) and has a culture all of it's own. This culture will either be really cool to you or annoying as hell, there is not much room for anything in between.If you want a competitive gaming experience that is largely shaped by the most competitive (and vocal) players. Counter-strike is for you. If you want something more like a typical modern shooter or something that is more casual, It's not the best place to start.In the end, this is just a opinion, I understand that Counter-strike is going to be a different experience for different people. I know that I am probably a bit old and thus missed the competitive level gaming boat by a few years but that does not change the fact that I have played (and own) Counter-strike: Global offensive and the culture that has formed around that game is not something I can really get into. Your mileage (of course) may very.

review: 2023 I have been playing total war games since Empire, and I have around 1700-2100 hours total between all of my owned total war games, and what they are doing to Warhammer 3 is an absolute DISGRACE. The game still has countless bugs, and listing them would take too long (others have thankfully done this already on their reviews), all the while they have the gall to charge 25 dollars for the new DLC, which was the same price as the Chaos Dwarfs with like 150% less content. I'm absolutely revolted especially by their recent statement to the community, in which they basically said they will stop support for the game if we don't suck it up and buy their overpriced lacking in content DLC, which will probably introduce new bugs that wont be fixed for months on end. Due to these recent developments, I can no longer support this franchise; I could not recommend this game, or this company's products to anyone in good faith anymore, and thus I will be uninstalling Warhammer 3, and will never buy another CA product until these issues are resolved in a timely and fair manner.

review: 2022 As someone who has been a huge fan of the total war series since Empire total war back in 2009, I have over 5000 hours of game play through the different games, I feel like I have a good understanding of these games.I have to say Warhammer 3 has been a huge disappointment from the start, very limited amount of factions to play if you're only playing the WH3 campaign, very limited set of units for each factions with most factions only have 2 units of renown, main story isn't too bad, but after doing it 3-4 times it gets very repetitive as theres isn't many ways to complete the campaign, and some factions are absolutely terrible compared to the others (Legion of Chaos is one, all units you get are weak versions of the actual factions worshipping a single chaos god). The main campaign also have some game breaking bugs that just make the game not fun to play, as example my buddy got one of his settlements attacked, drops in to the battle and the ogres that are attacking him bug at the entrance of the settlement and sit there till they're dead giving him free wins when it clearly shouldn't. Some battles the players has clearly the stronger army, lord and heroes but when you attack it says something along the lines of "valiant defeat" when you know for a fact that the Iron Dragon of Cathay is supposed to eat up nurglings like his morning cereal, but you're then forced to waste 5-10 minutes of your time to do a drop in battle that was completely unnecessary to begin with. You can select units and send them somewhere but for some reason they stand still even after selecting and trying to move them 5 times. For the immortal empire, I am aware that they're still working on it and it will get better, but with the last patch its only made things worst, they removed minor settlement siege battles cause apparently people live in the trees now instead of buildings and for some reason they're constantly making the terrain a hill for my opponents. As for large settlements the tower placements are terrible often being behind tall buildings or walls so the tower shots never connect, they constantly hit everything but the intended targets. Wall get taken down by peasants with swords or spears, towers get murdered by tier 1 harpies that literally lose to everything else. Your units will also break moral in the stupidest way (running while being 80-90% hp and into the enemy units instead of running away) and for no reason even if you're sitting with 14+ healthy units with a lord and heroes still being present. I could keep ranting amount all the other issues I've found, but it would taken way too much time. Anyway all this to say, Total War Warhammer 3 is an incomplete game with an industrial amount of balancing and bug fixing until it becomes fun and worth while to play, and currently the only fun part of the game is the Immortal empire that doesn't even allow players to select other races apart from the WH3 if they don't own all 3 Warhammer games, example buddy of mine has WH3 and WH2 with all dlcs, but the game won't let him choose a WH2 faction even though he already owns the content of it, he was forced to buy WH1 to be able to access the other factions that he's already paid for. I will not be returning to WH3 until the game has been worked on some more and even then I'll probably have to pay more to get the additional content that we were supposed to have to begin with, so I may refund the game and stick to WH2, I don't know anymore. Thank you for taking the time to read my rant, and feel free to let me know what you guys think.

review: 2022 I think it's finally time to change this review from negative to positive. A lot has happened and changed since I last updated this review, but the gist of it is, that CA has done a good job on fixing some of the glaring issues and began a sincere communication with their TWWH community. It's a glorious, BUGGY mess. Most of previous bugs were fixed, IE added a lot more, especially regarding quest battles, garrisons and building chains. If you're itching to play it, then get it. If you have the patience, wait a bit more.

review: 2022 If you do not own Total War Warhammer 2; you should get that over this. That game is leagues more developed and fleshed out than this game is. The story for TW WH2 is hands down better than this mess. The mechanics of TWWH2 are better thought out and handled.Overwhelmingly this game is just a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ mod of TWWH2 that just levels nerfs across the board at every race and strategy that could be employed to beat a game that only made itself more difficult by giving the AI broken cheats.Rather than address issues and correct problems with the AI or mechanics of the game the devs just chose to nerf the solutions to those problems, while ignoring overlapping bugs/glitches that were carried over from TWWH2. You will find the same, or similar bugs, in this game as you will find in TWWH2 but in TWWH2 you will at least get unique races that all get interesting end game rewards for completing campaigns.This game currently has one mode and is not slated to get any improvements or alternates to that mode until June (AFAIK) of 2022. Months after its release it is not going to have things that TWWH2 had on launch.This game really feels like it was a product of a secondary dev team that had no communication or interactions with the people that made the prior game fun and enjoyable. This game really feels like it was just someone's pet project for some resume padding and they didn't care what was actually produced.This game was horrifically phoned in.How do I know? Well, spoiler, when you win the campaign you are given a demon prince to command your armies. Thats neat, if you are a demon faction, but when you play a human or non-demon faction guess what your reward for beating the demons (a group of creatures that is, in the lore, antithetical to your existence)? If you guess that your human queen character who just spent years banishing demons back to hell is going to be given THE original demon prince to lead her armies, rather than getting an embodiment of her countries religion or even an avatar of her bear god she worked so hard to save, then you are correct.There is no variance to the rewards for completing the campaign with different factions, other than steam achievements. There is no benefits gained from completing important milestones in the overarching campaign. There is nothing but ridiculous challenges put in front of you that are still beaten by the nerfed units that you will eventually use.Think about that for a second. The devs have overwhelmingly nerfed units that were used to win the hardest difficulty campaigns in the prior game and THEY STILL FAILED TO ACTUALLY ACCOMPLISH THEIR GOAL. Even with nerfs there are certain units that you will always use over others, just because of cost effectiveness, and the only thing that was accomplished by the devs overuse of the nerf-stick was the disappearing of weird and wonky armies.Also, auto-resolve (what you used to avoid having to spend 40mins on a battle that should of been an easy win) has been changed to always be punishing to the player. You could have a full elite army going against two dudes in a hovel, and your elite army will come out of the autoresolve almost obliterated from two mud farmers with broken shovels.This game is nothing but a half-assed attempt at some DLC for TWWH2 that brings nothing really new to the series or world, and actually retcons a lot of stuff from the prior game, while also being incredibly boring to play. I've spent more time trying to undo the massively dumb decisions my allied AI make or correct weird things that happen to me than I have anything else.It just isn't worth it. Wait till maybe December and check back in, or until this game comes on a deep-deep sale (like 50% off or more) before dropping money on this, as you aren't really getting $60's worth of a game.Instead, if you really want to play a game like this, go to TW:WH2 and get that. Its expensive for the full game/dlc, but just get the base game and use the free-lc until the rest is on sale. It is LEAGUES better than this game right now.

review: 2022 I very rarely write reviews, but my conscience compels me to warn others so that they might avoid the massive disappointment that this game is to fans of the Total War: Warhammer series. The most glaring issues are both related to gameplay, as well as technical. I am honestly astounded by the state of the game, even now, nearly five months after release. It's as if the game didn't pass through any sort of quality control at all. Other reviews have done a great job of detailing the gameplay issues, so I will merely mention the technical issues I encountered myself. I have a Radeon RX 6600, and I can barely eek out 30 fps in this game. To say the game is poorly optimized would be an understatement. If I let the game choose setting, and use the "Recommended" settings, the fps drop to around 15, rendering the game completely unplayable. If you by any chance read this while considering to buy this game; do not. Go buy Total War: Warhammer II instead, if you do not already have it, as it is superior in almost every way. Hundreds of hours will zip by in that game, while just twenty hours in this game was a nightmarish slog.

review: 2022 This is the best souls game. Hell, this is the best game. Git gud.Edit: If you are a veteran invader you will probably not like this game. This is much more focused around the open world exploration and co-op aspects of the game than it is the PvP. With that being said, this game also has the absolute worst camera angle I have seen in any title by Fromsoft, which makes some of the main story bosses incredibly unpleasant to fight. All of the "build diversity" really goes away in PvP, when you need to use bloodhound step to survive almost any situation that involves more than one opponent. No true combos means its crazy hard to turn and burn and get a reset if you are getting chased by multiple opponents. I don't see the longevity in the Invasion scene in this game. Really sad for someone who has put countless hours into PvP in both DS2 and DS3. 1v1 duels will most likely be more popular than ever before.The auto camera recovery has to be broken cause even with the setting off it bounces off walls all the time. When you lock onto a boss, and it does an animation where it is moving quickly, your camera will go nuts. I personally felt as if I was fighting the camera more than the boss half the time. All that being said a single main story play-through still netted me around 100 hours and thats pretty killer compared to most releases in general. If you have not played a souls game you will probably love this game as co-op has been much more streamlined than before, and it is definitely at its best.

review: 2022 Game Good!!!If you like Strategy games this is the perfect franchise for it. Now I will say, the base game is okay, not the greatest IMO because the Realms of Chaos campaign mechanic isn't that fun. It's tedious and depending on the faction you are playing you can conquer basically the whole map before you can actually win the campaign. If you have the Champions of Chaos DLC the Realms of Chaos campaign is good, since you operate on a different mechanic that feels much better.Let's get into the juice of the game. The game is 100% at it's best when you own all 3 games because it will give you access to the Immortal Empires campaign which combines all the maps from the previous games into 1 BIG map with all of the previous factions on it. You don't have any gimmicks to worry about. It's just conquer the map with a few objectives depending on your faction. It's a giant sandbox where you'll have roughly 86 different Legendary Lords to play, each with different starts, abilities, buffs, etc. Also, you don't need to own all 3 of the games to play IE (Immortal Empires), if you have a friend that owns all 3 games you can play it with him. YOU WILL ONLY BE ABLE TO USE THE STUFF YOU OWN. So if you only have the 3rd game you can only use factions from the 3rd game. If you own the 2nd and 3rd game you can use the respective factions and DLC that you own. You can have up to 8 player campaigns that you can do entirely coop or however you want. You want to have to have an alliance with someone and go to war with someone else go for it. You all also get to have your turns at the same time which is a great feature, so you aren't stuck waiting for someone else to do their turn while you just sit there twiddling your thumbs. You can now get into situations where maybe the want to attack your army and they start walking towards your lord, you can walk your lord away.There is a lot of variety in the units and the battles are one of the biggest highlights of the game for me personally. The campaign map is like Civilization, but when you clash with another army or whatever it becomes more of an RTS where you control your units. It's honestly so much fun!I give the game a 6/10 with no DLC's or mods with just the base campaign. With mods, you can get rid of the Realms of Chaos mechanic which adds more replayability to the game because you can focus on more that just the dumb portals. Don't get me wrong Realms of Chaos is good for 1 playthrough after that it's tedious. With access to Immortal Empires the game shoots up to a 9/10 for me. As it offers a ton of variety that can make the game feel fresh with all the different races and factions to choose from.

review: Story is about 10 hours of gameplay (including doing the side coop missions at least once, that are part of the story, but also the content you grind after) and I enjoyed it for what it was. I think this is a great intro to the 40k universe/lore for people new to it.The gameplay is fun and with the classes and guns available right now there is enough variation to enjoy and keep playing. Where the game does lack though, is the mission content. The re-playable/grind-able missions I feel will get a bit boring after maybe 20-30 hours of grinding them. There is some variation in spawns (elites/bosses can spawn in certain parts of the mission path) but with the few missions that you can run, it isn't enough. Granted the devs plan to expand this later.There is a PVP mode that will extend the games life a bit but I am yet to try it, although I think it is probably gonna be quite fun.The game looks beautiful and runs smooth for me (7950x3d, 4090FE, 64gb 6000mhz ram) with the only issue being - when I try to quit the game, it doesn't actually quit. I have to kill it manually.Overall, id recommend this but if you are only here for the story - wait for it to be expanded with DLC releases or wait for the game to go on a 50% sale. I also got the ultra edition - don't do this unless you just want to support the game, the content it gives you over the Gold isn't really worth it.

review: 8/10 Game is really solid so far. A lot of Souls-mechanics without the punishment that comes along with it. So far, bosses have been fun to beat. Story is somewhat easy to follow given the amount of lore they provide. Love the skill tree respec available at any time, allowing for strategy changes for different bosses. Overall, a pretty solid game!Some issues that I have with this game:1) Invisible walls - invisible walls are very frustrating because it gives you a feeling that you have a big area to explore, only to be frustrated when you hit the wall. For crying out loud, there's even ledges that have invisible walls, only to find out later that you can explore the lower area! Either provide a skill that reduces fall damage, or design the map so that it actually shows the boundary of the area.2) Graphical issues - 3070Ti is suffering with FSR, Very High Graphics. You can literally lose a boss fight from stuttering and frame drops.3) Traversal - map traversal is so boring. Like, you have a monkey... that won't even swing around. I'm currently at chapter 3 and there doesn't seem to be any hint of that mechanic in the game. Even Jump doesn't have much use outside of combat, and when you do use it, it's so janky, and also, links back to the invisible walls issue. Sure, there's bits where you can transform into something, but it's not as fun as vine swinging (or web swinging as Spidey).4) UI Design - generally, the UI is pretty solid. My issue is the item "wheel". There are drink names that doesn't align against their intended effect. You would think "Evil Repelling Drink" is some kind of holy negation drink right? WRONG! It's Physical Damage Negation buff! So... I hope they fix this by adding icons of the drink effect in the item wheel.

review: 2022 The QoL changes from WH2 to WH3 are enough to reccomend this game on their own. The improvements to alliances, sieges, corruption are all very welcome additions. This isn't quite the same leap as between TWWH1 & 2, but still very nice improvements The new factions while a bit barebones at the moment, are all excellent both in variety between them and in how well they match the flavour of their factions. The Daemon Prince in particular is an excellent achievement I really enjoyed. It seems for this game CA have really invested in immersing in the Warhammer world, to an even greater extent than in the other 2 games in the series. For example the campaign map now has little icons you can hover over to get some lore information about particular sites of interest throughout the world. Which makes it even more surprising that the lore bits of previous games - Lord quests and Landmark building - seem to have been scaled back a lot. There are very few landmarks of any kind and the quests are no longer multi-stage with you having to perform several tasks to get to the end goal. I have not done all of them yet, but the ones I have done have consisted of "get to level X and fight a battle" with little justification for the battle and no preparatory steps beforehand. There is a caveat however. As it stands WH3 is much more strongly narratively driven than any Total War game there has been before, including WH2. The campaign is constrained by the story (though not to the extent others have said, it is perfectly possible to have a large Empire and constant expansion). 1.1 has added the ability to ignore the story to an extent but you still have to play around it even if you don't engage with it. This is not an issue for me, I enjoy a different approach to a Total War campaign than the usual paint the map Empire building and having to work within the bounds of the narrative comes with its own challenges and difficulties. In particular a lot of the mechanics serve as anti-snowball features; the larger your Empire the more intrusive these mechanics become so the late-game stage of previous total wars where you are no longer threatened by anyone and just finishing off the map painting is harder to achieve. However many longtime Total War fans are not enjoying the different direction of the main campaign and the constraints on playstyle.As of writing there is no roadmap or timeline for future expansions. The "Immortal Empires" campaign, a combined map of all 3 games including all the factions is coming at some point (hopefully soon) and will introduce a much larger and more sandbox mode, so if a "normal" Total War experience is what you are after I would wait until this mode is out. This mode also requires you to own all 3 Total War games on the same platform (Steam, Epic etc.) which is a lot of investment for someone new to the series.There are also quite a number of bugs, some game-breaking, others just annoying. These are being actively worked on and based on the experience with other TW games a lot of these will be ironed out in time. I have played 6 campaigns now and only one of them has broken to the point I had to abandon it but others have all had little irritants. I have still played nearly 300 hours in 2 months though, so clearly these bugs do not overly diminish the fun I have had with the game.Performance has been a bit of an issue for me as well. WH2 I played on Ultra settings for everything and only occassionally had a slowdown very late into the campaign. WH3 I am still able to play on Ultra settings, and the battles function at a good framerate, but the campaign map starts struggling to keep up from ~turn 50 onwards, with long pauses while it figures something out and frequent frame drops.Battle has some oddities. With 1.1. cavalry feel better than they have in any other entry in the series, and infantry are more responsive but there are still issues with infantry movement and ranged unit targeting when ordered. 1.1 was a large improvement and it looks like CA are still working on ironing out the issues. For the most part battles feel essentially the same as in WH2, though the AI does seem to have been improved. For example in WH2 the AI would always attempt to flank with their cavalry. This involved swinging cavalry out to the wings then charging into the flanks. If you placed units covering the flanks the AI would more often than not just charge into the covering unit, regardless of if that was a good matchup for them. In WH3 enemy cavalry will continue to move around and position themselves until they find a good angle to attack. They will move around your anti-large units and go for your artillery or missile units instead. There are still issues with the AI recognising that just because it is considered the defender doesn't mean standing still and waiting is the best tactic, but overall it feels much more intelligent than WH2. The AI struggles with the new sieges a little, never seeming to make up its mind whether it wants to fight or cap points, leading to it not doing either very efficiently. Additionally pathfinding in settlements can be pretty difficult. The AI does make fairly good use of the new supplies mechanic (though it cheats a bit on cooldown times and rarely if ever builds higher-tier towers, preferring to spam out the cheaper lower-tier ones), which is nice to see.The new "survival battles" are very nice and provide a good variety for the player. However they are LONG and draining. They can be autoresolved, aside from the last one which is good because sometimes I am just not up for the effort a survival battle takes, however auto-resolve is very punishing on the higher difficulties, so you can end up in a bit of a lose-lose when coming up to one of these.In short:Pros: Many QoL features that are improvements over TW2 New factions are excellent More immersive in Warhammer universe than the previous 2 games AI improvements (For me) The narrative-driven campaign forcing new playstyles and new solutions to issuesCons: Long-time fans are not enjoying the main campaign story Some bugs Some battle quirks that need fixing Performance issuesI rate this game 8/10 as it currently stands, and I have little doubt that number will rise as more patches and expansions come to the game

review: An absolute masterclass of an ARPG. Everything was painstakingly crafted from rich background material and moulded into something new and darker. The story of Journey to the West is known to most but this is a sequel. Animations, cutscenes, combat, visuals, story and character development... This game has it all. If you love a big, meaty action RPGs with rich lore and a great story then this game is for you, 100%.Small cons:1. Exploration is not exactly there because there are a lot of invisible walls in this game - far from open world. Still, it does not need to be open world if the world is that gorgeous.2. Some items are RNG based drops from enemies and harvesting plants. In a diablo style loot-driven ARPG this can work but not in a Soulslike or third person ARPG and might rub achievement hunters the wrong way.Overall a beautiful experience. 10/10 would recommend.

review: "Black Myth: Wukong" is definitely the most talked-about game in China in recent years. You know, in the Chinese gaming market, which is flooded with online games and pay-to-win mobile games, making an indie game was once considered a surefire way to lose money and fail. But the release of Black Myth has completely shattered that notion, showing investors the massive potential of this market. I bet in the future, China will be able to produce more high-quality AAA games that you can just buy outright!Here is the main text of the review.:Pros:1. The game features highly detailed sculpture models created from high-precision real-world scans, along with finely crafted scene modeling.2. The voice acting and soundtrack are incredibly immersive.3. It has an excellent and well-developed combat and progression system.4. There are several well-produced cutscenes, each with a distinct style.5. The game is based on the classic Chinese mythological novel Journey to the West. Many Chinese people have dreamed of becoming the Monkey King, Sun Wukong, and in a way, this game helps us fulfill that childhood dream!Cons:1. The invisible walls aren't well-defined, which is frustrating when areas that look accessible actually aren't.2. The lighting contrast is too high, and the diffuse reflection is too low, making the shadows overly dark.3. The color palette in some chapters is too monotonous, lacking visual guidance, which makes it easy to get lost.4. Some boss designs are really annoying, like General Miaoyin and the Hundred-Eyed Demon Lord.

review: 35 hours in, and I’m still at the beginning of Chapter 5. I thought this game was pretty linear at first, but oh gosh, there is so much to do in each chapter, so many secrets to uncover, and not to mention, the graphics are so BEAUTIFUL!The story is interesting; after each chapter, I always go to YouTube to find explanations about the lore. The combat system is the highlight here; it’s so fluid and amazing! I don’t like Souls games because they are too hard for me, but in Wu Kong, I can defeat every boss in just a few attempts. I really love the cutscenes and music videos! Highly recommended and absolutely a contender for Game of the Year in 2024!P.S. ♥♥♥ those "lack of diversity" reviews!

review: Score: 8.5/10Story:What more can be said? The narrative is rooted in a true literary masterpiece. There are some interpretations that I find intriguing and aligned with the overall message the game seeks to convey, though I might have differing views on certain aspects of how they twisted the original story. However, that's purely subjective and doesn't detract from the quality of the story.Visuals and Design:I absolutely love the landscapes, character designs, and costumes. As someone who grew up reading Journey to the West, seeing the novel's mythical creatures brought to life in the game is an exhilarating experience. The environments are breathtaking and immersive, with the grand Buddha statues and some architectural elements leaving a profound impact on me. The game features some of the most stunning scenery I've ever encountered, and they all feel authentically reminiscent of places I’ve actually seen. It’s simply marvelous.Boss Design:The boss designs are quite impressive, with some moves that are visually striking and others that are distinctly unique. What sets them apart is that, they defy conventional tropes and offer a refreshing experience. This uniqueness is a credit to the original author of the novel and the ancient Chinese folklore he drew upon.I really like some of the bosses, but I can’t go into details since I want to avoid spoilers.Combat System:The combat animations are cool, and the spells are visually captivating, especially because I’m a huge fan of Wukong. The way the spells are represented aligns well with my expectations.However, this is where my main critique lies. I prefer engaging in combat by directly confronting enemies rather than relying heavily on dodging and waiting for an opening to strike, as in Souls-like games. This game isn’t a Souls-like, or at least it attempts to incorporate more character abilities, primarily through spell. In my opinion, the key distinction between action games and Souls-like games lies in how players can influence enemy behavior. Action games allow for interruptions, counters, and disruptions, rewarding players for such high-risk maneuvers with a strong sense of satisfaction.In this game, the Monkey can interrupt or parry enemies, but it’s done through heavy after light attack or spells rather than the core combat system. This, to me, is the biggest issue: it lacks a dedicated blocking or counter system, placing too much emphasis on dodging. Parrying with heavy is a nice idea to bring the fluidity into the combat but in quite a lot time you just fail. Also there are a lot of attacks which cannot be parry and the only option is to dodge, or use magic. This results in less interactive combat, which diminishes the overall experience. (In my opinion Ghost of Tsushima had excellent interactivity, though I understand it’s a different scenario with mostly human bosses in a low-magic setting.)Overall, I feel that while the heavy parry derived from the staff techniques and the spell abilities are intriguing, they fall short in delivering the level of interactivity needed to make the combat feel rewarding. Once the novelty wears off, the battles can feel somewhat monotonous.Map:The map is decent. Personally, I don't have a strong opinion on invisible walls, though I understand why others might find them frustrating. What I do wish for is a mini-map because I often struggle with navigation. Relying on online guides to find my way slightly detracts from the overall experience.Chapters:The game boasts one of the coolest and most epic prologues I've ever seen, delivering a significant impact. The first four chapters are solid, offering plenty of content and expansive maps. However, chapters five and six feel a bit rushed and could have been more fleshed out.The side quests are not very clear and you could miss them.

review: It's pretty good, definitely not perfect as it comes with some flaws but it's a well done sequel to the first game and I've been enjoying a lot. Visuals Game's visual aspect looks great, especially considering the absolute chaos you see happening on the screen with so many enemies swarming and things blowing up, with even small attention to detail existing such as the fact you get mud stains on your armour (and blood ofc) as you go through some of the marshy parts of the planet, it looks damn good but due to performance being somewhat shoddy, up scaling is needed which softens the image so people who can't stand temporal softness to an image will not be happy Optimizaiton Not good but not entirely terrible, you will need a modern mid range machine to run this at a solid-ish fps and even then you need to use up scaling tech, i got a 3060 and Ryzen 5700x, so as mid-range of a set up you can get today and i get on average 60 fps (usually) on a mix of High/Medium in 1080p but with DLSS Quality mode up scaling. There is also some shader stutter problems and loading times can sometimes be painfully long, so there's def optimisation work to be done still. New Gameplay Additions It's very much Space Marine but expanded upon for the most part, you now get timed dodging and parrying, which might take a bit to get used to. The parry windows are generous but that's due to the fact you're almost always dealing with utter chaos on your screen with so many things attacking you which is what adds to the challenge of dodging and parrying. Campaign It's about 8 - 10 Hours long, has full 3 player co-op support and 4 difficulties, Easy, Normal, Veteran, Angel Of Death. Overral, it's really good, especially the final act but it starts a lil so-soMore Info:I played through it solo on Veteran, my initial experience was a bit Luke-warm with the first few missions but it didn't take long for me to get more into it, especially since the campaign gets better as you progress it, early missions have this more frequent re-occurring issue that is present when you're playing solo, where certain segments feel like they're not meant for you to be on your own with the two AI partners that share a singular brain cell, such as for an example having to use a flame thrower to push back a swarm of tiny lil' insects whilst dealing with lots of ranged enemies and having to complete some objectives, problem is, the flamer takes you primary weapon away so all you're down to is your pistol for ranged enemies plus enemies in solo mode tend to focus more on the solo player than the two AI partners, so these situations can feel a bit bad . However , this starts becoming less so of a problem at the mid point of the campaign where it starts feeling like they put some more thought into making it more enjoyable when playing solo. The campaign as a whole is really damn good by the end, apart from some stumbles in design where it can very much feel like it's a Co-Op campaign with an optional solo mode from time to time, it's epic, doesn't over stay its welcome , ends on a pretty satisfying note with a spectacular final act fight that was incredibly kick a**. PvP Multiplayer A solid PvP experience, but it kinda is the 2nd class citizen of the package, it has its balancing quirks in design that might get more notable/annoying as i play but it is an improvement over SM1's PvP largely due to it having dedicated servers, no more peer to peer constant lagging and host migrations and the addition of abilities adds a decent bit of more spiceMore Info:Just like in SM1's it's just 6v6 across 3 maps and 3 game modes, Annihilation (TDM), Seize Ground(Domination) and a KOTH-like mode with 6 classes . So it's light on the map variety but offers more variety than SM1 in terms of game play styles with more classes of which each one now has a unique ability to use, a frontal shield for the devastator heavy, a AoE chapter banner that heal's people armour from the Bulwark class or brief invisibility for the sniper and so forth.So far have dug into it a fair bit, melee is a notibly weaker compared to SM1's PvP, this is potentially partially due to the lag problems of SM1's not offering extra protection for lag-teleporting assault marines who due to SM1's bad netcode would often just ignore half of the damage you threw at em'. The game is also more team depended now, certain classes work together really well, the Bulwark is a shield guy with a power sword, his shield can absorb all ranged damage and surprisingly he can do it forever basically unless he gets hit from behind and then to boot he can deploy an AoE armor regen for everyone , so when you combine him with the heavy devastator class you got a combo that can deal with ranged and CQC targets very well , covering each others weaknesses and offering an armor heal from the bulwark and a frontal shield from the heavy devastator to keep each other in the fight.It's not half bad at all , matter of fact was somewhat addictive for me during the first two weeks of release but there are some balancing quirks such as the Bulwark turtle players and flash nade spams that can suck the fun out of it.However i do wish they did more with it, i wish it was 12v12 perhaps instead of 6v6, i wish the Chaos Marines could be properly customised, unlike loyalists the chaos boys just get preset colours and armor and that's it, the in-deph customization is completely lacking and missing for them. Also levelling in it works in a way that you just get a higher number on your report card, you also unlock new weapons and winning X amount of matches gets you new armour cosmetics, which also can be earned in Co-Op mode. There are no perks, no means to change attachment or flat out upgrade your weapons in PvP, those things exist in co-op but are absent here and that's honestly for the better, it means there's no perks one can unlock to give unfair advantages over others as in SM1 and since gear is equal there's no max level guy who has a bolter that does 6x more damage than yours, those all exists still but are just for the co-op strike missions where you have light rpg elements in which you get to further fine tune,upgrade and buff up your class and weapons. PvE Co-Op Multiplayer Very similar in terms of design to dev's previous game World War Z , you run through 6 special missions that are happening alongside the main narrative and you keep replaying these missions earning XP and gear for your marines and weapons to level up and get stronger, however it does suffer a bit from enemies becoming a lil too spongy perhaps on the last difficulties. More Info: Think of it like doing Left 4 Dead campaigns that you just keep replaying for fun but also in this case to level up, earn new gear or get your current gear to become stronger, because it's not just your class that levels up and unlocks various perks but also your weapons get stronger too, unlocking stronger versions, new weapon perks with even new cosmetics to boot to showcase that they are better. You play as one of the two other squads in the game that under-take missions whilst TITUs and his team are doing their own thing. Though here the game does become gear n level depended but i would argue it is still possible to do the 3rd and 4th difficulties (hardest ones) with the right classes and equipment set up even if under levelled to a degree. It's honestly an enjoyable chaotic romp that i do strongly recommend playing with 1 buddy at least, cause with randos it's just not the same fun. Final Note : Despite some stumbles in design, optimisation woes and lacking in PvP content, the game delivers a very much worthy sequel to Space Marine 1 and i am loving it a lot despite some of its flaws.

review: The game is not perfect by any means, it has bugs, it has crashes, it has a terrible policy for purchased cosmetics (they are making them account-wide in august instead of locked to a single character), but it is still an incredibly fun experience with a dev team that cares a ton about the lifespan of the game. This game manages to feel completely fresh in this genre without doing anything that changes the already functioning formula for MMORPGs. Playing with friends is enjoyable and the "dungeon" type content (that is released so far) is incredibly fun. I have never enjoyed grinding dungeons for loot but this game made queuing up with 3 friends and running a dungeon 45 times indescribably fun. If you're looking for a great free to play game that doesn't unfairly punish you for being a free to play player than this is my top choice. A side note to the devs, keep doing what you're doing. The community absolutely respects your desire to make changes based on their feedback and your commitment to improve the game based on our current suggestions is proof that you're worthy of my time. Thanks for making this game.

review: Product received for free With Space Marine II, Saber interactive proves, once again, that they know how to do action games, this time adding a ton of Co-op & PvP options powered by their squeaky-clean net code. The game runs excellently, looking great and performing to specification. I was able to stream it from the same rig I was playing on, and only got one random crash during my five-hour session. Visuals are great, audio is fantastic, and the writing found here is far better than any game in the genre usually gets. The Swarm Engine that made WWZ what it is comes into play and provides a breathtaking sense of scale to most encounters. The price-tag might be a bit steep, at least when we are talking about the Early Access Versions, but they come packed with the first Season Pass, which will eventually make the investment worth it. If you are looking for a really well-crafted action games to play with your friends, SPII will not disappoint. To War! Pre-Lauch Stream - FiOth

review: I really tried to enjoy this game, and even spend a little on the Meta Pass to support it, given the number of hours I put into a "free" game. But ultimately, Once Human just isn't for me, at least not yet.I was expecting this to be a Survival Crafting / Base Building game with shooter elements. But really, this is a shooter game with crafting and building elements. And that crafting / building is absolutely Early Access quality. Random scavenging gives random loot that somehow provides all my crafting needs, so long as I pick everything up. So there is little need for targeted resource hunting or exploration after the first few dozen hours of gameplay. Good luck getting roofs to snap to walls. And God-forbid you try to relocate your territory after building anything more interesting than a wooden box.Combat is okay, but there is little support for anything other than firearms. My dreams of being Kirito in Gun Gale are dashed. More seriously, hit detection for precision bow shots is endlessly frustrating and inconsistent, making every attempt at stealth missions an exercise in futility (or a two-hour endeavor to clear a single settlement for resources that can be found elsewhere).This is not a bad game. But it definitely should be treated as Early Access, not a full-release. I will probably come back to this game in the future after some hearty Quality of Life Improvements geared towards us solo survival crafting players. But so long as this is a shooter game first, it really just isn't the kind of game I am interested in.

review: 2022 This is the best souls like experience From Software could ever grace us. From the very moment you start in Elden Ring you are introduced to the new and interesting world and it just becomes ever more confusing the more you play! You meet tons of characters on your journey who may be of service, betray you, give you a chuckle, or just call you out that you have no maidens. There are tons of bosses and challenges for you to face even after you beat the game because of how expansive this game is. I am just going to put some good things and bad things I have with the game as I do want to specify a big issue I have. First I want to start off with the good: The world design is fantastic as every area feels different from the rest. Certain places give you a sense of adventure while some may give you a sense of dread and fear of dying in .2 seconds. The weapons and armor are some of the best in the souls series. The combat is much more fluid than the previous souls game. Horse combat and gameplay is a very nice addition to the game. Most if not all the characters you meet feel unique and confusing as they all speak tounge. Now I could go on and on about how good this game is but I just need to point out my biggest issue. There are tons of reused bosses in this game. In addition, I have seen regular enemies become bosses later. Worst of all, there are bosses that you fight one on one and then they are reused as a duo boss. The three biggest culprits are the dragons, godskin noble, AND THOSE CRUCIBLE KNIGHTS WHICH YOU FIGHT 7 DIFFERENT TIMES. These of course are just only a few examples of reused bosses. Just a side complaint here is the performance in some areas of the game. I know this will probably be fixed later in a patch but man those stutters are common and have affected a boss fight or two. But these performance issues didn't happen all the time to hamper my overall experience.In conclusion, Elden Ring is phenomenal and I do have my personal complaints of the game but at the end of the day if you enjoy souls like games that From Software releases I think you should pick this one up. Good luck out there Tarnished! My Rating: 9.5/10

review: 2018 So what do we need to do to get good in this game?Step 1:Accept you aren't the best and make mistakes like everyone elseStep 2:Setup your Gear. Have a good Microphon and use it.Step 3:Warmup before Competitive Games. Doesn't matter if you kill 1000 Bots on an Aim-Map or play Deathmatch for about 20 Minutes.Step 4:Practice all necessary skills for the Game- AIM -> Deathmatch; Aim-Maps; Practice-Maps (Recoilmaster etc.)- Movement -> Climb-servers; Surfing, Prefire-Maps (Shortcuts from Yesber too)- Gamesense -> Matchmaking; Retake-Servers- Mapknowledge -> Callouts; Demos from your favourite Pro-Player,- Nades -> pls learn them- Roles -> Entry; Support; Lurk; AWPerAdditional Steps:- Train your Habit (first callout then flame)- play daily to to improve your aim- make pauses every 2-3 games to reset (go outside from the room with your Pc)- stop at the point you get mad (after a loss may)If you follow all these Steps you will be able to climb the ladder and improve fast.Have a nice day and start fraggin! P.S.: Last Step: Get friends to play with and play for the win not for stats!!!

review: 2019 I originally played this game back when it was still in closed beta, when I gained access to it by bothering a Valve employee (sorry, Jeep). Back then I loved it, it felt great and performed great and everything just made sense. Since then, Valve took over the game where Hidden Path left off and only built on it - adding more depth to mechanics and gunplay and even movement. I fell out with the game around then, as the focus shifted to being a little bit too competitive for my tastes (yes, I am a casual, and I'm ok with that).Over time I saw more and more flaws with the game that turned me off. Weird premium passes, sprays that cost money, skins that cost money, lootboxes. Even gloves became a microtransaction. While I'm not anti-microtransaction (I understand that long-lasting games have to make money somehow), I felt Valve's approach to these microtransactions became increasingly anti-consumer. And that's what prevented me from coming back.But then something crazy happened: they shoehorned in a battle royale mode to cash in on a craze and made the game free-to-play. I thought this would be the final nail in the game's coffin, as I reinstalled it to "see how bad it was".Except it was really, really good.Danger Zone became my way back to Counter-Strike. I ignored the skins and sprays and stickers and gloves and who knows what else, and started playing with my friends and having a genuinely good time in this so-called tacked-on game mode. The mode is very tightly designed. Matches are kept small and quick, solving the big issue in other BR games where you spend 20 minutes looting copy/pasted houses in a map the size of Texas, only to be wiped out by some screeching 13 year olds. Now you spend 2 minutes looting unique environments in a map the size of a small island, only to be wiped out by some screeching 13 year olds. The small matches also meant quick queue times! Plus, they built a host of battle royale mechanics around CS's mechanics, instead of the other way around like every other game.And then they removed three player squads, for some unknown reason. Suddenly, I can't play with my friends, only a single friend. They even removed solo play, and began matching solo players against duos. This also resulted in much longer queue times, as people stopped playing it due to it no longer supporting squads and because of the weird new matchmaking rules. I'm not sure what drove this decision, but it actually did turn Danger Zone into the final nail in the coffin. Boutta head out.

review: Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine 2 - A Review Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine 2 delivers an exhilarating experience that both fans of the franchise and newcomers will find impressive. Developed by Saber Interactive and published by Focus Entertainment, this sequel successfully builds on the foundation laid by the original game while introducing fresh elements to keep the gameplay engaging and exciting. Story and Setting: Set in the grimdark universe of Warhammer 40,000, the game immerses players in a desperate battle for survival. As a Space Marine, you are thrust into the chaotic struggle against the Tyranids, a relentless alien species. The narrative does an excellent job of capturing the essence of the Warhammer 40K lore, with its dark and brooding atmosphere perfectly complementing the intense action. The storyline is well-crafted, offering a gripping and emotionally charged experience that keeps players invested in the fate of the characters and the broader conflict. Gameplay and Mechanics: The gameplay in Space Marine 2 is a standout feature. The game combines fast-paced action with deep combat mechanics, allowing players to engage in brutal, visceral battles. The combat system is robust, offering a satisfying mix of shooting and melee combat that feels both powerful and precise. The variety of weapons and abilities at your disposal ensures that combat never feels repetitive, and the ability to customize your loadout adds a strategic layer to the gameplay.The game also introduces new mechanics and refinements from its predecessor. The improved AI and enhanced enemy variety make each encounter feel unique and challenging. The level design is top-notch, featuring intricate environments that offer tactical opportunities and add to the immersion. The seamless transition between ranged and melee combat is particularly noteworthy, allowing players to fluidly switch between different combat styles depending on the situation. Graphics and Audio: Visually, Space Marine 2 is a treat. The game boasts impressive graphics that bring the Warhammer 40K universe to life with stunning detail. The character models, environments, and special effects all contribute to a visually striking experience. The dark, gritty aesthetic of the Warhammer universe is captured beautifully, enhancing the overall atmosphere of the game.The audio design is equally impressive. The sound effects are impactful, from the satisfying crunch of melee attacks to the deafening blasts of gunfire. The voice acting and soundtrack further immerse players in the game, with the voice work adding depth to the characters and the soundtrack heightening the tension and excitement of the battles. Multiplayer and Replayability: The multiplayer component of Space Marine 2 is a welcome addition, offering various modes that extend the game's longevity. Whether you’re teaming up with friends or competing against other players, the multiplayer matches are well-designed and provide a fun and competitive experience. The replayability is enhanced by the variety of weapons, skills, and loadouts available, allowing players to experiment with different strategies and playstyles. Conclusion: Overall, Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine 2 is a standout title in the Warhammer 40K series. It successfully builds on the strengths of its predecessor while introducing new elements that enhance the overall experience. With its engaging storyline, refined combat mechanics, impressive visuals, and immersive audio, it’s a must-play for fans of the franchise and a compelling entry point for newcomers. The game delivers a memorable and action-packed experience that is sure to leave a lasting impression.

review: To call the game "released", a long and fairly good quality beta test must pass (with a large team of competent testers for such a large open world and such a large number of mechanics), but when the company starts releasing in a hurry due to the fact that some group of sponsors or whoever rather started to get off their investments ...Then as a "game" we get a disgusting mixture of monotonous gameplay, with constant lags, bugs, inconsistencies with descriptions, broken crafting elements and not only, broken perks, absolutely raw events, illogical calculation and damage systems of buffs, and much more. I haven't seen such a RAW game in a long time. Apparently, we are at the stage called "welcome to the era of lazy and inexperienced gamedev without good skills(exmple: in optimisation/devops/put here what you experienced from nowadays games) and probably incapable of broad-mind game design."After spending almost 500 hours in the game, I can confidently say that, in the next month I will write a huge bug report without emotions but with raw information. Aaand, will monitor(gona post it elsewhere) the response to it and further actions regarding CRITICAL moments affecting the game experience EXTREMELY negatively for a lot of players(as i put some work to speak almost with everyone on my server to get feedback by this topic, and it's not good... if i say it soft...). Bottom line:At the moment, the game should add a BETA marker. Otherwise, presenting this abomination as a finished product is a deliberate deception, in my humble opinion - in my humble opinion, someone had an irresistible desire to release the product as soon as possible, the reasons, judging by what I realized during the game, are very prosaic. The potential of the game is huge. If not for all the bad things that it has, it would be just amazing with a competent dev approach. But we have what we have and it's very sad.I'm saying all this as a person with 6 years of experience in devops and 8 years in development (2 of which with django python, 4 with C, 1 with C++, 1 with ruby). I KNOW how it can be, I UNDERSTAND how it should be, and I've seen many times how NOT to do it, so the game is about 40% how NOT to do it.P.S. and ye, servers made of paper, working just terrible, load balancing on stone age level. It can't handle mass events, read the internet about PrimeWars... Terrible.
